Outdoors: Hunting Waterfowl When the Weather Is Cold
LEAD: HUNTING in the bitter cold of mid-winter does not necessarily require indifference to discomfort.
In fact, such stoicism may be beyond most of us.
But it can be both productive and instructive.

TV Review; 'Weekend War,' ABC
LEAD: THE television movie ''Weekend War'' is less impressive as a drama exercise than for what it reflects, probably accurately, about widespread public perceptions of United States Government policies in Central America.
Especially since the Iran-contra hearings, the overall picture is riddled with covert maneuverings, evasions and, to put it gingerly, disinformation.


No Plan to Ask Meese to Resign, Baker Reports
LEAD: The White House Chief of Staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., said today that President Reagan had no intention of asking Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to resign because he is under investigation for his involvement in an Iraqi pipeline project.

Carl J. Conti
LEAD: When Steve Chen, one of the nation's leading supercomputer engineers, left Cray Research Inc. in a dispute last year, it was only hours before Carl J. Conti called.
As I.B.M.'s chief of mainframe computer development, Mr.
Conti, 50, seized an opportunity to move I.B.M. into the only major computer field where it currently has no offerings.

Techniques to Add Speed Can Improve Form, Too
LEAD: THE start ramp is steep.
The first three gates look like a forest of slim trees that have been placed directly in your path. ''Ready . . .
Go!'' the starter says, and you push off.
Your heart is in your mouth and your legs are trembling as you breathe hard and aim straight at that first gate.


NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1988
LEAD:  International A3-14


The Basic Speech; 'America Can Do Better' in Offering 'More Opportunity in the Next Decade'
LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns.
Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way.
But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.


In Japan, Unsettling Ripple of Crime
LEAD: ''Because that's where the money is,'' Willie Sutton supposedly said when asked why he robbed banks.


Rock: Joe Ely and Band, at the Ritz
LEAD: JOE ELY delivered twanging, stomping, full-tilt rock-and-roll at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street, on Friday night.
For a decade, Mr.
Ely has been singing and writing songs that match basic rock to lyrics that delight in wordplay and imagery.
In the 1970's, he put together a band that reflected his Lubbock, Tex., background, mixing Mexican accordion, soul saxophone and country steel guitar with guitar-driven rockabilly; on his 1984 album ''Hi-Res,'' he also flirted with computers and synthesizers.


Reloading for Patrick Battle
LEAD: Reprise was the theme sought by all three metropolitan-area Patrick Division teams over the weekend, as each attempted to generate something resembling a winning streak.


Williams Stars as Redskins Smash Broncos
LEAD: Doug Williams turned Super Bowl XXII into a record-setting offensive show today, as well a historic event, by throwing four second-quarter touchdown passes in the Washington Redskins' 42-10 victory over the Denver Broncos.


Borges Is Prolific, in Wagner Tradition
LEAD: At Wagner College, the undergraduate enrollment is about 1,500, the longest walk from a dormitory to a classroom takes five minutes, and students still pay a quarter for a round-trip ride on the Staten Island Ferry.

LEAD: Washington's defensive schemes, which imprisoned John Elway's skills, and the use of the size advantage of its offensive line were the key elements in the Redskins' Super Bowl rout of the Denver Broncos.

LEAD: The rules governing many corporate takeovers are about to change dramatically, all with the stroke of a pen in Wilmington, Del.
The state's Governor, Michael N. Castle, is expected to sign tomorrow a bill that makes unfriendly takeovers harder.

LEAD: Far below a fierce landscape of sand and sagebrush a red laser pierces the darkness, guiding miners cutting the nation's first permanent nuclear waste repository from walls of salt that are hard as stone.

LEAD: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor whose bid to take over the Singer Company has been accepted by company executives, said yesterday that he had obtained about $505 million in financing for his offer.

LEAD: Two film makers and a video artist are the recipients of this year's Maya Deren Awards, sponsored by the American Film Institute.
The three - Bruce Conner, Yvonne Rainer and Bill Viola - will each receive a $5,000 cash award.
J.
Hoberman, a film critic for The Village Voice, is to receive a citation for contributions to independent film and video.


Data on Specialist Activity in Plunge
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange's specialists failed to respond to nearly two-thirds of the trading messages they received through the intermarket trading system during the October market collapse, according to an internal report prepared by the exchange.

LEAD: A 48-year-old man was fatally stabbed in a dispute with two younger men yesterday after he assaulted their mother on a Queens subway train, the police said.


Few Detect Signs of Fed Easing
LEAD: While economists vainly looked for signs last week that the Federal Reserve had eased monetary policy, interest rates in the credit markets fell sharply on the assumption that the Fed would ratify those declines by pushing short-term interest rates lower.


'Highlights in Jazz' Concert
LEAD: A number of noted jazz musicians, including Tito Puente, Phil Woods and Jon Faddis, are to perform at a ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert on Thursday, at New York University, Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place.
The concert marks the 15th anniversary of the jazz series.
Also to appear are John Pizzarelli Jr., Bob Mover, Tony Monte, Kenny Washington and James Williams.


Barge Spills Oil Near Puget Sound
LEAD: A barge carrying 318,000 gallons of heavy fuel oil sank four miles offshore today and began leaking, the Coast Guard said.


Iowa Paper Picks Candidates
LEAD: Iowa's largest newspaper, The Des Moines Register, endorsed Bob Dole and Paul Simon today in the state's Feb. 8 Presidential caucuses.
The Register normally does not endorse candidates before the caucuses.

LEAD: Ever so quietly, senior officials of the International Olympic Committee are still working on resolving the issue of North Korea's participation in the Seoul Olympics later this year.

LEAD: The Neuroscientific Corporation had the right names associated with it to be a hot new stock issue.
By selling shares to the public, the tiny manufacturer of medical equipment hoped to transfer a device developed in the laboratories of Rockefeller University into practical and immediate use in the nation's hospitals.

You may dress him up to look the part, but initially his behavior will remain rude, crude and socially unacceptable.

LEAD: Surgeons transplanted a heart into an 18-day-old boy born with a fatal defect and said today the infant was in critical but stable condition.

LEAD: An Episcopal Church official said yesterday that the decision of the Newark Diocese to bless homosexual couples ''has set off a lot of sparks'' and has placed the issue of homosexuality high on the church's agenda.

LEAD: At least four Palestinian youths were reported shot and wounded by Israeli soldiers today in continuing civil unrest, and a Jewish settler was severely burned by a gasoline bomb.

LEAD: The management restructuring that the International Business Machines Corporation announced last week is intended to bring the responsibility for decision-making closer to the company's operations.
The move will give the five general managers who will run the new major units much greater visibility in the world's largest computer maker.

Schwartz will head the I.B.M.
Application Business Systems, which will be responsible for System/3X products.


Music: 'Jacques Brel,' Revue, at Town Hall
LEAD: IT was almost exactly 20 years ago that the revue ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris'' opened in New York at the Village Gate and introduced a young generation of theatergoers to the dramatic songs of the Belgian singer and poet, who died 11 years later at age 49.
Arriving when the antiwar movement was in full flower and Bob Dylan's folk-rock diatribes had brought a caustic realism to American pop, Brel's songs of love, death, war and the homeland also spoke to the moment, though in a different vocabulary.

Pregnant? Do Exercise But Exercise Care, Too
LEAD: THE age in which a pregnant woman was regarded as a delicate flower to be secluded until her baby was born passed long ago, but questions remain about just how active she should be.
Increasingly, doctors are advising patients to exercise and stay fit if they wish; some even urge sedentary patients to begin an exercise program after becoming pregnant.

LEAD: The narrow streets and small wooden homes look at first like any other Japanese neighborhood.

LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board has approved the proposed merger of the Shawmut Corporation of Boston and the Hartford National Corporation of Hartford.

LEAD: FOR people who follow developments in the electric utility industry, the announcement on Thursday by the beleaguered Public Service Company of New Hampshire that it had filed for bankruptcy protection came as no surprise.


To Help Families, Help Housing
LEAD: In his State of the Union Message, President Reagan urged Congress to rally behind family values.
Meanwhile, hard-pressed American families are finding out the truth of December's grim statistics: Total housing starts dropped 18 percent below November.
Apartments are what home-starved city families need; families already combing the streets for vacancies know that apartment- house starts dropped a mammoth 33 percent.


LYLE'S BOGEY WINS PLAYOFF
LEAD: Sandy Lyle of Scotland almost committed the cardinal sin of missing his tee time this morning.
But he capped a big comeback when he won the Phoenix Open by beating Fred Couples on the third hole of a playoff.
He won with a bogey 5 after Couples drove into a pond on the left of the 18th fairway for the second time in less than an hour.


Redskins Rout Broncos, 42-10, in Super Bowl
LEAD: The most exciting Super Bowl in history may have been played in the second quarter of today's game here.


Learning From Errors
LEAD: Colleen Walker was sitting in a tent two summers ago, describing in detail her every golf shot to reporters at the Mastercard International Pro-Am.
She was recounting her final round, explaining how for the first time she had placed second in a Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour event.


A Reprieve From Winter
LEAD: Carsten Vala, a student at Williams College, sun bathing on the campus in Williamstown, Mass., yesterday as the temperature rose above the 50 degree mark.
Unseasonably warm weather prevailed over most of the East while frigid air sent the temperature below zero in parts of the Plains. (AP)


Social Themes in Art
LEAD: An exhibition that opened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art explores social and political themes in American printed art from the 1960's to the present, using 144 prints and 36 books by 108 individual artists and 16 collectives.
The printed works are organized into six categories: governments and leaders; race and culture; gender; nuclear power and ecology; war and revolution; economics, class struggle and the American Dream.


Capital Plan Is Based on Risks Involved in Bank Assets
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board's proposal to increase its bank capital requirements is based on the concept that certain loans and other assets held by banks carry a higher risk than others.


In Egyptian Schools, Israel Is Still on the Map
LEAD: To the Editor:


Release of Cubans Reported Up Since Riots
LEAD: The Federal Government is releasing five times as many Cubans from prison each month as it did before uprisings at two prisons last year focused attention on the Cubans' efforts to remain in this country, according to a report today in The Atlanta Journal and Constitution.


Dream Street
LEAD: Something there is about a Bond Street or a Rodeo Drive or a Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore that makes the head spin and the fingers itch and the ribs feel the scorch of a red-hot wallet. ''Buy me,'' the glories in the shops proclaim, ''and you'll get a leg up on life.''


Karen Monson, 42, Music Critic and Author
LEAD: Karen Monson, a music critic and author, died of complications arising from cirrhosis of the liver Saturday afternoon at the Monmouth County Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J.
She was 42 years old.

LEAD: Dr.
Leon Menaker, a charter member of the Lincoln Institute for Psychotherapy in Manhattan, died of liver cancer Friday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 72 years old.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Dec. 17 about newspaper editors' views on the character of Gary Hart misstated the year in which Richard M. Nixon ran for the Presidency against George McGovern.
It was 1972; his rival in 1968 was Hubert H. Humphrey.

LEAD: Their explanations came easily. Painfully easily.


Social Democrats in Britain Split Over Merger of Parties
LEAD: The Social Democratic Party voted today to merge with the Liberal Party in the latest effort by Britain's centrists to break the dominance of the governing Conservatives and opposition Laborites.


Finns Choosing President in 2-Day Election
LEAD: Finns began voting today in a two-day presidential election, with President Mauno Koivisto regarded as almost certain to win a second six-year term as custodian of Finland's sensitive relations with the Soviet Union.

LEAD: This has always been a city that has defined itself by the ways it differs from other cities: a cool, managerial island of businesslike calm amid the ferment of urban America.

LEAD: Forty Niner, the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby May 7, drew post five today for his seasonal debut Wednesday against a surprisingly strong field of 3-year-olds in the Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park.

LEAD: Four people were slightly injured when the eighth car of a 10-car D train was derailed just south of 145th Street and St.
Nicholas Avenue in Harlem last night, officials said.

LEAD: For more than two years, top officials debated whether giving clean needles to New York City drug addicts would do more good or harm in a city that is home to half the nation's heroin addicts and that expects to bear the worst damage from the rising AIDS epidemic.

LEAD: N.H.L.
Capitals 1, Flyers 0: Kelly Miller scored 3 minutes 17 seconds into overtime to give Washington the victory over Philadelphia yesterday in Landover, Md.
The victory moved Washington into second place in the Patrick Division, 4 points behind the Flyers and 1 ahead of the third-place Islanders.(AP)


Washington Talk: Briefing; Help for Caribbean
LEAD: Little noticed in President Reagan's State of the Union Message was his endorsement of further trade help for the Caribbean Basin.
Under 1983 legislation 22 Caribbean countries benefit from tariff-free access to the United States market.

LEAD: Larry Bird scored 29 points and grabbed 17 rebounds to lead the Boston Celtics to a 100-85 victory over Philadelphia today as the 76ers hit a National Basketball Association season low with 29 points in the first half.

LEAD: American Brands Inc. announced yesterday that it would buy E-II Holdings Inc. in a deal valued at $2.7 billion, ending a tangled month-long takeover fight that began when E-II made an offer for American Brands.

LEAD: A NEW promotion campaign for CBS-TV breaks today on the network, and if the hopes of Gene F. Jankowski, president of the Broadcast Group, are realized it will help bring a younger audience to the network that attracts the oldest.


Investigations On Boesky Tie Clear Goldin
LEAD: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, has been cleared of any charges of legal or ethical misconduct after a yearlong series of investigations into his financial relationship with Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator.

LEAD: EVER since George Halas sat on an automobile running board at the Hupmobile agency in Canton, Ohio during the 1920 founding of the National Football League, coaches have talked about their teams having to ''make the big plays.'' Not only is Mrs.
Hancock the highest-ranking woman to be an I.B.M. operating officer, but she may also hold one of the company's toughest jobs.

LEAD: Looking grander than it has in a generation, Grand Central Terminal will mark its 75th anniversary tomorrow with a clear Beaux-Arts victory over decades of neglect and abuse but without its fabled title, ''Gateway to a Continent.''


Being a Mother Takes Art and Science, Too
LEAD: To the Editor:


20 Are Seized in Gambling Raids
LEAD: An illegal gambling ring that handled about $500 million in bets on sporting events - including $5 million on the Super Bowl - was the target of raids on seven apartments in Manhattan Saturday night that resulted in the arrests of 20 people, the police reported.


AIDS, Marriage and Folly in Illinois
LEAD: The Illinois Legislature and Gov.
James Thompson have set an inglorious example of what not to do about AIDS.
Ignoring the advice of their own and other public health authorities, they enacted a law last year that compels everyone getting married in Illinois to be tested for the AIDS virus.
The classic results of this stubborn folly would be ludicrous were it not for the nuisance and dismay inflicted on so many people.


Panel Is Advised It Must Abolish New York City Board of Estimate
LEAD: The commission working to restructure New York City's government has been told by its legal experts that it must devise a radically new form of government - one that abolishes the powerful Board of Estimate and distributes its authority elsewhere.

LEAD: On the basketball court, Bob Gaeta has always been a gunner.
He lived and died by the jump shot.

LEAD: A leading Japanese university plans to build the first high school for Japanese students in the United States on the campus of Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y.

He was 80 years old and lived in Woodside, Queens.

LEAD: The Delta knitwear factory would simply be closed down, the article said, because environmental officials were tired of waiting for the company's management to put in chimney filters that stop soot.


BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1988
LEAD: THE ECONOMY  The Fed may increase capital requirements for banks by 1992, a move that could stall the acquisitions of large savings institutions.  [ Page A1. ]  The proposal is based on the concept that certain loans and other assets of banks carry a higher risk than others. [ D8. ]


B.A.T. to Get Financing
LEAD: B.A.T.
Industries P.L.C. said that it had secured a $3.2 billion line of credit from a consortium of banks to finance its unsolicited bid for Farmers Group Inc.
Last month Farmers, a Los Angeles-based insurance group, rejected a $4.2 billion bid from the British tobacco conglomerate.
B.A.T., based in London, said Saturday that it would finance the deal - worth $60 a share - through debt and cash.

LEAD: For years, The Wall Street Journal - with its huge circulation and staff and its soaring advertising revenues - has been the envy of newspaper publishers and editors throughout the land.


Dance: Olesker and Pou at St. Mark's
LEAD: LIZZIE OLESKER plunged into the supposed trivialities of life and Alyson Pou rose above them in a program of performance art presented by the Danspace Project on Friday at St.
Mark's Church.
In ''House Work,'' Ms.
Olesker conjured up three generations of women and paid a glance to a fourth, in the guise of a young sociology student engaged in a Marxist-feminist interpretation of housework.


Nuclear Plant Drain Put At $100 Billion for U.S.
LEAD: Nuclear plants that were abandoned before completion or finished at excessive cost will cost the nation's economy as much as $100 billion, according to utility experts.
The penalty for this technological wrong turn will be shared by residential and business electric customers, Federal taxpayers and, increasingly, utility stockholders and bondholders.


Man Seized for Threats Dies in an Ambulance
LEAD: A Brooklyn man taken into police custody after threatening neighbors in his apartment building died in an ambulance en route to the hospital on Saturday, the police said, and it is unclear what caused his death.


China Protests
LEAD: The Chinese Government has protested a plan by the Pentagon to include China on a new list of nations that are considered hostile to the United States, according to officials of the Defense Department.


Astronomers Discover Geminga Does Exist
LEAD: WORKING against such long odds that many colleagues had given up on the problem, two Columbia University astronomers have solved the mystery of Geminga, a seemingly empty point in the sky that emits intense gamma rays.


Fiscal Clouds: Connecticut Is Facing Time of Austerity
LEAD: For the last four years, Connecticut and its General Assembly have basked in prosperity.
Legislators in the nation's richest state have seen $1 billion in budget surpluses, cut taxes twice and put $313 million into a ''rainy day'' emergency fund.
Last year they raised spending by 14 percent, one of the highest levels in the country.


House Panel to Conduct Hearings on F.B.I. Spying
LEAD: A House civil rights subcommittee will conduct hearings this month on the F.B.I. surveillance of opponents of the Reagan Administration's Central America policies, the chairman of the panel announced today.

LEAD: Bob Coffey insists that he is not sore at the President.
But he thinks Mr.
Reagan has had some bad advice, and he is willing to help correct that.

LEAD: The United States has undertaken a new Middle East peace initiative to provide elections for Palestinian self-government in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and a formula for an early peace conference on the Middle East, American and Israeli officials said today.


Waldheim Panel Seeks Telegram
LEAD: A member of a commission investigating Kurt Waldheim's war record flew to Yugoslavia today to try to track down a document that is said to implicate the Austrian President in war crimes.

G.M. Increases Some Dividends
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation increased the dividends on its class H and class E stock, reflecting improved earnings of the independently reporting subsidiaries that they represent.
Class H shares, which represent G.M.
Hughes Electronics, will pay 22 cents each, up from 18 cents.
Class E stock, which represents Electronic Data Systems, will pay 17 cents a share, up from 13 cents.

LEAD: Bolstered by strong performances by its specialty chemicals, energy and general business operations, W. R. Grace &amp; Company reported yesterday that it had a net income of $50.1 million, or 59 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1987, in contrast to a loss of $559.9 million in the quarter a year earlier.

Steel Output Up 3.9%
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.939 million tons in the week ended Saturday, up 3.9 percent from the previous week's 1.866 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 90.3 percent of capacity, up from 86.9 percent in the previous week.
Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 7.954 million net tons, up 38.5 percent from the 5.743 million net tons in the previous year, when the steel operations of the USX Corporation were shut down by a strike.

Schwab Cutbacks
LEAD: Charles Schwab &amp; Company, the discount brokerage, said it would reduce its nationwide work force by about 5 percent, or 160 employees.

They followed other cost-cutting moves in recent weeks.

Rail Controller Accepts Blame in Amtrak Crash
LEAD: A control tower operator who fled his post after an Amtrak train and a maintenance vehicle collided last week has acknowledged causing the accident by forgetting to switch the train to an empty track, investigators said today.

Market Place; Good Times Seen In Leisure Sector
LEAD: SEVERAL sectors of the recreation and leisure industry stand to benefit from the sharply lower dollar, which makes foreign vacations more expensive, and the lingering fear of a recession, some analysts say.


Born-Again Couture Sets the Trends
LEAD: Five years ago it would have been absurd to think of Paris haute-couture designers as pace-setters for the world's fashion trends.
Charming anachronisms, the made-to-order collections were considered historical monuments, like the Eiffel Tower or the Arc de Triomphe.
The action was in ready-to-wear.

Kodak Suspends Production of Its Disk Camera
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it had suspended the production of its disk camera six years after its introduction.
The company said that declining demand and excess inventory had influenced its decision.


Devils Win Third in a Row
LEAD: Mark Johnson scored twice to lift the Devils to a 5-4 victory over the league-leading Calgary Flames tonight.

U.S. Vetoes U.N. Resolution Urging Restraint by Israelis
LEAD: The United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution that appealed to Israel to exercise restraint in the occupied territories and called for the Middle East situation to be resolved under United Nations auspices.


Weinberger Is Made An Honorary Knight
LEAD: Former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has been awarded an honorary knighthood in recognition of his ''outstanding and invaluable'' contribution to military cooperation between Britain and the United States, the Foreign Office said today.


Marriott Offering $100 Million Issue
LEAD: The Marriott Corporation is offering $100 million of 8 3/8 percent notes, due in 1994, at a price of 99.65 to yield 8.45 percent, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton.


Rail Workers Strike in Brazil
LEAD: Brazilian rail workers began their first national strike today to press for pay increases of 60 to 80 percent, union leaders said.
Antonio Araujo do Valle, president of the Rio de Janeiro rail workers' union and a member of the national strike command, said all 85,000 workers were on strike.

Nova Seeks Tests On Cold Remedy
LEAD: The Nova Pharmaceutical Corporation, as expected, asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve human testing of a cold remedy that the company hopes will revolutionize treatment of the common cold.
Nova is developing a nasal spray compound known as bradykinin antagonist, aimed at blocking bradykinin, a powerful pain-producing substance in the human body.

It is Stephen B. Schwartz who will head I.B.M.
Application Business Systems.


INOUYE CONCEDES 'ERROR' IN SENATE
LEAD: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, who may be in line to become the next Senate majority leader, acknowledged today that he had made ''an error in judgment'' in pushing a pet measure through Congress as it rushed to adjournment last year.

LEAD: Betty Dolen, executive director of the New York City Board of Elections, usually has more contact with the Justice Department in Washington than with City Hall a few blocks away.


G.S.A. Official Refuses To Testify on Bidding
LEAD: Sureshar Lal Soni, the design engineer accused of giving secret bid information to competitors for Government phone contracts, exercised his Fifth Amendment right today, as expected, when he was questioned in a deposition proceeding by a lawyer for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.


A Gain by Working Women
LEAD: For the first time on record, working women earned 70 percent as much as working men in 1987, the Government reported today.


Mildred Evans Williams, Psychiatrist, 81
LEAD: Mildred Evans Williams, who practiced psychiatry for more than 30 years in Manhattan, died Saturday at the Candlewood Valley Nursing Home in New Milford, Conn.
She was 81 years old.


Hot Plumes at Sea
LEAD: One of the most intriguing recent discoveries at sea has been the sudden outpouring of vast quantities of hot, mineral-laden water from at least one mid-ocean ridge.
They produce volumes of hot water that can be 12 miles wide and more than a quarter mile in thickness.


Home Video Industry Feeling Middle Age
LEAD: The home video industry, born just a decade ago, is already feeling the effects of middle age.

Theory Explains Slow Emergence of Mental Ills
LEAD: MEDICAL scientists have often seen illnesses that seem at first to be isolated reponses to external shocks but later take on lives of their own.
A single episode of depression, for example, can be followed by repeated attacks that come and go with increasing frequency for no apparent reason.

LEAD: Sam M. Walton, the chairman and chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., announced yesterday that he was relinquishing one of his titles as part of a management realigment.


Savings Unit Note Offering
LEAD: Federal regulators for the savings and loan industry in the Southwest said today they would try to lower the cost of funds for savings institutions in the region by issuing up to $4 billion in notes backed by certificates of deposit guaranteed by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

RJR Nabisco
LEAD: The Planters Lifesavers Company, a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., said it would consolidate some manufacturing operations by closing a plant in Canajoharie, N.Y., and transferring production to other sites.
The plant, which has a work force of 450 and is situated 60 miles west of Albany, will be closed by Dec.

British Banks Lift Rates
LEAD: Three big British banks raised their basic interest rates by half a point today, to 9 percent, after the Bank of England increased its money market rate.
The central bank's move came as a surprise, but Barclays, Midland and National Westminister actrd quickly.


Advertising; 2 New Bakery Accounts At Muller Jordan Weiss
LEAD: Stroehmann Bakeries of Horsham, Pa., has acquired two additional bakeries - Taystee in New York and Dreikorn's in Holyoke, Mass. - and it has assigned them to its agency, Muller Jordan Weiss.
Stroehmann, a powerhouse brand in Philadelphia, has been spending about $3 million through the agency.
The new business adds more than $1 million to the pot.

McDonnell to Follow His Advice and Retire
LEAD: Sanford N. McDonnell, a 6-foot-2-inch native of Arkansas, says he feels vigorous enough to keep working even though he has announced his retirement as chairman and chief executive of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, effective March 2.


7 Killed in Philippine Battle
LEAD: Six Moslem separatist rebels and one soldier were killed in a one-hour gunbattle in the southern Philippines, the military said today.
It said four soldiers and 15 villagers were wounded in the fighting, which erupted when about 200 rebels of the Moro National Liberation Front attacked an outpost in North Cotabato province on Sunday.

In Publishing, Job Mobility Starts at the Top
LEAD: Book publishing has long been an itinerant profession, partly because for younger editors, the best way to win a raise or a promotion was to move to another house - preferably with an author or two in tow.

Japan Ends 8 Farm Quotas, Keeps 2
LEAD: Caught between foreign pressure to end its quotas on agricultural goods and lobbying by its farmers to keep them in place, Japan's Government decided today to retain its quotas on starch and dairy products and drop eight others.


Murder Trial of 2 in Klan Set
LEAD: A jury of 13 whites and one black was seated today for the murder trial of two former Ku Klux Klan leaders accused in the death of a black teen-ager in a case that drove a Klan unit into bankruptcy.


U.S. Plan Is Aimed To Give Palestinians 'A Stake in Future'
LEAD: Explaining the new United States initiative in the Middle East, one official said today that the aim was to provide ''some kind of interim arrangement that would give the Palestinians a stake in their future.''


Police in Warsaw Detain 50 In Protest Against Rumania
LEAD: The Polish police halted a demonstration outside the Rumanian Embassy in Warsaw in less than a minute today, detaining at least 50 people as they unfurled protest banners.

LEAD: THOUGH the focus of most taxpayers over the next two and a half months will be on April 15 and all the sweeping changes incorporated in their 1987 returns from the Tax Reform Act of 1986, the Revenue Act of 1987 also holds immediate implications for many people.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Do animals like dogs and cats have blood types the way people do?
A.
Blood from animals can be ''typed'' just as blood from people is, according to Dr.
Michael S. Garvey, chairman of the department of medicine at the Animal Medical Center in New York City.

He was 75 years old and lived in Greenwich.

Concert: Kronos Plays Soviet Work
LEAD: WHETHER or not female composers are getting enough chances to show their music, they are certainly getting more.
As with all such cases - where a cultural movement has received its impetus in good part from outside sources - there will be a future reckoning, a shaking out process.
At this date, some considerable reputations are going to have to stand on the basis of musical quality alone, not on questions of equal rights or past wrongs.

LEAD: The staff of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission recommended today that futures exchanges consider increasing the margin, or down payment, investors must put up to buy futures contracts ''to insure greater protection against unexpected price spikes.''

LEAD: With the start of the Winter Games 12 days away, everybody around here has been talking about the weather.
One person did something about it.

Leading Indicator
LEAD: For an event only XXII years old, the Super Bowl has generated amazing lore.
Consider Koppett's Theory.

Hong Kong Port Gain
LEAD: Hong Kong has overtaken Rotterdam. the Netherlands, as the world's busiest container port, the Marine Department director, Gerry Higginson, said today.
He told a news conference that the port recorded a 24.6 percent increase in container traffic in 1987, while officials in Rotterdam expected that their port registered no increase.

Sports People; Boxer Arrested
LEAD: Donovan (Razor) Ruddock, the ninth-ranked heavyweight in the World Boxing Council rating, was arrested along with his brother and sister Sunday night after a dispute at an airline ticket counter in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

LEAD: Gloves keep hands warm in cold weather.
But now, and especially for this coming spring, they have a more glamorous purpose.
In fact, the right pair just may be the strongest gesture of a personal fashion statement.
To contrast with, not match, the rest of an ensemble is the point.
And the stronger the color, the better.

Advertising; New Mission For Bunny At Playboy
LEAD: THE management of Playboy magazine feels it is beginning to recover from the body blow delivered two years ago when an intimidating letter was sent to retailers by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's Commission on Pornography.
Advertising pages and circulation figures are turning up for the first time in a long time.


Koch Proposes Cut in Services With Tax Rise
LEAD: Mayor Koch, saying New York City's fiscal condition was poised in the middle ground ''between the high slopes and the valley,'' proposed a $24.9 billion spending plan yesterday that calls for increased taxes and substantial cuts in services to close what he said would be a $758 million budget gap.


Terminal, 75 Years Old, Is Still Grand
LEAD: It is tightly crowded by skyscrapers, its concourse is filled with the homeless as well as with travelers, and it no longer receives such spectacular trains as the Twentieth Century Limited, but Grand Central Terminal is still, at 75, as potent a symbol of New York as it has ever been.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Euthanasia Debate Revives in China
LEAD: Two magazine articles have revealed that China has revived a sensitive debate on whether to permit the killing of incurably ill people and that one of the country's most prominent women has emerged as an advocate of euthanasia.


BellSouth Offer
LEAD: The BellSouth Corporation said it hadwithdrawn its $564 million offer to acquire the Mobile Communications Corporation of America.
The company said that negotiations had not resulted in a final agreement.
But Mobile Communications said the talks were ended when it told BellSouth that other potential acquirers had expressed serious interest in buying the company, with offers in excess of BellSouth's proposal.

Our Towns; As a Mob Howls, One in Yonkers Pleads for Sanity
LEAD: Laurie Recht says she is 4 feet, 10 1/2 inches tall, though she wears her hair teased up, so this may be a slight exaggeration.
She is 34, has lived on her own since she was 18, working as a secretary.
She's the kind of person who, before going shopping Sunday, peeked into her apartment building rec room and asked if anybody needed anything.


Moseley to Sell Branches
LEAD: The Moseley Holding Corporation said yesterday that its board had decided to sell 28 retail branch offices to other brokerage firms because of continuing losses from their operations.
The company, which was founded in 1850, said it was in the final stages of talks with three other regional brokerages.


Chicago Printers Reject Pact
LEAD: Union printers have overwhelmingly rejected a proposed contract with The Chicago Tribune and will continue their 31-month strike against the newspaper, union officials say.
The vote Sunday by members of Chicago Typographical Union No. 16 was 284 to 51 against the proposed contract.
The contract would have brought lifetime annuities of $500 a month to most of the striking printers, but it also would have meant that only a small minority would have kept their jobs.


Sanders in Awe Over Record
LEAD: On Sunday, Ricky Sanders set a Super Bowl record with 193 yards in pass receptions.
Then came seemingly endless visits from family and friends.
He was weary and tired and happy.
He felt he was on a roller coaster.

Careers; Selecting A Specialty In Medicine
LEAD: ASTUDY by Glaxo Inc., the pharmaceutical company, confirms something that medical students have grappled with for years: Prospective doctors pick a specialty with difficulty, even a little agony.
Glaxo discovered that ''an overwhelming majority of 80 percent of medical students'' believed they did not have enough valid information on which to base a decision.

Georgi Malenkov Dies at 86; Stalin Successor
LEAD: Georgi M. Malenkov, who was a leading political figure in the Soviet Union after the death of Stalin but who was ousted in a Kremlin power struggle and sent into political oblivion, died last month, a Soviet official said yesterday.
He was 86 years old.
Malenkov was Prime Minister for two years and, for a short time, head of the Communist Party.

LEAD: A restaurant operator said he planned to acquire Naugles Inc. and Del Taco Inc. in separate transactions and combine them into what would be the nation's second-largest Mexican-American fast-food chain.
Terms were not disclosed.

LEAD: Some of Islam's holiest and most ancient shrines are here, in this small town in Iraq.

Extinctions and Isotopes
LEAD: Two groups of scientists studying isotopes (forms of atoms) have reached sharply contrasting conclusions about the possible causes of mass extinctions.
Their papers appear to add fuel to the debate over comets' role.


Stockman, at Nofziger Trial, Recalls Lobby Effort
LEAD: David A. Stockman, President Reagan's first budget director, described in Federal District Court today how, in 1982, senior White House officials offered Presidential support for a New York military contractor in exchange for votes for an Administration tax bill.


Brazil to Use Own Cash in Paying Debt
LEAD: In a move toward ending its year-long moratorium on debt repayment, Brazil said yesterday that it would pay $350 million today to banks around the world.


Hyperactive Boys Often Turn Out Normal
LEAD: CONTRARY to the expectations of many experts, a new study indicates that boys who are hyperactive do not always have emotional or intellectual difficulties when they grow up.


Shultz to Discuss Arms In Shevardnadze Talks
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union later this month in an effort to narrow differences on the issue of reducing long-range arms in preparation for another summit meeting in May or June, Administration officials said today.


D. S. Kane Dies at 81; Lawyer and Professor
LEAD: David Schilling Kane, a former president of the American Patent Law Association and former adjunct professor at the New York University School of Law, died of cancer Saturday at Naples (Fla.) Community Hospital.
Mr.
Kane was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Queens Police Are Accused of Torture
LEAD: A man who accused a Queens police sergeant of torturing him with a stun gun testified yesterday that the sergeant repeatedly administered the gun to his body, delivering jolts of electricity that put him in agony and left him scarred.

LEAD: There is more to selling Florida real estate these days than promising an absence of backyard alligators and a plentiful harvest of oversized oranges.
New communities tempt prospective settlers with famous resident tennis pros, championship golf courses, horse farms or, in the case of St.
Lucie West, a hometown major league baseball team.


Index of Economic Trends Drops A 3d Month but Few Are Worried
LEAD: The Government's main economic forecasting gauge declined in December for the third straight month.
Such a move has historically indicated a possible recession, but most analysts said the evidence of a downturn was not yet persuasive.

Sports People; Not Guilty
LEAD: Pete Johnson, the former Ohio State fullback who played for three teams in the N.F.L., was found not guilty of cocaine charges yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, after a United States District Court jury deliberated for only a short time.
Johnson, 33, of Miami, had been charged with conspiracy to distribute cocaine, distribution of cocaine and traveling between states to promote a cocaine deal.

Let It Pour
LEAD: Over much of the Eastern Seaboard yesterday, people on rainswept streets battled blown-out umbrellas; those who stayed home watched the soaps.
Pigeons sheltered on windowsills; stray cats crouched in doorways; housebound children drove their elders mad.
The groundhog definitely failed to see his shadow.

Citicorp Rates Fall
LEAD: Interest rates fell at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper.
The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.61 percent, down from 6.7916 percent last week.
Another $50 million of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 6.635 percent, down from 6.879 percent.

LEAD: TRW Inc. said today that it would furlough 3,000 workers, or about 10 percent of its space and military sector work force, in the next few months because of proposed cutbacks in military spending.


Japan Hesitant On Quotas
LEAD: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trades told Japan today to lift its import quotas on 10 types of farm products to comply with international rules.
Japan said it accepted the ruling, which it had previously blocked but immediately made clear that it wanted to exempt two categories of items.

Soybeans Plunge Below $6 On Weak Export Demand
LEAD: Prices of soybean futures plunged below $6 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday amid weak export demand.
Grain prices were mixed.
The soybean decline reflected a drop in export demand for soybean meal and soybean oil, said Joel Karlin, an analyst in Chicago for Research Department Inc.

LEAD:  Economic and Social Council


Sports People; Illini Hires Mackovicy
LEAD: The University of Illinois selected John Mackovic, the former Kansas City Chiefs' coach, as its new football coach yesterday.
Mackovic, 44, was selected during a closed-door meeting of the school's Athletic Association Board, the sources told The Associated Press.
The Illini defensive coordinator, Howard Tippett, who also had sought the job, said Athletic Director Neale Stoner had called him to say Mackovic had been selected.


MICROWAVE COOKING
LEAD: IT seems as if almost everyone is, like me, on a postholiday diet but bored to death with simple pieces of fish, salads and grilled bits of this and that.
Fortunately, the microwave oven can cook rich-tasting but low-calorie dishes quickly.
You can make enough for just one or two or enough for a group of friends who won't even know they are eating diet food.


Carrington To Head Christie's
LEAD: Lord Carrington will become chairman of Christie's International after his retirement in June as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the British-based auction house announced yesterday.


Policy on Black Judicial Nominees Is Debated
LEAD: The Justice Department official in charge of screening potential Federal judges testified today that the small number of black nominees, six out of 367 chosen for judgeships in the last seven years, was largely a result of the paucity of qualified black lawyers who share the Reagan Administration's judicial and political outlook.

LEAD:  Markets


N. M. Bodecker, 66; He Wrote and Drew Books for Children
LEAD: N. M. Bodecker, an illustrator and author of children's books, died of cancer of the colon Feb. 1 at his home in Hancock, N.H.
He was 66 years old.


Prime Rate Is Lowered By Major Banks to 8 1/2%
LEAD: The nation's leading banks lowered their prime lending rate yesterday by a quarter of a percentage point, to 8 1/2 percent, its lowest level since September.

LEAD: Officially, our European allies are supporting without reservation the new treaty banning intermediate-range nuclear forces.
This surface unanimity, however, masks a sea of uncertainty about the long-term reliability of the United States as a defense partner.

SUPERMARKET CHAIN ACCUSED OF BREAKING VOW ON PESTICIDE
LEAD: Consumer groups complained today that Safeway supermarkets had violated a promise to customers by selling apples containing trace amounts of a potentially hazardous farm chemical.


Sports People; Arbitration Winner
LEAD: Baseball's first salary arbitration case of the year was decided yesterday in favor of a player, Gerald Perry, the 27-year-old first baseman for the Atlanta Braves.
Last season, at a salary of $225,000, Perry batted .270, hit 12 home runs, knocked in 74 runs and stole 42 bases.
The Braves then offered him $375,000 for next season, but Perry asked for $425,000.

Benjamin Kuhn, one of seven friars who established Siena College here in 1937, died Sunday at St.
Anthony's Hospital in Warwick, N.Y, after a heart attack earlier in January.
He was 82 years old and lived in Warwick.

LEAD:  International A2-12


Campeau Amends Federated Offer
LEAD: The Campeau Corporation has sent a letter to Federated Department Stores amending its $47-a-share cash offer for Federated to remove the condition that the offer be approved by Federated's board.This apparently signals that Campeau intends to proceed with its $4.2 billion offer even if Federated's board, scheduled to review the bid on Friday, rejects it.


MEESE ADDS LITTLE TO WEDTECH CASE
LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d testified in Federal District Court today that he could not remember details of the White House role in the Wedtech Corporation's efforts to obtain a $32 million Army contract in 1982.
But he said at the time he wanted the company to receive a fair hearing.


Foreman Is Fighting Waistline And Critics
LEAD: Last March, after an absence of 10 years from the prize ring, George Foreman stepped between the ropes in Sacramento, Calif., to fight a journeyman named Steve Zouski.


Pentagon Adds to Jobs for Women And Demands End to Harassment
LEAD: The Defense Department directed the military services today to enforce rules against sexual harassment more rigorously and to open more positions to women.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Monday incorrectly reported a resignation at TW Services, the parent company of Denny's fast-food restaurants.
Donald L. Pierce has resigned as president of Denny's and as a director of TW Services.
Frank L. Salizzoni remains the chairman and chief executive of TW Services.


New Clash on Estimate Board's Fate
LEAD: The intensifying dispute over the future of the New York City Board of Estimate grew more pointed yesterday when the board's special counsel took public issue with Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Charter Revision Commission.

LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: FOOTBALL season is over.
I realized the end had come the other night when God was prominently mentioned several times on television.
This doesn't happen much.
I'm not counting those times on ''Dynasty'' when Alexis says, ''Thank God Blake will never own that oil pipeline.''


Discount Stores for Fledgling Gourmets
LEAD: IN the suburbs around New York City consumers weaned on Twinkies and cheese spread are broadening their gastronomic horizons at Passport Foods Outlet.
The fledgling seven-store chain, retail experts say, is the nation's first to sell imported delicacies at discount prices.

Profits Plunge At First Boston
LEAD: First Boston Inc., battered by losses in its risk arbitrage unit and by the general downturn in business activity after the stock market collapse in October, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings plummeted 91.7 percent on a 35.3 percent decline in revenues.

California Bond Rate Higher In Response to Tax Rules
LEAD: California's first issue of tax-exempt bonds with interest subject to the Federal alternative minimum income tax resulted in interest rates that were about half a percentage point higher than is traditional for the state's bonds, which are completely exempt from Federal income tax.


Ex-Pan Am Executive Gets Continental Post
LEAD: Martin R. Shugrue Jr., who was ousted two weeks ago as vice chairman of the Pan Am Corporation, yesterday was elected president of Continental Airlines Inc.
For much of the last year, Continental has been seeking to solve service problems that brought a flood of customer complaints.


Appeal Is Filed on Special Prosecutor Law
LEAD: The Supreme Court was asked Monday to reinstate legal provisions that created special prosecutors to investigate charges of wrongdoing by high-ranking officials of the Federal executive branch.


Finnish Chief Wants to Cut Power of His Job
LEAD: According to a Government official here, Mauno Koivisto once likened his mission as President of Finland to that of the character played by Gary Cooper in ''High Noon.''


When Trade Tigers Grow Up
LEAD: President Reagan had good reason to drop Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore from a program that gives favored tariff treatment to most of the third world.
Those nations, known in trade circles as the ''four tigers,'' no longer need special help.
Indeed, the time has come for them to share more responsibility for world trade expansion by relaxing their own import restrictions, by adopting flexible currency exchange rates, or both.

How Fragonard Came to Met
LEAD: In the Jean-Honore Fragonard exhibition that opens this Saturday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, both the artist and the museum have done their magic.
The show radiates color, clarity and completeness of design, and the paintings hang like seemingly inevitable expressions in a seemingly permanent home.

Shad, Too, Signal the Season
LEAD: THE groundhog did not see its shadow , and to confirm that spring is on its way shad is also here.
The first are on sale at a few fish markets in the New York area.
This succulent and richly flavored member of the herring family is excellent to broil, grill or bake.
Shad roe is also available and is at its best lightly sauteed in plenty of butter or olive oil.

LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., a British hotel conglomerate, formally ended a six-week bidding war for the French cognac maker Martell &amp; Compagnie by saying it would not contest a rival offer from the Seagram Company.

Bridge: Best Possible Aceless Hand Turned Up in Quebec Game
LEAD: Back in the 30's, Ely Culbertson offered a cash prize for an authenticated case of someone picking up the best possible hand - 37 high-card points, although he did not express it that way - or the worst possible hand, all the deuces, treys and four spots plus a five.
Nobody collected.

Munford, a rookie, had been sidelined several weeks with a herniated disk in his back.

From Out of the Past, Angel Food Cake
LEAD: SEVERAL weeks ago a friend served homemade angel food cake with raspberry sauce, and everyone asked for seconds.
It wasn't until later that it dawned on me that I hadn't had angel food cake in 20 years.
And that my angel cake slicer, the one with the long teeth, had been sitting idle in the silver drawer.

District of Columbia Will Provide Bleach For Addict Needles
LEAD: District of Columbia health officials will begin giving drug addicts vials of bleach to clean hypodermic needles in an effort to halt the spread of AIDS, Health Commissioner Reed V. Tuckson has announced.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary yesterday about Georgi M. Malenkov, who succeeded Stalin as Soviet leader, misstated the current name of the town in which he was born.
The town, Orenburg, was called Chkalov between 1938 and 1957; it is now once again called Orenburg.

EATING WELL
LEAD: NUTRITIONISTS fall, roughly, into two categories: those who champion vitamin and mineral supplements - the more the merrier - and those who are dead set against them.
The former are looked down on by the latter as quacks; the latter are looked down on by the former as old-fashioned fuddy-duddies, stuck in the mind set of the 1950's before certain nutritional information was known.

Super Bowl Rating Falls
LEAD: Super Bowl XXII was the lowest rated Super Bowl since 1974, according to the A. C. Nielsen ratings released yesterday.

Security Guard Convicted
LEAD: A jury in Brooklyn convicted a former security guard yesterday in the slaying of Dawn Livecchi, a 20-year-old design student, in the doorway of her Fort Greene brownstone.
The defendant, Anthony Jenkins, 26, was accused of shooting her after she refused his sexual advances.
He was convicted on two counts of second-degree murder, one count of second-degree manslaughter and one count of criminal possession of a weapon.

Foster Wheeler
LEAD: The Foster Wheeler Corporation said its president, Louis E. Azzato, was prepared to meet with Asher B. Edelman, but not to discuss his proposal to pay $16.50 a share, or almost $575 million in cash, for the company's stock.
Mr.
Edelman, who holds about 11.5 percent of Foster Wheeler's common stock outstanding, proposed last week that the company create a recapitalization plan or, as an alternative, accept his buyout offer.

Rig Count Down Again
LEAD: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States dropped again last week, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today.
The count fell by 62, to a total of 964.
A year ago, the count stood at 826.
Although the rig count usually declines during the first few months of the year, the drop last week was particularly large.

Time to Save Open Land Is Running Out
LEAD: At this rate, there may be no farmland left in New Jersey in two decades.
Litchfield County, Conn., lost nearly half of its agricultural acreage over two decades.
Scout camps in Hunterdon County, N.J., and Dutchess County, N.Y., beset by declining attendance, encroaching suburbs and even a lack of lifeguards, were coveted by developers.


Defeat of Contra Aid: The 219-211 Roll-Call Vote in the House
LEAD: Following is the 219-211 roll-call vote by which the House today rejected President Reagan's request for $43 million in aid to the contra rebels in Nicaragua.
A ''yes'' vote is to approve the President's plan; a ''no'' vote is to reject it.
Voting yes were 47 Democrats and 164 Republicans.
Voting no were 207 Democrats and 12 Republicans.

The Crash and Its Best Students
LEAD: In the latest formal study of the October stock crash, the Securities and Exchange Commission paints the picture of a rapidly changing market organized around obsolete rules and expectations.
The proposed reforms could reduce the probability of another crash.
But meanwhile, a much larger and more constructive change has probably already occurred among the pension and mutual funds that now dominate the market.

A U.S. Frame-Up of Nicaragua Charged
LEAD: A former senior Panamanian official said today that the White House set up a secret operation in 1986 that called for Panama to arrange an East bloc arms shipment that could be captured in El Salvador and falsely linked to Nicaragua's Government.


The Limit of Chaos Tempts A New School of Architects
LEAD: SITTING at his drafting table wearing leopard-spot shoes, jeans and a shaggy sweater, a 25-year-old student at the Southern California Institute of Architecture in Santa Monica works on a model that looks like a sprawling house of cards.
With leaning walls and inclined floors, the building seems about to collapse.

LEAD: Dr.

He was 62 years old.

BP America Bids For Lear Petroleum
LEAD: BP America Inc., the United States subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company, has offered to acquire the Lear Petroleum Corporation in a deal that BP America has valued at $250 million.
The Dallas-based Lear said it would study the offer with a recapitalization plan presented to the company by an investor group last month.

Abrams stayed in office.


Prison Aides Give Inmate Murder Alibi
LEAD: A man charged by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office with murdering a stranger beneath a highway overpass one year ago tomorrow was in an upstate prison at the time of the killing, state correctional officials said yesterday.


Film: Pavarotti in China, in 'Distant Harmony'
LEAD: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI and China make a formidable match in ''Distant Harmony,'' a cheerful documentary about the tenor's tour of the country in June 1986.
The director, DeWitt Sage, had the playful notion of playing off Western grand opera against traditional Chinese music and, in the course of these 85 highly entertaining minutes, reconciling them.

Muzzleloading in Vogue Again
LEAD: DAVE PEDIGO, a field representative for the National Muzzleloading Rifle Association, will explain the fundamentals of black-powder shooting at the meeting next Wednesday of the Nassau County Fish and Game Association.


Price Tag On Rescue In Texas
LEAD: Federal regulators estimated today that between $6 billion and $7 billion would be needed initially to curb the capital shortages of battered savings associations in Texas.
But industry advisers cautioned that the full cost of restoring health to the ahaelathe state's savings institutions to health would be much higher.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Duplicate Studies
LEAD: The inspector general of the Labor Department has begun an investigation to determine whether departmental procedures were violated by the award of a $1.3 million contract for a study that virtually duplicated a study done by the department's own Bureau of Labor Statistics.


Paris Opera Ballet to Perform at Met
LEAD: The Paris Opera Ballet will return to the Metropolitan Opera House for three weeks this summer, in a season featuring the American premiere of Robert Wilson's ''Martyre de St.
Sebastien,'' the New York premieres of works by William Forsythe and Maguy Marin, and productions of ''Swan Lake'' and ''The Nutcracker'' by Rudolf Nureyev, artistic director of the company.


Advertising; Emhart Begins Ads For Its New Operation
LEAD: For some 75 years the Emhart Corporation had two operations, one producing such industrial products as machine tools, the other making such consumer goods as Tru-Temper lawn and garden tools and golf club shafts.


Senate, 97 to 0, Confirms Kennedy to High Court
LEAD: The extraordinary seven-month battle over the vacant seat on the Supreme Court ended without a dissenting vote today as the Senate confirmed Judge Anthony M. Kennedy as an Associate Justice.


Market Place; Japanese Bought During Plunge
LEAD: UNTIL the last stages of the bull market, Japanese investors were big buyers of United States equities.
And even when Wall Street prices collapsed in October, the Japanese kept nibbling at stocks in this country, in contrast to the liquidation by American traders, mutual funds and other domestic institutions.


Salk's Injectable Polio Vaccine May Be Revived
LEAD: Health officials are considering a major change in the strategy of polio vaccination, using a new, more potent version of the injectable Salk vaccine that helped eradicate polio in the United States almost 30 years ago.


REAGAN BACKS F.B.I. OVER SURVEILLANCE
LEAD: President Reagan is satisfied that the Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted a proper surveillance campaign against groups opposed to his policies in Central America, the White House said today.

LEAD: Traffic was light today on Big Creek Lake.
For the most part, the cars that usually cruise its frozen surface on brisk winter days stayed on land instead, their drivers cautious after a brief thaw.


Critic's Notebook; A Flawed 'Tristan' That Improves With Distance
LEAD: I LIKE the ''Tristan und Isolde'' of the Los Angeles Music Center Opera a lot better now than when I saw it in December.
I have forgotten most of the things I thought were wrong, but the vestiges of what was right survive in my head, serving as reminders of the ''idea'' that Wagner's opera really is.


Advertising; Soviet Ad Conference
LEAD: Barry Day, vice chairman and director of professional services at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, will be telling 400 Soviet manufacturers today the basics about Western advertising at the first advertising conference in Moscow.
Mr.
Day is expected to show and discuss television spots for L'Oreal, Coca-Cola and Sony and warnings about drug abuse.


Sports People; Bigger Than Life
LEAD: The worst nightmare for National Basketball Association defenders - a 7-foot, 275-pound Larry Bird - came to Boston Garden last night, but only for a public unveiling at halftime of the Celtics-Indiana Pacer game.
The detailed sculpture of the Boston superstar, hand carved in more than 2,000 hours from a single 1,800-pound block of laminated basswood, was the work of Armand LaMontagne, a Rhode Island sculptor.The study of Bird, crouched as if prepared to release a jump shot, was privately un-veiled on Tuesday night at a $1,500-a-couple benefit dinner for the New England Sports Museum.

LEAD: One day after setting the Staten Island record for most points in a high school basketball game with 75, Kenny White of Monsignor Farrell was late for dinner.

Rev. Harold Mulqueen Dies at 93; A Longtime Professor at Fordham
LEAD: The Rev.
Harold Mulqueen, S.J., whose 80-year association with Fordham University gained him the name ''Father Fordham,'' died of burns Sunday at Bronx Municipal Hospital.
University officials said the burns were sustained in a fire apparently started by his pipe.
He was 93 years old and lived in the Bronx.


Dollar Is Mostly Higher, Lifted by Gold's Decline
LEAD: The dollar rose against most foreign currencies yesterday, buoyed as gold prices plunged to their lowest levels in recent months.


Tunisia Did Not Shoot Palestinian Supporters
LEAD: To the Editor:


Searching For the Best In Day Care
LEAD: A WELL-DESIGNED day-care program can foster your child's emotional and physical development in ways that you may not be able to at home.
Studies have shown that children in group day care may be more self-confident and relate better to both children and adults than children who stay at home.
A poor program, however, can be little more than a preschool parking lot.


U.S. Says Soviet Offered to Cut Aid to Nicaragua
LEAD: The White House said today that the Soviet Union in recent weeks had offered to cut off most military aid to the Nicaraguan Government if the United States ended its aid to the contras and all military assistance to the nations of Central America.

BRITISH ARTS FESTIVAL IN LOS ANGELES
LEAD: A three-month festival of British arts is to begin here Thursday with the city's first major retrospective of art by David Hockney; it will end April 30, after five performances by the Academy of St.
Martin-in-the-Fields.
Squeezed in between will be more than 50 musical, theatrical and visual-arts events.


The Editorial Notebook; At Home With Lyme Disease
LEAD: A month ago, Lyme disease forced my wife, Elizabeth, back into the hospital.
But this time she was allowed to leave quickly and self-administer the major part of her treatment in the comfort of home.
There's a lesson in her experience that applies to far more than Lyme disease.
Such home care saves money, buoys morale and upgrades the health care delivery system.


2.5% Rise In Factory Orders
LEAD: Factory orders, propelled by heavy demand for aircraft, surged 2.5 percent in December, closing out the best year for American manufacturers since 1984, the Government said today.

Palestinian Demonstrations Continue
LEAD: Twenty or more Palestinian boys and young men - rocks and chunks of concrete in their hands, checkered kaffiyehs wrapped around their faces - clustered excitedly by their barricade of burning tires at the turnoff to this isolated village among the stony hills, waiting for cars with yellow Israeli license plates.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A brief article from The Associated Press in some editions last Friday about the indictment of 15 people in a scheme to hide drug profits, included a name erroneously in the list of those indicted.
Former Representative Robert Hanrahan of Illinois was investigated by the Internal Revenue Service but was not arrested or indicted, as prosecutors originally reported.


Sports People; Camacho Arrested
LEAD: Hector (Macho) Camacho, the former lightweight champion, was arrested Tuesday in Florida on cocaine and assault charges.
The police reports alleged that Camacho pulled a gun on a person who made an obscene gesture at Camacho's companion.
He was later released on bail.
Camacho, 25, unbeaten in 31 bouts, has not fought since retaining his World Boxing Council lightweight title with a 12-round decision over Cornelius Boza-Edwards at Miami Beach, Fla., on Sept.


Study Backs Theory That AIDS Festered in Africa
LEAD: A new study has found that a low incidence of AIDS infection in a remote African village is unchanged after a decade, suggesting that urbanization and war have played major roles in the continent's recent AIDS explosion.

EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: Bank of America, San Francisco, named Robert Capwell a senior vice president.
It also named Larry D. Hartwig, a senior vice president, to oversee its Houston-based Southwest operations.


Gandhi's Wife Pulled Into India Political Fray
LEAD: Returning from a recent holiday in the sun, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi faced new criticism for vacationing at a time of hardship in India.
Even worse, it was described as a vacation with foreigners, including family and friends of his Italian-born wife, Sonia.


Wall Street Executives Call Program-Trade Curb Weak
LEAD: New York Stock Exchange restrictions on program trading do not go far enough, a number of chief executives of major Wall Street firms said yesterday at a special meeting at the exchange.
The meeting of 25 chief executives was held to hear their views on the controversial trading strategy that has been cited as a factor behind increased volatility of stock prices.


New Jackson Finding Dividends in Iowa
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson argues that he is already a winner in Iowa.
And on a frigid Tuesday night, as he entered a union hall to warm applause, the distance he had traveled since his 1984 campaign was clear.

LEAD: Gov.
Evan Mecham testified today that he had been ill-informed and ill-advised by his staff, and he accused state police officers of lying in testimony about his actions.


Dance: Karen Bernard
LEAD: WHEREAS many choreographers seek to connect movements, Karen Bernard and Tina Dudek emphasized deliberately disjointed movements on Monday night at the Dia Art Foundation.


Advertising; Lord, Geller Shifts
LEAD: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein has reorganized its executive ranks.
Edward D. Yaconetti, 49 years old, becomes vice chairman, from executive vice president; C. Ray Freeman, 45, is now executive vice president, general manager, from executive vice president, managing director, and Kevin B. O'Neill, 34, becomes executive vice president, creative director, from senior vice president, creative director.


As Isabel Allende Sees Herself
LEAD: Like most other serious novelists, Isabel Allende of Chile would prefer not to be fingerprinted and imprisoned in a confining category - not as a female writer or as a political writer or even as a Latin American writer.
Just plain novelist, she said the other day, will do.

Dow Falls 28.35 After Early Gains
LEAD: Stock prices slumped yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average, which was up in the early going, fell 28.35 points, or 1.5 percent, to close at 1,924.57.


THEARAPISTS SEE NEED FOR 'SECURITY BLANKET' THROUGHOUT LIFE
LEAD: People who talk to themselves or who have imaginary companions are not necessarily mentally unhinged.
To the contrary, experts say these tactics are two of innumerable helpful and healthy ways to find solace amid life's pains.


Charges Dropped in Quarrel
LEAD: Prosecutors today dropped charges of battery and disorderly conduct against Gary Dotson, whose rape sentence was commuted in 1985 after the woman who accused him of raping her recanted.
Mr.
Dotson was accused of stabbing a cook in a barroom quarrel Dec. 26.
Officials said they were dropping the case because the cook did not want to pursue it.

LEAD:  BASEBALL


British Airways
LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. said it had signed a $2 billion order for eleven 767 jets from the Boeing Company with an option to buy 15 more.
The first aircraft will be delivered in November 1989, the company said.
The order was first announced last August.
British Airways said that it had signed contracts totaling $400 million with the British engine maker Rolls-Royce P.L.C to supply RB211-524H engines for the aircraft.


Robert Duncan, Poet and Author Of Works on the Creative Process
LEAD: Robert Duncan, a poet and author of a work on the Imagist poet H. D. (Hilda Doolittle), died yesterday at his home in San Francisco.
He was 69 years old.

Laudner, a free-agent catcher, agreed to a salary of $295,000, plus an additional $12,500 if he plays 95 games or more.

PMS Drugs Questioned
LEAD: A small study of hormones and moods in women shows no relationship between any of a variety of hormones and premenstrual syndrome.
The finding calls into question certain drugs that have been used to treat the problem.


U.S. and Germany Called Pleased With Dollar's Level
LEAD: The United States and West Germany, whose disputes over economic policies last fall contributed to the decline of the dollar's value, are content with one another's policies now and with current levels of the dollar and interest rates, an Administration official said today.


THOUSANDS ASSAIL OFFSHORE OIL PLAN
LEAD: A Federal hearing on Government plans to allow offshore oil drilling brought ordinary life in this lumber and fishing town of more than 5,700 people virtually to a halt today.


Sports People; Packers Name Infante
LEAD: Lindy Infante, the offensive coordinator who helped the Cleveland Browns to two consecutive appearances in the American Conference championship game, took over yesterday as coach of the Green Bay Packers.
Infante, 47, signed a five-year contract.
Tom Braatz, the Packers' executive vice president of football operations, said Infante's expertise made him attractive.


Argentina Reported Upset by Vaccine Test
LEAD: The Argentina Government will send a formal protest note to the Pan American Health Organization over vaccine experiments on Argentine cows involving a genetically altered virus that it says accidentally infected humans, sources in the Foreign Ministry said Tuesday.

LEAD: October's stock market collapse may have given some stock exchange specialists a lasting case of the jitters, with many of them backing away from buying or selling stocks when they are most needed, the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission reported in its market study released Tuesday.

LEAD: Divers taking a break yesterday from salvage work on a barge that sank Sunday in Rosario Strait near Anacortes, Wash.

LEAD: NO trip can be called an odyssey unless it inspires serious contemplation.
With the 92d Street Y's odyssey-like Schubertiade, which intends to present the composer's complete work over the course of 10 years, listeners are invited to piece together the strands of a composer's evolution and, by extension, to reflect on the creative process itself.

LEAD: The Hughes Aircraft Company said it had agreed to buy the satellite system of the Western Union Corporation.
Terms were not disclosed.
Hughes, the Los Angeles-based subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said that it would operate the three orbiting satellites in Western Union's Westar VI-S system and that it intended to replace one with a newer model.

LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns.
Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way.

LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company today reported a 3.5 percent rise in its fourth-quarter profit, although net income was helped by several one-time gains.


Sports People; Yankees Bow Out
LEAD: The Yankees told Donnie Moore yesterday that they were no longer interested in him.
Moore, a relief pitcher who was declared a free agent Jan. 22, had been scheduled to be in New York today for a physical examination, but the Yankees canceled the appointment.
Moore, who has one year left on his contract with the California Angels, was one of seven players included in the ruling by Thomas Roberts, an arbitrator.

Musicians Vote to End Strike in San Francisco
LEAD: The musicians of the San Francisco Symphony voted, 71 to 18, over the weekend to ratify a new contract and end a 12-day strike.


PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: Say ''root canal'' and most people shudder with imagined pain and apprehension.
But ask the millions of Americans who have had root canal treatments in recent years and you will hear a far happier tale.
In a 1985 survey of 1,019 adults, 80 percent said the procedure was painless and far less complicated and uncomfortable than they had expected.


Car Plant Shift Seen in Japan
LEAD: Japanese auto makers will probably increase their annual production capacity at their United States and Canadian plants to 2.2 million vehicles by early 1990, from 300,000 in 1985, the Confederation of Japan Automobile Workers Unions said today.

FRANK GEHRY'S CHAIRS: HE CAN'T GIVE THEM UP
LEAD: PEOPLE who see Frank Gehry's cardboard furniture in 1988 may think they've seen it before.
And they may have.
Mr.
Gehry, the iconoclastic architect based in Venice, Calif., introduced Easy Edges, a seating collection made from corrugated cardboard, in 1971.
Because of their imaginative and experimental nature, the chairs continue to stand out in the crowd of architect-designed furniture.

LEAD: FOR many amateur inventors, the original idea came as a fluke.
Consider two nonprofessionals who successfully brought their toy concepts to market.

He was 59 years old.

Domingo Cancels
LEAD: Placido Domingo has canceled his scheduled appearances in the Metropolitan Opera production of ''Luisa Miller'' on Feb. 10 and 13, saying he has a cold.
The tenor Ermanno Mauro will sing the role of Rodolfo at those performances.


F.D.A. Issues Advice on Children's Ear Infections
LEAD: Visit a pediatrician's waiting room these days, and chances are that one patient in three is suffering an ear infection, according to estimates by the Food and Drug Administration.


Pan Am to Pay Retired Pilots In Age Bias Suit
LEAD: Pan American Airways Inc. has agreed to pay $17.2 million to a group of former pilots who were not allowed to work as flight engineers after they were required to retire as pilots at the age of 60, a Federal agency announced today.


Dance: Limon Troupe's 'Poems'
LEAD: THE Limon Dance Company, which began the final week of its season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, has maintained a special relationship with Anna Sokolow since Jose Limon, the troupe's founder, died in 1972.
Both choreographers belonged to the second generation in American modern dance, although they could be classed as pioneers in their own right.


A Sentence and 3 New Arrests in San Juan Fire
LEAD: A maintenance worker who admitted he set the fire that killed 97 people at the DuPont Plaza Hotel here on New Year's Eve, 1986, was sentenced to 30 years in prison today and three other members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters were charged in the case.

Jazz: John Carter Group
LEAD: THE clarinetist John Carter ended his first set at Carlos 1 on Tuesday with a quiet climax.
Given Mr.
Carter's ease with the unexpected - his compositions hop around registers, while his improvisations set up contrasting section after section - it makes sense he finished the show with a ballad instead of the obligatory sweat-pourer.


Desperately Seeking Iowa
LEAD: Three cheers for the television networks for refusing to broadcast President Reagan's predictable speech urging Congress to vote further aid for the contras in Nicaragua.
But don't expect the networks and the rest of the press to be as independent in giving next week's Iowa caucuses the coverage they deserve - which is not much.


Over a Philosophic Temple, Shadow of a Swastika
LEAD: Is the cultural legacy of one of the most powerful and influential thinkers of the 20th century poisoned at its roots?
The Nazi past of the German philosopher Martin Heidegger has become the focus of a roiled debate among French intellectuals, one that is belatedly spilling over into West Germany as well.

Iowa Becomes a Test of Organization
LEAD: At Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis's headquarters here, staff members in a second-floor room that is barred to outsiders have been exhorting precinct workers this week to increase the turnout of Dukakis supporters at Monday night's caucuses.

Nurses Strike British Hospitals
LEAD: London police officers stopping nurses from marching to Parliament yesterday as the Royal College of Nursing, Britiain's largest nurses' union, began its first nationwide walkout in the 40 years of the National Health Service.
No major disruptions were reported, but many hospitals postponed non-urgent admissions and surgery.


Tenacious Purslane Returns, Prettier and Good Enough to Eat
LEAD: AONG the chief pleasures of gardening are the unpredictable discoveries and surprises that occur almost constantly.
Even a very long lifetime is not sufficient to contain them all.
We gardeners need to wear our knowledge lightly, for it is always subject to correction.

Gene Defect Pinpointed in Bad Reactions to Drugs
LEAD: An international team of scientists has discovered the genetic defect that makes as many as 10 percent of white Americans and Europeans suffer bad reactions to many drugs used to treat high blood pressure, disturbances of heart rhythm and other conditions.
