Don't Wait for the Stock Market to Cure Itself
LEAD: To the Editor:


Canadian Growth Seen
LEAD: Canada's economy should shrug off any negative impact of the October stock market collapse and expand at a healthy rate, the Conference Board of Canada said today.
The board's assessment is that the economy will grow by 2.9 percent this year and 2.6 percent in 1989.


JUDGE QUESTIONS CASE ON NOFZIGER
LEAD: The Federal district judge in Lyn Nofziger's trial questioned today whether prosecutors had proved an essential element of the allegation that Mr.
Nofziger, a former adviser to President Reagan, illegally lobbied Edwin Meese 3d for the Wedtech Corporation.

LEAD:  ''This is the sale of a child, or, at the very least, the sale of a mother's right to her child, the only mitigating factor being that one of the purchasers is the father.''  - Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the New Jersey Supreme Court, in the unanimousBaby M decision.  [ B6:3.

Gulf War Premiums Cut
LEAD: War risk insurance premiums have been cut, effective Thursday, for cargoes on ships sailing to and from many Persian Gulf ports, the War Risk Rating Committee said today.
The decision stemmed from what the committee said was a slightly less volatile situation in the Persian Gulf and a decline in attacks on shipping.

LEAD: THE indomitable Peggy Lee has not only surmounted the physical problems that have beset her recently - double heart-bypass surgery three years ago and a fall last year resulting in broken bones in her feet from which she has still not recovered - she has also adapted and, in the process, become an even more subtle and moving performer than she had been.

LEAD: An article on Saturday about the restoration of a hotel in Ho Chi Minh City identified it incompletely; it was the Continental Palace.
The family that owned the business until 1975 was named incorrectly; it was the Franchini family.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. My house is heated by steam and one radiator makes a banging sound when it is on.
What causes this, and can eliminate it?
A.
As the steam in a radiator dissipates, it condenses into water and runs through the radiator valve to the boiler for reheating.
If the water cannot run out easily and meets the incoming steam, a knocking sound sometimes results.


Robert S. Sturtevant, Advertising Executive, 56
LEAD: Robert S. Sturtevant, co-founder and chairman of a Manhattan advertising agency, Sturtevant and Hildt, died Saturday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 56 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

LEAD: Esa Tikkanen scored three goals and Dave Hannan had two as the Edmonton Oilers outscored the New Jersey Devils, 8-5, tonight.

LEAD: Only a few hours before he admitted to the police that he had killed Jennifer Levin in Central Park, Robert E. Chambers Jr. denied being at the scene of her death and said his cat had left the red scratches that were visible across his face and chest, a police detective testified yesterday at Mr.

Palestinian Raid Kills 2 Soldiers, Israelis Say
LEAD: Palestinian guerrillas crossed into Israel from Lebanon early today and killed two soldiers, the army said.
One Palestinian was reported killed in the raid, which the army said was a mission to seize civilian hostages.


Times to Introduce A Television Weekly
LEAD: The New York Times will introduce a new guide to broadcast and cable television programs on March 6.
The magazine, called Television, will offer four-color advertising and will be printed by rotogravure on premium calendered paper, 8 1/4 by 11 inches, press-stitched and trimmed.

LEAD: Compagnie Financiere de Suez said tonight that it had purchased a 10 percent stake in Societe Generale de Belgique, becoming the third major player in a struggle for control of Belgium's biggest company.

Productivity Up, but Rise Is Slower
LEAD: The nation's businesses continued to improve their productivity in 1987 but were less successful in squeezing out more efficiency gains than in the previous four years, the Government said today.


Film: 'Serpent and the Rainbow'
LEAD: IT'S a long way from a Harvard ethnobiologist's thoughtful account of his search for exotic Haitian medicinal potions to a film with the advertising slogan ''Don't bury me . . .
I'm not dead!'' But in fact these two sides of ''The Serpent and the Rainbow'' aren't as different as they sound.
Wade Davis's fascinating 1985 book is much more an adventure story than a scientific tract, and the film is the work of Wes Craven, whose horror credits (''A Nightmare on Elm Street,'' ''The Hills Have Eyes'') give an incomplete impression of his talents.

A Correction
LEAD: An editing error altered a sentence in Tuesday's article ''For Local Elections in the West Bank and Gaza.'' The sentence should have said that Arabs in Gaza have insisted that the killing of four Arabs ''was an act of retaliation for the knifing murder of an Israeli merchant.''


Iraq Denies That It Requested Guarantees for Pipeline Plan
LEAD: Iraq said today that it had not sought ''political guarantees'' from Israel or other parties in negotiations in 1984 over a projected oil pipeline to Jordan.


Gerald Knoff, 80, of Church Council, Dies
LEAD: The Rev.
Gerald E. Knoff, who served for 20 years as associate general secretary of the National Council of Churches, died of cardiac arrest Friday at the Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass.
He was 80 years old and lived in East Sandwich, Mass.


Film: 'She's Having a Baby,' From John Hughes
LEAD: FOR John Hughes's Ferris Bueller, it was only a day off; for his Jefferson (Jake) Briggs, it may be an entire life.
In the first scene of ''She's Having a Baby,'' which opens today at the Paramount and other theaters, Jake is seen marrying a woman he can barely stand, and this is only the beginning of his half-heartedness and disenchantment.


Inside a 'Shooting Gallery': New Front in the AIDS War
LEAD: Amid the flicker of stubby one-inch candles, the only light in an abandoned building near the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn, a 32-year-old man who calls himself Wollenski fidgeted as he watched another man glide a hypodermic syringe filled with cocaine and heroin effortlessly into his right biceps.

Congress Unit Sees Federal '89 Deficit Far Beyond Target
LEAD: The Congressional Budget Office estimated today that next year's Federal budget deficit would be $176 billion, or $40 billion higher than the target stipulated in the budget-balancing law that Congress passed last year.

Financial Job Cutbacks
LEAD: As many as 75,000 financial workers in London and New York may lose their jobs as a result of the Oct. 19 stock collapse, a banker told a conference today.
Hans-Joerg Rudloff, deputy chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., said dismissals could total between 20,000 and 25,000 in London and up to 50,000 in New York.

European G.N.P. Jumps
LEAD: Growth in the European Community accelerated in the third quarter of 1987, outpacing the United States but still lagging behind Japan, the European Community statistics office said today.
The community's gross national product surged by 5.4 percent in the quarter because of strong domestic demand and higher exports, the office said.

LEAD:  Markets


Court Rebuffs Joyce Brown, Citing Release
LEAD: New York State's highest court declined yesterday to rule on Joyce Brown's appeal of her involuntary hospitalization, saying the issue was moot because she has been released.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Uruguayan Front-Runner
LEAD: Uruguay's Foreign Minister, Enrique Yglesias, is emerging as a leading candidate for the presidency of the Inter-American Development Bank, a 44-nation Washington institution that makes development loans to Latin American countries.


SEOUL PLANS LINKS TO EASTERN BLOC
LEAD: South Korea, whose Government is as fiercely anti-Communist as any to be found, has mounted a full-scale diplomatic offensive to improve relations with Soviet-bloc countries and China.


Shift at Sports inc.
LEAD: Steven L. Isenberg, 46 years old, is giving up his post as interim publisher of Sports inc.
The magazine styles itself ''The Sports Business Weekly'' and is directed at decision makers in the sports business.
Scott Kabak, 33, will replace Mr.
Isenberg and will continue as president of the magazine, which is one of the Times Mirror Magazines.


First Fabulous Friday
LEAD: The Muir String Quartet - Peter Zazofsky and Bayla Keyes, violinists; Steven Ansell, violist, and Michael Reynolds, cellist - will perform works by Haydn and Brahms, and the New York premiere of Sofia Gubaidulina's String Quartet No. 3, tonight at 8 in Weill Recital Hall.
The concert is the first in a monthlong series called Fabulous Fridays.

LEAD: ''Bartok,'' said Zoltan Kocsis, who has specialized in his music and is currently performing his Third Piano Concerto with the New York Philharmonic, ''was very fond of French music, and he truly inherited something from Debussy.''

Brokers Play Down Surrogacy Case
LEAD: Prominent surrogate-mother brokers around the country said today that commercial surrogate contracts were legally risky but that the New Jersey Supreme Court's ruling banning the agreements did not extend to their clinics.


Concert: Muti Leads Philadelphians in Copland and Brahms
LEAD: AARON COPLAND began his Symphony No. 3 in 1944 when the outcome of World War II was still in doubt, and finished it two years later in a time of national euphoria.
Like other Copland works of the 1940's (''A Lincoln Portrait,'' for instance), it spoke in an optimistic, oratorical style that caught the upbeat mood of the times.


'Cop,' a Thriller
JAMES WOODS is more frequently seen eating on-camera than just about any other actor, but he's so edgy and thin that there's nothing voluptuous about this behavior.
If anything, it's borderline rude.
So are Mr.
Woods's smoking and his wisecracking; so is virtually everything else he does.
Combine this taunting manner with the fierce, obsessive dedication Mr.
Woods brings to almost any role and you have the makings of a perfect Elmore Leonard character, which Mr.
Woods is bound to play some day.
In the meantime, he has arrived as the detective hero of ''Cop,'' based on James Ellroy's crime novel ''Blood on the Moon.''
In ''Cop,'' which opens today at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters, Mr.
Woods plays the extremely hard-boiled Detective Sgt.
Lloyd Hopkins, who is led by the long arm of coincidence onto the trail of a mass murderer.
The character is a reasonable embodiment of certain detective-movie conventions, but the plot leaves a lot to be desired, especially since it devotes no more than 30 seconds' thought to the killer's motive or his history.


Defeat of Contra Aid: The 219-211 Roll-Call Vote in the House
LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 219 to 211 Wednesday night by which the House rejected President Reagan's request for at least $43 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.
A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the President's plan; a ''no'' vote was a vote against it.
Voting ''yes'' were 47 Democrats and 164 Republicans.


'Land Of Promise,' By Wajda
AT first glance, the mid-1970's seems like the least inventive phase in the career of Andrzej Wajda, the brilliant, prolific Polish director.
His trilogy from the 50's, ending with the masterly ''Ashes and Diamonds,'' assessed the emotional cost of World War II.
In 1976, he would tear down Stalinist icons in ''Man of Marble.'' But earlier in the decade, films such as ''A Wedding'' and ''Land of Promise,'' both set in the 19th century, seemed to signal, if not a retreat from the political wars, at least an escape from the pressure of recent events.
''Land of Promise,'' the 1975 film that will have its first commercial run in New York at Cinema Village today and tomorrow, offers only a visual rest from contemporary battle.
It has all the indirection you would expect of a defiant film maker whose work must pass Government censors and film boards (for years they rejected the idea for ''Man of Marble''), all the accomplishment of one adept at portraying the personal drama of history.


W. Marko Antich Investment Executive, 29
LEAD: W. Marko Antich, managing director of the Redwood Capital Group, a venture capital concern in Manhattan that specialized in the health care industry, died in a skiing accident Monday in Vail, Colo.
He was 29 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Metro Datelines; Accountant Is Slain In Midtown Building
LEAD: A 28-year-old accountant was found fatally stabbed in the throat in the hallway of his midtown office building yesterday, the police said.


VOW TO PRESS ON
LEAD: Nicaraguan rebel officials today bitterly criticized the House vote denying the contras further aid but vowed to continue fighting.

Corrections
LEAD: A front-page article yesterday about supermarket tabloids, and a picture caption with it, misstated circulation figures for some of the papers.
The Star, published by News America, reports a circulation of 3.7 million.
Globe Communications says its three publications - The Globe, The National Examiner and The Sun - have a combined circulation of 3.2 million.

Citicorp Singing
LEAD: Cast members from the Off Broadway show ''Mama, I Want to Sing!'' are to perform songs from the show today at 1 P.M. in the first of a series of free performances at the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue and 53d Street.
The series, called Mardi Gras at the Market, will run through Feb. 27 and feature jazz performances at various times throughout each day.


Weicker Will Seek a 4th Term in the Senate
LEAD: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announcing his candidacy for a fourth term yesterday in Farmington, Conn.
With him were his wife, Claudia, and other members of his family.
The liberal Republican, who is often at odds with his party's leadership, will probably face Joseph I. Lieberman, the state's Attorney General, who is expected to announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination later this month.


Sports People; Madlock to Japan
LEAD: Bill Madlock, a four-time National League batting champion with a .305 career average, will play this season in Japan for the Lotte Orions, The Associated Press has reported.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about Brent Owens, a film maker, misstated the release date for Spike Lee's film ''School Daze.'' It is to be released nationally on Feb. 12.


Profit Rises At Parent Of ABC
LEAD: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. reported yesterday that its net income rose 46 percent in the fourth quarter because of higher revenues from its broadcast group and reduced costs.
The company also said that the ABC Television Network had returned to profitability during 1987.

Market Place; Analysts Favor Tobacco Stocks
LEAD: PRODUCT liability lawsuits involving the effects of cigarette smoking have in recent years created a cloud over tobacco stocks.
But a number of Wall Street analysts believe that investor fears on this score are overblown.


Dumptruck at the Ritz
LEAD: A rock triple bill tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800), is to include Love Tractor, Dumptruck and Pianosaurus.
The music begins about 11 P.M.; tickets are $10 in advance, $12 tomorrow.

Japanese, Reacting to Allegations Of Illegal Fishing, Plan New Rules
LEAD: Japanese officials, reacting to allegations that their fishing fleet is involved in widespread ''pillaging'' in American waters in the Bering Sea, said today that they would seek new regulations to control the problem.

Senate, by 51-48 Vote, Backs Reagan Aid Request for the Contras
LEAD: The Senate, giving President Reagan a surprising but only symbolic victory, voted tonight to support his request to provide at least $43 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.


Gephardt Calls Simon Radio Ads In Iowa 'Negative Campaigning'
LEAD: In a tight Democratic Presidential contest where the candidates are searching for any advantage, the campaigns of Representative Richard A. Gephardt and Senator Paul Simon traded volleys today over whether Mr.
Simon was engaging in ''negative campaigning.''


Results Plus
LEAD:  Golf  Rizzo Ahead by a Shot: Patti Rizzo one-putted six holes yesterday on her way to a five-under-par 67 and the first-round lead in the Mazda Classic in Boca Raton, Fla., the opening tournament of the L.P.G.A. season.
Trish Johnson of England, playing in her first L.P.G.A. event, and Missie McGeorge were next at 68.


Inmates Assail Thai Prison Over AIDS Care
LEAD: Forty-eight Thai and foreign prisoners in an AIDS unit of a Bangkok prison have asked the country's leading human rights lawyer and a Thai-American anti-AIDS campaigner to help them get medical care and draw attention to jail conditions that they say could help spread the disease.

Leon Schwartz
LEAD: Leon Schwartz, an 84-year-old violinist, is to give two klezmer concerts today at the Richmondtown Restoration, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown, S.I.
Mr.
Schwartz, who was born in the Ukraine, has been playing klezmer music since the age of 12.
Shows are at 8 and 9:30 P.M.
Tickets are $6.
Information: (718) 351-1617.


Film: 'Julia and Julia,' With Kathleen Turner
LEAD: ''JULIA AND JULIA,'' opening today at the Embassy 3 and other theaters, is minor movie making, but it does prove two things: that Kathleen Turner has become the kind of star who can carry even third-rate fiction without losing her beautiful, voluptuous cool, and that high-definition tape (on which this was initially shot) can be transferred to film and look as good as anything shot on film to start with.

Hearts - and Minds - on Nicaragua
LEAD: By an eight-vote margin, the House has given a deserved rebuke to President Reagan's failed policy toward Central America.
The majority told Mr.
Reagan, in effect, that they and the people they represent believe he has been pursuing a war without end in Nicaragua, not peace.
Accordingly, the legislators disapproved the Administration's plan for renewed aid to the contras.


G.S.A., Citing Report, May Fight A.T.&amp;T. Bids
LEAD: The General Services Administration said today that, if the American Telephone and Telegraph Company received secret bid prices of its competitors for Federal Government telephone switch contracts, as said in a news report, it would seek to prevent the company from gaining the contracts.


3 Share Lead at 67 At Pebble Beach
LEAD: Jim Booros, who spent the last two years as the head pro at the municipal golf course in Allentown, Pa., decided that at 37 he would give the PGA Tour one more shot.
He had not been too successful in five years on the circuit - 1977 and 1981, as well as 1983-85.

L.I. Power Authority Upheld
LEAD: A state law that created the Long Island Power Authority is constitutional, Justice Eli Wager of State Supreme Court ruled today.
The decision clears the way for a takeover by the authority of the Long Island Lighting Company and the closing of the $5 billion Shoreham Nuclear Power Station.

Singer Offer Ends
LEAD: The company established by Paul A. Bilzerian to acquire the Singer Company said it had accepted more than 17 million shares in response to its tender offer of $50 a share, which expired Wednesday.
The Singer Acquisition Company said it now owned about 90 percent of the aerospace and military electronics company.


Accord Said to Be Near On the Sale of The Post
LEAD: Rupert Murdoch is close to a deal to sell The New York Post to Peter S. Kalikow, a New York real-estate entrepreneur, sources familiar with the negotiations said last night.


ADVERTISING;
LEAD: Ketchum Advertising, Pittsburgh, part of Ketchum Communications, has won the Cullinet computer software business-to-business account, beating out five other agencies.
The budget is $5 million.

Diner's Journal
LEAD: THE roadside diner, that stainless-steel citadel of all-American cuisine, is making a comeback in Manhattan.
Recent examples include the spiffy Broadway Diner (two locations, 1726 Broadway, at 55th Street, 765-0909, and 590 Lexington Avenue, at 52d Street, 486-8838), Ellen's Stardust Diner (1377 Avenue of the Americas, at 56th Street, 307-7575), and now, the month-old Horn &amp; Hardart Dine-o-Mat, at 942 Third Avenue, between 56th and 57th


NORIEGA ORDERED COLOMBIA SLAYING, PREDECESSOR SAYS
LEAD: As Panama's military leader, Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, awaits the formal announcement of his indictment on drug-trafficking charges in the United States, he and the military-dominated Government have been rocked by accusations made public here.


4 Die in Colombian Clash
LEAD: One policeman and three leftist guerrillas were killed today in a clash at a police station in this northwestern Colombian city.
A police spokesman said the clash occurred when the guerrillas, apparently from the pro-Cuban National Liberation Army, unsuccessfully tried to seize the station.

Sports People; One at a Time
LEAD: Butch van Breda Kolff ran up some impressive numbers in his career Wednesday night when his Lafayette College Leopards defeated Towson State, 73-60, at Easton, Pa.
For van Breda Kolff, 64, the victory was the 700th in 1,200 games that he has coached in high school, college, the National Basketball Association and the American Basketball Association during the last 33 years.


Robert Fitzsimmons, Actor, 73
LEAD: Robert Fitzsimmons, an actor and union leader, died of cardiac and pulmonary arrest on Jan. 31 at Mt.
Sinai Hospital.
He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Baby M Ruling Welcomed at Meeting of Surrogacy Experts
LEAD: Lawyers and others participating in a workshop on surrogate motherhood today praised the New Jersey Supreme Court decision that restored parental rights to the mother of Baby M and said they expected it to influence lawmakers around the country.

Struggle for Recovery Altering Rural America
LEAD: On the day in 1982 when Jack Briggs opened Macon County's economic development office, the local Dairy Queen announced it was shutting down.
That is just about the ultimate in despair for a dying small town in rural America.


Europe Research Plan
LEAD: The European Community said it was willing to spend 550 million European Currency Units, or about $670 million, to co-finance research projects in advanced telecommunications to help companies enter a world market estimated to be worth more than $600 billion.
The projects involve transmitting voice, data and images quickly and cheaply.


Mortgage Rates Down; Buyers Wary
LEAD: The recent steep decline in interest rates has pushed mortgage lending rates in most areas of the nation to their lowest levels in more than six months.
Yet consumers seem to be reacting cautiously to the decline.


Mets and Gooden Are Stalled
LEAD: With less than two weeks to go to arbitration, the Mets and Dwight Gooden were hardening their positions yesterday over the issue of the two months that the star pitcher lost in drug therapy last season.

Fire Hits Country Club in Upstate New York
LEAD: Firefighter hosing a fire early yesterday at the Lafayette Country Club in Onondaga.
Firefighters, hindered in responding to the fire by heavy snow and unplowed roads, fought the blaze for almost four hours before they were able to bring it under control.
The fire destroyed the main building of the club, one of the oldest golf clubs in the area.


Quotations of the Day
LEAD: ''People deserve better than this kind of low-down, nasty, mean politics.
What kind of a candidate would put out a statement attacking another candidate and his wife without reading it.'' - Senator Bob Dole.  [ A12:6. ]


Senators Told of Mistakes in Oil Spill
LEAD: The chairman of Ashland Oil Inc. conceded today that ''mistakes were made'' by company employees responsible for the tank that ruptured on Jan. 2, spilling nearly a million gallons of diesel fuel into the Monongahela River.


Manes Had Stake in Collection Agency, U.S. Says
LEAD: A new Federal indictment against a Queens lawyer and his son has charged that the late Donald R. Manes was a secret partner in a private agency ''corruptly'' set up to collect overdue parking fines for the city.

The U.N. Today
LEAD:  General Assembly


How Great Were the Injustices of Arabs to Jews; French-German Way
LEAD: To the Editor:


Expose Albany's Secret Spending
LEAD: New York State's Legislature has budgeted a generous $167 million for its own operations in 1988, but how the money is being spent remains known only to the Assembly and Senate majority leaders, Mel Miller and Warren Anderson.
Minority-party lawmakers, fed up with second-class treatment, justly complain.


Music Benefit For Troupe Of Veterans
LEAD: Several musical forms - jazz, choral singing, movie music and new music - by Dizzy Gillespie, Dave Brubeck, Anthony Davis, Philip Glass, Tania Leon and the Gregg Smith Singers will be presented in a benefit Sunday for the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company and the three-month-old Borden Avenue Shelter in Queens, the only shelter in New York specifically for homeless veterans.


Film: 'Lightness of Being,' From Novel by Kundera
LEAD: PHILIP KAUFMAN'S ''Unbearable Lightness of Being'' begins with much promise, as if it were a ribald fairy tale. ''In Prague in 1968,'' says a title card, ''there lived a young doctor named Tomas.'' Tomas (Daniel Day-Lewis) comes out of the operating room and goes straight to a pretty nurse waiting in the supply room.

Japan Posts A Trade Deficit
LEAD: Japan posted a trade deficit for the first 20 days in January, but Government officials and economists said today that the unusual shortfall probably did not indicate a trend.


Breland Fights to Rebuild Reputation
LEAD: From the start of his pro career, Mark Breland has been a special case.


'Die Winterreise'
LEAD: Marian Thompson, a soprano, will sing Schubert's ''Winterreise'' on Sunday at 8 P.M. in Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street).
Alexander Valery Ryvkin will be the pianist.
Tickets are $10, or $5 for students and the elderly.
Information: 362-8719.


Luge Racer Must Obtain A Passport
LEAD: Raymond Ocampo's attempt to retain his Olympic accreditation and represent the Philippines hinges on his ability to get a Philippine passport before the Games begin, a week from Saturday.


Newark Man Fatally Stabs A Woman in a Bus Terminal
LEAD: A 21-year-old woman died today after a man, apparently unprovoked, stabbed her in the back with a 12-inch butcher knife in a Penn Station waiting room, the N.J.
Transit police said.
Thomas J. Rouse, 33 years old, of Newark, was charged with homicide and criminal possession of a weapon, said Kevin Moran, a transit officer.


U.N. Aide to Go to Mideast
LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is sending a special envoy to Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria to seek ways of achieving peace in the Middle East, a spokesman said today.
The envoy, Under Secretary General Marrack Goulding, will also meet with Palestine Liberation Organization officials, probably in Tunis, said the spokesman, Francois Giuliani.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 417 money market mutual funds increased $326.1 million, to $275.24 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $426.5 million, to $80.68 billion.
Assets of the 207 general purpose funds were down $177.3 million, to $81.06 billion.


IN SEARCH OF TOOTS SHOR: MANTLE'S BACK
LEAD: The dreams of banishment he had every night, when he would wake up startled and sweating, are gone now.


A City in Misery, Betrayed by a Taste for Clams
LEAD: Lu Guiying, a portly woman in a white apron and cap, stood glumly outside her restaurant, her arms folded across her chest.


Art: 'Committed to Print,' on Political Themes
LEAD: WITH its new exhibition, ''Committed to Print,'' the Museum of Modern Art, defender of a relatively pure modernist faith, treads cautiously but deliberately where it doesn't often go: into the terrain where art and overt political sentiment mingle and sometimes fuse.
The title invites two readings, and Deborah Wye, the organizer of the exhibition, makes good on both of them.


Brooklyn Arts Council Holding Film Festival
LEAD: The actor and director Danny DeVito once had a film shown there.
So did Ira Wohl, who made ''Best Boy,'' winner of the 1980 Academy Award for best feature-length documentary.

LEAD: Reacting to suggestions from various commissions that have examined the October stock market collapse, directors of the Chicago Board of Trade have voted to raise the minimum margins, or down payments, on purchases of the Major Market Index futures contract.

3 Masters Have a Kick Left
LEAD: In their prime, they were the best.
Peter Snell of New Zealand won three Olympic gold medals and set world outdoor records for the mile of 3 minutes 54.4 seconds in 1962 and 3:54.1 in 1964.
Jim Ryun, still a teen-ager, lowered the world record to 3:51.3 in 1966 and 3:51.1 in 1967.
Frank Shorter's fastest mile was only 4:02.6, but he won Olympic medals in 1972 (gold) and 1976 (silver) in the marathon.


College Basketball; No. 1 Arizona Is Upset by Stanford, 82-74
LEAD: Todd Lichti scored 23 points and Howard Wright 22 as Stanford scored the final 10 points of the game tonight to upset No. 1-ranked Arizona, 82-74, ending the Wildcats' eight-game winning streak.

LEAD: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said it had formed a joint venture with the New Century Entertainment Corporation to finance and distribute 25 to 30 New Century films in the next five years.

AIDS Virus, for First Time, Is Proved to Infect Colon Cells Directly
LEAD: The AIDS virus can directly infect cells of the colon and rectum, a group of scientists reports, a finding that may answer questions about the transmission of AIDS and about why many of its victims have chronic unexplained diarrhea.

New Bausch Shield
LEAD: Bausch &amp; Lomb Inc., based in Rochester, said marketing of the first collagen corneal shield, which would deliver medication to the eye without blocking vision, would begin immediately, after approval last week by the Federal Food and Drug Administration.
The lens has a potential yearly market value of $50 million for the company once improvements in the shield are cleared by the F.D.A., said Frank Jepson, a corporate vice president at Bausch &amp; Lomb.


Sports People; Molitor Honored
LEAD: Paul Molitor, whose 39-game hitting streak during the 1987 season was the fourth longest in American League history, has been named the winner of baseball's Hutch Award by a panel of broadcasters and writers covering the major leagues.


Malfunction of Rocket Stalls Anti-Missile Test
LEAD: A major test of President Reagan's proposed anti-missle system was delayed today after a Delta rocket meant to launch a three-ton military satellite developed a problem with a fuel tank.

At the Movies
LEAD:  Lighting a 'Bonfire'


First Boston Official Quits
LEAD: The First Boston Corporation suffered another high-level defection yesterday with the announcement that Yves-Andre Istel, co-head of its international operations, had resigned to join a new firm being formed by other former senior First Boston executives.


Orange Juice Falls by Limit; Grain and Soybeans Gain
LEAD: Orange juice futures prices retreated as far as they could go yesterday as fears of a Florida freeze melted away.

Gannett Profit Increases 20%
LEAD: The Gannett Company, the newspaper and broadcast concern, said yesterday that its profits grew 20 percent in the final quarter of 1987 on the strength of its local newspapers and USA Today, its national newspaper.
Gannett, based in Arlington, Va., outside Washington, reported fourth-quarter earnings of $106.6 million, or 66 cents a share, up from $88.8 million, or 55 cents a share, in the corresponding period in 1986.


F.B.I. Had File on Knopf
LEAD: Two agencies of the United States Government, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, maintained dossiers on Alfred A. Knopf, one of the country's most distinguished publishers, according to a book being published this spring.

Rapid Rate Drop Seen Slowing
LEAD: Interest rates are still far lower than a month ago, but as the Treasury concluded three consecutive days of note and bond auctions totaling $27 billion yesterday, there were signs that the rapid decline in rates had leveled off.


Dole Confronts Bush in Senate; Voices Anger at Criticism of Wife
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole confronted Vice President Bush on the Senate floor twice today to denounce him for campaign statements that the Senator said were unfair to him and his wife.


Rose Bird a Commentator
LEAD: Rose Bird, who was ousted by the voters as California's Chief Justice, will become a commentator for television stations KABC in Los Angeles and KGO in San Francisco, which are owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc.
Ms.
Bird will begin work within the next few days, a spokesman for KABC said.

LEAD: A coalition of Jewish groups declared yesterday that concern among American Jews over the violent clashes in Israeli-occupied territories had not diminished the Jewish community's ''prime concern'' for Israel's security.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  AN ORTON BLACK COMEDY


Washington Lobbyists Find Skies Over Iowa Are Friendly
LEAD: Representative Richard A. Gephardt has campaigned for President on a populist theme, but when he flew a planeload of supporters to Iowa last week he took along the most inside of Washington insiders: about a dozen registered lobbyists.


Restaurants
LEAD: AFTER four visits to Aquavit, the dramatic new Scandinavian restaurant in the former John D. Rockefeller town house on West 54th Street, I'm still hard-pressed to define this northern cuisine.
Indeed, some of the ingredients are exotic - cloudberries, bleak roe, snow grouse - but the style of cooking, at least in this urbane establishment, is unmistakably French.


Mideast Tightrope: Clashes Stirring Call for Talks
LEAD: In reviving some old ideas about Middle East peace and giving them new twists, the Reagan Administration is counting on a change in atmosphere, created by the recent clashes between Palestinians and Israelis, to remove the old obstacles to negotiations on the future of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.


Net Soars At Warner
LEAD: With record results in its films, records and cable television divisions, Warner Communications Inc. reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 48.4 percent.


Corrections
LEAD: A table in Business Day on Jan. 22, showing uncovered short sales for the New York Stock Exchange for the month ended Jan. 15, carried incorrect figures supplied by the Orion Pictures Corporation for its stock.
As a result, the total Big Board short interest and the decline for the month were also incorrect.


Chrysler Profit Up, but Less Than Expected
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation reported today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 8 percent, but the results were below the forecasts of many analysts.


Bridge: Series of Conditions Makes 4-3 Trump Fit Appropriate
LEAD: Standard bidding methods often have trouble finding the right game contract when a 4-3 trump fit is appropriate.

Martha Love McCagg Snow Architect, 83
LEAD: Martha Love McCagg Snow, an architect, died of colon and stomach cancer Wednesday at her daughter's home in Edison, N.J.
She was 83 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

How Great Were the Injustices of Arabs to Jews; 'Pacification' of Gaza
LEAD: To the Editor:


450 LTV Layoffs
LEAD: LTV Aircraft Products Group said it would lay off about 450 Dallas-area workers in the next two months and would slash its work force by 1,000 by the end of the year.
The company said it was cutting back because of lower spending planned by the Defense Department.
LTV Aircraft, a subsidiary of the LTV Corporation, said the layoffs would reduce the work force to about 10,000.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Amax, Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a minerals and energy concern, elected Stephen C. Knup senior vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Martin V. Alonzo, who resigned last year.


A Poem for Seven Judges
LEAD: Most of the important news stories journalists deal with are sad or dreary.
People are killed, hijacked, swindled.
Nations go to war, or spend their energies and fortunes preparing for it.
Earthquakes, explosions, plagues.
Everybody is always saying something nasty about somebody else.
That's the way things are in the world - or that is how it comes out by the time we are finished slicing it up into words or pictures.


Sports People; Manager Charged
LEAD: Manager Cal Ripken of the Baltimore Orioles, was charged with drunken driving after he was pulled over for speeding, the Baltimore County police said yesterday.


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said it had repurchased 27.4 million shares last year for $1.1 billion.

A Capitalist Innovator in Vietnam
LEAD: Le Cong Thanh's flashlight factory is not much of an industrial complex by most people's standards.

ARCO-Tricentrol
LEAD: ARCO said it had acquired a controlling interest in Tricentrol P.L.C. today, a day after the small British oil company agreed to a deal valued at about $330 million.
ARCO, which had held a 14.8 percent stake in Tricentrol, announced it had made additional stock purchases in the last two days that increased its interest to 54.5 percent.

Sports People; Irons Out
LEAD: The United States Golf Association's executive committee reaffirmed its position that, starting in 1990, it will not permit use of the Ping Eye 2 irons in its competitions.
The U.S.G.A. has declared that club illegal for general use starting in 1996, saying that the square grooves in the club are not set far enough apart.

Talks on Lear Bid
LEAD: Executives of the Lear Petroleum Corporation and the United States arm of the British Petroleum Company met to discuss BP America's $250 million bid for the Texas natural gas concern.
Oil industry analysts said such an acquisition would serve both companies well.
Lear has not made money in two years, and needs a strong backer like BP America, which does not own any gas pipelines.

Questions on Waldheim and Reprisal
LEAD: Kurt Waldheim knew of and criticized Nazi reprisal killings of civilians in Greece in 1944, according to a newly discovered German army dispatch found by an American historian.


West Coast Jazz Stars To Play
LEAD: NEW YORKERS tend to get smug about the city's status as the world's jazz capital.
This weekend, however, two of the best jazz groups in town can testify to the existence of jazz life in Los Angeles, the home of both John Carter, the clarinetist leading a quartet at Carlos 1, and Harold Land, the tenor saxophonist who's featured with the Timeless All-Stars at Sweet Basil.


Federated, Fighting Bidder, Is Said to Consider Buyout
LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc. is weighing a management-led leveraged buyout to fend off a hostile takeover threat from the Campeau Corporation, banking experts familiar with the deal said yesterday.


Inconvenience Foods
LEAD: A friend who makes lists has begun yet another, of self-defeating ''convenience'' packaging.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Missing Ingredient
LEAD: The Democratic candidates for the Presidential nomination have been accused of lacking ideas, vision, charisma and experience.
But Governor Cuomo of New York thinks that is not their real problem.


Drug-Free Games Expected
LEAD: The chief medical officer of the Calgary Olympics said today that he did not expect any athletes competing in the Games, which start next Saturday, to test positively for a substance banned by the International Olympic Committee.

First Nationwide
LEAD: The First Nationwide Bank, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, said it had completed the acquisition of Uptown Federal Savings of Chicago for an undisclosed amount.
Uptown Federal, which has deposits of about $1.5 billion and $2 billion in assets, operates 22 retail branches in Chicago and its northern suburbs, the company said.

Pall Picks Greenstone
LEAD: The Pall Corporation, a manufacturer of industrial and medical filters based in Glen Cove, L.I., has named Greenstone &amp; Rabasca Advertising, of Melville, L.I., to handle advertising for seven of its divisions.
The budget exceeds $1 million.
Jarman, Spitzer &amp; Felix is the former agency.


Art: 31 Late Drawings By Picasso in a Show
LEAD: IT has always been accepted wisdom that late Picasso was lesser Picasso.
During the decade or so before the artist's death in 1973 at the age of 92, Picasso's untiring energy was often spent on drawing images of splay-legged women.
This was greeted by the artist's many followers with considerable, if reasonable, unease, especially coming as it did during the 1960's and early 70's when the women's liberation movement was beginning to gain steam.

First Executive
LEAD: The First Executive Corporation said two of its shareholders had filed a lawsuit seeking to block the completion of a tender offer from the ICH Corporation and to overturn a standstill agreement.
ICH, a Louisville, Ky., insurance holding company, began a $134.4 million tender offer last month for 11.2 million shares of First Executive at $12 a share.

LEAD: In a move to restore investor confidence in the stock market, the board of the New York Stock Exchange voted unanimously yesterday to restrict a form of computerized stock trading that had been blamed for accelerating the market's chaotic plunge in October.


Heinz Acquisition
LEAD: The H. J. Heinz Company said it had agreed to acquire Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc. of San Diego.
The price was not disclosed.
Bumble Bee, which was acquired in a leveraged buyout from Castle &amp; Cooke Inc. in 1985, produces tuna, salmon and oysters and Figaro cat foods. ''The acquisition of Bumble Bee will bring into Heinz operations another brand of well-respected, high-quality food products,'' said Anthony J.

The Law; At the Bar
LEAD: At the beginning of Tom Wolfe's ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' there is the disclaimer, so beloved of lawyers, that all of the characters are imaginary.
But that is only partly true.
The prosecutors and policemen and defense lawyers who populate the book may technically be fictional, but they are also the people Edward


Roll-Call Vote In the Senate
LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 51 to 48 by which the Senate tonight approved $43 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.
The vote was largely symbolic because the House defeated the measure Wednesday.
FOR REAGAN PLAN - 51  Democrats - 12  Bentsen, Tex.

LaRouche, on TV, Cites AIDS
LEAD: Lyndon LaRouche, the political extremist running for President as a Democrat, said on network television tonight that the AIDS virus was transmitted much like any other virus, including through casual contact, and that most medical warnings about how it is spread are ''an outright lie.'' Mr.
LaRouche spoke on a 30-minute taped program televised nationally on CBS, from which his campaign bought air time.

Rock: Sting At Garden
LEAD: HANS EISLER, a composer who worked with Bertolt Brecht, might well have been amused to hear one of his melodies sung at Madison Square Garden with teen-age girls shrieking at the end of each chromatic phrase.
But that was only one of the unlikely treats at Wednesday's concert by Sting, who somehow balances musicianly experiments and melancholy, high-minded songs with the charisma and showmanship of a pop star.

South Africa Opens a New Session of Parliament
LEAD: President P. W. Botha and his wife, Elize, listening to the national anthem during the opening of Parliament yesterday in Cape Town.
Mr.
Botha recommitted his Government to the removal of rules and regulations, often related to the maintenance of apartheid, that obstruct the development of the informal economic sector.


PHILHARMONIC: DUTOIT CONDUCTS RACHMANINOFF
LEAD: In 1940, when Rachmaninoff completed his last work, ''Symphonic Dances,'' the tides of history were running powerfully away from his heart-on-sleeve kind of music.
For years, the score's only committed friend seemed to be Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra, to whom it was dedicated.
But tides, being tides, inevitably turn.


Isaac L. Asofsky, HIAS Director, 98
LEAD: Isaac L. Asofsky, retired director of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, died at his home in Manhattan Jan. 18 after a short illness.
He was 98 years old.


Cuomo Reports A Spending Rise Of $258 Million
LEAD: Governor Cuomo announced today that state spending in the current fiscal year would be $258.5 million higher than he had originally projected.
That means total spending for will be 7.9 percent more than in the previous year, exceeding the 7 percent limit on growth the Governor had set.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''In plain language, what he did was he utilized his position to sell the country of Panama to drug traffickers.'' - Leon B. Kellner, a Federal prosecutor, speaking of Gen.


No Room for Difference in East Germany
LEAD: At a mid-January march commemorating Rosa Luxemburg, the German Communist murdered in 1919, East German police arrested 120 activists.
Protesters carried banners quoting her appeal from the Kaiser's prison: ''Freedom is real only when there is freedom for those who think differently.'' Blasphemy, one official called it.


Arrest in Ghana Leads To Fight Over L.I. Home
LEAD: Efua Cabiri last saw her husband in July 1986, when she waved goodbye to him at Kennedy International Airport.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Art Schlichter, the quarterback who is Ohio State's career leader in total offense, has been denied re-entry into the N.F.L. because of his gambling history.
He plans to try out next summer with the Ottawa Rough Riders of the Canadian Football League. . . .
Jack Evans of the Hartford Whalers, at 59 the oldest head coach in the National Hockey League, said he would retire when his contract expires at the end of the 1988-89 season, according to a report published yesterday in The Hartford Courant.


In Wrong Place With a Gun
LEAD: A man with a gun was hustled away from a restaurant today as Gary Hart, a Democratic Presidential candidate, arrived to have breakfast, but the Secret Service said it was a case of ''being in the wrong place at the wrong time.'' LEAD: San Pedro Bay, off Los Angeles and Long Beach, Calif., will be the site of the America's Cup defense in September, Sail America and the San Diego Yacht Club announced today.

Rapid Rise of Fast Photo Processing
LEAD: Fran Rosenthal-Myer burst into the 1 Hour Foto Lab in Times Square in Manhattan one day recently and plopped down a roll of film. ''When I need it fast, I come here,'' she said.
A few hours later, she returned to pick up pictures she wanted to have before leaving town the next morning.


Bank of New York
LEAD: The Bank of New York filed suit in New York State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to enjoin the Irving Bank Corporation from issuing new convertible preferred stock to investors friendly to Irving's current management, the Bank of New York reported.
Despite the objections of Irving's management, the Bank of New York has been trying to acquire Irving.

UNEMPLOYMENT IN THE U.S.
LEAD: Unemployment remained unchanged at 5.7 percent in January, the Government announced yesterday.
Jobs grew more slowly than some economists had expected, but others were heartened that growth continued and appeared to be concentrated in export-oriented industries.

LEAD: Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military ruler of Panama, in effect sold his government to drug traffickers for millions of dollars in bribes and turned Panama into a capital of international cocaine smuggling, the Justice Department charged in two indictments made public today.

LEAD: No disciplinary action will be taken against teachers, counselors and other school worker for failing to report signs that 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg was being abused, the superintendent of Community School District 2 said yesterday.

Mullin Impressive
LEAD: In what his coach, George Karl, called ''the best game he's played since he's been back,'' Chris Mullin scored 18 of his 22 points after halftime Thursday night and sank two free throws in overtime to break a tie.

Perestoika in New York Schools, Please
LEAD: The more I learn about the New York City Board of Education's amazing contract with its school custodians, the more I appreciate what Mikhail S. Gorbachev is up against.
The hero of perestroika - restructuring - would surely find something familiar in an arrangement that rewards sloth and irresponsibility and discourages initiative.

ADRIAN WILSON, 64, A PRINTING TEACHER AND BOOK DESIGNER
LEAD: Adrian Wilson, a book designer and scholar who was considered one of America's leading fine printers, died Wednesday of congestive heart failure at the Pacific Presbyterian Hospital in San Francisco.
He was 64 years old.

50 Years After His Execution, Soviet Panel Clears Bukharin
LEAD: A Communist Party commission reviewing the purge trials of the 1930's announced today that Nikolai I. Bukharin, among the most prominent victims of Stalin's terror, was wrongly convicted and executed.


German Backs Dollar Level
LEAD: In the clearest sign of the intentions of the major industrial countries for the recently tumbling dollar, West Germany's Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, said today that the current exchange rate was acceptable.


Goldman, Sachs Ends Program Trading for Itself
LEAD: One day after the New York Stock Exchange announced new restrictions on program trading, Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company said yesterday that it would no longer use the strategy to manage its own capital.
However, the institutional firm will continue to execute such trades for its customers.


Northwestern Steel Accord Set
LEAD: The Northwestern Steel and Wire Company said that it had tentatively agreed to be bought by a management group led by its president and chief executive officer, Robert Wilthew, and other employees and investors.
The payment would consist of $18 a share in cash and 13 percent subordinated notes due in 1997 with a $4.50 principal amount.

LEAD: Kenneth Lee Porter, one of the last surviving American air aces of World War I, died Wednesday at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens.
He was 91 years old.

Hitachi to Expand
LEAD: Hitachi Ltd. said it would expand its semiconductor subsidiary here into a full-time production unit, which may employ 100 more workers.
Hitachi Semiconductor America, which now employs 200 in an operation that handles computer chips imported from Japan, had suspended construction on its manufacturing plant here in October 1986 because of a slump in the semiconductor industry.


Correction
LEAD: Because of a computer error, the film review of ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' in Weekend yesterday included a phrase erroneously in the second paragraph.
The passage should have read: '' 'Take off your clothes,' says Tomas.
After three seconds of playing hard-to-get, the nurse does.
On the other side of a frosted-glass window several other hospital employees watch Tomas's technique with admiration.


2 Arrested in Hotel Stabbing
LEAD: The police arrested two teen-agers yesterday in the stabbing of a 14-year-old boy during a drug-related robbery in a welfare hotel in midtown Manhattan.
Another youth was being sought.
The incident occurred Wednesday at the Bryant Hotel on Broadway at 54th Street.
Sgt.
John Venetucci of the police said the three youths stabbed the victim and stole $1,000.

DRUG COURT CUTS NEW YORK BACKLOG
LEAD: A drug court has been strikingly successful in cutting a backlog of cases that almost overwhelmed judges and prosecutors in Manhattan last year when crack-related arrests soared, officials say.


MUSIC: STUART DEMPSTER
LEAD: For a moment on Wednesday, dreaded seriousness took the floor at the Alternative Museum.
Stuart Dempster, the trombonist, wandered out from off stage, playing his plastic didjeridu -a long tube, derived from the Australian aboriginal wooden instrument of the same name, which, when blown into, makes buzzing sounds.


A Lawyer's Fast Track to Destruction on Wall Street
LEAD: Six days before he was to be sentenced last month for his role in an insider trading scandal, David W. C. Clark collapsed at his mother's home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
Within an hour, he was dead, a victim of chronic alcoholism.


Renee Pollack, Health Aide,53
LEAD: Renee Pollack, executive director of Westchester Jewish Community Services, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Thursday in White Plains Hospital Medical Center.
She was 53 years old and lived in Hartsdale, N.Y.


POLYGAMIST CLAN LEADER CHARGED IN BOMBING
LEAD: Addam Swapp being escorted from Federal Court in Prove, Utah, after he pleaded not guilty at arragnment on charges stemming from the bombing of a Mormon chapel.
Mr.
Swapp had been released earlier in the day from a hospital.
He is recuperating from wounds received in a shoot-out that followed 13-day standoff with authorities.


How Did the F.B.I. Go Astray?
LEAD: Aggressive F.B.I. surveillance of the Government's foreign policy critics supposedly ended with the regime of J. Edgar Hoover.
News that such activity apparently continued under F.B.I.
Director William Webster does not yet warrant alarms about political police, but neither can the bureau be exonerated on the basis of what's been revealed so far.


Florida Votes to Limit Medical Malpractice Costs
LEAD: The Florida Legislature has approved a bill calling for major changes in medical malpractice laws, including a limit on the amount of money that may be awarded in malpractice lawsuits.

ANSWERS TO QUIZ
LEAD: Questions appear on page 13.


Nashville Musicians Defy Order to Cancel Season
LEAD: Musicians of the Nashville Symphony, defying a board decision to shut down the 85-member orchestra, vowed to appear as scheduled at the Tennessee Performing Arts Center tonight, even though orchestra officials designated last night's concert as the orchestra's final performance.


2 Europeans Seized in Lebanon
LEAD: Two Scandinavians working for the United Nations were reported kidnapped in southern Lebanon today.
No group claimed responsibility, but the police here said the kidnappers were Palestinian guerrillas loyal to Abu Nidal.


4th-Quarter Charge Widens Amax Loss
LEAD: Amax Inc., the large natural resources company, announced yesterday that it had taken a fourth-quarter charge of $385.6 million to cover the costs of diminishing its molybdenum business.
Largely because of that charge, the company reported a net loss of $280.8 million, compared with a net loss of $49.7 million in the fourth quarter of 1986.


Reagan's Cruel Abortion Politics
LEAD: Millions of Americans and third world women literally are hostages trapped in the Reagan Administration's cruel global war on abortion, taken prisoner primarily because they are poor and disadvantaged.
Unless Congress or the courts intervene, these women will lose their right to effective family planning, the best protection they can get against unwanted pregnancy and, ironically, against abortion itself.

13.09 Drop Sends Dow To 1,910.48
LEAD: Stock prices remained listless most of yesterday before late selling pushed the the Dow Jones industrial average down 13.09 points to close at 1,910.48.
Over all, the market ended mixed.

Simon Campaign Says Gephardt Exceeds Spending Limits in Iowa
LEAD: Stepping up the level of confrontation in the final days of the Iowa caucuses, Senator Paul Simon's campaign manager today called on Representative Richard A. Gephardt to suspend television advertising here until his campaign had filed a report on his finances with the Federal Election Commission.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd., Melbourne, Australia, has agreed not to increase its stake in Bell Resources Ltd. beyond its existing 5 percent for at least two years, according to its capital restructuring plan.


The Public's Indifference To On-Time Flight Data
LEAD: Despite the Federal Government's efforts in recent months to inform the public of the major airlines' on-time performance, travel agents and others in the travel industry say the data are having little impact among ticket buyers.


Ruling on Texaco
LEAD: United States District Court Judge Charles L. Brieant is expected to rule early next week on whether Texaco Inc. may continue mailing its bankruptcy reorganization plan to shareholders.
Judge Brieant heard arguments from shareholders opposed to the plan but has made no decision on their request to halt the mailing, which began on Wednesday.


Correction
LEAD: A picture caption on Jan. 11 about the participation of Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis in a forum at Miami Shores, Fla., misidentified the sponsor.
It was the Forum of North Dade, a nonpolitical organization, not the Democratic Party.


Congressional Pork, White House Pork
LEAD: President Reagan mocked Congress recently for tucking dozens of frivolous expenditures into the catch-all 1988 budget bills.
Shortly he will send back all the items that he says he would cross out if he had a line-item veto, and ask that they be canceled.
That, he suggests, will test whether Congress really thinks the Government should subsidize such things as cranberry, crawfish and wildflower research.


Federated Rejects Bid By Campeau
LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that its board had unanimously rejected the $47-a-share cash tender offer by the Campeau Corporation.
Federated also challenged Campeau to prove that it had the financing for the $61-a-share merger offer it had announced Wednesday.


Help on Children's Books
LEAD: Adults who want to select the best in children's books may refer to ''Children's Books 1987: 100 Books for Reading and Sharing,'' a list available at branches of the New York Public Library.
The guide, published annually since 1911 by the library's Office of Children's Services, costs $2 and cites books that are recommended by children's libraries.


Correction
LEAD: An article yesterday about redistricting of seats in the House misidentified the Representative from the 11th District in New York.
He is Edolphus Towns, Democrat of Brooklyn, not Major R. Owens.


Dog Show Preparations
LEAD: Wendell Sammett grooming Rage, a standard poodle, at Madison Square Garden.
The dogs are there for the annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show that opens Monday.
A total of 2,649 dogs of 140 breeds and varieties are entered in the show, which is the 122d consecutive running of the event. (The New York Times/Edward


U.S. Agent and Suspects Slain
LEAD: A Federal drug agent and two gunmen were shot to death today during an undercover drug operation, the authorities said.
Two other Federal agents and a third gunman were wounded.

LEAD: Consumer debt rose by $4.5 billion in December, the biggest monthly gain in three months, the Federal Reserve said yesterday.

President Signs Housing Bill
LEAD: President Reagan today signed the first major housing legislation passed in his Administration, saying it ''will efficiently and effectively meet the challenge of America's changing housing needs.'' The $30.6 billion measure is the first substantial housing legislation since 1980.
It includes $15 billion for housing and community development in the fiscal year beginning Oct.


Senate Group Says Canada Is Jeopardizing Trade Pact
LEAD: The Senate Finance Committee's leaders on trade issues warned the Reagan Administration today that approval of a free trade agreement with Canada was imperiled by Ottawa's proposals to help its domestic apparel and dairy producers withstand American competition.


Panel Backs Curbs on Surrogate Motherhood
LEAD: After a second day of heated discussion, a panel of specialists concluded today that payment to surrogate mothers for bearing a child should be prohibited when it involves a loss of parental rights.


Foreman Wins Again
LEAD: George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, tonight scored his seventh consecutive victory since returning to the ring last March, stopping a bloodied Guido Trane in the fifth round of their scheduled 10-round bout.

Jackson Cooperative
LEAD: The Bo Jackson saga, baseball division, continues.
In view of Jackson's batting collapse in the second half of last season that cost him his starting assignment in left field, his career in the major leagues is now viewed as uncertain by the Kansas City Royals, who plan to open with Gary Thurman in left field.


Kenyan Disbands Parliament And Frees 9 Before Elections
LEAD: President Daniel arap Moi dissolved Parliament today to prepare for general elections March 21, and released nine political prisoners who had been held without trial.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing  Fletcher and Brown Triumph: Pam Fletcher won her second race in two days, and Mike Brown got a measure of revenge for being left off the Olympic team in super giant slalom races yesterday at the United States Alpine championships in Crested Butte, Colo.
Fletcher flashed to victory in the women's race by more than a full second.

LEAD: At tomorrow's Pro Bowl game in Honolulu, Walter Payton will be honored on the occasion of his retirement as the National Football League's career rushing leader.
But while talking to reporters yesterday, his retirement after 13 seasons as a runner for the Chicago Bears didn't sound as definite as it had a few weeks ago.

Horn &amp; Hardart In King's Table Bid
LEAD: The Horn &amp; Hardart Company, based in Las Vegas, Nev., said that it had agreed to acquire International King's Table Inc., which operates King's Table Buffet restaurants in California, Oregon, Washington and other Western states.
Horn &amp; Hardart, which already owns 19.9 percent of King's Table, will make a cash offer to purchase a minimum of 31.1 percent and up to all common shares oustanding for $20.25 in cash, or a total indicated price of $58.7 million.


Dollar Moves Up Strongly, But Price of Gold Slumps
LEAD: The dollar rebounded sharply against leading currencies in active domestic trading yesterday.


West to Resume Farm Aid to Ethiopia
LEAD: The World Bank and several Western nations will resume agricultural development aid to Ethiopia, which has agreed to create new incentives for food production to combat a famine, United Nations officials and diplomats say.

LEAD: About 2,000 residents, law-enforcement officials and politicians gathered this evening to rally against the possible parole of a man convicted of killing two police officers in 1963.
About 30 police cars from municipalities throughout Essex and Bergen Counties lined the street in front of the municipal complex.


Casting Is Completed For the Musical 'Chess'
LEAD: Casting was completed yesterday for ''Chess,'' the Tim Rice-Bjorn Ulvaeus-Benny Andersson musical that is scheduled to begin rehearsals Monday.
The principals are David Carroll and Philip Casnoff as Soviet and American chess masters and Judy Kuhn as the woman in love first with the Russian and then with the American.


Mortgages Dip Below 10%
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages have fallen below 10 percent for the first time since last April, according to a nationwide survey.


Edward S. Tauber, 79, Psychiatrist and Writer
LEAD: Dr.
Edward S. Tauber, a psychiatrist and author, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital Medical Center from complications of a stroke he suffered two weeks ago.
He was 79 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.


Tops in Losses
LEAD: Among National Basketball Association coaches, Gene Shue stands fourth in career victories with 767, only 171 behind the 938 of the leader, Red Auerbach.
But in defeats, Shue heads the list.
And on Thursday night in Los Angeles he became the first N.B.A. coach to lose 800 games when his Clippers fell to the Lakers, 117-86.

So you take eight Northwestern University graduates, all drama majors, and you plop them down in New York, give them a few years knocking around looking for a break, pour a few beers down them one night in 1986, and inevitably one says, ''Say, why don't we put on our own show!

Correction
LEAD: Because of editing errors, articles from Washington on Jan. 30 and 31 about the Iraqi oil pipeline project, and an article on Feb. 2 that incorporated the error, misidentified a law against bribery of foreign officials by American companies.
The law is the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, not the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.


Correction
LEAD: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about Grecian music gave an incorrect date for a performance by Microcosmos.
The group will play at 8 P.M. tonight, not tomorrow, at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street.


FOR SOVIET OFFICIAL, GOOD WILL AND FLU
LEAD: When Vasily G. Zakharov, the Soviet Union's Minister of Culture, left New York for Moscow early yesterday morning, he took along the memory of a flood of good-will speeches, a few rocky moments with Congressmen who challenged the Soviet record on human rights and a severe case of the flu.

NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1988
LEAD:  International 2-5  Panama's strongman was indicted.
Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega sold his position to drug traffickers for millions of dollars in bribes and turned Panama into a capital of international cocaine smuggling, the indictments say.
Page 1  News analysis: The indictment holds little promise of leading to the arrest of General Noriega, and it complicates efforts by the Reagan Administration to ease the Panamanian leader from power.


CONCERT: THE CLEVELAND AT CARNEGIE HALL
LEAD: The clarinet explains Mozart as well as any other instrument.
It was a relatively new and unused device in his time, but the quintet, trio and concerto he wrote for it form the base on which the clarinet literature has rested ever since.
Mozart must have been attracted by its sour sweetness, soft yet with an aftertaste of tartness.


Shift of Titles Atop Ogilvy
LEAD: William E. Phillips, the 58-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Group, said yesterday that he would relinquish his titles to Kenneth Roman, 57, the chairman of Ogilvy's largest operating company, Ogilvy &amp; Mather Worldwide, at the firm's annual shareholder meeting on May 17.


Baby M Surrogate Settles Fraud Suit
LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead Gould and her former husband, Richard, have agreed to a settlement of their Federal fraud and negligence suit against the Infertility Center of New York, which arranged the February 1985 surrogate-mother contract that the New Jersey Supreme Court invalidated Wednesday.


Ugandans to Ration Fuel
LEAD: Uganda is beginning fuel rationing after years of periodic fuel crises.
The Energy Ministry this week ordered all vehicle owners, including those with tractors and motorboats, to register at their nearest filling stations within 10 days.

Emeric Pressburger Is Dead at 85; The Screenwriter for 'Red Shoes'
LEAD: Emeric Pressburger, a British screenwriter whose widely acclaimed films made in collaboration with the director Michael Powell included ''The Red Shoes'' and ''Tales of Hoffmann,'' died yesterday of bronchial pneumonia at a nursing home in Saxstead, England.
He was 85 years old.


American City Journals' Shift
LEAD: American City Business Journals announced today that it was no longer for sale but would shed several unprofitable weeklies to shore up its ailing financial position.


Amending Lemon Laws
LEAD: Lemon laws, enacted by 43 states since 1982 to protect owners of unrepairable vehicles, have themselves proved defective, according to attorneys general in several states that have amended these laws.

LEAD: Fighters older than 36 should be barred from participating in title fights, said Jose Sulaiman, World Boxing Council president, and he will ask his organization to do that at its convention in October.

N.B.A. Union Asks To Be Decertified
LEAD: Team representatives for the National Basketball Players Association voted unanimously tonight to decertify their union as the bargaining agent with the league.
In a separate action, the union agreed not to call for a strike of the All-Star Game or the playoffs.

LEAD: The Government's report yesterday of a slowdown in job growth sent a new wave of worry through the already pessimistic precious-metals futures markets, causing gold and silver prices to fall.


A GRANDDAUGHTER LEAVES CHILDHOOD BEHIND
LEAD: I DIDN'T cry when my grandfather died.
This man had taken me in, loved me and did the job his son couldn't do, but when he died I didn't cry.
His death wasn't a sad death or a shocking death.
It was a long time coming: he was a long time going.
We called it senility back then.
But for those last five years, he had been in steady decline.

Nathan Engel of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced.

Is this the way to correct the problem?

LEAD: A shortage of health care workers and inadequate state financing have prompted two of Maine's largest home health care agencies to stop accepting new patients under a state program designed to lessen the reliance of the elderly and the handicapped on nursing homes.

Katarina Witt.

A 'CRUCIAL OMISSION' IN ARTICLE ON EGGS
LEAD: The Jan. 17 article ''Animal Rights Group Assails Egg Farm'' omits a crucial fact about factory farming: Since the hens that are crammed together in tiny cages could easily succumb to infectious illness, their feed is heavily dosed with antibiotics.

LEAD: The site of a 112,000-gallon chlorine dioxide leak at a paper mill was being monitored today by environmental officials while the mill awaited the Governor's permission to resume normal operations.


CASE OF THE DISAPPEARING STAIRS
LEAD: INSTALLING a prefabricated disappearing stairway as an attic entrance is worth considering if a larger or more convenient opening is needed.
The task is simple for two people (an assistant is necessary to help maneuver the staircase), provided that the opening for the stairway can be cut so that its long sides are parallel with the existing ceiling joists, and that the roof is supported by rafters, not trusses.

Car Stereos Cover the Ground
LEAD: The uses of MOzart are manifold.
For example, last week I discovered that the Haffner Serenade is good for frayed nerves while you're waiting to be pulled out of a ditch.
No cause for alarm - it's all part of winter driving in the Berkshires, but it explains why, under certain conditions, a good sound system in a car gives as much comfort as a good heater.

LEAD: FEW subjects are more ripe for satire than the so-called ''new age'' movement with its assorted gurus, nuts and charlatans all spouting different brands of transcendental mumbo jumbo.
Jeff and Julie Olmsted, the songwriter-performers who created ''Jeff and Jewel's New Age Blues Revue,'' which plays at Don't Tell Mama on Thursdays through the end of the month, have done their homework in researching a field that encompasses phenomena as different as Werner Erhard's EST training seminars and Shirley MacLaine's thoughts on reincarnation.

Workers to Register
LEAD: WHEN large employers sponsor voter registration drives for their workers, the number of new registrants can be as large as the voting population of an entire small town.
The Nationwide Insurance Companies, with 14 regional offices, has registered or reregistered an average of 3,000 voters a year since 1984.


THE REGION: City Charter Changes; If the Board of Estimate Dies, Who Will Inherit Its Powers?
LEAD: IF the New York City Board of Estimate is dismantled, as some legal experts were proposing last week, there could be an ironic result.
A challenge to the board that originated in a desire for a more representative city government could so upset the city's system of checks and balances as to give more power to an already powerful mayor.

LATE MOTHERHOOD
LEAD: As the 46-year-old mother of a healthy 6-month-old daughter (and a 19-year-old son), I read Melvin Konner's article ''Childbearing and Age'' with considerable interest (Body and Mind, Dec. 27).
While I do not dispute the reality of his statistics on the decreasing chances of conception with advancing age, it must be said that, despite atrophying organs and waning hormonal levels, the life force can be more generous to older women than mere statistics might lead us to believe.

LEAD: By RACHELLE GARBARINE


For a Very Sizable Majority More Than Enough Politics
LEAD: There are many here who refer to this week as ''the end of the world.'' The candidates will stop talking to animals and will fly East.
The reporters will stop caring that Iowa is the Jell-O-eating capital of the country, and will stop buying products of the new political tourist industry, like ''Ski Iowa'' T-shirts and ''Weak-End in Des Moines'' lingerie.

LEAD: Q. I live in a new town house condominium that has an outdoor wood deck made of pressure-treated 2-by-4's.
The decking has turned green with mildew, and the builder has suggested using a K2 spot remover to clean it.
Is this the way to correct the problem?


Abrams Frustrated by Lawyer in Assault Case
LEAD: New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams, who was appointed by Governor Cuomo last month as special prosecutor in the Tawana Brawley case, has expressed frustration over the continuing refusal of Miss Brawley's lawyer, Alton H. Maddox Jr., to cooperate in any way.


Warming Up in the Wings: A Revival of 1970's Rock
LEAD: A 1960'S REVIVAL IS gusting through rock.
Musicians and critics are jostling one another to praise the human scale and anything-goes spirit of 1960's rock; college radio stations can play hours of recent music in which the hoarse vocals and garage-band production are virtually indistinguishable from the ''Nuggets'' collections (on Rhino Records) of half-forgotten 1960's singles.

LEAD: Back in the 60's, Woody Her-man was asked if the big bands would ever come back.
His answer was blunt: ''No.''

LEAD: FOR more than 27 years, a three- acre slab of concrete, surrounded by barbed wire, has been a silent witness at Fort Dix, N.J., to the deadly potential of nuclear arms.


THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
LEAD:  Supplies and Services For the Wedding


Tipping at Sea
LEAD: To the Editor: ''Calming the Jitters About Tipping on Cruises'' (Practical Traveler, Nov. 1) was timely.
Some crew members on our recent Royal Caribbean Cruise Line cruise seemed to receive virtually no monetary remuneration, only uniforms, bed and board.
With such an arrangement, company loyalty is minimal, and the caveat regarding personal effects (stressed by the cruise line) becomes more significant.


Eye of the Beholder
LEAD: To the Editor:


Are U.S. Companies Learning to Share?
LEAD: BATTERED by foreign gains in manufacturing and high technology, American companies are increasingly favoring cooperation over competition, as they band together in order to survive.
Taking a hint from the Japanese, endangered industries are forming research consortiums to pool limited supplies of talent, money and managerial skill.

Correction
LEAD: A roundup of educational tours on Jan. 10 misstated the languages used for liberal arts courses in the Paris program of the University of California at Berkeley.
Only one class, ''France d'aujourd'hui,'' is conducted in French; the rest are in English.

LEAD: Woonsocket has fallen heir to a parcel of land in New England that may be worth up to $500,000.
But the Boston-based company that advised the city of its inheritance has declined to say where the land is.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration plans a full-scale show of military force in and around South Korea next fall to deter possible North Korean terrorism or attack during the Olympic Games in Seoul, Administration officials say.

Overtired
LEAD: THE PROBLEM HAS ALWAYS been what to do with them.
One Minnesota plant turns them into a re-usable rubber compound.
And, of course, they make good rope swings.
There are an estimated 2 billion discarded tires in this country; about 40 million - the world's largest pile (above) - are near Westley, Calif.

Guides to the Bible
LEAD: To the Editor:


KOHL WOULD KEEP TACTICAL MISSILES
LEAD: In a major policy declaration, Chancellor Helmut Kohl today formally spurned the idea of eliminating short-range nuclear missiles from Europe but demanded negotiations that would reduce to equal ceilings the number of such weapons held by NATO and the Warsaw Pact.


In the Philippines, The Politics of Turmoil Casts A Murky Shadow Over the Arts
LEAD: The major artistic creation of the Philippines today is a passion play in which a simple widow challenges a dictator she believes killed her husband, and leads her nation to freedom.
In its second act, the widow, as president, faces down a series of violent challenges, clinging perilously to power as the forces of darkness struggle to reassert themselves.


A Statute Was Needed to Stop Abuses
LEAD: LAST spring the United States Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the Indiana Control Share Acquistion Statute, which limits company takeover activity in that state.
This statute requires certain hostile bidders to obtain the approval of the disinterested stockholders - the bidder or management - in order for the takeover bidder's shares to have voting power.


Next Week; Who Was Better, Mantle Or Mays? (Or Snider?)
LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

He was 91 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

Victim of Vietnam Identified
LEAD: An Army laboratory in Hawaii has identified remains returned to the United States by Vietnam last September as those of Maj.
Michael J. Bosiljevac of Omaha, an Air Force officer who disappeared on a flight over North Vietnam more than 15 years ago.
He was the 146th American whose remains, having been returned by Hanoi since the Vietnam War, were subsequently identified by the Central Identification Laboratory in Honolulu.

LEAD: LOVE songs are normally an inevitable part of a cabaret singer's repertory, but Marlene Ver Planck has built her entire program at Dannys' Skylight Room (346 West 46th Street) on songs that trace the ups and downs of a love affair.


In Calgary, Samaranch Plans for Seoul
LEAD: In his first meeting with a North Korean official since North Korea announced it would not participate in the 1988 Seoul Summer Olympics unless it is a co-host, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, warned that time was growing short for North Korea to participate in any form.

Jazz: Cecil Taylor Quintet
LEAD: FRANTIC, unpredictable, turbulent and - out of nowhere - harmonious, Cecil Taylor's music mirrors urban life in all its hyperactive sprawl.
The pianist brought a new quintet to a packed Knitting Factory Thursday through last night; his Bosendorfer concert grand was squeezed onto the tiny stage along with Thurman Barker's drums and vibraphone and William Parker's bass.


Malay Party Ruled Illegal, Spurring Conflicts
LEAD: The political party that has headed every Malaysian Government since independence in 1957 was ruled illegal last week by a Malaysian judge because some of its branches were improperly registered.
The unexpected ruling is likely to pose political, legal and possibly financial problems for Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and the party, the United Malays National Organization.


Scholars in Poland Protesting Political Control
LEAD: Poland's authorities are struggling to close a festering wound at the nation's prestigious Academy of Sciences, where members published an unusual open letter charging that inroads of political control crushed work in the academy's social science institutes.
