LEAD: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri ranked first today in The Des Moines Register's final poll of Iowans before the state's precinct caucuses Monday night.


POSTINGS: On a Hilltop, w/Vus; Houses Share the Waters
LEAD: Sparta Brook will share attention with the Hudson River in a colony of 20 houses being built in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.
Mitchell Hochberg, the co-developer, promises a backyard babbler for 12 of them and a Tappan Zee view for seven.
The project, called The Orchard, will also retain some of the apple trees that once dominated the 30-acre hilltop off Scarborough Road.

CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD:  'WALLENBERG AT 75'  Harvey Rosenfeld, the author of ''Raoul Wallenberg: Angel of Rescue,'' will give a talk in Hartford tomorrow about the Swedish businessman who ran an underground from Germany to England during World War II and saved many Jews from the Holocaust, The talk is titled ''Raoul Wallenberg at 75: The Unresolved Question.


In Cornwall, a Meal in a Crust
LEAD: IN the 18th century in England's Cornwall, tin smelters would stand around a basin of the silvery liquid as a huge block of wood dropped into it and sent up a fountain of molten metal.
The impact of the wood made the tin boil off impurities.
Sparks flew and the heat was intense, but according to a contemporary historian, the workers scarcely noticed the bright specks of tin flying about them.

The latest, URANUS (Morrow Junior Books, $12.95. Ages 4 to 8), like its companions, is beautiful, evocative, neat, simple, informative.

Package Deals in Three Capitals
LEAD: TRAVELERS watching their pounds, francs or lire - and the dollar buys fewer of each these days -might consider buying a package deal to Europe.
A weeklong package in Paris, London or Rome can represent a substantial saving over standard prices because airlines and tour companies get discounts by negotiating for large blocks of rooms.


FICTION
LEAD:  GOD'S WATER CARRIERS.
By Manes Sperber.
Translated by Joachim Neugroschel.
Foreword by Elie Wiesel. (Holmes &amp; Meier, $24.50.) In ''God's Water Carriers,'' Manes Sperber (1905-84) describes a time during his youth when, questioning God and beginning a lifelong debate over his faith, he climbed a barn roof in his shtetl in Poland to hurl stones into space, in the hope of challenging the God he was certain waited behind the ''trapdoor'' in the sky.

LEAD: NOW that our last child will be leaving home for college and our net worth is down approximately 40 percent since October's Black Monday, I have finally realized my dream - a magnificent new kitchen.
Just a few thousand dollars more than the original purchase price of our house in 1970, the room has brought me all the obvious anticipated pleasures.

President Reagan instructs the driver to keep turning right.
Seeing that the car is going in circles, Mr.
Gorbachev takes over.
He tells the driver to keep turning left.

SCIENCE FICTION
LEAD: The three long tales that make up THE BRIDGE OF LOST DESIRE by Samuel R. Delany (Arbor House, $17.95) display one of science fiction's finest writers at the top of his form.
This book is an addition to Mr.
Delany's unique Neveryon series, which slyly builds on archeological speculation to body forth a world at the very beginning of civilization in which such important events as the change-over from hieroglyphs to alphabet have occurred within the life spans of the characters.

Looking Back
LEAD: What did Martin Heidegger think about the Nazis, and when did he think it?
Debate over the German philosopher's Nazi past was rekindled in France recently with the publication of a new book, ''Heidegger and Nazism,'' by a former student, Victor Farias.
Mr.
Farias produces evidence that Heidegger, whose thinking has had widespread influence on postwar intellectual life in France, was no mere dabbler in Hitlerian politics, as his apologists maintained after the war.

Body and Mind; Too Much of a Good Thing
LEAD: WHEN A NEW acquaintance told me not long ago that he runs five miles every day, I felt jealous and ashamed (I jog only three miles, three times a week) and vowed to step up my program.
Only later, and with some effort, did I remind myself that I jog as much as current medical opinion says is needed to keep my heart and lungs fit.

What's Doing in Cairo
LEAD: From the 900-year-old walls that once marked the northern boundary of Cairo stretch the remains of a city many tourists never see.
Graceful minarets still punctuate its horizon like exclamation points, while in the narrow streets below, men in turbans and striped robes sell onions, garlic and lemons from donkey-drawn carts.

Correction
LEAD: A Sports of The Times column last Sunday about the old boy network in professional football gave an incorrect figure for the number of assistant coaches in the National Football League.
There are 282, of whom 41 are black.

LEAD: It finally snowed last week, a blustery storm that lasted long enough to paint the entire landscape a pristine white and dump more than a foot in the nearby Rockies.

LEAD: Many first-rate recordings of Beethoven's complete trios have become available in recent years, and to these may now be added the cycle by the Borodin Trio, containing the basic six (the three of Op. 1, the two of Op. 70 and Op. 97), two sets of variations and several rarely heard early works.
All are available on a set of four Chandos compact disks (CHAN 8352/3/4/5; also on

LEAD: SOME of Connecticut's lawmakers sounded like weather forecasters last week after Governor O'Neill unveiled his $6.3 billion budget proposal for the next fiscal year and recommended spending $73.8 million of the state's five-year old budget reserve, more commonly known as the ''rainy day fund.''


Cambridge
LEAD: To the Editor: I read with great interest your coverage on travel-study in England - Cambridge and Oxford (Travel, Jan. 10).
In fact, the bit on Corpus Christi, Cambridge, brought smiles to me because some years ago I myself was a student at Corpus Christi College, Oxford, with Dr.
E.
J.
Wolff's University of Detroit program there, and as part of our program we visited our sister school in Cambridge.

Too Close To Reality
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


FACING FACTS ON NASSAU'S PROBLEMS
LEAD: CONCERN is rising that Nassau County is rapidly reaching its capacity to absorb more people.
Lack of planning, inadequate land-use controls, poor design and unsatisfactory maintenance of our ecological systems are taking a toll on our communities.


Sunday Observer; Cartoon Crisis
LEAD: SOMETIMES IT SEEMS I am being drawn by a cartoonist.
How else can I explain my being in this supermarket with an impulse to ask the manager to recommend a soap for my dishpan hands?


Legislation to Help Alaska Natives Keep Land
LEAD: A measure that has been signed into law by President Reagan gives Alaska's 85,000 Eskimos, Indians and Aleuts a fighting chance to keep native lands and other wealth in native hands, several of their leaders say.


New York's Cabaret Scene, Ertegun Style
LEAD: A record set called ''New York Cabaret Music'' (Atlantic LP 81817-1, six disks; CD 81817-2) is both more and less than that title might suggest.
There has been cabaret music of one sort or another in New York for decades, but this collection deals primarily with the 1950's.
Even more specifically, it reflects the tastes and interests, personal and business, of the Ertegun Brothers, as indicated by its subtitle, ''The Erteguns' New York.


Film
LEAD: With the weather outside somewhat frosty, a welcome warning trend has settled into several theaters. ''Distant Harmony,'' at the Carnegie Hall Cinema (Seventh Avenue at 57th Street), gives us Luciano Pavarotti conquering and being conquered by China, during his 1986 tour with the cast of ''La Boheme.

ALLAN BLOOM'S GREAT IDEAS
LEAD: Allan Bloom's book is a pretentious account of his own nostalgia for the days when white-male authority went unquestioned.
Such yearnings are the standard litany of extreme conservatism.


IN QUOTES
LEAD: ''Something had to snap.
If it didn't happen in October, it would have happened soon thereafter.
The immediate cause of the break was incidental.'' - Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, in Congressional testimony about regulating the markets.


Curbing Raiders Is Bad for Business
LEAD: Congressional action to preserve a free market is now more necessary than ever, since Delaware, the nation's second-smallest state, adopted legislation to sharply restrict contested mergers.
The measure, signed by Delaware's Governor last week, will affect companies around the country.

LEAD: Flood victims on the roof of a house in Petropolis, where five days of heavy rain left at least 58 dead.


Dupes or Partners?
LEAD: General Noriega forestalled American retaliation for years by playing Federal agencies off against one another and against other countries, American officials said.


POSTINGS: Geologist Strikes Marble; SoHo Landmark
LEAD: Owain Hughes, a Welsh geologist, made a significant discovery recently.
While rehabilitating a New York City landmark at 597 Broadway in SoHo, Mr.
Hughes, who left Oxford University to mine real estate, found a white-marble facade beneath decades of accumulated grime.
His training had almost failed him.


The Big City on the Beach
LEAD: A FRIEND stopping off in Miami to break up a New York to Buenos Aires trip inquired if there was anything to do in Miami for two days besides the beach.
He didn't mean Miami Beach, of course.
Everyone knew that was dead, he said, a kind of Far Rockaway with palm trees, and not too many of those.


86-Game Slump Ends
LEAD: The University of Dallas ended its 86-game losing streeak today, beating John Brown University by 76-68.
The streak was the longest ever by a four-year college.

'ART INTO PRODUCTION'
LEAD:  Before the Revolution of 1917, Russian artists were already experimenting with radical visual vocabularies based on abstraction and geometric forms.
The pioneers of Suprematism and later Constructivism further championed a new marriage of ''art and life.'' After the Revolution, artists such as Alexander Rodchenko, Vladimir Mayakovsky, Liubov Popova and El Lissitzky actively participated in advertising the virtues of their new society.

Palestinian Turmoil Could Provide the Seeds of Peace
LEAD: SINCE the birth of Israel nearly 40 years ago, the Arab-Israeli conflict has fallen into a circular pattern.
Statesmen try to move ahead, push some distance but finally fail.
Amid diplomatic stagnation, warfare erupts.
Then the combat ends, having loosened some of the old positions, providing a period of diplomatic fluidity.

A House of Art That Is Quirky, Aloof and Grand
LEAD: Though best known in his lifetime for having invented an invaluable antiseptic, Dr.
Albert C. Barnes (1872-1951) had an auxiliary reputation as a major art collector and the founder of a private educational facility in the suburbs of Philadelphia.
In its turn, that facility had also a double reputation.


CASE OF THE DISAPPEARING STAIRS
LEAD: INSTALLING a prefabricated disappearing stairway as an attic entrance is worth considering if a larger or more convenient opening is needed.
The task is simple for two people (an assistant is necessary to help maneuver the staircase), provided that the opening for the stairway can be cut so that its long sides are parallel with the existing ceiling joists, and that the roof is supported by rafters, not trusses.

WHAT'S NEW IN GETTING OUT THE VOTE
LEAD: IT'S far too early to tell whether voter turnout for the 1988 Presidential election will be greater than the 53.1 percent of eligible voters who turned out for the 1984 Presidential election.
But if it is, a number of businesses will be able take some of the credit.


Hints That Repression May Lead to Reform
LEAD: FOR weeks, a battle has been raging in Angola that could have repercussions throughout southern Africa.
The battle is for Cuito Cuanavale, the strategic town in southern Angola; the warring forces have been fighting for control of the region for more than a decade.
On the defending side are the troops of the Angolan Government, backed by Cubans and Soviet advisors; on the offensive, the UNITA forces of Jonas Savimbi, the guerrilla leader, receiving 5-million-a-year in American military aid, stiffened by a South African army of at least 5,000, perhaps as many as 7,000 men.


IN HASTINGS, A TREASURY OF HISTORY
LEAD: EVERY weekday afternoon in Hastings-on-Hudson, the 4:30 whistle signals the end of the workday of yesteryear - calling phantom laborers from the abandoned factories that still line the waterfront and that may soon become condominiums.

POSTINGS: Mixing Uses; Greenwich Project
LEAD: Choosing a clean sweep rather than a renovation of the 10-acre industrial complex, Arthur Collins and James R. Psaki began demolition last November of a former Electrolux factory in Old Greenwich, Conn.
Next month construction will begin on a mixed-use development to take its place.
The $75 million project on Forest Avenue will include a four-story office building, scheduled for completion in the fall of 1989, as well as 167 low-rise condominium units and a recreation center.


Jazz: The Art Farmer-Clifford Jordan Group
LEAD: MAINSTREAM jazz - now essentially bebop - may be the most deceptive of all the kinds of music played under the name of jazz.
It has staid connotations: middle-aged musicians play music demarcated by a rigid set of harmonic and rhythmic rules; not much goes on formally, and musicians prize a logical narrative flow, with a minimum of abstraction.


WARMING UP TO WINTER
LEAD: WE are about at the half-way mark of winter and I have been accused of counting time, even days, too much, as though I were not a great fan of the season.
A few weeks ago, I was, in best Pollyanna fashion, buoying up a neighbor who was doggedly scraping ice from his car's windshield.
I said, cheerily, ''Hey, less than two months until spring.

How Explorers Saw the Brave New World
LEAD: Europeans took a long time assimilating their discovery of the New World.
It was almost a century before artists, in representing the New World, broke away from Eurocentric preconceptions and classical or medieval styles.
Initial attempts at realism may not have been great art, but they left a revealing historical record of one civilization's encounter with another.

The U.A.W., battered by layoffs, was equally intent on preserving jobs.

FICTION
LEAD:  1919: The Year Our World Began.
By William K. Klingaman. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $27.95.) The year 1919, by any yardstick, was an eventful one, and the historian William K. Klingaman persuasively demonstrates that it began with hope, ended in despair and shaped the 20th century.
Consider these highlights: With hostilities ended in the Great War, Woodrow Wilson spends several months in Paris working on a treaty; by year's end, his dream of a League of Nations is shattered.


Art
LEAD: One of the most distinguished exhibitions to have been mounted in recent years by a dealer's gallery is the loan show of 44 oil paintings, drawings and gouaches by Piet Mondrian that can be seen at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 110 West 57th Street, through Saturday.

LEAD: THE Bee Battle of Mexico has started, and the bees have won the first encounter without wasting a sting.

LEAD: THERE'S a female rite of passage even more traumatic than the first date, and I recently came through it with flying colors.

LEAD: Anthony M. Frank, a successful California executive who came to the United States as a child when his parents fled Nazi Germany, figures he owes America something.


Choice Dining Around Miami
LEAD: JUST five years ago, the odds of wandering into a first-rate restaurant in greater Miami were roughly equal to your chances of finding a 16th-century Spanish doubloon in the Fontainbleau Hotel's swimming pool.
Except for some gutsy Cuban haunts downtown, Miami cuisine was characterized largely by over-air-conditioned tourist places featuring humdrum chain-restaurant fare.

On Long Drives, Tolstoy Helps
LEAD: WHEN we prepare for a long driving trip, one of our tasks is picking a taped book to play on our cassette deck during the hours spent on monotonous interstates.
We call an 800 number and rent one because a six-hour tape is an expensive purchase.
If it's a book we discover we like, it can then be bought for our shelves at home.


How the Morgan Bank Struck Out
LEAD: IN a highly visible advertising campaign, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has been holding itself out as the bank that stresses its ''relationship'' with its clients above all else. ''We don't promote M.&amp;A. deals just to generate fees,'' heralds one ad that proudly shows an empty tombstone - symbolic of a takeover deal that wasn't done, presumably because it wasn't in the client's interest.

LEAD: Illinois officials and the lawyers for Gary Dotson, a convicted rapist who was freed after Cathleen Crowell Webb recanted her accusation, are turning to a new genetic testing procedure in an effort to determine Mr.
Dotson's guilt or innocence.


Carmen Polo de Franco, Widow Of Spanish Dictator, Dead at 87
LEAD: Carmen Polo de Franco, the Spanish dictator's widow, who was considered a significant influence on some of the repressive policies of his 36-year rule, died today in her Madrid apartment.
She was 87 years old.

IDEAS &amp; TRENDS: Baby M; Taking the Money Out of Motherhood
LEAD: THE New Jersey Supreme Court last week undid most of the decision that a lower court judge reached in the case of Baby M, and it has declared that, contract or no contract, the woman who gave birth to her is her legal mother.
But the new decision leaves Baby M, now Melissa Elizabeth Stern, where the earlier one did - with her biological father.


Baseball Notebook; Economist Says McReynolds Will Lose Arbitration 3d Time
LEAD: If Kevin McReynolds loses his salary arbitration case with the Mets, he will join Julio Cruz as the only three-time losers in the 13-year history of the system.
People on both sides of the arbitration table have speculated that McReynolds will indeed lose because they think he submitted too high a number, $1.15 million.


AT A MINIMUM
LEAD: AN EXPANSIVE GREEN-house that overlooks Manhattan in Alfred Hitchcock's 1948 movie ''Rope'' so inspired Jon Weiser, president of Charivari Men's, that he obtained a production still to show Shigeru Uchida, the Japan-based interior designer who had begun to renovate Weiser's new apartment.
To Uchida, the views were intriguing and the space vast by Japanese standards.

NBC will not be moving to New Jersey.
Thanks to Mayor Koch, it's going to stay at Rockefeller Center for at least another 35 years. ''The peacock can have both brains and beauty,'' the Mayor said last December as NBC accepted his offer.

LEAD: WHILE residents of the east side of Yonkers protest a Federal Court order to build 200 low-income housing units on the mainly white side of town, residents of the west side are fighting a condominium development proposed for their neighborhood because they say it would displace low-income minority families.

LEAD: An Amtrak train carrying 190 passengers ran a red signal and collided with a Burlington Northern freight Thursday, slightly injuring 13 people, the authorities said.

Cutting the Cost of Car Insurance
LEAD: WHEN Mariarosa Cartolano, a New York lawyer, recently purchased her first car, a 1987 Chrysler Le Baron, she was prepared to find high prices in the dealer's showroom.
What she wasn't prepared for was the size of the insurance bill: $4,000 a year, or about 25 percent of the cost of the car itself.

AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS ON THE ISLAND
LEAD: The article ''After School, They're at School'' on Jan. 3 has, I believe, some misinformation.
To my knowledge, the oldest program, Clasp, is located in Great Neck.
The second oldest program is the North Bellmore After-School Center Inc., which was incorporated in October 1979 and started in September 1980 at the Saw Mill Road School by Marilyn Deiner.


Jury by Trial
LEAD: William Shakespeare must have just returned from jury duty when he wrote, ''The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers.'' He might especially have had in mind the selection of civil juries in the New York State Supreme Court, a process that makes suicide seem user friendly.


Maine Company Drops Suit
LEAD: The Patten Corporation, a large development company based in Vermont, has agreed to drop its $1 million lawsuit against Hartford, Me., a small town in Maine's western mountains.


Piano: Thomas Lorango
LEAD: THE first simple chords of Beethoven's ''Les Adieux'' Sonata at Alice Tully Hall Friday night let us know about Thomas Lorango's intelligence and sympathy for the piano literature.
Each voice had its own life and each was joined together by Mr.
Lorango's natural feel for the tensions of movement.
This sensitive, almost private, feeling for music carried over into the finale of Schumann's Fantasy and the three Intermezzos from Brahms's Opus 119.

Taking Back
LEAD: Senator Daniel K. Inouye apparently is a sensitive kind of guy.
The Hawaii Democrat said last week that he was ''hurt and angered'' when critics accused him of ''sneaking'' a measure through Congress that channeled $8 million to a campaign contributor's pet project.
The $8 million, attached to a huge spending bill that was rushed through Congress in December, was to support the Jewish education of North African refugees in France.

Malle Confronts Haunting Memory
LEAD: His name appears, at one moment, to be Jean Kippelstein - already a sign of a mixed identity - even though his classmates knew him as Jean Bonnet, teasing him for being a ''bonnet de nuit,'' a nightcap.
The historical fact is that he was neither Kippelstein nor Bonnet.
His real name was Hans Helmut Michel, and he was born in Frankfurt, Germany, on June 6, 1930.

Evans's Bamboozle, But in Reverse
LEAD: ABOUT 40 years ago, as a young grandmaster, the syndicated chess columnist Larry Evans jocularly broached his idea that the easiest way to win a game was to pick the ripe moment for a transition to an ending where the opponent could be bamboozled.
It was not quite all in fun either - he won loads of games ''transitioning'' his opponents.

Piano: Barry Hannigan in Recital
LEAD: BARRY HANNIGAN came up with a dandy program for his piano recital Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.
The music consisted of two of the most admired, large-scale piano scores of the mid-1970's, both experimental and involving whistling and vocalizations from the performer, yet both looking forward to today's accessible post-modernism.

Vice president Bush and Dan Rather were only prelude.
Tomorrow night, television gets down to the real stuff.
Who will win the Iowa caucuses?

Pros vs Amateurs
LEAD: WHAT is it that separates the ''pros'' from the amateurs in photography?
To many minds, it's a matter of equipment.
Professional photographers, according to this theory, have access to a special breed of cameras, lenses, flash units and the like.
Using pro-level equipment, they are able to take pro-level pictures.

Barcelona
LEAD: To the Editor: Two hundred and sixty dollars for dinner for four in Spain?
Have travel writers no conception that many ordinary travelers choose Spain (and Portugal and Morocco and some others) because it is one of the less expensive places to visit?
If the writer of a ''What's Doing in'' must indulge himself in expensive restaurants, let him do it in a special category placed between ''Hotels'' and ''Restaurants.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''I'm so sick and tired of the great, galloping hordes of candidates criss-crossing the state and burrowing into every nook and cranny, every home.
Every time you turn around you crash into one of them.
Enough, enough!''  Betty Dumbaugh  of Storm Lake, Iowa,  who plans to stay home  on caucus night.


ALLAN BLOOM'S GREAT IDEAS
LEAD: If it was distressing to be a professor during the 1960's, it was equally distressing to be a student.
Instead of sharing Professor Bloom's youthful experience of walking through the gates into a world in which intellectual endeavor was taken seriously, the student was plunged into a society ruled by demagoguery of the most extreme kind, in which slogans were substituted for ideas, and even attending class was sometimes a risky business.


NEHEMIAH SEEKS OLD FORM
LEAD: Renaldo Nehemiah is angry.
Not at his longtime archrival, Greg Foster, who won the hurdles Friday night in the Panasonic Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden.
Not at the others who beat him in that race as he finished next to last.
Not at the public, which wants to know what has happened to the old Renaldo

LEAD: REMEMBER when your mother warned you to be careful what you wished for because you just might get it?


Concert: Australian Orchestra
LEAD: FOUNDED in 1975, the Australian Chamber Orchestra maintains an active schedule at home in Sydney, plays elsewhere in Australia and has toured Asia and Europe.
But its current 16-city swing through the United States is its first in this hemisphere.
A part of the Australian bicentennial celebrations, the tour brought the orchestra Friday night to the Metropolitan Museum of


Rude and Belligerent
LEAD: To the Editor:


MOIRA VOSS ENGAGED
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
Charles Voss of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Moira Damaris Voss, to Rene Garcia-Grayre, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Raul Garcia-Grayre of Brooklyn.
Ms.
Voss, a graduate of Hampshire College and an intern at the Actors' Fund, is studying at Columbia University for a master's degree in social work.


Dance: Limon Company
LEAD: THE presentation of dances-in-progress is always a tricky business.
Unfinished, they defy reasonable critical analysis, and most tend to exist in a kind of limbo between inspiration and execution.
The three pieces presented by the Jose Limon Dance Company in a gala showcase on Thursday at the Joyce Theater were no exception.


CASE OF THE DISAPPEARING STAIRS
LEAD: INSTALLING a prefabricated disappearing stairway as an attic entrance is worth considering if a larger or more convenient opening is needed.
The task is simple for two people (an assistant is necessary to help maneuver the staircase), provided that the opening for the stairway can be cut so that its long sides are parallel with the existing ceiling joists, and that the roof is supported by rafters, not trusses.


Wright Seen Anew as an Architect of Thoughts
LEAD: In the 28 years since Frank Lloyd Wright's death, his associates, who have tried to keep the flame of his reputation burning, have often done more to damage his name than to enhance it.
Under the rubric of Taliesin Associated Architects (named for the architect's famous houses in Spring Green, Wis., and Scottsdale, Ariz.) they have produced new buildings that are generally mediocre imitations of the great architect's late work.


Valedictorian, Denied West Point, Will Settle for Texas A&amp;M
LEAD: A Dallas high school student who was not allowed to apply to the United States Military Academy because she is not yet a citizen has received a scholarship to Texas A&amp;M University.


IF KING AND MALCOLM X HAD MET...
LEAD: ''WE DO make quite a team,'' the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr. remarks to Malcolm X at the end of a hypothetical meeting in a Harlem hotel room.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  LOVING LITTLE EGYPT, by Thomas McMahon. (Penguin, $6.95.) In the early days of electrical power, Thomas Alva Edison fought with Nikola Tesla over whether direct current or alternating current would be the wave of the future.
In this novel by Thomas McMahon, a Harvard science professor, Edison and Tesla are on opposite sides again, in a dispute over an electronics wizard who creates a secret underground telephone network for the blind.


Philadelphia Ex-Judge Convicted of Extortion
LEAD: A former Common Pleas Court judge was convicted today of one of two Federal extortion counts.
He is the third Philadelphia judge convicted of corruption in six months.


Policeman Gets Reprimand For Giving Shelter in Snow
LEAD: The General Services Administration has reprimanded a Federal policeman who gave refuge in a snowstorm to a homeless man who has been living on the steps of the Federal courthouse here for much of the last eight years.


ABOUT SOFTWARE AND HARDWARE
LEAD: The article ''Computers: A Necessary Insidiousness''  [ Opinion Page, Jan. 17 ]  renders a distinct disservice to your readers.
Especially in the over-30 generation, there's enough nervousness about these marvelous machines without adding to it by maligning them, even if facetiously.
Worse yet, to tell all sorts of untruths about them!


Shorter Bout
LEAD: The International Boxing Federation has decided to limit today's title fight in England between the middleweight champion, Frank Tate, and Tony Sibson to 12 rounds instead of the 15 the I.B.F. ususally insists on for a championship fight.
In doing so, the I.B.F. appeared to be bowing to the safety concerns of British boxing authorities, who refused to sanction the fight at 15 rounds and called on the I.B.F.

LEAD: THIS will be another week of competing events.
Today alone, there is a dance program at 2 P.M., a violin recital at 2:30, five solo or chamber concerts at 3 and seven recitals with 4 o'clock starts.

OLYMPICS TAKE A FIRST STEP ON THE ROAD TO REALITY
LEAD: WHEN the Olympic athletes from 57 nations parade Saturday during the opening ceremony of the 15th Winter Games, one of the Canadian team members will be Andy Moog, the same Andy Moog who was an established goaltender for the Edmonton Oilers of the National Hockey League.
And more than any other athlete in Calgary, he will be taking the first step to Olympic reality.

THOSE OTHER L.I.R.R. RIDERS
LEAD: Re: ''L.I.R.R. Main Line to Enter Electric Age,'' Jan. 17:


Birds of a Feather
LEAD: GUESTS were invited to create fantasy headdresses for the Christian Dior dinner Thursday at the New York Public Library for the opening of the exhibition ''Splendid Plumage.'' Chignons sprouted pheasant feathers, curls supported ostrich plumes and one bold spirit wore a bird's nest filled with eggs.


Evoking Childhood Isn't Kid Stuff
LEAD: Toward the end of Steven Spielberg's ''Empire of the Sun,'' there's a haunting sequence in which 13-year-old Jim Graham (Christian Bale), who has survived four years in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp outside Shanghai, witnesses the first American air raid on the adjacent Japanese airfield.


About Men; The Magic Classroom
LEAD: I'VE BEEN MEETING FORMER students of mine lately: one on the A train, one in Zabar's, another at a street fair.
They are shy about it at first - scrutinizing me, trying to find the someone they knew behind the years, the changes. ''You're Professor Lyons, aren't you?'' one asked, and I stuttered a bit, because the last time this happened, I said ''I was,'' meaning ''without the title now'' though I am still Lyons.


CASE OF THE DISAPPEARING STAIRS
LEAD: INSTALLING a prefabricated disappearing stairway as an attic entrance is worth considering if a larger or more convenient opening is needed.
The task is simple for two people (an assistant is necessary to help maneuver the staircase), provided that the opening for the stairway can be cut so that its long sides are parallel with the existing ceiling joists, and that the roof is supported by rafters, not trusses.


CHINA'S MODERN MASTERS
LEAD: IN THE LIBRARY OF A 23-ROOM apartment on Fifth Avenue, four blocks from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a rug that was once in the emperor's quarters in Beijing's Forbidden Palace.
Somehow, during the turbulent years following the Opium War of 1839-42, the rug was removed from the palace and, some decades later, found its way into the hands of an American pilot who had brought a single-engine plane to China, offering his air-freight services to opium traffickers.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  COUSIN JOE: Blues From New Orleans.
By Pleasant (Cousin Joe) Joseph and Harriet J. Ottenheimer. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) On the last page of this curious memoir, the blues singer Pleasant Joseph writes: ''The good Lord gave me a chance to make a comeback.
I had messed up my whole life from drinking: from slow horses, from fast women and bad whiskey.


Is the Consumer Binge Really Over?
LEAD: FOR years, Americans have been the world's most determined, enthusiastic consumers.
The simple living conveyed in Norman Rockwell's illustrations or Grant Wood's famous painting of a severe, Midwestern farmer and his wife, has been lost in the 1980's.


Where Fabric Reigns in Italy
LEAD: PRATO is Florence's industrial alter ego, the milling ants to Florence's blithe cricket, as in the fables of La Fontaine.
But when it comes to play, it is Prato that does the chirping.
Porsches from Prato are parked outside the expensive restaurants of Florence, and it is the matrons of Prato who patronize the fashionable boutiques and jewelers of Florence.


Haugen Regains I.B.F. Lightweight Crown
LEAD: Greg Haugen is the International Boxing Federation lightweight champion again.

LEAD: MANY developers of urban malls fail at the delicate art of attracting a successful mix of tenants.
Herald Center, the vertical shopping center at 34th Street and Broadway, has been a disappointment since it opened three years ago.
In lower Manhattan, dozens of retail spaces sit vacant at the South Street


Many Haitians Ignore Strike on Inaugural Eve
LEAD: On the eve of the inauguration of Leslie F. Manigat as President of Haiti, a general strike today closed most stores in the heart of the capital.
But many people who earn their living in open-air markets and street stalls went about their business as usual.


Regulators Battle To Define Turf
LEAD: The regulatory waters are still being roiled by the October market collapse.
The S.E.C. staff urged curbs on stock index futures trading, saying the technique aggravated the dive of Oct. 19.
Among other things, the 900- page report recommended that margins on futures be raised from the current 10 percent.


Police Seeking Stolen Truck And a Cargo of Nitroglycerin
LEAD: A truck believed to be carrying explosives was reported stolen in Queens yesterday, and the police appealed for help in finding it.


Correction
LEAD: Last Sunday, in his essay ''Can TV Be Taken Seriously?'', John J. O'Connor neglected to mention that the British-made ''South Bank Show,'' currently being saluted in the Museum of Broadcasting's ''New York World Television Festival,'' is also available on the Bravo cable service; it is presenting the cultural series on Thursday evenings at 10.

No Headline
LEAD: It was nice to see our hero, Olympian skier Pirmin Zurbriggen, in The New York Times Magazine (''On the Edge of Greatness,'' by Trip Gabriel, Dec. 27).
But what does Mr.
Gabriel mean by calling him a ''Goody Two-shoes'' or a ''lollipop''?
What is wrong with being shy, religious and modest?
Pirmin Zurbriggen does not have to tell anyone he's good.

Dance
LEAD: The Ohio Ballet, which opens a week's season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue) Monday, has the look and feel of a well-tuned single instrument.
Celebrating its 20th anniversary this year, the company is the creation of Heinz Poll, its director and chief choreographer, and Thomas Skelton, the lighting designer; and it bears the imprint of an informed and articulated artistic vision.

The remainder of the chain's 1,114 outlets in the Southwest and Midwest will hold voter registration campaigns in September, in time to enable new registrants to vote in the November

PACE IS PICKING UP FOR THE PHILHARMONIA VIRTUOSI
LEAD: THE Philharmonia Virtuosi took January off, but February finds the ensemble back in concert action on this and the following two Sundays.
Today at 3 P.M., Cyprien Katsaris is the featured soloist at the State University of New York at Purchase, with the brilliant French pianist tackling two great concertos, the Liszt A major and Beethoven's Third.

LEAD: FOUR eastern Connecticut hospitals, all facing a shortage of beds partly because of population increases, are working out an agreement to share space.


On Seeking A Better Rattrap
LEAD: RATS are not a big problem in Takoma Park, Md., but when the city moved to help homeowners who were occasionally troubled by them, it found no easy solution.

LEAD: With a softened ideology and assertions of battlefield prowess, Iran's principal exiled opposition movement, crushed during the Islamic revolution, is seeking to project itself as a new force in this region's conflicts.


Lead Content in Mobil Glasses Is Questioned
LEAD: With an eight-gallon purchase of unleaded gasoline, Mobil Oil service stations around the country have been giving motorists drinking glasses decorated with the logo of a football team in leaded enamel.


Smalley on the Move
LEAD: The deals that sent Roy Smalley from the Yankees to the Chicago White Sox during the 1984 season and from the White Sox to the Minnesota Twins before the 1985 season were not your usual baseball trades.
They were more like rent-a-player deals in which the Twins and the White Sox each secured the right to return the player to his previous club in exchange for a minor leaguer.

LEAD: IN the early years of the Winter Olympics, the most successful athletes were mainly skiers and skaters from the northern European belt of Norway, Sweden and Finland.

Then East Germany did the same.

LEAD: The commander of United States forces in Latin America has said that the Nicaraguan rebels are on the verge of a three-way split that will erode and possibly destroy their military strength.


Ups and Downs Aside, Iowa Has 'Middleness'
LEAD: IN Waterloo, a town that has lost 12,000 manfacturing jobs in the last decade, the John Deere foundry and tractor plant has recalled 500 workers since November.
In Albia, a rural crossroads where the farm crisis drove one bank and at least three shops out of business, a small pipe-making company plans to open a factory that will employ 100 people.

LEAD: When you see your best friend acting in a way that will ruin his life, do you pretend not to see?
Do you insist to others that it is really not so bad as it looks?
Do you tell yourself that it is his business, not yours?

Question Of the Week; Are Free Agents Free Again in Baseball?
LEAD: Whoever said they were enslaved?

Some of their salaries practically rivaled the Treasury balance.
LARRY L. KUNTZ  Brooklyn


New Attention for Early Black Artist
LEAD: The surreal setting of Joshua Johnson's ''Little Girl in Pink With a Goblet Filled With Strawberries'' adds drama to this folk portrait of a small child identified as Emma Van Name, which dates from about 1805.
The painting, attributed to one of the nation's first black artists, was sold at Sotheby's last weekend for $660,000 - more than 14 times the previous record at auction for this artist - a price that represents a growing awareness of Johnson's importance.


Denial of Female Guard's Promotion Upheld
LEAD: A female deputy sheriff was properly denied a promotion to sergeant that would have placed her in an all-male wing of the Oneida County Jail, the Court of Appeals, New York's highest court, ruled this week.

Blooms for the Winter
LEAD: INDOORS sow seed of geranium, petunia, salvia, begonia, impatiens, eustoma, portulaca and coleus.
It is too early to sow vegetable seed indoors especially tomatoes, peppers, melons, eggplants; wait until March.
Pot paperwhite narcissus bulbs in pebbles, but discard any of these tender bulbs that have already bloomed; they cannot be forced again.

LEAD: ONCE again, Edwin Meese 3d is under fire.
And once again, Washington is wondering how long the Attorney General, the nation's highest law enforcement officer, can keep on surmounting accusations of impropriety and misjudgment.

LEAD: After increasing for eight consecutive years, the number of business failures in the United States declined slightly in 1987, the Dun &amp; Bradstreet Corporation said Friday.


States Assuming a New Role in Consumer Issues
LEAD: State attorneys general, working collectively on consumer issues they say are ignored by Federal agencies, are emerging as an alternative national enforcement agency in an era of deregulation.


Sikhs Kill Four at Wedding
LEAD: Sikh militants opened fire today on a Hindu wedding party, killing the bridegroom and three other people, the police said.
Four Sikh radicals arrived at the party near the town of Kapurthala, about 43 miles north of here, and began shooting AK-47 assault rifles, the police said.


Dawn Upshaw to Sing With Chamber Group
LEAD: The soprano Dawn Upshaw will be guest soloist with the Apple Hill Chamber Players on Wednesday when the group gives the first of three monthly chamber-music concerts at Merkin Concert Hall.
The ensemble, which is based in Nelson, N.H., comprises a string quartet, double bassist and two pianists.


British Air's Airbus Order
LEAD: British Airways said today that it would take delivery of all 10 A320 aircraft on order from the European Airbus consortium despite a dispute over fuel consumption.


Music: Canadian Quartet
LEAD: TOWARD the end of their Friday evening concert at the Public School 41 auditorium, the French Canadian traditional quartet La Bottine Souriante struck up a jig.
Yves Lambert, who plays accordion and harmonica, began to vocalize in an argot that suggested an American mountain auctioneer singing in French in a jazzily syncopated diction.


Networks to Broadcast Results of Caucuses
LEAD: Results of the Iowa caucuses will be broadcast tonight by all three commercial networks, with NBC and ABC airing 30-minute news specials at 10:30 P.M.
Eastern standard time, and CBS following at 11:30 (11:35 in New York City).
Cable News Network will provide live coverage from Des Moines beginning at 8 P.M.

LEAD: Aaron C. Sterling, a fund-raiser and promoter of charitable causes, died of congestive heart failure Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center.
He was 63 years old and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1988
LEAD:  International A2-9


Nigeria Plants Finished
LEAD: Two petrochemical plants that Nigeria set out to build 18 years ago are finally ready, an official for the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation said Friday.
The plants will turn part of the country's oil and gas output into stocks that can be used to make products ranging from drugs and paints to car parts and printers ink.

LEAD: IT was so delightful, so delicious, so absolutely delovely that even Michael Jordan himself got embarrassed.

LEAD: The Westminster Kennel Club show will feature 2,651 dogs vying for the best-in-show title.
The sporting, hound and toy breeds will be benched and judged today, starting at 9 A.M., with the groups at 8 P.M.
On Tues-day, the working, terrier, non-sport-ing seven rings, from 8:30 A.M.


This Painting Shakes Hands And Audiences
LEAD: Sometimes you get a little grouchy, said Stephen Taylor Woodrow, when you hang on a museum wall for six hours a day, covered with black spray paint.


Gang Violence Shocks Los Angeles
LEAD: It began as a pleasant Saturday night out for Karen Toshima: dinner with a friend and a stroll through the bustling Westwood Village on the affluent West Side of Los Angeles.
A short time later Miss Toshima, a 27-year-old graphic artist, lay mortally wounded on the sidewalk next to a parking meter, a bullet through her head.

Haiti Says Philadelphia Garbage Was Dumped by Ship on Its Beach
LEAD: A cargo ship chartered in the United States has dumped about 4,000 tons of garbage from Philadelphia on a Haitian beach, according to Haitian Government officials.

LEAD: At last, tonight's the night.
After watching months of campaigning, some 200,000 Iowans will assemble in gyms, firehouses and living rooms and declare for one of the six Republicans or seven Democrats running for President.
And at last, three kinds of easy criticism will have to stop.


Rafi Nelson, Resort Owner
LEAD: Rafi Nelson, a former journalist and public relations man who became the owner of a beachfront resort, died Saturday of a heart attack, the Israeli radio reported today.
He was 57 years old.
Mr.
Nelson operated Rafi Nelson's Holiday Village, a popular resort in the tiny enclave of Taba, claimed both by Egypt and Israel.


A Cautious Cushion for Banks
LEAD: It's almost a deal: the Federal Reserve Board and regulators in Western Europe and Japan have agreed to common capital requirements for commercial banks.
The reforms may crimp the style and profitability of some giant ''money center'' banks.
But that's a reasonable price to pay to cushion the world financial system against the stresses of rapid growth and integration.


Carbide Plea on Bhopal Aid
LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation complained Friday that a court order requiring interim relief payments to victims of the Bhopal gas disaster did not specify who would get the aid, the United News of India reported.

LEAD: The First New York International Festival of the Arts, scheduled in June and July, is announcing its offerings by discipline.
Dance, listed below, was officially announced today.

PANAMA RECALLS ENVOYS FROM U.S. AS CRISIS DEEPENS
LEAD: In an action reflecting the growing crisis in relations between Panama and the United States, the Panamanian Government has recalled three senior diplomats, including its Ambassador to Washington, for ''urgent consultations,'' state-controlled radio stations and newspapers here said today.

Police Chief Of Jersey City Kills Himself
LEAD: At 6:15 A.M. yesterday, the Jersey City Chief of Police, John Fritz, walked into Police Headquarters at 8 Erie Street, went to his third-floor office and locked the door.
He took his .38-caliber off-duty revolver from a safe and sometime in the next three hours, police officials said, sat down in his high-backed executive's chair and killed himself with a single shot to the right temple.


Strong Quake in Aleutians
LEAD: A strong earthquake occurred this morning near the far western end of the Aleutian Islands, the United States Geological Survey said.
It was centered in the Pacific Ocean, about 130 miles south of Shemya Island, and was felt slightly on Shemya.
The quake registered 6.1 on the Richter scale.

LEAD: The adultery conviction of a female Air Force officer accused of having an affair with another officer has been set aside by the Air Force Court of Military Review, her civilian lawyer says.

Art: Picasso's 'Demoiselles'
LEAD: ''Les Demoiselles d'Avignon,'' the 1907 masterpiece that liberated the savage genius of Pablo Picasso and set the tone for a century of artistic discontinuity and shock, has, for a few months at least, come home.
In an exhibition of around 85 works that is itself ground-breaking, the Picasso Museum has documented the evolution of this complex and convulsive painting and presented it within its artistic context for the first time.

LEAD: As giant banks flounder and regional banks flourish, the turmoil churning the nation's banking system is beginning to show up in the rankings of the nation's largest banking companies.

Canadian Jobless Rate
LEAD: Canada's unemployment rate remained unchanged, at 8.1 percent, in January as the growth in jobs was matched by an increase in the labor force, Statistics Canada reported Friday.
The Government agency said that on a seasonally adjusted basis there were 12,228,000 people employed in January, up 38,000 from December.

Recital: Sylvia Kowalczuk
LEAD: SYLVIA KOWALCZUK'S recital at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday night addressed two problems faced by everyone who plays the harp for a living.
One is to find a consistently strong repertory; the other is to create clear, unambiguous diatonic statements - melodic lines and harmonic progressions capable of penetrating the harp's rainbow of overtones.

LEAD: In an effort to reunify South Korea's divided opposition, Kim Young Sam resigned this morning as president of one of the nation's two main opposition parties.

LEAD: A senior Hong Kong official said Friday that the colony's currency, which is linked to the United States dollar, would not be revalued and he denied that Washington had directly asked the Government to do so.

LEAD: Mayor Richard Flickinger, who guided the passage of what may have been the nation's first municipal ban on pistols, died at his home Monday after a long illness.

27-Year-Old Author Bemused by Success
LEAD: Ethan Canin is 27 years old, a graduate of Stanford and a fourth-year medical student at Harvard.
He is also the author of the just published ''Emperor of the Air,'' a collection of nine short stories.
His work has appeared in The Atlantic, Esquire and Ploughshares, and has been reprinted in ''The Best American Short Stories'' of 1985 and 1986.

LEAD: ONE day not long ago I took our younger daughter, Jamie, who is 8 years old, out to the backyard to run.
I set up a course and asked her to circle it several times.
An active child, she'd been jogging on and off for a couple of years and began this session with a spirited stride.


Fort Chaffee Journal; From Training Ground to Film Set
LEAD: A visit to this nearly deserted Army post is a journey back in time, mostly to the grim, early days of World War II.
Since then, Fort Chaffee has been a training camp for American soldiers, jail for German prisoners of war, reception area for Vietnamese refugees and holding camp for Cuban expatriates.

LEAD: United Jersey Banks, Princeton, N.J., has narrowed its search for an ad agency.
Still in the running are three New York shops: Geer, DuBois plus Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos and McCaffrey &amp; McCall.
The previous budget was estimated at more than $2 million.

LEAD: OPEC's oil production fell sharply last month, mainly because of cutbacks by Persian Gulf exporters, including Saudi Arabia, according to the International Energy Agency.

2 Die in Bangladesh Quake
LEAD: At least two people were killed and more than 100 injured Saturday night when a moderate earthquake shook Bangladesh and eastern India.
The Government newspaper Dainik Bangla reported today that the deaths and most of the injuries occurred in the northeastern city of Sylhet.
Walls of houses caved in around Slyhet, cracks opened up in a hospital building containing 500 beds and people ran into the streets in panic, the newspaper said.

Safety of All-Terrain Vehicles
LEAD: The Consumer Product Safety Commission and a Federal district judge are expected to decide soon whether to give final approval to an agreement on the future sale and production of all-terrain vehicles, which have been linked to about 900 deaths over the last five years.
Under the pact, manufacturers have agreed to end production of three-wheel ATV's, but they would be allowed to continue making four-wheel models, which are considered less dangerous.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week are limited to the bill market, starting with today's regular weekly sale of three-month and six-month issues totaling $12.8 billion and ending Thursday with a one-year issue of $9.25 billion.

LEAD: Since white settlers began arriving here 150 years ago, Natal has been known for its magnificent beaches and mountains, its sugar cane and a brand of racial politics as conservative as any in South Africa.
Now some of its leading citizens are promoting a plan for a multiracial government in the province, hoping that it will head off demands for black majority rule.

LEAD: The British Government won't prosecute Northern Ireland police who blocked an investigation of the police shooting in 1982 of seven unarmed men, six of whom died.
Nor will the Attorney General, Sir Patrick Mayhew, publish the report of an inquiry into these shootings.
Thus he seems to confirm a cover-up but won't do anything about it for reasons of ''national security.

LEAD: Mike Moore, the Seattle pitcher who suffered 19 losses last season, has become only the seventh player in the 13-year history of salary arbi-tration to suffer a pay cut in the procedure.

Foreigners Buy Less U.S. Stock
LEAD: Contrary to some projections, foreigners' net purchases of United States stocks fell in 1987 from their 1986 record, an industry group said Friday.


Portugal Cuts Rates
LEAD: Portugal announced on Friday a half-point reduction in interest rates to help ease credit costs and increase investment in one of Western Europe's fastest-growing economies.
The Finance Minister, Miguel Cadilhe, said the cut, the fourth in just over a year, would take effect Monday.
He said the maximum interest rate for all loans would drop to 18 percent while the minimum rate for time deposit savings of between six months and a year would fall to 13.5 percent.

But this month there are not one but two exhibitions dealing with the firm's architecture, proof that McKim, Mead &amp; White continues to possess, more than three-quarters of a century after its leading partners' deaths, nearly mythic status in New York.

Music: Boston Quartet In 4 Composers' Works
LEAD: THREE of the four composers on Sunday afternoon's program by the Boston Composers String Quartet have roots in either jazz or rock-and-roll; yet there was probably no one moment during this Weill Recital Hall event when either element spoke out directly.
The pull of popular culture in all these pieces was, I think, more fundamental than imitation blues, synthesized bop chords or syncopation.

Dassault Plane Order
LEAD: Dassault, the French aerospace company, said Friday that it had won its first export order in more than two years when Jordan agreed to buy 20 Mirage-2000 multi-role combat aircraft.
No exact value was given, but the sale ended a lean period for Avions Marcel Dassault-Breguet Aviation.
The state-controlled company's previous significant sale had been more than two years ago, when India purchased Mirage-2000 aircraft.

LEAD: Dumb.
Deceitful.
Self-defeating.

That doctrine, intended to protect President Reagan's Star Wars dream, prompted senatorial fury over legal treachery.

Music: Schubertiade Ends First Season
LEAD: THE 92d Street Y left Schubert on Sunday afternoon where he has always seemed most comfortable - at home, among friends.
For the final concert in the first season of its projected 10-year-long Schubertiade, the Y presented music of an exclusively intimate nature: not the works composed for the concert stage but pieces written to be heard and performed in an informal, social setting.

For Paperback Industry, Fear of Paper Shortage
LEAD: Fearing a shortage of the paper on which they print their books, publishers of mass-market paperbacks are talking about cutting back print runs on certain books and possibily not printing some books at all.
Smaller paperback houses, by contrast, are scrambling to try to get enough paper to meet their production schedules.

Highly Diverse Forest
LEAD: A new survey by botanists has found that the tropical rain forest of upper Amazonia in Peru may well have the greatest diversity of tree species of any place on earth.
At two study sites near Iquitos, as many as 300 species were identified per hectare, an area equivalent to about two and a half acres.

Dr. Richard Page, 76; Invented a Dental Drill
LEAD: Dr.
Richard Wilson Page, a dental surgeon and inventor who developed the first high-speed dental drill, died of bone cancer last Tuesday at Columbia Memorial Hospital in Hudson, N.Y.
He was 76 years old and lived in Churchtown, N.Y.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing  McKinney and McGrath Win: Tamara McKinney, whose season was interrupted by a broken leg, overtook five others on the second run yesterday to win the women's slalom at the United States Alpine championships at Copper Mountain, Colo.
McKinney, who placed third Saturday in giant slalom in her first competition of the season, said her victory would give her confidence a needed lift heading into the Olympics.

Rig Count Rises Slightly
LEAD: After falling sharply in the previous week, the number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States rebounded somewhat last week, increasing by 22, to a total of 986, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
The rig count had dropped by 62 in the previous week.
This week's total reflects the number of rigs working as of last Friday.

LEAD: You are supposed to be 21 to gamble in an Atlantic City casino, but Kim Cohen started at 15, first with slots, then blackjack. ''My girlfriend said: 'Why waste time on the slots?
Make it faster at blackjack,' '' Kim said.
One day, this friend had 10 minutes to kill before her after-school job - and won $40.

LEAD: A smoky fire broke out shortly before midnight yesterday in a six-story Midtown office building and was still burning out of control at 2:25 A.M. today.
About 135 firemen battled the three-alarm blaze, which began on the fourth floor of the building at 552 Seventh Avenue near 40th Street, fire officials said.

Japan-Pretoria Trade
LEAD: Japan's leading business organization urged member companies today to restrain their trade with South Africa, following a Government plea.
The Federation of Economic Organizations ''asked member firms to voluntarily restrain themselves from trading with South Africa,'' the director, Masaya Miyoshi, said.

Airline Delays Up in December
LEAD: Flight delays increased sharply in December, partly because of harsh weather that disrupted traffic at some of the busiest airports, the Transportation Department said today.


Sleaze Control for City Politics
LEAD: A bill now before the City Council offers a promising antidote to sleaze.
It would establish public financing of city election campaigns, similar to the system used in national Presidential races since 1976.
Today's Council vote on the measure will reverberate in Albany and across the country.

LEAD: An inside Washington brouhaha erupted a few days ago when officials at the Federal Reserve Board let it be known that the Treasury's rather shy and professorial chief economist, Michael R. Darby, had sent a letter to some of the board's governors advising them that they allow interest rates to go down.


McDonald's Test
LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation and Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company are teaming up in a test that offers hamburgers from the fast-food chain at Sears stores.
McDonald's and Sears are trying the idea at a store in Pittsburgh and investigating ''a few other locations,'' Sears told The Chicago Sun-Times.


Administrator For Surrogates Will Resign
LEAD: The Manhattan Public Administrator, whom state officials recently accused of mismanaging the estates of people who die without proper wills, said yesterday that he would resign upon the appointment of a successor.

Market Place; Mutual Fund Investors Wary
LEAD: IN the aftermath of the October market slump, mutual fund investors continue to tread the path of caution.
They are shying away from aggressive stock funds and, in the fixed-income area, they tend to favor bond funds with short maturities.

Edward S. Tauber, a psychiatrist and writer, misstated the date of his death.
Dr.

Stake Is Increased In Postal Instant
LEAD: A New York insurance holding company, the Orion Capital Corporation, has raised its stake in Postal Instant Press Inc. to 12.7 percent and might increase its stake ''to 20 percent or more.'' The move could revive a takeover battle between Postal Instant Press and the Kane-Miller Corporation.


Advertising; Marketers Prepare for Cup Races
LEAD: Dennis Conner and his crew are not the only ones scrambling to get ready for the America's Cup races to be held off Long Beach, Calif., in September, three years earlier than the defenders had planned.


Six Climbers Die in Britain
LEAD: Rescuers today found the bodies of two mountain climbers lost in a blizzard in Wales, bringing to six the number of climbers killed in weekend accidents.
Air force and volunteer teams found the bodies in northern Wales, one in Snowdonia's Ogwen Valley and the other in the Garn area of the mountains.


2 Admit to Arson to Fight Drugs
LEAD: Two men upset over drug trafficking in their neighborhood admit they have set fires to drive out crack dealers.
They say it has worked.


Dole Wins in Iowa, With Robertson Next
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas won a clear victory in the Iowa Republican caucuses tonight, and Pat Robertson, the former television evangelist, pushed Vice President Bush into third place.


Tickets to Michael Jackson Concerts Sell Out in 4 Hours
LEAD: Prospective concertgoers outside Madison Square Garden to obtain tickets for the Michael Jackson concerts on March 5 and 6.
Tickets sold out in four hours after a lottery was held to see who could purchase them. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)


Korean Surplus Grows
LEAD: Helped by rising exports and increased tourism, South Korea's current account surplus reached $9.8 billion in 1987, Bank of Korea officials said today.
The current account, which includes trade in goods and services, was up sharply from $4.6 billion in 1986, officials of the central bank said.
The December current account surplus widened to $942 million, from $857 million in November and $478 million in December 1986.

As Hems Dither, Pants March On
LEAD: Pants, including pants suits, are on the march.

Last month in Paris, couture designers, who never paid much attention to trouser fashions even in their heyday in the 1970's, gave them a surprisingly strong place in their spring and summer collections.

Samaranch Blasts Drugs and Boycotts
LEAD: The 93d session of the International Olympic Committee opened today with Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, strongly criticizing athletes who cheat by using drugs and nations that cheat their athletes by boycotting the Olympics.


Stunning Result Carries a Grim Message for Bush
LEAD: Iowa produced a stunning Republican result tonight, one that promised to alter dramatically the course of the 1988 Presidential campaign.
A surprisingly feeble showing by Vice President Bush raised insistent questions about his chances of winning the nomination, even though almost every major politician had been decribing him for months as the favorite.


Baker Proposes a 'Club' of Free-Trading Nations
LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d threatened today to form a club of free-trading countries that would keep out nations that do not reduce their barriers to imports.

LEAD: Matt Guokas, who stepped out of the broadcast booth of the Philadelphia 76ers on June 1, 1985, to succeed Billy Cunningham as the coach of the team, was dismissed yesterday.

Air Decontrol Benefits Cited
LEAD: Airline deregulation has lowered fares, saving consumers $100 billion, the Federal Trade Commission said in a report issued today.
The number of airline passengers increased 50 percent between 1978 and 1986.

Jersey Agriculture
LEAD: The New Jersey Department of Agriculture has retained Gillespie Advertising, Princeton, N.J., as its agency of record after a five-way review of local agencies lasting three months.
The budget is $1 million.
Gillespie, which created the ''Jersey Fresh'' slogan for the department's first major campaign, was initially chosen to handle the account four years ago.

LEAD: A group led by Sumner M. Redstone, the owner of Viacom International Inc., said yesterday that it had asked Federal antitrust regulators for clearance to increase its stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation.

The Stage: Five One-Act Comedies
LEAD: IN Mary Gallagher's one-act play, ''Perfect,'' two single women compare notes on prospective mates.
Mary Testa (an actress not averse to mugging) has found a man who is her match in every department, with the possible exception of politics.
As she confides to her friend, the appealing Janet Zarish, ''I will not sleep with anybody who voted for him.


American Perfects 'Ultimate Sledding'
LEAD: There are not many people who enjoy swooshing down a mountain at approximately 80 miles per hour, on their backs, no less.
Most of those who do enjoy it live in Europe.
But who can blame Americans for disdaining the luge?
If 80 m.p.h. is considered speeding on a highway, what must it feel like to go that fast on a small sled, feet dangling, in a posture more conducive to sleeping?

LEAD: Marghanita Laski, a novelist, critic and prolific amateur lexicographer, died Saturday, according to her family.
She was 72 years old.

LEAD: Salomon Inc., the parent of one of Wall Street's largest securities firms, announced late yesterday that it lost $74 million in the fourth quarter because of trading losses stemming from the stock market collapse and a series of moves to restructure its troubled operations.

LEAD: THERE was wonderment, not to mention a dash of skepticism, in some financial circles when the Dun &amp; Bradstreet Corporation announced Sunday that it was buying I.M.S.
International, a medium-sized company that collects and sells facts about the drug industry.
Why, some people wanted to know, would Dun &amp; Bradstreet, the big information services company, agree to exchange more than $1.5 billion in stock for I.M.S., which had estimated earnings in 1987 of less than $45 million?

Monday night, Iowans sent forth two official winners, Bob Dole and Richard Gephardt; a loser who seemed to win by placing, Pat Robertson; and a loser nobody was calling a winner, Vice President Bush.

LEAD: A prisoner serving a 30-year term for embezzlement has been accused of tampering with computer records at the State Penitentiary, allowing him to sell about 100,000 pounds of cotton and possibly to seek early release.


10 Accused of Commodity Schemes
LEAD: In a renewed crackdown on commodity fraud, 10 people were charged today with taking part in illegal trading schemes at the Chicago Board of Trade, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange.


Film and TV Programs Included in Arts Festival
LEAD: Experimental film making and the performing arts are the influences most strongly reflected in the film and television programming of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, officially announced today.
The festival's attention to Hollywood film making and to television qua television, on the other hand, is considerably less intense.


Canada Trade Accord Draws Fire in House
LEAD: The Reagan Administration today asked Congress to ratify a free-trade pact with Canada, saying it would provide a huge improvement in overall access for American companies in the Canadian market.
Not to ratify, it added, would be thinking small.

Court Rejects Arson Liability
LEAD: A service-station chain cannot be held liable for damages occurring when arsonists used gasoline bought at one of its stations to set a fire that killed 25 people at a social club in the South Bronx, the state's highest court said today.


Westminster Show; Pomeranian Takes Top Dog Ribbon
LEAD: The smallest dog in the ring, a four-and-a-half-pound Pomeranian, scored the biggest victory of his career last night when he was selected by Michele Billings as the best of 2,651 dogs at the 112th annual Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden.


Charleston May Acquire Ancient Oak
LEAD: Charleston, S.C., is within its rights to acquire a tree estimated to be 1,511 years old, according to the State Attorney General's office.
Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. has proposed that the city use its condemnation powers to acquire the tree and land around it for a park.
However, S. E. (Speedy) Felkel, who has owned the tree since 1963, says it's not for sale and that he'll go to court if the city tries to seize it.

LEAD: Times Mirror Magazines has formed two publishing groups for its eight magazines, naming Robert Beauregard, 48 years old, and John Crawley, 42, as group publishers.
Mr.
Beauregard, previously a senior vice president at J. Walter Thompson, will oversee Golf magazine and Ski magazine, as well as Skiing and Yachting magazines.

LEAD: Clement G. Hurd, illustrator of ''Goodnight Moon'' and almost 100 other books for children, died last Friday in a convalescent hospital in San Francisco.

The Editorial Notebook; The Hazards of Arms Control
LEAD: What did the rise of Japanese militarism 60 years ago and the German pocket battleships of World War II have in common?
Both may have been fostered by the major arms control agreements of the interwar years.
With Mikhail Gorbachev pressing new treaties on the White House, the pitfalls of past attempts to control weapons are worth trying to avoid.


U.S. Opposes Job Equality Bill
LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that it opposes a House bill that would require Federal agencies to document their efforts to comply with equal employment laws.

Ambrose Nugent, 78, Korean War Prisoner
LEAD: Lieut.
Col.

California's High Court Broadens Use of Illegally Obtained Evidence
LEAD: The California Supreme Court has ruled that statements by suspects that were illegally obtained by the police may be admitted as evidence if the suspects choose to testify at their trial.
The decision upset longstanding rules barring the use of illegally seized evidence in criminal trials in the state.

McKesson Sale Of Stationer
LEAD: The McKesson Corporation plans to divest itself of its unprofitable office products operation.
McKesson said on Monday that it had agreed to combine the unit with the Stationers Distributing Company Inc. of Fort Worth, a wholly owned subsidiary of the privately held SDC Corporation, exchanging inventory and certain other assets in return for a 20 percent equity interest in the combined operation.


Director of San Francisco Opera Resigns
LEAD: Terence A. McEwen, general director of the San Francisco Opera since 1982, resigned yesterday afternoon.
The announcement was made at a news conference in San Francisco by Tully M. Friedman, president of the San Francisco Opera Association.

Jersey Man Accused of Rape and Quackery
LEAD: A 63-year-old New Jersey man was arrested at his Bronx office yesterday afternoon and charged with rape, sodomy and unlawfully practicing dentistry, the police said.


Sports People; Undisputed Marriage
LEAD: Mike Tyson, the undisputed heavyweight champion, was married again yesterday, and this time he was licensed.
The 21-year-old fighter and the actress Robin Givens, 23, were married by the Rev.
George Clements Sunday in Chicago, but the couple did not have an Illinois license. ''In Chicago he grabbed me and said lets get married,'' Givens said last night in New York.


Little Change Reported in Prices
LEAD: A steep late-afternoon drop in the overnight rate for bank loans yesterday kept alive suspicions that the Federal Reserve might be encouraging lower short-term interest rates.
But those suspicions caused little change in prices or in rates, partly because interest rates have already fallen sharply in the last month.


Martha Graham at Work After Hospitalization
LEAD: Martha Graham has returned to work after being hospitalized for 10 days at New York Hospital for dizziness and exhaustion.
Miss Graham began work Sunday with her company on new choreography for her ''Persephone,'' on the reconstruction of her 1937 ''Deep Song,'' and preparations for a tour of Holland, Poland and Czechoslovakia in April.


Ashton-Tate's New Products
LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Corporation, the third-largest personal computer software company, will initiate a thrust into the market for Macintosh software Wednesday.
That market is dominated by its rival, the Microsoft Corporation.

Advances; A Bicycle Easy to Ride, Hard to Sell
LEAD: FOR more than a century, people have been propelling bicycles by pushing pedals round and round so that a gear turns a chain connected to a wheel.
This system is, to say the least, an example of an entrenched technology, something that works well and that most people see no need to change.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Friday about Iraq's denial that it had sought Israeli guarantees in talks on an oil pipeline misstated the relationship between the Bechtel Group and E. Robert Wallach, a San Francisco lawyer.
Mr.
Wallach had a financial interest in the project, but there is no evidence that Bechtel entrusted him with obtaining Israeli guarantees.

Advertising; Sherwood &amp; Schneider
LEAD: After a three-way review, Curtain Country, a bed and bath retail chain of 33 stores in six states, has awarded its $2 million business to Sherwood &amp; Schneider Advertising.
The agency will focus on newspaper advertising, as well as the yearly production of 7.5 million circulars.
Previous advertising was handled in-house.


TV Reviews; Lanford Wilson's 'Lemon Sky,' on Channel 13
LEAD: LANFORD WILSON'S ''Lemon Sky,'' heavily autobiographical, was first produced for the stage in 1970.
Christopher Walken and Charles Durning played the father-and-son leads.
I saw that production, which had a very brief run on Broadway, and found it a good deal less than memorable.
Now, after having had a successful revival in 1985, ''Lemon Sky'' is an ''American PLayhouse'' presentation on Channel 13 tonight at 9, and it's terrific.


Japanese Are Expected to Bid for California's Union Bank
LEAD: Japanese banks without a foothold in California are the most likely suitors of Union Bank, the state's fifth-largest bank, industry analysts said today.


Goalie Gets Vengeance In Beanpot Tournament
LEAD: It is wonderful to win.
But it is even better to get even, according to Bruce Racine, the victorious goalie as Northeastern demolished Boston University, 6-3, to capture the 36th Beanpot Tournament, this city's annual college hockey gala.


Blanche Lasker, Principal, 79
LEAD: Blanche Lasker, a retired principal in School District 10 in the Bronx, died of cancer Sunday in the Tally Ho Manor in Boonton, N.J., where she lived.
She was 79 years old.

The Shallowness of the Campaign
LEAD: Mr.
Robertson's performance cannot readily be explained just by his own strength.
It's unlikely that a relative unknown could bring in enough supporters to score so well against the Vice President unless Mr.
Bush's own support were shallow.
In the shadow of the Iran-contra crisis, the Reagan record is a hard one for someone else to ride.


Education; Lessons
LEAD: If education and discipline really begin at home, then certain failures of our age - the decline of learning, the disorder of the classroom and the scourge of drugs in schools - must first be fixed where they belong, at the warm spot by the hearth.


Jury Rules ABC Documentary Did Not Libel Conservative Author
LEAD: Victor Lasky, a conservative author, lost his libel case yesterday when a jury rejected his charge that an ABC television documentary had portrayed him falsely.


The House of Lords Seats Its First Rabbi
LEAD: Immanuel Jakobovits, the Chief Rabbi of the United Hebrew Congregation and of the Commonwealth, in the robing room of the House of Lords with Lord Young.
He swore an oath of loyalty under his new title, Lord Jakobovits, Baron of Regent's Park, to become the first rabbi to sit in the House of Lords.


Bridge: Top Players Are More Likely To Use a Strong Club System
LEAD: The higher one looks in the hierarchy of tournament players, the greater the frequency of strong club systems, with a corresponding diminution of standard methods.


Education; S.A.T. Coaching Disparaged
LEAD: The admissions director at Harvard said today that a new study suggested that special classes to improve scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test might not be effective.


Soviet Withdrawal Offer Raises Stakes for an Afghan Compromise
LEAD: The Soviet offer to start withdrawing from Afghanistan in May is putting new pressure on the other parties in the civil war to reach a compromise peace settlement next month, according to officials involved in the United Nations effort for a settlement and other experts on the conflict.

LEAD: West Germany and its principal NATO partners are heading for a confrontation over the alliance's commitment to replace an aging short-range missile system, Western diplomats and German politicians say.

Texaco Data Plea Denied
LEAD: Federal District Judge Charles L. Brieant yesterday denied a request that Texaco Inc. be required to add more information to the description of its bankruptcy reorganization plan that it is mailing to the 230,000 shareholders who will vote on it.


Fire Kills 4 of 21 Living in Rockland House
LEAD: Firefighters standing in front of a frame house gutted by flames early yesterday morning in Spring Valley, N.Y.
Authorities said that 4 of the 21 or more Haitian immigrants who lived there were killed and nine others were injured.
Beds and cots were found in the attic and basement in violation of building code provisions, officials said.

Citicorp Rates Fall
LEAD: Interest rates fell yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper.
The bank holding company said it sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 6.431 percent, down from 6.61 percent last week.
Another $50 million of 182-day paper was sold at an average rate of 6.4306, down from 6.635 percent.


Sympathy for the Homeless Expressed in Gifts to Neediest
LEAD: Vivian Rivkin Friedman and her husband, Sidney, a native of South Carolina, met and fell in love in New York City and say, ''The city has been good to us.'' Both professionals, they bought a home here, had a child and plan to stay.


DE GUSTIBUS
LEAD: THE Occidental Restaurant in Washington, a landmark that opened in 1906, provided the ultimate culinary nostalgia trip down an American memory lane last Sunday.
The food would have been of interest to ardent historical cooking buffs, but a little nostalgia goes a long way.


Israel Nathan Herstein, Mathematician, 64
LEAD: Israel Nathan Herstein, a leading mathematician and educator at the University of Chicago, died of cancer Monday night at his home in Chicago.
He was 64 years old.
Dr.
Herstein was the author of the widely used textbook ''Topics in Algebra.'' His own work included pioneering advances in the theory of rings, an algebraic system.


Baseball Teams Win Arbitration Round
LEAD: Club owners gained a significant double-barreled victory yesterday when two arbitrators selected the clubs' salaries over those submitted by two noted relief pitchers, Tom Henke of Toronto and John Franco of Cincinnati.
The outcomes had instant ramifications for salary arbitration cases involving three other relievers.


Panamanian Charges Cover-Up in Killing
LEAD: Jose I. Blandon, a former aide to Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's de facto leader, testifying yesterday before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee in Washington.
Mr.
Blandon testified that a Central Intelligence Agency official was involved in a cover-up of the 1985 murder of a political opponent of General Noriega.


Pete C. Sianis, Hanoi Raids' Planner, 68
LEAD: Maj.
Gen.
Pete C. Sianis, retired, an Air Force officer who planned devastating B-52 bombing raids on North Vietnam, died Saturday after a long illness.
He was 68 years old and lived in Bellevue.


Royalty Rides the Bobsled
LEAD: What makes Albert Grimaldi, the Prince of Monaco, unique among the 87 members of the International Olympic Committee is not his royal bearing.
There are several other members of ruling families in the group, including Princess Nora of Liechtenstein and Sheik Fahad al-Ahmad al-Sabah of Kuwait.

LEAD: Hazard Earl Reeves 3d, an executive in the real estate and communications industries, died of heart failure Jan. 30 in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 51 years old and lived in Monroe, Conn.
