LEAD: *
Affiliated Publications Inc., Boston, said its McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. affiliate had agreed to acquire privately held McCaw Communications Cos. for about 11.5 million class B common shares.

LEAD: The Republic National Bank of New York is offering $100 million of 9 percent notes, due in 1998, at a price of 99.35 to yield 9.10 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.


Dart Raises Bid To $37 a Share
LEAD: The Dart Group Corporation said it had increased its cash tender offer for the Stop and Shop Companies to $37 a share, from $31, in a move Wall Street investors said was designed to increase pressure on the company's directors.

Times Mirror Net Off; Washington Post Up
LEAD: The Times Mirror Company, publisher of The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, yesterday reported a 45 percent drop in fourth-quarter income.
Meanwhile, the Washington Post Company reported a 77.4 percent improvement.


Slow Gasoline Leak Rattles Nerves on L.I.
LEAD: On Robin Hood Lane today, residents anxiously traded news about an 800,000-gallon gasoline leak oozing underground toward their homes.


Union Leader Rejects Concessions Sought by Post
LEAD: New York City's top newspaper union leader said yesterday that the unions at the New York Post would ''absolutely not'' meet Rupert Murdoch's demand that they grant $24 million in concessions by Feb. 19.
Without the cuts, Mr.
Murdoch said, he will shut down the paper.

Cleveland-Cliffs
LEAD: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., an iron-ore supplier based in Cleveland, said it would spin off to its shareholders its 4.1 million shares in the MLX Corporation of Troy, Mich., a 26 percent holding valued at $12.8 million, based on Monday's closing price.
This would amount to a one-time special dividend of about 78 cents for every share of Cleveland-Cliffs, the company said.


The Inglefinger Rule
LEAD: To the Editor:


Education; Volunteers In Dual Role On Campus
LEAD: Between tomorrow's term paper and yesterday's social gathering, somewhere within the harried run of events that make up ''the college experience,'' more and more students are likely to be found working in soup kitchens or in other public service jobs but pursuing apparently different goals.


Memorial for Kleban
LEAD: A memorial tribute to Edward Kleban, the lyricist for ''A Chorus Line,'' will be held at 12:30 P.M. tomorrow in the Susan Anspacher Theater at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.
Mr.
Kleban died in December at the age of 48.
Among the speakers are to be Betty Buckley, Bob Balaban, Avery Corman, Marvin Hamlisch, Sheldon Harnick, Priscilla Lopez, Peter Stone and Wendy Wasserstein.


High-Tech Executive Signs On With Priam
LEAD: The Priam Corporation, a struggling producer of disk drives based in San Jose, Calif., said yesterday that John V. Titsworth had been appointed president and chief executive.
For Mr.
Titsworth, who worked at the Control Data Corporation and the Xerox Corporation, the move is a return to management of a high-tech manufacturing concern after several years in venture capital.

LEAD: SALMON seems to maintain its freshness better than any other fish.

Sports People; Cutting Ties
LEAD: According to a message sent by Zola Budd to a friend and adviser in Johannesburg, the South Africa-born running star, a target of protesters whenever she competes because of her strong identification with the apartheid nation, has broken her allegiances to her native country and will return there only to see her family at Christmas.

LEAD: What many people here consider the fertile core of the Central Kingdom, the sanctum of Chinese civilization, is suddenly endangered.

LEAD: In an effort to avoid a delay in Senate action on the new missile treaty, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has prepared a letter to Senate Democratic leaders responding to their concerns on the key issue of how treaties are made and interpreted, Administration officials said tonight.

LEAD: After missing practice without permission last week, Michael Porter, St.
John's 6-foot-1-inch junior guard, was held out of the starting lineup in the Redmen's 80-76 loss to Boston College at Alumni Hall Monday night.
Steve Shurina replaced him.

LEAD: Some regional Bell telephone companies had access to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's secret bid price for Government telephone switch contracts and may have shared the information and used it to calculate competing bids, an official of one regional phone company said yesterday.

Concert: String Music From Ottoman Court
LEAD: NEW YORK has a voracious appetite for music from beyond the mainstream, whether it be from Cajun Louisiana or Anatolia.
This creates a performance problem.
Shows featuring functional music - music for weddings, for dancing or for rituals -don't have a context, and they can become museum exhibits, disemboweled parts of a culture, tough to make sense of.

LEAD: The New England Journal of Medicine has suspended prepublication delivery of its weekly magazine to the British news service Reuters for six months, saying the agency broke an agreement on how soon it could release information from the journal.

FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Itel Corporation is offering $175 million of 12 5/8 percent senior subordinated notes, due in 1998, at a price of 99.303 to yield about 12.75 percent, through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.


Week's Steel Output Off
LEAD: Steel production fell 3.3 percent last week, to 1.88 million tons, from the previous week's 1.94 million tons, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
The output equaled 87.3 percent of capacity, down from 90.3 percent.
Production so far this year totals 9.83 million tons, up 39.1 percent from 7.07 million tons a year earlier.


2 Suitors May Unite in Belgian Battle
LEAD: Andre Leysen of Belgium and Carlo de Benedetti of Italy announced tonight that they were considering joining forces for the ''effective management'' of Societe Generale de Belgique, providing a new twist in the three-week wrangle for control of Belgium's largest and most important company.

Recital: Marian Thompson
LEAD: IN Merkin Concert Hall Sunday evening, Marian Thompson gave an honest, devoted and unaffected performance of Schubert's master work in song, ''Die Winterreise.'' She did not sing any of the 24 songs in an unusual or surprising way, nor did any of them seem to slip through her without contact, as happens when temperamentally unsuited artists essay the work.


U.S. Bond Prices Up a Half-Point
LEAD: Treasury bond prices rose about a half-point yesterday, while interest rates were little changed on short-term bills.


Workshop Opens Doors In Directing for Women
LEAD: For 10 years Randa Haines worked as a script supervisor on other people's movies - all of them directed by men.
Then she heard about Directing Workshop for Women, sponsored by the American Film Institute.
She applied, was accepted, directed her own project for the workshop and began a new career, going on to win an Academy Award nomination as best director for ''Children of a Lesser God.

Jazz: Bill Frisell Quartet
LEAD: BILL FRISELL'S music dances on quicksand.
Nothing is solid or dependable; his guitar notes slide off the beat, his tone mutates from glassy clarity to echoes and noisy distortion.
His better pieces are equally unstable; they start out as country tunes or boppish jazz lines, only to add extra beats or dissolve to new tempos partway through.

LEAD: Dwight Gooden announced yesterday that he would give $1,000 to a children's hospital every time he pitched a victory for the Mets this season.
He will select a hospital in each city in the National League and make a donation wherever he wins.
He opened the program by giving $1,000 to the All-Children's Hospital in St.

Eaton Profits Fall 44.9%
LEAD: The Eaton Corporation, a manufacturer of vehicle components and electronic equipment, said today that it earned $25.8 million, or 97 cents a share, in the final quarter, down 44.9 percent from $46.8 million, or $1.53 a share, in the final three months of 1986.
In October, Eaton announced it would sell its military electronics business, and from that point it accounted for that segment's performance as a discontinued operation.

2 Senate Democrats End Threat to Delay Pact
LEAD: Two Senate Democratic leaders announced today that they were dropping their threat to delay hearings on the new missile treaty with the Soviet Union after receiving a letter from Secretary of State George P. Shultz addressing their concerns about how treaties are made and interpreted.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Horse Racing  Wind Chill Wins: Wind Chill fought off an early challenge by Derby Wish and drew away through the stretch to score a 6 1/2-length victory in the $47,000 allowance feature yesterday at Aqueduct.
Ridden by Chris Antley, Wind Chill carried 115 pounds over 1 mile 70 yards on the fast track in 1:44 3/5 to earn $28,200 for his owner, Topofthepines Farm.


Concert: Quartet From Duke
LEAD: AT the end of the slow movement in Beethoven's ''Harp'' Quartet (Op. 74), there are a series of short, delicate phrases separated by rests - nothing out of the ordinary but the sort of telltale gestures that require from the players a difficult blend of precision and grace.
To make this passage really glow, which is what the Ciompi Quartet accomplished on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, it takes more: a genuine warmth of expression and an effortless sense of coordination among the musicians.


Assembly Chief Leads Attack on Koch
LEAD: The Speaker of the Assembly, Mel Miller, declaring that Mayor Koch ''has lost all credibility'' in Albany, said today that Assembly Democrats were considering changing the way some state aid to New York City was allocated so the Mayor had less direct control over it.

Airline Traffic Rises
LEAD: Leading United States airlines reported yesterday that the number of passengers they carried in January rose by a surprisingly strong 6 percent - a gain analysts said came at the expense of smaller regional and national carriers.
January is usually a slow month for air travel, according to analysts.

Savings Unit Deposits
LEAD: Deposits at the nation's savings institutions increased in December for the third consecutive month, continuing a trend that began after the October stock plunge, the Government said Tuesday.
Net deposits rose by $2.4 billion in December, after gains of $3.2 billion in November and $6.2 billion in October, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said.

LEAD: Kurt Herbert Adler, a Viennese-born conductor who led the San Francisco Opera for 28 years until his retirement in 1981, died of a heart attack Tuesday evening at his home in Ross, Calif., a suburb north of San Francisco.
He was 82 years old.

Deducting Job Expenses Harder but Still Possible
LEAD: Writing off the cost of a leisurely lunch at the Four Seasons in Manhattan or a night on the town as a business expense is still possible under the new tax law.
So is the cost of hunting for a new job, going to night school or traveling to a midwinter convention in balmy Palm Beach, Fla. - provided a good business connection can be shown.

LEAD: William E. Woodman, a retired insurance executive, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Fort Myers, Fla.
He was 68 years old and also lived in Short Hills, N.J.

A Purged Chinese Intellectual Derides Talk of Liberalization
LEAD: China's most prominent dissident intellectual, breaking an imposed silence, today assailed harsh political controls on university students and teachers.


Terra Cotta On Exhibit And as Part Of the City
LEAD: TERRA cotta, the fireproof and durable baked clay material that has ornamented many of New York's most famous facades, is making a comeback.
No longer restricted to gargoyles and Art Deco swirls, it has captured the interest of contemporary urban artists and architects, who see it as a pliable, practical building material that can still respond to an artist's imagination.

Expansion Backed At Freddie Mac
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation's board yesterday authorized the quasi-governmental agency, known as Freddie Mac, to broaden the variety of securities it may issue to include up to $15 billion in real estate mortgage investment conduits and an unidentified amount of interest-only, principal-only securities.

Olympic Notebook; Good Start for Zurbriggen
LEAD: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, the favorite, recorded the fastest time today in the first men's downhill training run for the XV Olympic Winter Games.
Competition in Alpine skiing will start Sunday with the men's downhill.


Museum Show Honors 25 Years of Channel 13
LEAD: The Museum of Broadcasting at 1 East 53d Street will mark the 25th anniversary of WNET starting tomorrow, with a three-month survey of distinguished programs that have been seen on the public television station since its inception.

EVANS'S 20 ASSISTS LEAD TEMPLE, 98-86
LEAD: Mark Macon, a freshman guard, scored a season-high 31 points and Howard Evans, the senior playmaker, had 15 points and a school-record 20 assists tonight to lead No. 1 Temple to a 98-86 rout of Villanova.


Holiday Weekend
LEAD: Tomorrow is Lincoln's Birthday; Washington's Birthday is observed Monday.
Following are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Parade: Monday, begins 9:15 A.M. at 35th St. and heads north on 5th Ave. to St.
Patrick's Cathedral.
Parking: Alternate-side rules are suspended tomorrow and Monday.


Jazz: Shearing Trio
LEAD: SINCE George Shearing gave up playing with a quintet 10 years ago, he has been performing in a duo with a bassist.
However, as part of his annual three-month stand in the Cafe Carlyle, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, he has enlarged his group to a trio for the month of February.


U.S. Says Schiff Was Mastermind of $40 Million in Fraud Schemes
LEAD: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that Irwin Schiff, a wealthy businessman who was slain in a Manhattan restaurant last summer, was the mastermind of a series of fraudulent financial transactions believed to total about $40 million.

U.S. FINDS 6 STATES FAIL TO MEET GOALS IN DESEGREGATION
LEAD: The Education Department said today that six Southern and border states were still in partial violation of a 17-year-old court order to rid their public colleges of the effects of segregation.


Stage: 'Mythos Oedipus' at La Mama
LEAD: ELLEN STEWART goes behind and beyond Sophocles in ''Mythos Oedipus.'' Gods, monsters, seers and appalling freaks of nature only mentioned in choruses by Sophocles inhabit the world of what Miss Stewart calls her ''dance-opera,'' being given its American premiere by the Great Jones Repertory Company at the La Mama Annex (it was first presented in Delphi and two other Greek locations in 1985).


Parole Scheduled for Convict In Tylenol Extortion Scheme
LEAD: An imprisoned tax accountant who plotted to extort $1 million from the manufacturer of Tylenol after seven people were killed here by cyanide-filled Tylenol capsules will be paroled in August 1989 if he stays out of trouble, a Federal official says.

Kuwait B.P. Stake
LEAD: The Kuwait Investment Office announced it had further increased its stake in the British Petroleum Company to 19.27 percent from 19.24 percent.
The London-based investment arm of the Kuwaiti Government said it had bought another two million partly paid shares on Tuesday.
It did not disclose the purchase price.


Gore Asks U.S. for Ruling On Foes' Spending for TV
LEAD: Questioning the practices of two rivals, Senator Albert Gore Jr.'s Presidential campaign today asked the Federal Election Commission to rule on the legitimacy of skirting state spending limits by counting television advertisements as fund-raising expenses.


Today's Bathrooms With Yesterday's Elegance
LEAD: OUT of America's fascination with all things antique has grown a market for bygone bathroom styles that is bringing back the pedestal sink, the ornate ceramic toilet and the claw-foot tub.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Washington Talk page Tuesday, about Senator Bill Bradley and his vote against aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, misidentified the only non-Southern state with a Democratic Senator who voted for the aid.
The state was Nebraska, not Kansas.
Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the year in which Senator Bradley began his support of the aid.


Beyond Needles: the AIDS War
LEAD: Imagine Sam, a heroin addict: His habit is up to $100 a day - he's dropped out of community college and started stealing cars full time.
But that's the least of it.
Now his girlfriend has begun to hassle him about AIDS.
She's plainly terrified that he might get the disease from one of the junkies with whom he shoots up, passing needles around.

South Africa Quells Coup Attempt in a Homeland
LEAD: The South African Government sent troops into a nominally independent black homeland today and reinstated its leader 15 hours after he was ousted in a military coup.


New Opera Seasons Announced
LEAD: New York's two major opera companies announced their new seasons yesterday.
The Metropolitan Opera will present five new productions in an extended 32-week 1988-89 season, one of them a double bill, as well as three complete cycles of its new production of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen.''


American Cellular Deal
LEAD: The Comcast Corporation, a fast-growing operator of cable television systems, said yesterday that it would break into the cellular telephone business with the acquisition of the American Cellular Network Corporation for $230 million.

Itinerant Painter Only Does Ceilings
LEAD: THE itinerant ceiling painter Larry Boyce has arrived in New York City after clocking 8,600 miles across the Canadian Rockies on his bicycle.
Mr.
Boyce may be identified by his zebra-striped tights and his tendency to color-coordinate his clothes with his ceilings.


BOBSLEDDER REGAINS BACKUP POSITION
LEAD: He received encouraging news from his attorney in Boston this morning and immediately began packing for his trip to the Winter Olympics.
Although the issue has not been officially resolved, Donald LaVigne will be rejoining his teammates on the United States bobsled team, fulfilling a goal he set a year ago when he decided to take a year off from Harvard to pursue his


A Furnished Apartment Is a Start for a Homeless Family
LEAD: ''IT looks like we went out and bought the furniture,'' said Edwin DeLeon, still in shock six weeks after opening the door to his new apartment and finding it furnished like a Seaman's showroom. ''It was exactly what we had in mind.''


Art Gallery Raid Involved Daring Acrobatics
LEAD: The thieves who took $6 million in paintings and drawings from a New York City art gallery this week carried out ''a very daring raid,'' lowering themselves from a skylight in an acrobatic rope manuever in which one slip could have sent them plunging down a four-story stairwell, a top police investigator said yesterday.


Weakened Pistons Turn Back Knicks
LEAD: Joe Dumars, the subject of trade rumors, scored 12 of his 18 points in the third quarter tonight, leading the Detroit Pistons to a 98-87 victory over the Knicks.
The loss was the Knicks' 16th straight on the road.

First Executive
LEAD: The First Executive Corporation said that a Delaware state court had refused to halt a tender offer for First Executive shares from the ICH Corporation, an action sought by two shareholders as part of a lawsuit.
The suit seeks to overturn a standstill agreement between the Los Angeles-based insurer and ICH, of Louisville, Ky.


Temple Vandal Sentenced
LEAD: The son of a Russian Orthodox priest was sentenced today to five years probation for spray-painting swastikas and anti-Semitic slogans on a synagogue, Temple Beth Shalom, in Mahopac last November.
The youth, Andrei Federoff, 17 years old, of Mahopac, was also ordered to pay damages, get counseling and do community service.


Man Gets Prison Term in Bid To Send Metals to Pakistan
LEAD: A man convicted of trying to export to Pakistan special metals used in making nuclear bombs was sentenced today to five years in prison.


Bill Controlling Campaign Gifts Could Affect 3
LEAD: A substantial majority of the campaign money raised by Mayor Koch and two other officials in 1985 would have been barred under a bill passed by the City Council Tuesday, according to Board of Elections records and politicians familiar with the campaigns.


Mark D. Soroko, Corporate Executive, 87
LEAD: Mark D. Soroko, a retired senior vice president and board member of Revlon Inc., died of heart failure Saturday at St.
Francis Hospital in Miami.
He was 87 years old and lived in Bal Harbor, Fla.


Syracuse Wins The Showdown
LEAD: A crowd of 16,798 packed the Civic Arena tonight to watch the Big East's two best teams duel in a conference showdown.
Pro basketball scouts came in droves to see four of the nation's best big men: Charles Smith and Jerome Lane for Pitt, Rony Seikaly and Derrick Coleman for Syracuse.

U.A.W. Action Set On Chrysler Unit
LEAD: The United Automobile Workers union said it would oppose the sale of the Chrysler Corporation's Accustar subsidiary and would take action to try to prevent any sale, including seeking a meeting with Chrysler executives and demonstrating in front of Chrysler headquarters.


Italy's Government Falls After Budget Defeats
LEAD: Prime Minister Giovanni Goria resigned today after six months as head of Italy's 47th postwar Government, a coalition battered by political infighting and a hostile Parliament.


Commuter Plane Crashes
LEAD: A commuter plane on a training flight crashed near Springfield Municipal Airport on Tuesday, killing three people, the State Highway Patrol said.
Officials said the Piedmont Airlines plane was practicing takeoffs and landings at the airport when it crashed about 3 P.M.

LEAD: It was bound to happen.


A Shift in Third World Funds' Flow
LEAD: The world's poorest and most indebted countries are beginning to get less in combined aid each year from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund than they are paying in interest and principal on outstanding debt to the two organizations, an analysis has disclosed.

NASA May Replace 72 Bolts in Nozzles Of Shuttle Boosters
LEAD: The space agency and Morton Thiokol Inc., the rocket manufacturer, are debating whether they must replace 72 bolts inside the nozzle of each space shuttle booster rocket as a safety measure.


Remains of 6 Vietnam War Fliers Identified
LEAD: Six sets of remains, including one returned two and a half years ago, have been positively identified as Navy and Air Force fliers missing from the Vietnam War, the Pentagon said Tuesday.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.We put down new carpet in our entrance hall with a thick pad beneath it.
The bottom of the front door had to be trimmed slightly to clear the carpet, and now on windy days we get cold drafts under the door.
I can't put regular weatherstripping along the bottom of the door because it won't clear the carpet.

LEAD: A former translator of Chinese for the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been arrested and indicted on a charge of providing classified information to the Government of Taiwan, the bureau announced today.

LEAD: In an unusual effort to calm investors' fears about the options market, the American Stock Exchange said yesterday that as much as $1 million would be refunded to some customers who traded stock index options on Oct. 20.

LEAD: Two men who held 19 people hostage at a newspaper office last week to dramatize complaints of discrimination and public corruption have been indicted on weapons and hostage-taking charges.

LEAD: Federal officials said today that they had found three more plants where a widely used industrial device leaked tiny particles of radioactive polonium, but added, ''So far we've seen nothing that would pose a threat to public health.''

Talks on Dana Unit
LEAD: Robert Bosch G.m.b.H., a privately held manufacturer of electrical appliances and auto parts, said that it was negotiating the acquisition of the Racine Hydraulics division from the Dana Corporation, based in Toledo, Ohio.
The German company said in a statement that its Robert Bosch Corporation unit in Broadview, Ill., was holding talks with Dana representatives.


Michael Jackson and U2 Share British Awards
LEAD: Michael Jackson, Britain's George Michael and the Irish group U2 have won the British record industry's top 1988 awards.


Quotations of the Day
LEAD: ''Laws that limit the acceptable focus of one's sexual desires to members of the opposite sex, like laws that limit one's choice of spouse (or sexual partner) to members of the same race, cannot withstand constitutional scrutiny absent a compelling governmental justification.'' - Federal Judge William Norris, in a decision overturning the Army's ban on homosexuals.


Critic's Notebook; Decrescendo in the Concert Business
LEAD: THE troubles suffered recently by the Nashville Symphony, which was forced by financial problems to stop performing, come as the latest in an ominous series of setbacks for orchestras around the country.
In the past several months, ensembles in New Orleans, San Diego, Vancouver, Denver, Detroit, Oakland, Calif., and elsewhere have been disbanded, gone on strike over wage cuts or accepted reduced salaries or shortened schedules.


Manhattan Board Rejects Salant Bid
LEAD: Manhattan Industries said that its board had rejected an unsolicited takeover offer from the Salant Corporation.
The apparel maker characterized the $16-a-share offer as inadequate and not in the best interests of its shareholders.
Officials at Salant, also an apparel company, said they had no official comment on the rejection.


Talking Deals; The Hostile Bid Reaches Europe
LEAD: IT can now be said that the hostile bid has arrived in Europe - and in a big way.
Hostile has certainly become the right word since Carlo de Benedetti stirred so much antagonism with his bid to take control of Societe Generale de Belgique.
He has encountered a hostile management, hostile Government, hostile press and hostile citizenry.

LEAD: The Education Department's finding that six Southern and border states had failed to desegregate their higher education systems included a number of steps that the department said were required to bring the systems into compliance.
Following are some of the steps ordered and comments about those state's systems.

LEAD: In the gloomy chamber where the town council convenes, Mayor Jacques Barat-Dupont pointed a stubby finger at the slab bearing the names of Verdun's citizens of honor.
In freshly carved wooden letters stood a surname that stirs pride and shame in France: ''General Petain, victor of Verdun.''

Slave's Daughter, 104
LEAD: Daisy Turner, the daughter of a slave who ran away from a plantation and moved to Vermont after the Civil War, died Monday.
She was 104 years old.


Waldheim Telegram Called Fake
LEAD: The Yugoslav press agency reported today that a document said to link President Kurt Waldheim of Austria to Nazi war crimes was a fake and that a forgery investigation was under way.


HOMOSEXUAL BAN IN ARMY REJECTED BY APPEALS COURT
LEAD: A Federal appeals court in San Francisco struck down the Army's ban on homosexuals yesterday, ruling that homosexuals are entitled to as much protection against discrimination as members of racial minority groups.

LEAD: John Beckwith Madden, a general partner in the private banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman &amp; Company, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Brooklyn Heights.
He was 69 years old and also lived in Christmas Cove, Me.

LEAD: Mike Pagliarulo, who in the previous two winters encountered bitter contract negotiations with the Yankees, lost his salary arbitration case yesterday after having rejected a compromise settlement.

LEAD: The touching story of a veteran who saw the photograph of a young Vietnamese girl in a magazine and thereby found the long-lost daughter he fathered in the war has taken an unexpected turn: The girl he brought back to California may not be his child.

Fight Canceled
LEAD: The International Boxing Federation light-heavyweight title fight between Charles Williams of Grand Rapids, Mich., the champion, and Tom Collins of Britain, scheduled for Feb. 20 in Windsor, England, was canceled yesterday.


Malaysia Stops Traders
LEAD: Malaysia closed 16 commodity firms today and said it was investigating them for suspected illegal trading on overseas exchanges, a senior official said.
Malaysia's Commodities Trading Commission said the 16 had been trading on a number of overseas exchanges but had not been registered.
The firms' premises were raided by the authorities early this morning.

Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Await Report on Trade Gap
LEAD: The dollar was mixed against major foreign currencies yesterday as traders weighed prospects for lower United States interest rates while awaiting tomorrow's report on the American trade deficit for December.

Description By Chambers Is Disputed
LEAD: Jennifer Levin's neck was compressed by a ''considerable force'' lasting at least 20 to 30 seconds and perhaps a minute or more, a pathologist testified yesterday.


U.S. Lifts a Ban on Florida Citrus Shipments
LEAD: The United States Department of Agriculture on Tuesday lifted a three-year embargo on shipments of fresh citrus fruit from Florida to other critus-growing states.
The embargo was imposed as a protection against canker.

LEAD:  General Assembly


A Confidant Turns Against Noriega, but Why?
LEAD: For two days, Jose I. Blandon has transfixed Capitol Hill with vivid accounts of wrongdoing by his former boss, Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military leader.
But it is still unclear why a man many Panamanian exile leaders in Miami and Costa Rica denounce as General Noriega's confidant in unsavory operations over the years would suddenly switch sides.

LEAD:  International A3-15


INSIDE
LEAD:  Ginsburg-TV Probe Dropped


Ford Shift on Plant
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would not buy the auto assembly plant in Westmoreland County, Pa., that Volkswagen of America plans to close later this year.
Ford, which had given notice in November that it might bid for the plant, said it had decided that it had enough production capacity to meet demand for the next few years.

Philharmonic Planning Its First 'Voix Humaine'
LEAD: Francis Poulenc's ''Voix Humaine,'' an opera for solo soprano, will be presented by the New York Philharmonic for the first time at 8 P.M. next Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall.


REGULATORS SHIFT FINANCIAL CORP. STRATEGY
LEAD: Federal regulators, indicating a significant shift in their strategy for solving the problems of the ailing Financial Corporation of America, have decided to begin selling the savings and loan company's $17 billion portfolio of mortgage-backed securities.


U.S. Declares Japan in Violation On Whaling and May Curb Trade
LEAD: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. today declared Japan in violation of a moratorium on commercial whaling.
A spokesman for Mr.
Verity said the Secretary might recommend an embargo on imports of fish from Japan.


British Court Refuses 'Spycatcher' Press Ban
LEAD: The British Government lost another round today in its 20-month effort to ban publication of ''Spycatcher,'' the memoirs of a former British counter-intelligence officer, which the Government calls a threat to national security.


Take a Yes for Afghanistan
LEAD: The United States has been trying for eight years to drive Soviet troops from Afghanistan.
On Monday, Mikhail Gorbachev announced that the troops would all be gone by March 1989 if the U.S. keeps its pledge to stop aiding the Afghan rebels.
It was an extraordinary statement, hailed by the Reagan Administration as ''a positive step.


CUBAN DISCUSSES DECISION ON SEOUL
LEAD: Cuba decided two years ago not to attend the Seoul Olympics if some events were not staged in North Korea, the president of the Cuban Olympic committee said today.


Long Live the King
LEAD: ''Judicial activism'' is a term of special abuse in modern conservative rhetoric.
Judges who protect individual liberty in constitutional cases are accused of distorting history, disrespecting elected legislators and ignoring the practical needs of government.


The Stage: 'Loose Ends'
LEAD: MORE than most of his theatrical peers, Michael Weller writes plays that could serve as time capsules of their period.
His first full-length work, ''Moonchildren,'' summarizes the 1960's through the perspective of a crucial academic year. ''Loose Ends,'' a play with broader scope, focuses on the 1970's - post-hippie, pre-yuppie, a time of searching and changing identities.

Chaya Schneerson, Wife of the Leader Of the Lubavitchers
LEAD: Chaya Moussia Schneerson, the wife of Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson, the Lubavitcher Rebbe, died early yesterday at New York Hospital.
She was taken to the hospital Tuesday night complaining about feeling ill.
She was 86 years old and lived in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn.


On to Royalty Filly Winner
LEAD: On to Royalty stamped herself as Florida's leading 3-year-old filly with a 1 1/2-length victory over Social Pro in the $61,700 Forward Gal Stakes today at Gulfstream Park.


CBS Net Up 12.8% In Quarter
LEAD: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 12.8 percent, buoyed by cost-cutting efforts and by strong results at its television and radio stations.

Reagan Didn't Know of Afghan Deal
LEAD: An American commitment in 1985 to end military aid to the Afghan guerrillas at the beginning of a Soviet troop withdrawal was made without the knowledge or approval of President Reagan, according to White House and State Department officials.


New Look For Urban Newsstands
LEAD: HELP may be on the way for the New York City newsstand, which has come to resemble ''a gigantic coat hanger for every conceivable object,'' in the words of Bartholomew Voorsanger, a vice president of the New York City chapter of the American Institute of Architects.


City Ballet: Balanchine's 'Jewels'
LEAD: ''JEWELS'' is a crowd-pleaser that is also, in subtle ways, one of George Balanchine's most problematic ballets.
Presented by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, ''Jewels'' was danced by a cast that included a number of dancers in new and recently acquired roles.
It was a performance that pointed up the ballet's difficulties.

Broadway Takes to Broadway for AIDS Rally
LEAD: Performing artists, stage workers and others who work in New York City theaters marching to Duffy Square yesterday as part of the Broadway Cares Week, which was proclaimed by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch.
Broadway Cares, an umbrella organization for the various theater groups, was set up to channel the theater industry's resources and fund-raising efforts in the fight against AIDS.


Accountant Says Noriega Helped Launder Billions
LEAD: An accountant testified under oath to Congress today that he laundered billions of dollars in illegal drug profits through Panama's banking system with the help of Gen.
Antonio Manuel Noriega, commander of the country's army and police and de facto leader.

Youth Gets 5 to 15 Years For Howard Beach Attack
LEAD: After publicly expressing sorrow, a white teen-ager was sentenced yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison for his part in the attack that led to the death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens.


Israel Says It Seized 3 Guerrillas From Egypt
LEAD: Israeli troops captured three armed guerrillas who infiltrated into the country across the southern border with Egypt last week, apparently to carry out an attack on civilians, the army said today.


Advertising; Pontiac's Gift to Soviet
LEAD: David Deutsch Associates announced that Pontiac dealers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were planning to ship a red Pontiac Grand Prix to the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Timed to coincide with the gesture, a 30-second spot will appear on television in the New York metropolitan area over the next six weeks, with hopes of national syndication.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article on Wednesday about reactions to a commission's findings on the war record of President Kurt Waldheim of Austria characterized Simon Wiesenthal's background incorrectly.
Mr.
Wiesenthal, head of the Jewish Documentation Center in Vienna, had been acquainted with Mr.
Waldheim and had spoken in support of restraint on the Waldheim issue until the evidence was complete.


Lewis Wolberg, 82, Clinic Psychoanalyst In New York, Is Dead
LEAD: Dr.
Lewis R. Wolberg, a psychoanalyst and founder and former chairman of the Postgraduate Center for Mental Health, died of a heart attack Feb. 3 at his winter home in La Penita, Jalisco, Mexico, near Puerto Vallarta.
He was 82 years old and also lived in Putnam Valley, N.Y.


Fumes Sicken Hospital Staff
LEAD: Surgery at the Westchester County Medical Center here was canceled today when 15 staff members were overcome by fumes as they prepared the operating floor in the morning.
A spokeswoman for the hospital, Nancy McPartlin, said all elective surgery was postponed and emergencies were referred to other hospitals.

LEAD: President Reagan's new budget lays down a comprehensive blueprint for Federal policies in the post-Reagan era, including increased spending on education and science and a dramatic expansion of his campaign for the private sector to take over Government functions.

Polysar Spurns Bid
LEAD: The Polysar Energy and Chemical Corporation said it had rejected as inadequate an increased offer of $16 a share (Canadian), or about $12.60 (American), for its 13 million shares by the Nova Corporation of Calgary, Alberta.
The new bid, raised from a previous offer of $14 a share, raises to about $163 million the total offer for the common shares, which would increase Nova's stake in Polysar to 31 percent from 10 percent.

As seen here, Sheeler's career spans five decades, from 1910 to the late 1950's, in the media of painting, drawing and photography.

LEAD: The people here who would have the most to gain by fulfillment of the Central American plan for peace and democracy are not very optimistic.
Of course, it is the long-suffering Nicaraguan population in general who would gain.
But it is the opposition leaders and human rights advocates who are going to be the key players.

Film: 'A Tiger's Tale,' Starring Ann-Margret
LEAD: ORDINARILY you can tell a lot about a film from the names of its characters, and the principals in ''A Tiger's Tale'' include Rose Butts (Ann-Margret), Shirley Butts (Kelly Preston), Bubber Drumm (C. Thomas Howell), La Vonne (Angel Tompkins) and Claudine (Ann Wedgeworth).
To be fair, this film, written, produced and directed by Peter Douglas (from a novel by Allen Hannay 3d), is a little better than that, but it does place excessive stock in rustic quirks and cracker-barrel humor.


SMELTER IS FINED FOR LEAD HAZARD
LEAD: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration today levied its third largest fine ever, $2.78 million, against a Missouri smelting plant accused of exposing workers to high levels of lead and then dismissing them to sidestep Government medical leave requirements.


Children's Benefit
LEAD: Youngsters with professional theatrical ensembles around the city will take part in a special performance on Monday at 7:30 P.M. at the John Houseman Theater, 450 West 42d Street.
Proceeds from the evening will benefit the Tibetan Children's Villages in Dharmsala and Bylakuppe, India, where more than 1,000 orphaned children are cared for.


Sparse Turnout at Koch Meeting on Pensions
LEAD: Notably less confrontational, Mayor Koch met with a small group of New York City legislators yesterday to try to persuade them not to support a measure to increase pensions for former city and state workers.

Greenwich Village Sculptor Acquitted of Pushing Wife to Her Death
LEAD: Carl Andre, the sculptor, was found not guilty yesterday of charges that he murdered his wife by pushing her from the window of their 34th-floor Greenwich Village apartment.


3 Shot in School Cafeteria
LEAD: A teen-age boy drew a gun in a fight in a high school cafeteria today and shot two teachers and a student before fleeing, officials said.
One of the teachers, Richard Allen, was shot in the head.
He was reported in serious condition in the hospital.
The other teacher, who was shot in the abdomen and thigh, and the student, who suffered leg wounds, were reported in stable condition at another hospital.


Mexico Delays Bond Auction
LEAD: Mexico said yesterday that it had postponed for a week, to Feb. 26, an auction of up to $10 billion in bonds in exchange for loans held by banks around the world.
The banks are being asked to exchange their loans to Mexico at a discount for the bonds, which would be backed by United States Government securities.


Canadian Bank Examines Loss
LEAD: The National Bank of Canada, the nation's sixth-largest bank, said today that it was investigating unauthorized trades by a bond dealer in its New York office.
The trades cost the bank $25 million in Canadian funds, it said, and the amount will be taken as a loss against its first-quarter earnings.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Golf  Five-Stroke Lead in Seniors: Bob Charles of New Zealand flirted with a PGA Seniors Championship record yesterday, shooting an eight-under-par 64 that led him to a five-stroke lead after 18 holes of the $350,000 golf tournament.
Charles, coming off a Seniors victory in South Africa, was nearly flawless in posting an opening round of eight birdies and no bogeys on the par 72, 6,530-yard Champion course at PGA National.


Love Songs
LEAD: Al Carmines, a composer and pastor of the Rauschenbusch Memorial Church, and Speckled Bird, a folk-gospel trio, will present a sampler of love songs, with champagne and hors d'oeuvres, on Sunday at 5 P.M. on the second floor of the Trinity Presbyterian Church, 422 West 57th Street.
Tickets, which benefit the Rauschenbusch church, are $25.

Ailing Mexico Economy Will Be a Focus of Talks
LEAD: As President Miguel de la Madrid and President Reagan prepare for their last scheduled official meeting, Mexico is struggling to emerge from its worst economic crisis in half a century and hoping the United States will play a key role in helping it recover.


Julie Christie in 'Gold Diggers,' From Britain
THERE are critics in Britain who have praised Sally Potter's ''Gold Diggers'' as ''witty,'' ''visually entrancing'' and ''an absorbing pleasure,'' and there may also be like-minded individuals on the planet Jupiter.
But by any reasonable earthly standard, this thing - a 1983 oddity, sort of a feminist, deconstructionist, riddle-filled anti-musical, much of it set on the Icelandic tundra - is pure torture.
Its only noteworthy attribute is the presence of Julie Christie, who embodies some sardonic notion of the archetypical unenlightened movie heroine through the ages.
Like it or not, Miss Christie is infinitely better off playing such creatures straight than she is satirizing them here.
''The Gold Diggers,'' which opens today at the Thalia SoHo, begins with a black woman (Colette Laffont) and a white one (Miss Christie) outlining a vexing riddle (''Only in the darkness am I visible. You can see me but never touch me. I can speak to you but never hear you . . . who am I?'').
One of them then maintains that since there are only 90 minutes to find an answer, ''Time is short.'' This is laughable, under the circumstances.
The camera goes on to explore a plotless configuration of bare Arctic landscapes, mock silent-movie scenes and caricatures of masculine behavior, and never has the clock moved more slowly.
There is also about a 15-minute encounter between Miss Christie and a tap-dancing mime.


'Chronosymphonies'
LEAD: The American Composers Orchestra and the Kronos Quartet will perform the premiere of Matthias Kriesberg's ''Chronosymphonies'' on Sunday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall.
The orchestra, conducted by Dennis Russell Davies, will also present works by Gordon Getty, John Alden Carpenter and Roy Harris.
Tickets are $11 to $17.50.


Simon and Gephardt Seek Funds
LEAD: Two nights after his victory in the Iowa caucuses, Representative Richard A. Gephardt was a long way from New Hampshire, where other Presidential contenders were seeking support for Tuesday's primary.


Colgate Net Up in Quarter
LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company yesterday reported sharply higher fourth-quarter earnings although its profit for all of 1987 tumbled because of restructuring expenses.


Second Stage Benefit
LEAD: A $200 celebrity bowling benefit for the Second Stage Theater, sponsored by Seagram's, will be held on Monday at 6 P.M. at the Madison Square Garden Bowling Center, at 32d and Seventh Avenue.
Couples may choose their bowling partners from a roster that includes Treat Williams, Marsha Mason, Betty Buckley, Kevin Bacon, Carrie Fisher and about 20 others, and prizes will be awarded.

Dreaming of a Medal?
LEAD: Don LaVigne waiting for a flight to Calgary at the Albany County Airport Wednesday night.
After being reinstated as a member of the U.S. bobsled team, LaVigne received approval yesterday from the International Olympic Committee to compete in the Games. (AP)


Retail Sales Rose 0.5% In January
LEAD: In a report that many economists found reassuring, the Government said today that retail sales throughout the country climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in January and that December's sales, upon revision, were considerably higher than first estimated.


Film: 'School Daze'
LEAD: FROM the intimate, funny sexual battleground on which Spike Lee's ''She's Gotta Have It'' unfolded, Mr.
Lee has moved on to bigger, bolder and messier ambitions.
The new occasion is ''School Daze,'' his scathing look at a fictitious white-financed, all-black college whose motto is ''Uplift the Race.


Susan Osborn
LEAD: Susan Osborn, the former lead singer of the Paul Winter Consort, will be singing a mixture of gospel, folk and other popular romantic ballads, tonight at 8 o'clock at the Church of the Holy Apostle, 296 Ninth Avenue (at 28th Street).
Tickets are $12.
Information: 219-2527.


WHITE HOUSE BANS OFFICIALS HELPING CONTRA DONATIONS
LEAD: The White House announced today that it had forbidden Reagan Administration officials to ''provide assistance or encouragement of any kind to private individuals or third parties raising funds'' for the Nicaraguan rebels.


Bourne Retrospective
LEAD: A retrospective of films by the American independent film maker St.
Clair Bourne begins tomorrow at noon at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street.
Mr.
Bourne is known for his documentaries and feature films about the lives of blacks living in the United States and abroad; among them are profiles of the writers Amiri Baraka and Langston Hughes.

Not All Tenants Praise Cuomo Proposals on Rent Regulation
LEAD: To the Editor:


Conferees Seek 'Founding Mothers'
LEAD: Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor told nearly 1,500 women here today that the Supreme Court would ''linger for a good many more years'' on women's rights cases in order to eliminate some of the effects of a Constitution that makes ''no specific mention of women.''

Battle Begins For Control Of Gillette
LEAD: A complex battle for control of the Gillette Company broke out yesterday with the disclosure by Coniston Partners of New York that it owned about 6 percent of the big Boston-based producer of razor blades, cosmetics and other consumer goods.


Restaurants; French bistro on the East Side.
LEAD: WHEN the wind chill hammers the thermometer into single digits, one of the most effective human antifreezes is a bracing stew along with a slab of rough country bread and a glass of husky red wine.
To the French, that translates as pot-au-feu, and one of the best around is ladled out at Voulez-Vous.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Justice's Decision
LEAD: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court has resigned from the Cosmos Club, the prestigious club whose all-male membership policy has come under increasing attack from the District of Columbia Government and from disaffected members as well as from feminists.


City Ballet: 2 Bolshoi Stars Visit
LEAD: IF any idea once seemed highly unlikely it was that the New York City Ballet would be the first American company to play host to Soviet dancers for an extended time.
Until his death in 1983, George Balanchine, the company's artistic director, did not hide his criticism of the Soviet Union, including its ballet.


Our Towns; Casinos' Allure: Weaning a Girl From the Tables
LEAD: The 12 casinos in Atlantic City say they turned away minors at the door 200,000 times last year and kicked them off casino floors more than 30,000 other times.
The casinos say they do their best to keep out those under 21.
If so, what is striking about the case of Kim Cohen, an Atlantic City teen-ager who started playing blackjack at 15, is the encouragement the casinos gave her to keep gambling.

Kluge Lifts Stake In Orion Pictures
LEAD: John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Company, has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Company for the second consecutive day.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr.
Kluge said he had raised his holdings to 26.7 percent from 25.6 percent, through purchases of an additional 221,400 Orion shares on Tuesday at an average price of $17.02 each.


Leonard Martelli, 50, Writer and Executive
LEAD: Leonard J. Martelli, a former publishing executive and co-author of ''When Someone You Know Has AIDS: A Practical Guide,'' died of complications resulting from AIDS on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn.
He was 50 years old.


Olympia Increases Stake in Santa Fe
LEAD: Olympia &amp; York Developments Ltd., controlled by the Reichmann family of Canada, has increased its stake in the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation to 10.54 percent, from 10.3 percent.
Olympia said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it expected to buy more Santa Fe shares.


Ford-Mazda Car Is Shown
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company today introduced a Japanese-American sports car, the Probe, which it hopes will recapture sales from Japanese companies like the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company.

Horse Racing Notebook; 71 Stakes Races Granted Higher Status
LEAD: Is American racing getting better all the time?
Apparently so, in the opinion of the committee that classifies the nation's most important stakes races.
The North American Graded Stakes Committee recently published its listing of this year's top races, and changed the status of 76 of them: 71 were upgraded and 5 were downgraded.


Suggestion, on Intruder: Off With Its Head
LEAD: There is no telling how many neighborly quarrels have flared, flamed and faded into the mists of the past on Elfreth's Alley, the oldest continuously inhabited residential street in the United States.


On Eve of Tet, Vietnam Tries to Ease Friction
LEAD: As Vietnam prepares to celebrate Tet, the Lunar New Year - and the 20th anniversary of a series of wartime attacks known as the Tet Offensive - the Vietnamese people and army are being urged to get along better with each other.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Jose Santos rode five winners for the second straight day yesterday at Aqueduct, giving him 10 winners in 13 races.
The only other jockey in New York history to ride 10 winners in two days was Steve Cauthen, who did it twice in 1977. . . .
Pat Riggin, the Pittsburgh Penguins' starting goaltender at the beginning of the season, was assigned to the Penguins' Muskegon farm club in the International Hockey League.

Chinook: Gold-Medal Warmth
LEAD: WE have seen the chinook wind and it works, melting the snow in its path like a giant microwave oven demolishing an ice-cream cone.


Gay Ex-Soldier Wants to Return to the Army
LEAD: Thoughout his 16-year stint in the Army, Perry J. Watkins said today, he made no secret of his homosexuality, even performing as a female impersonator.
Early in his Army career he asked for a discharge, naming his lovers so that the Army could substantiate his claim.


Women in the Law Aren't Yet Equal Partners
LEAD: Like most major law firms in the early 1970's, Rogers &amp; Wells resembled an elegant men's club, and the Manhattan firm had only one female associate among its 95 lawyers in 1971.
A recruiting manual listed attractions like a villa on a Florida golf course and a private barbershop providing free haircuts.


Economic Scene; Military Budget Under Pressure
LEAD: THE effort to bring down the United States' budget deficit, which has swollen the gross national debt from $1 trillion to more than $2.5 trillion in the last seven years, is increasing the pressure on the military budget.

Rap Group in a Salute To Paterson Principal
LEAD: Run-DMC, the rap group, treated about 3,000 students at Eastside High School today to a high-decibel salute to the school's principal, Joe Clark.


Valley National Finds Chief at Smaller Rival
LEAD: Banking ''is an all-out war now, while 15 years ago it was a fairly simple business,'' said James P. Simmons, who was elected chairman and chief executive of the Valley National Corporation earlier this week.
Valley is the parent of Arizona's largest bank.

Allah and Gorbachev Mixing in Central Asia
LEAD: Worshipers who come to the mosque of Imam Ibudulayev Nasrulo may sometimes find it difficult to tell where Mohammed leaves off and Mikhail S. Gorbachev begins.


Stage: John Gielgud Stars in London Play
LEAD: As the curtain rose Wednesday night on John Gielgud's first stage performance in a decade, the audience's trepidation was palpable.
Mr.
Gielgud is 83 years old and the sole active member of the acting trinity whose other legendary figures, Laurence Olivier and Ralph Richardson, are retired or dead.

Advertising; Jordache to Broadcast Its New Commercials
LEAD: Jordache, a maker of jeans and casual clothes, will begin airing its latest 10- and 30-second television spots on Monday.
The half-dozen spots, created in-house, will continue to aim at the teen-age audience with the tagline ''Jordache Basics - Because Life . . .
Is Not.''

LEAD: From 6:30 on last night, the top officials of the New York City Police Department were out on the town, dancing, drinking and dining at the annual winter benefit dance of the New York City Police Foundation at Police Headquarters.

Infant Ejected in Car Crash
LEAD: The police filed drunken driving and other charges today against the mother of a 13-month-old boy who hurtled out a car window in an accident early Wednesday and spent 15 minutes in an icy stream.
The boy, Eric McCourt, was in critical condition at Children's Hospital in Pittsburgh suffering head injuries and exposure, a hospital official said.


Albert Fink Milton, Executive, 90
LEAD: Albert Fink Milton, a former financial executive in New York City, died last Friday at his home in Washington, Conn.
He was 90 years old.


The Stage: 'Cave Life'
LEAD: EARLY in ''Cave Life'' (at the Circle Repertory Company), Robin Bartlett leads a tour through the prehistoric wing of the Museum of Natural History.
As she stops at an exhibit of Neanderthal man, one of the loin-clothed sculptural figures suddenly leaps to life and grabs the guide in a passionate embrace.


Another Quake in California
LEAD: A strong earthquake rocked a wide area of Southern California today, injuring at least 25 people and bringing on a fatal heart attack but apparently causing little damage.


Advertising; WPP Refinancing
LEAD: WPP Group, London, reported that it had signed its previously announced refinancing agreement for its acquisition of the JWT Group, which occurred last July.
WPP said the new package includes a seven-year, $160 million loan set up by S. G. Warburg &amp; Company, with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York acting as agent and lead manager.


Islanders Beaten Late
LEAD: Vincent Damphousse scored his second goal of the game tonight with 22 seconds left in regulation time as the Toronto Maple Leafs broke a six-game losing streak with a 4-3 victory over the Islanders.

LEAD: TAKEOVER situations dominate the handful of issues recently hitting new highs on the New York Stock Exchange.
But the class H stock of General Motors - certainly no acquisition candidate - finds itself in this select group.


Iranians Celebrate Revolution's Anniversary
LEAD: Part of the crowd that gathered in Azadi Square in Teheran yesterday to mark the ninth anniversary of the Islamic Revolution and the end of the Persian monarchy.
Meanwhile, an Iranian gunboat attacked a large Norwegian tanker in the Persian Gulf, the sixth such attack since the 10-day celebration started Feb.


Dawson Shoots for Arbitration Record
LEAD: While Andre Dawson was preparing to shoot for a record arbitration salary today, two other outfielders who had sought salaries of more than $1 million negotiated new contracts yesterday.
Kirby Puckett of Minnesota accepted a $1,090,000 salary and Eric Davis of Cincinnati agreed to $899,000.


2 Are Seized in Beirut, Then Freed
LEAD: Gunmen kidnapped two Swedish journalists in Beirut's southern suburbs today but released them after realizing that they were not West Germans, the police said.

LEAD: As the sun set below the Canadian Rockies far to the west, Team Swider-Peltz was finishing up another grueling workout inside the Olympic Oval.

LEAD: Hartz Mountain Industries, Secaucus, N.J., the real estate subsidiary of the Hartz Mountain Corporation, has tapped Keyes Martin Gaby Linett Advertising, Springfield, N.J., as the agency for its waterfront project in Edgewater, N.J.
The $1 million budget will be used for print, outdoor and direct marketing campaigns.

LEAD: Bishop Frederick Donaghy, a Roman Catholic missionary in China and Taiwan, died of cancer Friday at Maryknoll, the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America's center in Ossining, N.Y.
He was 85 years old.

NOFZIGER IS CONVICTED ON 3 COUNTS OF VIOLATING FEDERAL ETHICS LAW
LEAD: Lyn Nofziger, who served as one of Ronald Reagan's close advisers in the California Governor's office and in the White House, was found guilty today of illegal lobbying under the Federal ethics law.


Advertising; Foote, Cone Gets Client And Reports Profit Rise
LEAD: Foote, Cone &amp; Belding Communications Inc., Chicago, has won the account for the Chicago-based United States League of Savings Institutions over four local agencies and the incumbent, Metacom, New York.
A national campaign is scheduled to begin this spring.
The budget is $5 million.
Foote, Cone yesterday reported a 37 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings.

Advertising; Leo Burnett: Steady as It Grows
LEAD: The worst snowstorm of the season struck today in a city not known for its gentle weather.
But while many Chicagoans refused to go outside, the Leo Burnett Company's most famous advertising creations -Tony the Tiger, the Pillsbury Doughboy and Charlie the Tuna - as well as its top executives stood in the 11-below-zero cold to celebrate the near completion of the agency's 50-story headquarters building.

LEAD: On the face of it, the Democratic primary in New Hampshire next Tuesday is a straightforward affair: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts should win on the strength of his New England-ness, with Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Paul Simon of Illinois fighting for second place.

Metro-North Delays at High
LEAD: More than 16 percent of the trains on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad ran late in January, the poorest month in four years, the railroad said yesterday.
The New Haven line had the worst time with 21 percent of its trains late and an average delay for those trains of 17 minutes.
Metro-North calls a train late if it is more than five minutes behind schedule at its destination.


G.M. Rebate Plan Special to The New York Times
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it was offer-ing a $1,000 cash rebate to buyers of eligible 1988 Pontiac Firebirds, in a program that expires on April 30.
First-time buyers will qualify for an additional $600 payment in a pro-gram that ends Sept. 30.

Threat Investigated
LEAD: The F.B.I. said yesterday it has entered the investigation of a death threat that prompted Tony Yates, the University of Cincinnati basketball coach, to stay away from Wednesday night's game in St.
Louis, the first game he has missed in five seasons.


Eastern Pilots Win Ruling
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday ordered Eastern Air Lines to produce internal documents about plans to transfer any of its major assets, including its shuttle operation on the East Coast.


Murdoch to Buy 2 More Magazines
LEAD: The publisher Rupert Murdoch will buy a consumer fashion magazine and an apparel trade publication, Murdoch Magazines said.
Sportswear International, a trade publication, and In Fashion, a bimonthly consumer magazine, will be purchased for an undisclosed sum.


Times Co. Net Up 22.1%
LEAD: The New York Times Company said yesterday that net income rose 22.1 percent, to nearly $42.5 million, or 52 cents a share, in the last three months of 1987, from $34.8 million, or 43 cents a share, in the comparable 1986 quarter.
Revenues rose 7.2 percent, to $447.8 million, from $417.9 million in the 1986 period.


Holiday Weekend
LEAD: Today is Lincoln's Birthday; Washington's Birthday is observed Monday.
Following are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Parking: Alternate-side rules are suspended today and Monday.
Sanitation: No collection or street sweeping either day.
Government offices: Federal and state offices are open and city offices are closed today; all are closed Monday.

Interest Deductions Limited By Maze of New Regulations
LEAD: Until this tax-filing season, deducting interest on home mortgages, car loans, margin accounts and business loans used to be a straightforward affair with hardly any limitations.
To most taxpayers, interest was interest, and they were usually able to deduct any kind of interest expense in full with few complications.

LEAD: Grey Advertising, Los Angeles, has come out the winner in the three-month competition for the U S West Inc. corporate advertising business, with a budget of $10 million.
U S West, one of the regional Bell operating companies, serves 14 Western and Midwestern states.

RANGERS SINK; DEVILS 4, CANADIENS, 2
LEAD: For Coach Jim Schoenfeld of the Devils, the words of praise did not appear to be enough to describe Bob Sauve's remarkable goaltending against Montreal tonight.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 418 money market mutual funds increased $2.76 billion, to $278.03 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $1.65 billion, to $82.33 billion.
Assets of the 208 general purpose funds were up $305.7 million, to $81.4 billion.

Campeau Renews Bid for Retailer
LEAD: The Campeau Corporation, strengthened by an alliance with two powerful real estate developers, yesterday renewed its $61-a-share cash offer for Federated Department Stores Inc.
Separately, the Securities and Exchange Commission supported Campeau's right to challenge Delaware's new anti-takeover law.


Whatever You Do, Don't Call Burns Bobby

Sounds Around Town
LEAD:  Audible Rituals


'Trickster of Seville'
LEAD: Ever since Tirso de Molina first recorded the story of the legendary libertine Don Juan in 1630, this drama of passion, seduction and revenge has been retold many times.
A new version of the 17th-century Spanish writer's ''Trickster of Seville'' will be presented in a free staged reading Monday at 7 P.M.


Lukewarm Welcome for Professionals
LEAD: In the past, the Olympics were closed to professional athletes, or at least those defined as professionals by the International Olympic Committee.
In fact, a double standard existed, most clearly exemplified by athletes from the Eastern European countries, who are subsidized by their governments, but who usually listed their occupation as student or soldier.


Michigan Sets Bonuses For Pension Managers
LEAD: To compete with the high salaries of the securities industry, the Michigan Civil Service Commission yesterday approved a plan to pay bonuses to the state employees who manage Michigan's $15 billion pension fund, based on the fund's performance.


Film: 'Au Revoir les Enfants,' From Louis Malle
LEAD: LOUIS MALLE'S ''Au Revoir les Enfants'' (''Goodbye, Children'') is based on an event that took place during January 1944, when the French writer and director, then 12 years old, was attending a Jesuit boarding school near Fontainebleau.
At the end of the Christmas holidays, in the middle of the scholastic year, there appeared at the school three new boys, one of whom became the young


Shultz Likely to Undertake Mideast Peace Mission
LEAD: Administration officials said today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz would probably travel to the Middle East at the end of this month to explore the prospects for movement toward Arab-Israeli peace negotiations.


Jersey State Opera
LEAD: The New Jersey State Opera will present Pietro Mascagni's ''Iris'' on Sunday at 6 P.M. in Newark's Symphony Hall.
Adriana Maliponte, a soprano, will sing the title role.
It is the first production of the opera in this area since its performance at the Metropolitan Opera in 1931.
Tickets are $6 to $42.

Winner of Nobel Prize Assails Candidates on Issue of AIDS
LEAD: Opening the annual meeting of the nation's leading scientific organization, Dr.
David Baltimore, a Nobel prize-winning molecular biologist, today criticized the Presidential candidates of both major political parties.


The Great Game Goes On
LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev faces a challenge entirely worthy of his abilities as a master politician.


Estimate Board Reacts To Threats With a Vote
LEAD: The Board of Estimate, its existence threatened by the prospect of changes in the New York City Charter, rose up in oratorical ire yesterday to assert its powers and challenge Mayor Koch's right to order quietly the closing of a Brooklyn firehouse.


Illinois on Probation
LEAD: The University of Illinois, which admitted to football recruiting violations during the tenure of Mike White, a former coach, was placed on probation yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association but received no major penalty.
The N.C.A.A.
Committee on Infractions said Illinois would be on probation until July 1, 1989, and must submit two internal audits of the football program.


WHITE HOUSE SETS NEW SPACE POLICY
LEAD: After a bitter internal struggle, the White House yesterday made public a new policy meant to rejuvenate the Government's ailing space program and speed the growth of the nation's emerging commercial space industry.


Corrections
LEAD: A listing on page B1 yesterday about holiday weekend closings referred incorrectly to a parade.
The Washington's Birthday parade, originally scheduled for Monday, has been canceled.
An article on the subject appears today on page B2.

P.L.O. Dispute: U.S. and U.N. on Collision Course
LEAD: After years of growing tension in their relations, the United Nations and the United States are on the brink of their most damaging confrontation as a result of Congressional moves to close the Palestine Liberation Organization mission here, diplomats and senior officials of the world organization say.


TREASURES AND TRIFLES: BROWSING IN ART BOOKSTORES
LEAD: IN matters of art, New York has everything in depth -museums, dealers, magazines, practicing artists.
So it should come as no surprise that this is also a city where art bookstores are in good supply, a city, in fact, where books about art are as easy to buy as - and certainly more nourishing than - a takeout dinner.

LEAD: Britain is currently in the midst of an unofficial Noel Coward festival.

IU Urges Caution On Neoax Offer
LEAD: The board of the IU International Corporation urged stockholders to refrain from tendering their shares to Neoax Inc. because of uncertainties about its tender offer.
IU said it was exploring alternatives to the hostile $20-a-share offer, including a recapitalization or a leveraged buyout.


Revamping of Air Traffic System Urged, Including Private Control
LEAD: The new Secretary of Transportation called today for a restructuring of Federal aviation regulations and said that turning the air traffic control system over to private industry should be among the options.

This is essentially a formula film, and as such it's nothing fancy.

Buddy Tate
LEAD: Buddy Tate, a saxophonist who played with Count Basie, will lead a quartet with the guest vocalist Carrie Smith tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, near Ninth Street (982-3260).
Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

LEAD: Senior Honduran Army officers and a powerful drug dealer with past ties to Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian military leader, are setting up major drug operations in Honduras, according to American officials and worried Honduran political leaders.

The Trade Gap: Myths and Crocodile Tears
LEAD: The trade figures scheduled for release today will no doubt show that Asian nations continue to sell us much more than we sell them, the declining dollar notwithstanding.
In fact, America's trade deficit with the ''four tigers'' of Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan is now greater than our trade deficit with all of Western Europe.


Rabbi Israel Raphael Margolies Dies at 72
LEAD: Rabbi Israel Raphael Margolies, who spoke out on a variety of social issues and was a longtime civil rights advocate, died of complications from hypoglycemia yesterday at his home in Teaneck, N.J.
He was 72 years old.

Reagans to Help Raise Funds
LEAD: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will appear at a $10,000 a couple fund-raising event Friday for the California Republican Party, state party officials said.
The event will be held at the Bel-Air home of David Murdock, a real estate developer.
The event is expected to draw 100 to 125 people.
The Reagans are making a brief stopover before traveling to Mexico over the weekend to visit President Miguel de la Madrid.

LEAD: J. R. Reid and Scott Williams scored 4 points each in overtime to lead sixth-ranked North Carolina to a 75-73 victory over No. 16 North Carolina State in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

LEAD: Election-related violence broke out in three cities near the capital today, a day after similar violence left at least 80 people dead, officials said.

LEAD: Two brothers being tried on charges of illegally exporting 87 high-performance Hughes helicopters to North Korea have pleaded guilty to reduced charges, a prosecutor said.


High Voltage Bid
LEAD: The High Voltage Engineering Corporation of Burlington, Mass., has agreed to accept a sweetened offer of $18 a share, or about $91.8 million, from Hyde Park Partners L.P., a New York investment firm.
Hyde Park had made unsolicited offers of $15.25 a share and then $17 a share for High Voltage, a which makes electrical and communications instruments.

TV Weekend; Ramey In 'Don Giovanni'
LEAD: ''DON GIOVANNI'' may be the world's best opera; we remember the music even when we've forgotten which grieved woman was Donna Anna and which one was Donna Elvira. ''Great Performances,'' on Channel 13 at 9 tonight, presents the Salzburg Festival production of Mozart's great work.
It is not a feast for the eyes; on the other hand, it is ''Don Giovanni.


Early Music Players
LEAD: The Early Music Players will present a program entitled ''Musick With Her Silver Sound'' on Sunday at 3 P.M. that includes pieces from the English courts of Henry VIII, Elizabeth I and James I, played on original instruments, at St.
Bartholomew's Church (109 East 50th Street).
A $5 contribution is requested.

NRBQ to Perform
LEAD: NRBQ, a rock band, will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 14 West Fourth Street (228-6300), with True Image opening.
Double bills begin at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.


AIDS Experiment Based on Salk's Theories
LEAD: Some patients infected with the AIDS virus are being injected with an inactive form of the virus in a program in which Dr.
Jonas Salk is using the same theories that led to his vaccine for polio.


Study Urges Tougher Checks To Meet Clean Air Act Goals
LEAD: More stringent controls to reduce smog and carbon monoxide pollution from motor vehicles are required if the nation is to reach the goals of the Clean Air Act, according to a study released today by the American Lung Association.


Largest L.I. Hospital Curbs Elective Care In Nursing Shortage
LEAD: The Nassau County Medical Center, the largest hospital on Long Island, began turning away all non-emergency cases today because of a severe shortage of nurses.


Asante Dancers
LEAD: Drummers and dancers from the Asante tribe in Ghana will give a free demonstration on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Hillside School, 54 Orange Avenue, Montclair, N.J.
The performance is sponsored by the Montclair Art Museum as part of a celebration of Black History month.
A reception will follow at the museum, South Mountain and Bloomfield Avenues.


The Larger Peril in Panama
LEAD: It's not necessary to believe all the charges against Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega to know he's an abomination and that his continued rule is disastrous for Panama and dangerous to the United States.
Even the Reagan Administration says so.
The problem is that no one seems to have a good plan for ousting Panama's strongman.


Washington Talk: The Commerce Department; In 'Lockup,' Itchy Reporters Count the Secnds
LEAD: None have been handcuffed, none subjected to strip searches, none fingerprinted.
But for reporters covering the United States Government's periodic releases of critical economic statistics, their compulsory incarceration for a half-hour or so before the magic moment of data release produces a sensation not all that different from being under arrest.


Old Tollbooths on Merritt: Trying to Save 30's Artifacts
LEAD: After a long campaign, the tolls on the Merritt Parkway will be abolished next July 1.
Now, a new campaign is starting to save the tollbooths as a historical reminder of the 1930's, when people went motoring instead of commuting.

Newmont's Gold Loan
LEAD: The Newmont Mining Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had recently obtained a loan of one million ounces of gold from a group of lenders led by the Bank of Nova Scotia.
At current bullion prices, the loan is valued at roughly $445 million and is believed to be the largest of its kind by a mining company.

2 More Quit In Turmoil At Salomon
LEAD: Two more senior executives resigned from Salomon Brothers yesterday, joining the growing list of defectors from the large investment banking house, people close to the firm said.


Pop/Jazz; Resurgence Of Big Bands In New York
LEAD: THE 1980's have seen an explosion of jazz activity, in just about every form imaginable.
One of the most fertile movements of the decade, for instance, has been built around the re-emergence of the big band as a composer's forum.
Artistically challenging orchestras have been like taxes: they seem to be everywhere.

Scientists Urge Huge Project To Chart All Human Genes
LEAD: An expert committee of the National Research Council said yesterday that the United States should immediately begin a 15-year effort to diagram and describe in detail the chemical language of all the possibly 100,000 human genes.

John Reich Dies at 81; Led Goodman Theater
LEAD: Dr.
John Reich, who guided the Goodman Theater from an academic adjunct of the Art Institute of Chicago to one of the nation's best resident professional ensembles, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida.
He was 81 years old.

LEAD: RESTAURANT LAFAYETTE, the three-star French restaurant in the Drake Hotel on Park Avenue at 56th Street, has added some engrossing traditional winter dishes to its menu.

Exiled Afghan Dean Is Killed At Press Service in Pakistan
LEAD: A prominent exiled professor from Afghanistan, Prof.
Sayd Bahouddin Majrooh, was killed today by an unknown gunman in Peshawar, his son said.

LEAD: Lawyers for Rupert Murdoch argued before a Federal appeals court here today that Congress acted unconstitutionally when it passed a law before Christmas whose sole object, they said, was to damage Mr.
Murdoch.

LEAD: A man initially believed to have been an accomplice in a hostage-taking here last week was released from jail after a prosecutor said it appeared he had been forced to participate at gunpoint.

Lutes of Many Lands
LEAD: Lutes of Arabia, China and Iran will be presented tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street (362-8719).
Simon Shaheen will play the Arab oud, Tang Liang-Xing will play the Chinese pipa and Dariush Dolat-Shahi will play the Persian setar and tar, all lutes of various shapes and tunings, in a concert presented by the World Music Institute (206-1050).


Wallace R. Cotton, 64, Supreme Court Justice
LEAD: Justice Wallace R. Cotton of State Supreme Court died of melanoma, or skin cancer, Wednesday at New York University Medical Center.
He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: A cylinder of black-tinted glass that rises 46 stories above Second Avenue, the apartment building is the epitome of Upper East Side elegance.

In the basement, two theaters show first-run films.
