Mozambique: Few Escape Fury of War
LEAD: Hundreds of people sought refuge from war at a relief camp outside this decaying town.
But Mozambique's cruel reality crept up on them there.


Pork Posts Steep Decline; Midwest Storm a Factor
LEAD: Prices of pork futures fell steeply yesterday as concerns about the weather combined with other market forces to foreshadow a possibly sharp increase in hog slaughters.


Advertising; Mingo Reorganizes
LEAD: Frank L. Mingo, who runs Mingo-Jones Advertising, has reorganized the firm's executive ranks so he can devote more time to clients of the mi-nority -owned shop.
Mr.
Mingo turned over the posts of president and chief operating officer to Samuel J. Chis-holm, who will look after day-to-day operations.


Troops Kill Palestinian Youth
LEAD: Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian youth at the Tulkarm refugee center in the West Bank today, an army spokesman said.
The shooting brought the unofficial death toll to at least 54 in more than two months of violence in the Israeli-occupied territories.


10 Elected to Academy
LEAD: John McPhee, Cynthia Ozick and Reynolds Price are among 10 leading cultural figures who have been elected to the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters.
The other new members, whose names were announced yesterday, are Alex Katz, the painter and printmaker; Elmer Bischoff and Giorgio Cavallon, painters; Francis Thorne, the composer, and Raymond Carver, Leslie Fiedler and Evan S.


Mr. Waldheim and Mr. von Weizsacker
LEAD: Nothing better illustrates Kurt Waldheim's unfitness for leadership than his response to the new report on his World War II record.
The report confirms his knowledge of Nazi atrocities by his army units and his subsequent concealment of this record.
Yet what Austria's President pulls from the report, sadly for


Recital: Dawn Upshaw
LEAD: A TALENTED singer, like a great impostor, learns how to switch personalities, not merely clothes or facial expressions, to suit the occasion.
The remarkable soprano Dawn Upshaw demonstrated such ability at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening in two successive, drastically different vocal dramas.


About Real Estate; Converting All-Suite Hotels in Stamford
LEAD: As all-suite hotels continue to proliferate around the nation, some owners are taking advantage of their broader potential: transformation into residential condominiums should an oversupply develop or demand for transient accommodations slacken.


Timeless All-Stars
LEAD: The Timeless All-Stars - Harold Land on tenor saxophone, Bobby Hutcherson on vibraphone, Curtis Fuller on trombone, Cedar Walton on piano, Buster Williams on bass and Billy Higgins on drums - are performing tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785).


Samaranch Calls for 'Vigilance'
LEAD: With the opening ceremonies of the XV Olympic Winter Games two days away, less attractive Olympic issues continued to share the forefront with final preparations.


Texaco Investors Win Plea
LEAD: Shareholders challenging Texaco Inc.'s proposal to grant sweeping releases and indemnities to officers and advisers involved in its acquisition of Getty Oil will have the right to gather documents and testimony from them before the March 22 hearing on Texaco's bankruptcy reorganization plan, Bankruptcy Judge Howard


Workers' Total For New York Soaring in 80's
LEAD: Employment in New York City in the 1980's has risen to its highest level since the years just after World War II, with women experiencing the largest gains, according to a Federal report issued yesterday.


Convicted Killer Is Captured After Photo Is Shown on TV
LEAD: A convicted murderer who escaped from an Indiana prison in 1986 was captured by the F.B.I. on Staten Island yesterday, four days after his picture was shown on a television program about the F.B.I.'s most-wanted list, the authorities said.

State Dept. Is Faulted on Embassy Guard Incidents
LEAD: A preliminary investigation by the General Accounting Office, the Congressional monitoring agency, has found that the State Department failed to inform military investigators of more than 500 instances of possible wrongdoing by Marine guards at American embassies worldwide, a Congressman said today.


It's Not Luge Weather
LEAD: Warm weather and sudden gusts of wind hampered practice runs today for the Olympic luge competition and were blamed for two crashes on the Calgary Olympic Park course.


Ethiopian Troops Said to Kill 20 at Aid Center
LEAD: Ethiopian troops killed 20 people on Monday when thousands of drought victims at a food relief center in a northern region refused to leave for resettlement, Western relief officials and an Ethiopian rebel said today.


Painless Tax for New York Commuters
LEAD: In search of ways to close New York City's projected budget gap, Mayor Koch asks the State Legislature to double the tax surcharge on commuters who work in the city.


UNHAPPY DUNKER
LEAD: Still miffed over the judging in last weekend's National Basketball Association slam-dunk competition in Chicago, Dominique Wilkins of the Atlanta Hawks says he will not participate in the future - unless he gets the homecourt advantage.

The pianist Peter Serkin will be the soloist.
Tickets are $10 to $20.
Information: 874-6770.

LEAD: The International Olympic Committee and all other concerned governing bodies agreed today that Don LaVigne could be added to the United States Olympic bobsled team as the 13th member.

Art: Jennifer Bartlett
LEAD: JENNIFER BARTLETT'S latest works, now at the Paula Cooper Gallery, are smart and suave and highly polished, and they cast a seductive, unsettling spell.
For her latest exhibition, the well-known former Minimalist has returned to familiar ground, depicting boats, houses and fences on four huge canvases (9 by 14 feet), in front of which have been placed sculptural re-creations of the painted images.


Rebels Hint New Actions In Argentina
LEAD: Some of the soldiers involved in a rebellion last month have indicated in recent days that they intend to continue agitating against the military leadership and the civilian Government.


Vital Repair for Civil Rights Law
LEAD: When Federal money flows to one department of a school or hospital, Federal law should prohibit discrimination in all parts of the institution.
For years that was accepted as the clear intent of several Federal civil rights laws.
Then in 1984, the Supreme Court narrowed their scope.
The Senate now has restored the laws' broader reach and the House is about to follow.

Redesigned Rocket For Shuttle Is Tested For Margin of Safety
LEAD: The space agency today tested a section of the space shuttle's redesigned booster rocket with intentionally flawed joints to determine whether the new design had a dependable safety margin.

Appeals Court Rejects Testing Of Rail Workers
LEAD: The Government's policy of requiring railroad workers to submit to drug or alcohol tests after accidents or rule violations was struck down as unconstitutional today by a Federal appeals court.

Arbitragers Return to the Game
LEAD: Although individual and institutional investors are still nursing their wounds from the October stock market collapse, Wall Street's risk arbitragers are back at the tables.
The resurgence of giant takeover deals is making it possible once again for them to rake in big profits in a matter of days or weeks.


Stage: 'Faithful Servant,' A Mild Joe Orton Work
LEAD: The bite and twist of Joe Orton are present in ''The Good and Faithful Servant,'' which he wrote for British television shortly before his murder in 1967, but the plot is not twisty enough to surprise and the bite is not all that biting.
The title character is one-armed Buchanan, whom we meet as he is about to be retired after 50 years ''in charge of the main entrance.

Mexico, After Reagan and de la Madrid
LEAD: The mini-summit meeting today between Presidents Miguel de la Madrid and Ronald Reagan at Mazatlan is the last encounter of two men who have learned to get along but not to understand each other.
It also marks the end of the Reagan era in Mexican-American relations, a time of tensions and misunderstandings, resentment and deterioration on almost every item of the two nations' agenda.

LEAD: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, boarding Air Force One at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., for a flight to California, where they attended a Republican Party fund-raising affair last night in Los Angeles.
Today, Mr.
Reagan is to fly to the Mexican Pacific resort of Mazatlan for talks with President Miguel de la Madrid.


BIDEN IS OPERATED ON FOR ANEURYSM IN BRAIN
LEAD: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. underwent surgery yesterday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center to correct an aneurysm of an artery supplying blood to the brain, his spokesman said.

Alfred S. Eichner Is Dead at 50; Major Post-Keynesian Economist
LEAD: Alfred S. Eichner, a leading member of the post-Keynesian school of economics and a professor at Rutgers University, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Closter, N.J., where he lived.
He was 50 years old.


Gerber to Shut Unit
LEAD: The Gerber Products Company of Fremont, Mich., said it would close its trucking subsidiary, CW Transport Inc. of Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., because its management had been unable to secure financing for a leveraged buyout and no other acceptable offer for the company had been received.
Closing of the company and its operating subsidiaries will put 1,500 people out of work.


Concert: Philharmonic In 'Sacre du Printemps'
LEAD: A concert entirely made up of Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1 and Stravinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps'' may not be everyone's idea of judiciously balanced programming, but it is certain to give the eardrums a workout.
Zubin Mehta, who conducted the New York Philharmonic in just such a program of Russian blockbusters on Thursday evening, could not salvage much out of the Tchaikovsky, which Alexander Toradze alternately brutalized and sentimentalized as the soloist.

Jersey Housing Lottery Makes Hundreds Happy
LEAD: At 7 A.M. yesterday, an ecstatic John Galea was the first to arrive.
He was two hours early.


Suit Against Dart
LEAD: The Stop and Shop Companies filed suit against the Dart Group Corporation in connection with a tender offer made by Dart for the retail company's stock.
Stop and Shop earlier rejected Dart's offer of $37 a share.
The suit, which was filed in Federal District Court in Boston, charges that Dart violated Federal laws by not disclosing its purported intention to raise Stop and Shop's stock price so that Dart could sell its holdings at a higher price.


Guidepost
LEAD:  Yields on I.R.A.'s  Bank promotions for Individual Retirement Accounts are expected to be modest this year, compared with the marketing blitz when the I.R.A. was the most popular tax deduction for middle- and upper-income taxpayers.
But despite new restrictions on the deductibility of contributions, the I.R.A remains a viable savings instrument.

LEAD: A free guide, published by the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, offers information that is of special interest to museum visitors with physical disabilities.
In addition to general information, ''A Guide for Disabled Visitors'' indicates the availability of wheelchairs, sign-language interpreters and sound amplification at the Smithsonian's 13 facilities.

Doctors in Erie, Pa., have advised John Bowen, the Gannon University forward who is one of the leading rebounders in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division II, not to play basketball again this season because of a mild stroke.

Jazz: Buddy Tate at 72
LEAD: Long ago, the tenor saxophonist Buddy Tate reached the point where every set of his deserved to be recorded.
He's made an art out of unpredictability: at age 72, his solos have a feeling of wildness to them; they career into raunchy lower-register honks, then climb woozily into silvery squeaks, pushing the upper limits of his horn.

Gillette Stock Off; Profit Taking Seen
LEAD: Despite an announcement on Thursday that the investment group Coniston Partners holds a 6 percent stake in the Gillette Company, the stock yesterday fell $1.875 a share, to $39.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Many analysts attributed the drop to profit takers, who have watched their shares gain handsomely as it was rumored that someone was accumulating shares.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Auto Racing  Elliott Sets Mark: Bill Elliott never trailed in a record-setting victory yesterday in the opener of the Budweiser International Race of Champions series at Daytona International Speedway in Florida.
In the 40-lap, 100-mile race, Elliott averaged 186.239 miles per hour, the fastest winning speed in the series' history.

LEAD: The Topeka Sizzlers of the Continental Basketball Association have suspended Lloyd Daniels, the former New York City high school star, for the rest of the season because he failed to get into playing condition and had not participated in a drug rehabilitation program.

Producer Prices Up In January
LEAD: Prices at the producer level rose a surprising four-tenths of 1 percent in January, as higher food costs more than offset declines in energy prices, the Labor Department said yesterday.


Concert: Tokyo Quartet Presents More Beethoven
LEAD: Not least among the 92d Street Y's recent complete traversals of this and that is its current Beethoven quartet cycle with the Tokyo String Quartet, the second concert of which took place Wednesday night.


A Wrinkle Treatment Has Its Risks
LEAD: Retin-A, prescribed to treat acne since 1971, is suddenly in the spotlight as an alluring lotion that makes wrinkles disappear, fades brown spots and gives skin a rosy glow.
Dermatologists say it does, to some degree.
But it is strong medicine, involves a long-term commitment and is not for everyone.


Nevada County Is Held Illegal
LEAD: The formation of Bullfrog County, an unpopulated expanse of scrubland created to help the state win Federal dollars, violates the State Constitution, a judge has ruled.


Lorimar Reports $19 Million Loss
LEAD: The Lorimar Telepictures Corporation said today that it had lost $19.2 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31, largely because of a $22 million reserve for possible losses in its scandal-ridden home video subsidiary.


Kaisertech Units
LEAD: Kaisertech Ltd., the holding company for the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, said that it had agreed to sell the rest of its chemicals assets to various purchasers as part of its strategy to concentrate on its aluminum business.
In December, Kaiser announced its intention to sell the Harshaw/Filtrol Partnership, a specialty chemicals business, to the Engelhard Corporation.


Robertson Comments on South Africa Unrest
LEAD: Pat Robertson says black Americans ''don't understand what they're dealing with'' in South Africa, and that he will not criticize that nation to gain votes for his Presidential bid.


Retail Sales Up In New York
LEAD: Several of New York's leading department stores had average sales gains in January of 11.4 percent in the city and 7.4 percent in the area over January 1987, a spot-check found yesterday.

Bank Wary On Dollar
LEAD: The Bank of England said this week that the recent fall of the United States dollar was likely to prove more important to the world economy than the October stock market collapse.


Belgian Ends Societe Generale Role
LEAD: In a dramatic turnaround, the Belgian entrepreneur Andre Leysen today abruptly dropped out of the battle for control of Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest company, after 3 of his 18 partners refused to ratify his plan for expanded control.

More Children Must File And the Bill Will Be Higher
LEAD: For the nation's youth, this tax filing season is a turning point: Legions of children who never had to file a return before will be drafted into the ranks of the country's 105 million filers.
And children of all ages, from toddlers to college students, will be subjected to very different and harsher tax treatment.

Holiday on Monday
LEAD:  Washington's Birthday will be observed on Monday.
Following are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation: No collection or street sweeping.
Government offices: Federal, state and city offices are closed.
Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail delivery.


An F.B.I. Inquiry Fed by Informer Emerges in Analysis of Documents
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's sweeping inquiry into a group opposed to United States policy in Central America was largely fueled by an undercover informer who has said he invented much of his information.


About New York; Where Are You? A Nameless Man In a Grim World
LEAD: Where are you?
You weren't at the subway stop this morning.
Our mutual friend hasn't seen you either.
She's the one you touched by saying, ''You certainly look beautiful today -but then you always do.'' She would try to pass you by, and you would say something like that, and turn her on her heel.


Brooklyn Father Surrenders In Drug and Child-Abuse Case
LEAD: The father of two lice-infested young girls discovered in a suspected crack house in Brooklyn surrendered yersterday after seeking the help of a television reporter, the police said.


1 Slain in Manhattan Restaurant; Suspect Is Seized in the Shooting
LEAD: One man was killed and another was injured when a gunman opened fire in a lower Manhattan restaurant early yesterday, the police said.
A suspect was later arrested and charged in the shooting.


Older Skiers Gaining Interest in Slopes
LEAD: Gray power is becoming an important force on the ski slopes.


Cowboys, Not Boycotts
LEAD: If this is the Olympics, the headlines are supposed to be of politics and problems.
But not here in this Canadian prairie city of 640,000.
Not yet, anyway.


HOCKEY SPOTLIGHT SHUNNED
LEAD: Suddenly everybody wants to be a hockey underdog in the XV Olympic Winter Games.


New Squabbling In Israel Widens 2 Leaders' Split
LEAD: As violence flared again in the occupied territories, a rift in Israel's governing coalition widened today as Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir angrily accused Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of trying to ''sabotage'' his attempts at peace.


It's Time We Stopped Blaming the Homeless
LEAD: To the Editor:


Waldheim Backer Cites Jews
LEAD: A former Foreign Minister and close associate of President Kurt Waldheim charged today that the panel that investigated Mr.
Waldheim's wartime past was filled with Socialists or Jews.


Art: Opening of Degas Retrospective in Paris
LEAD: The Degas retrospective that opens Saturday at the Grand Palais is one of the great exhibitions this season.
With nearly 400 works, it is the largest Degas show in more than 50 years, spilling onto three levels of the museum.
It was so carefully selected and installed -and Degas's art, for all its nerve and audacity, is so reserved and discreet - that it is never unwieldy or overblown.


Refunds Bigger On '87 Returns
LEAD: Fewer Americans are rushing to file their Federal income tax returns this year as they grapple with the new rules of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
Returns are due by April 15.
For taxpayers who have filed early, however, the average refund is up almost 20 percent from last year, the Internal Revenue


OUSTED CALIFORNIA JUDGE IN CENTER OF NEW STORM
LEAD: Since the California voters ousted Rose Elizabeth Bird as Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court in 1986, she has not shied away from controversy.


8 in French Terror Group Get 10-Year Terms
LEAD: Eight members of the terrorist group Direct Action were sentenced today to 10 years each in prison, the maximum term, on charges of criminal conspiracy.


Taiwan Bars Rice Pact
LEAD: Taiwan will not renew a five-year rice agreement with the United States when it expires at the end of 1988 because the accord is ''unfair and unnecessary,'' Koh Chin-chao, deputy chairman of the Council of Agriculture, said this week.
The accord limited Taiwan's total rice exports to 1.375 million tons from 1984 to 1988.


The Afghan Future: With Soviet Pullout Offer, the Talks Build Momentum
LEAD: The Soviet Union's proposal for a 10-month withdrawal of its 115,000 troops from Afghanistan has plunged the United States, Pakistan and the Afghan guerrillas into intensive negotiations with one another over the wisdom of demanding that a coalition government be established in Kabul before an agreement is signed.


Iran Gulf Raid Kills a Dane
LEAD: An Iranian helicopter firing rockets and machine guns attacked a Danish supertanker in the Persian Gulf today, shipping executives said.
They said a Danish seaman was killed and three others wounded.
A spokesman for the owner, A. P. Moller of Copenhagen, said the attack crippled the 390,000-ton Kate Maersk.


Hoyt to Start Term
LEAD: At a time when other players will be reporting for spring training, LaMarr Hoyt will be going to prison.
The 1983 Cy Young Award winner, whose career has been plagued by drug-related problems, will begin serving a year in Federal prison Feb. 22 for a probation violation in California.
On Thursday, Hoyt was sentenced in Columbia, S.C., to two and a half years in prison by Special Judge Frank Eppes.


Gannett-Cowles
LEAD: The Gannett Company, the diversified media company that publishes USA Today, said it had sold its 640,492 shares of the Cowles Media Company back to Cowles for $200 a share, or $128 million.
Gannett had acquired the shares of the Minneapolis-based concern in 1985 for about $83 million.
Most of the stake had been acquired in connection with Gannett's acquisition of The Des Moines Register, The Jackson (Tenn.) Sun and two Iowa weeklies from The Register and Tribune Company.


Test for Consumers: Finding the Real Bargain in Electronics
LEAD: It's high season for electronics bargains.
Presidents' Birthdays sales, running at full tilt, allow dealers to clear inventories before new products are introduced in April and May.


Misguided Guidelines on AIDS in Court
LEAD: AIDS inflicts suffering on its victims and their families - and unreasonable fear on many people who should know better.
The latest to succumb to such fear are New York State court officers and judges, many of whom apparently believe that defendants afflicted with AIDS imperil others in the courtroom.


Double Life Of a Murderer Shocks S.I.
LEAD: In the homeless shelters and the soup kitchens on Staten Island where he worked, Bob Lord was known as a gentle and compassionate man.

Mattel Closes Two Plants
LEAD: Mattel Inc. said today that it had closed two plants in the Philippines where its Barbie doll production was slowed by labor strife and that it had dismissed 4,000 workers.
Doll making was transferred to the company's other plants in Asia and Mexico.

Mets Say Gooden Accepts Idea of Cut
LEAD: Dwight Gooden's contract negotiations with the Mets took their most significant turn yesterday since Gooden filed for salary arbitration four weeks ago.
Al Harazin, the Mets' negotiator, said that for the first time, Gooden's agent had said he would be willing to accept the idea of a pay cut.


An Odd Stage in an Unusual Theater
LEAD: Thomas Eisenhardt performing yesterday on the platform of the Bowling Green subway station in Manhattan.
The show was a preview of ''Vespers Underground: Mass Transit'' to be put on next week by the Changing Dance Theater at the Merce Cunningham Studio. (The New York Times/Angel Franco)


Europeans Agree on a Budget Overhaul
LEAD: An emergency meeting of the leaders of the 12-nation European Community reached a laboriously negotiated agreement early today that will permit an overhaul of its finances and ease the transition to a barrier-free market by 1992.


Rumania, Faulted by West, Returns Aide to U.N.
LEAD: The Rumanian Government, which has been strongly criticized by Western governments for its human rights record, unexpectedly allowed one of its citizens to return to his United Nations post in Geneva today after confining him to Rumania for over two years.

LEAD: Far from Flatbush, where her marriage proposal was conditional on the great adventure of migration to biblical Judea, Pauline Moskowitz said her husband is recovering now, his skull but not his spirit fractured by Palestinian stone throwers.


Banks' Plans On Mexico
LEAD: Leading United States banks are not expected to participate in Mexico's innovative debt-reduction plan, an American banker said today.
But a senior official at the Swiss Bank Corporation said his bank will tender some loans.

Mr. Gephardt's Reckless Driving
LEAD: Richard Gephardt is campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination in a misused car.
A Hyundai costs $10,000 in America, he says, but a comparable Chrysler K car would cost $48,000 in South Korea because Seoul slaps on ''nine separate tariffs.'' Mr.
Gephardt's wrong-way stance on trade policy has led him to abuse the facts.

LEAD: Officials of The New York Post and the leaders of its 10 unions will meet Monday to discuss $24 million in cost cuts that Rupert Murdoch, the owner, calls mandatory if the paper is to be sold to a real-estate developer and not closed next Friday.

LEAD: The first game is three months away, but already the ranks of the International Basketball Association, the league for players 6 feet 4 inches and shorter, have been diminished.
The league has suffered the loss of one team and the movement of another one that is having trouble keeping its head above water.

Fed Minutes Show Revival of Old Policy
LEAD: With the economy calming down following the rout of the stock market, the Federal Reserve began reverting in December and January to its economic policies of the months before the collapse and worrying less about interest rates, the Fed said today.


Black &amp; Decker Is Backed on Bid
LEAD: The Black &amp; Decker Corporation announced that a group of commercial banks had arranged $2.2 billion in financing for the company's $2.1 billion hostile takeover attempt of American Standard Inc.
The syndicate comprises 19 domestic and foreign banks, including Chase Manhattan Bank, which earlier pledged $750 million of its own funds toward the deal, the company said.

Music: American Songs
LEAD: A perhaps unintended message from Wednesday's evening with the Alliance for American Song was that social rectitude and the musical muse do not necessarily walk hand in hand.
Patrons of Weill Recital Hall, at any rate, were treated to a fascinating history - set to music - of this country's continuing indignation over the rich, the rapacious and the repressive among our own.

Why the Melody Doesn't Linger On
LEAD: What ever hap-pened to melody in popular music?
I'm not talking about tunes - hummable little ditties with short catch phrases - but a fluid, cohesive theme of at least 16 bars in which no musical phrase is repeated.
Richard Rodgers's ''Some Enchanted Evening'' has such a melody.
As it flows along, moving through rich, unforced chromatic harmonies, its indelibility can't be explained by the hammering home of a formula.


Trade Gap Narrows For the 2d Month
LEAD: The trade deficit for December was the lowest in 11 months, coming in at $12.2 billion.
With imports unchanged, the improvement came from a 4.2 percent gain in exports, to a record $24.8 billion.
Most predictions had been for a December deficit of at least $13 billion, and the financial markets strengthened when the report came out.

LEAD: IT was when I was walking into the lobby of one of New York's finest old hotels that I realized the world isn't small after all.
I had just returned from summer vacation.
The distance between the remote Irish coastal village where we have a holiday cottage and this gilded and brocaded interior was so vast that they seemed separated not only by an ocean but also by centuries.

Lovers are celebrating today with flowers and candy; shoppers are reving up for Presidents' Day sales; travelers are heading to New Orleans for Mardi Gras, and serious eaters are in training for Chinese New Year feasts.

LEAD: Richard A. Gephardt and Paul Simon clawed at each other today in a fight for second place in the New Hampshire Democratic primary next Tuesday.
They were battling despite the fact that since 1952 no one has been elected President without coming in first in the New Hampshire primary.


Philadelphians Choosing Sides Over City Hall
LEAD: If there is anything in this city that is the target of more jokes than the city itself, it is City Hall. ''The world's most beautiful ugly building,'' a ''monument to corruption,'' an ''architectural abomination'' are among the many unflattering descriptions the building has earned.

LEAD: In the 1988 Presidential campaign, with its crowded field and surfeit of debates, about the last thing anyone expected was to have a deficit of candidates for a Republican debate three days before the New Hampshire primary.

LEAD: Political action committees say they are increasingly resentful of greedy lawmakers, yet go along with their demands for contributions for fear of losing vital access in Congress.

LEAD: SIXTY parking spaces and a few signposts are all that stand in the way of new Amtrak rail service at Yonkers, according to Amtrak officials and Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko of Yonkers.


Notebook; Sutter Among 75 Seeking Post-Injury Comebacks
LEAD: IN the Georgia countryside north of Atlanta, in the town of Kennesaw, there's a piece of rustic property 50 acres or so in size.
Tucked away among the trees on that property are a pond, a swimming pool, a tennis court - and a pitcher's mound.
On that mound the past week has stood the man who owns the property, and Bruce Sutter wasn't standing on it just to survey his domain.

LEAD: THIS summer when J. Russell King of New York and his mother, Mary Ann King of Ardmore, Okla., fly to London on vacation, they will take different airlines and land at separate airports.
Mrs.
King will take Delta at no cost; her coupon was a Christmas gift from a son-in-law who travels in his work and had points to share.

LEAD: In an effort to show that its transactions with Richard A. Gephardt's Presidential campaign were legitimate, a Washington bank furnished documents today detailing $1.4 million in loans it made to the campaign last year.

LEAD: Lured by out-of-date house prices and a twin set of superhighways, growing numbers of New York and New Jersey residents are settling into dozens of small northeastern Pennsylvania communities stretching from the old mill town of Easton to the heart of honeymoon land in the Pocono mountains.

LEAD: The young woman in Gdynia, on the Baltic coast, recounted how her father, a former close associate of Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, had left Poland with the rest of the family, complaining that there was no future.


Gurkhas Attack in India
LEAD: Militant Gurkhas blew up road bridges, set fire to government offices and ambushed a police patrol on Friday night as a 40-day strike called to press their demand for autonomy took hold, security officials said.


THE DRINK-A-DAY LORE
LEAD: At last, some straight talk about a highly ambiguous subject by a responsible commentator (Body and Mind: ''The Drink-a-Day Lore,'' by William Ira Bennett, Jan. 10)!
The flaws in the various studies that seem to demonstrate ''protective'' value in one or two drinks a day are not so subtle that the interested public could not understand them.

LEAD: A SMILING young couple pose above the caption ''They Found Each Other Through the Personal Ads,'' and each time I notice them, I wonder if they are merely some editor's fiction, extended from the fantasies reflected in the ads themselves.


Mexico
LEAD: To the Editor: Your readers should be aware of one inaccuracy in the otherwise very informative article on economic factors affecting tourists to Mexico (''Mexican Prices Down Just a Bit,'' Travel, Dec. 13).
While it may be true that in Mexico some credit cards ''use the controlled rate'' (about 1,750 pesos to the dollar) American Express does not.

LEAD: Jacqueline Dejud will return to her native Panama this spring with a bachelor's degree in business and a desire to ''find work, to help my family, and to improve, as much as I can, my country as well.''

LEAD: If you enjoy watching Americans win gold medals, pay close attention when full-scale competition starts Sunday in the XV Olympic Winter Games.
The Americans' best chance for a gold medal in these Olympics will come in the men's 500-meter speed skating.

LEAD: WAY before the advent of MTV and VCR's, the Westbury Music Fair, the eclectic entertainment center, was making a pitch for younger audiences.
Its co-producer, Shelly Gross, even remembers the time Stevie Wonder was an opening act - he doesn't remember the act that followed - and the Doors and the Beegees played the theater in the round in the early 1960's.

LEAD: Suzanne Mubarak, the wife of the Egyptian President, rejects the job description of ''first lady.'' That, she says, is ''an imported, a Western title'' in Egypt.

LEAD: A careful study of the newer types of statistics, like slugging percentage and on-base average, show that Mantle, particularly the Mantle of the 1950's, was one of the most prolific and valuable baseball players of all time, a shade below Ruth, Williams and Gehrig.

LEAD: THE Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck, as it so often does, provides a wonderful diversity of musical treats this week.
Because many county youngsters are enjoying school holidays, children's programs fill the midday, midweek roster, starting tomorrow and Tuesday, when Puppetworks goes ''Around the World in 80 Days'' in what the troupe describes as ''a vivid and specially designed production'' of the Jules Verne classic.

I scrubbed the floor with a strong household detergent and the odor is not as strong, but it is still there.

Mantle is frozen as a good ol' boy, fronting a saloon, buddy to Martin and Ford, running to fat in public.

Broadcast TV
LEAD: Televising an Olympic Games is only slighlty less complicated than staging one.
ABC, which televised both the Winter and Summer Games in 1984, has moved 17 tractor trailers of equipment to Calgary and plans 90 or so hours of programming, beginning last Saturday through Feb. 28.
Because of Calgary's Mountain Time zone location, most of ABC's coverage will be live.

Prospector colt was held back off the early pace for the first time and still proved an easy winner, but his final time and final furlong were not up to his standards.

Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
LEAD: An everyday player can compete in five areas: hit for average, hit for power, run, field and throw.
Mays could do all five excellently.
A lifetime .300 hitter, 660 home runs, a base-stealing threat at all times, he made great catches (see Vic Wertz, 1954 World Series) and great throws (see Billy Cox thrown out at home trying to score from third on a single to right-center field).


Boy Scouts to Allow Women to Be Leaders
LEAD: Officials of the Boy Scouts of America have voted to allow women in leadership positions, including scoutmaster, ending a male-only policy that has often been challenged in court, organization officials say.

LEAD: Billy Wilder is to receive the Irving G. Thalberg Award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Oscar night, April 11.
The award honors a body of work that ''reflects a consistently high quality of motion picture production.''

Q AND A
LEAD:  Security Deposit  Question: For several years we received interest on the security deposit for the apartment we rent.
This year we received notification that the interest had been withheld due to the Interest and Dividend Tax Compliance Act of 1983.
Can you tell me what this act is and why we did not get interest this year?

LEAD: Because James LeMoyne wrote at considerable length on Nicaragua in his article on Costa Rican President Oscar Arias, I am compelled to respond to two inaccuracies.


WHAT'S NEW IN OUTPLACEMENT
LEAD: IN 1980, the outplacement industry - which, simply put, is the business of counseling people who have lost their jobs - recorded $35 million in revenues, according to James H. Kennedy, publisher of Consultants News.
By 1986, revenues had grown to $225 million, with the number of firms rising to 154 from 43.

Prentice, is not cured but liberated and exploited.

LEAD:  N.H.L.

What to Look for in Laser Printers
LEAD: SOME companies justify the higher expense of a laser printer on a strict bottom-line analysis.
A laser costing $2,000 or more can be shared by several personal computers and cough out material quickly enough to keep everybody happy - none of the waiting in line that slower shared printers create.
On a per-user basis, that can eliminate the price advantage of daisy wheels and dot matrix printers.

LEAD: In college I took methedrine and read Chaucer.
This was in 1968.
During the day we sat in at Army induction centers, and at night we went to our boyfriends' apartments and took drugs and read Chaucer because there was a required Chaucer section on the senior English honors exam and we couldn't graduate with honors without it.

THE DRINK-A-DAY LORE
LEAD: It seems to me that just because we do not understand how alcohol lowers the cardiac death rate is no reason not to recommend it.
After all, it took over 200 years for us to understand how digoxin helps the heart.
Furthermore, Dr.
Bennett might have mentioned that there are several other epidemiologic studies that show that the overall death rate, cardiac as well as noncardiac, is reduced by moderate alcohol intake.

Brazil
LEAD: To the Editor: I appreciated the Dec. 27 ''Following the Sun'' feature with emphasis on the Brazil discoveries of Paraty and Sao Jose da Coroa Grande.
I lived in Brazil for two and a half years and am familiar with both areas.
They are ideal for the American who wishes to see parts of Brazil that the ordinary tourist would not see.

Q AND A
LEAD: Older Drivers  Question: I understand that Ireland has a limit of 70 years old on drivers renting cars.
Are there such limitations in other European countries? - B. K., Ambler, Pa. -  Answer: Drivers over age 70 can rent a car in Ireland.
It is true that some auto rental companies there (not Ireland itself) set an age limit of 69 or 70, but the two largest agencies, which are both represented in the United States, do not.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  A COMMON ROOM: Essays 1954-1987.
By Reynolds Price. (Atheneum, $23.95.) Most writers know something about their motives, though few are as impassioned - or as expansive - as Reynolds Price is in sharing them.
Indeed, in many of these 57 essays by the acclaimed author of ''Kate Vaiden'' and other novels, the treacherous business of examining artistic intent - in his own writing as well as in others' - is managed with considerable grace.


EMERGENCY WORKERS AND AIDS
LEAD: It is easy to sit in an ivory tower and say that the firemen of Baltimore overreacted.
I am a registered nurse, and the day I pricked my finger with a patient's bloody needle, my life changed.
Because it would be a violation of his rights to have him tested against his will, it is I who must endure months, maybe years, of testing, waiting, wondering.


Going for the Gold in California
LEAD: ON a small, grassy hill overlooking the ruins of Chinese Camp, an old mining settlement, stands St.
Francis Xavier Roman Catholic church.
The tombstones in its graveyard bear the names of Irish and English immigrants who crossed the Atlantic in search of gold.
But the most arresting monument to those who sought riches here is the lush canopy of trees that covers much of the town.

LEAD: Q. Recently I moved into a house that has a sunroom with a slate floor.
I suspect that the previous owners had kept pets in this room because there is a strong odor of urine, especially when the windows are closed.
I scrubbed the floor with a strong household detergent and the odor is not as strong, but it is still there.

A Balmy Beach Town In New South Wales
LEAD: I SAW Byron Bay for the first time three years ago.
I was driving north on the coastal highway from Sydney to Brisbane with my wife.
The rain had stopped just beyond the town of Ballina, where the highway snakes inland toward the foothills of the northern coastal ranges.
By the time we were west of Byron Bay, the iron-gray wedge of cloud had lifted to let the sun cast its warm, early evening light across the undulating grasslands to the flat brown marshes and pale dunes on the ocean's edge.


SHOWER DOORS FOR AN ELEGANT TOUCH
LEAD: IF your bathtub is installed in a recess, that is, if the tub is surrounded by walls on three sides, creating a built-in appearance, one of the easiest ways to add a touch of elegance is to install bathtub shower doors in place of a shower curtain.


Helping the Disabled Find Careers in the Arts
LEAD: CAN ONE be realistic about the arts and still make money?
Yes.
The New Jersey Department of Labor's Division of Vocational Rehabilitation Services is a career-networking providing system that is designed to help the disabled find employment in the arts and promote the products of the division's clients.

Dance: City Ballet in Balanchine's 'Bugaku'
LEAD: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Bugaku'' is very peculiar.
It often looks cliche-ridden, even corny.
But the cliches turn into surprises, and even the corniest scene has a serious point. ''Bugaku'' was as fascinating as ever when the New York City Ballet danced it Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

ITALIAN FARE FOR HEALTHY APPETITES
LEAD: PEPPERCORN GRILL in Hartford is just what the ravenous diner ordered.
Slipping easily into the high-ceilinged storefront space formerly occupied by Panache, this sparkling new eatery has high-voltage visual impact.
Its white walls hold etchings, paintings and bright neon sculptures counterpointed by red chairs and park benches and track lighting in a black ceiling.

How's that for self-assertiveness?


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Business Forum article by E. Norman Veasey on Feb. 7, about Delaware's new takeover law, omitted a phrase.
The second sentence of the first paragraph should have read: ''This statute requires certain hostile bidders to obtain the approval of the disinterested stockholders - other than the bidder or management - in order for the takeover bidder's shares to have voting power.

LEAD: If President Reagan is worried about the Federal deficit, he conceals it well.
He is the man, after all, who has more than doubled the national debt in a mere seven years.

The Prince and His Czar - Letters From Exile
LEAD: The countries of the world should be divided into two classes, countries of immigrants and countries of emigres.
Everybody knows that America - her might, her prosperity, her culture - has been created mainly, if not exclusively, by huddled masses yearning to breathe free.
The culture of Russia, on the other hand, has been created, almost to the same extent, by her emigres, the wretched refuse of that ancient, pompous empire.

HUMAN FIGURES ENSHRINED BY THE EARLY GREEKS
LEAD: Like other Greek sculptures of standing women, or korai, this figure is frontal, her left leg slightly in front of the right.
Her face is fleshy, ripe, her expression both attentive and aloof.
Unlike Greek sculptures of standing males, she is clothed, but she seems both more naked and more secret than male figures nearby.

Annual AIDS Test
LEAD: Boxers are not one of the groups known to be at heightened risk of contracting AIDS.
Nevertheless, over the last year, British boxing authorities have screened foreign boxers for acquired immune deficiency syndrome, New Jersey authorities have mandated plastic gloves for all cornermen, and the medical advisory board to the New York State Athletic Commission has recommended that all boxers and ring personnel undergo tests for the virus.

Correction
LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on page 3 in some copies of the Travel section today misstates airline policy on frequent flier programs.
Points cannot be shared among family members belonging to an airline's program, although the coupons awarded at fixed point levels can be.

Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
LEAD: The sight of Mantle limping to home plate, of Mantle dripping blood down the right leg or fruitlessly chasing Roger Maris elevated a generation as he carried a team.
The human frailty of his fatal flaws made Mantle a mythical hero and made baseball accessible to 10-year-old boys who would marvel at the Joe Hardy in pinstripes and wait for next year when the Mick would play a full season without being injured.

Move Over, Ozzie and Harriet
LEAD: The only family that can disappoint you more than your own is a network executive's vision of a family.
Television betrayed us when it gave us the perfect 1950's families in which every daughter was a princess and every son an honest and brave all-American boy.
Our parents could never measure up to the kindness and patience we saw dispensed on television, and yet it seemed they should.

Words Can Be Their Own Music
LEAD: Some years ago, i was fascinated to learn that an ambitious British composer had chosen as a theme thoughts from Ludwig Wittgenstein's ''Tractatus Logico-philosophicus,'' one of the most brilliantly arcane works in the history of linguistics.
For all I know, many musicians who were also professional philosophers took it into their repertories, but I never heard of it again.

But when Del Dellal, a partner in MFD Holding Ltd., purchased the vacant building at a city auction in 1986, he was rejected by several banks for financing and had to finance the $280,000 project himself.

THE WEDDING
LEAD: THE MORE THINGS CHANGE, the more they stay the same.
Almost.
The formal, traditional wedding is back, in many cases with unprecedented lavishness.
Even second weddings are more festive today.
But rather than following a standard script, more brides and grooms are putting their personal stamp on the wedding ceremony and reception.

Question of the Week; Who Was Better, Mantle, Mays (or Snider)?
LEAD: Mantle was clearly superior to Mays, which is obvious at the first look at statistics.
The two had identical lifetime slugging percentages, at .557, but Mantle's on-base percentage was higher, .420 to .383.
Since these are the two most important offensive categories, Mantle already has him beat, but Mantle also had a higher stolen-base percentage, .80 to .77, and grounded into six fewer double plays per year than Mays.

Letting Off Steam: Con Ed Rebates
LEAD: To those unfamiliar with central air-conditioning systems, steam seems the last thing to make them go.
But two types of systems are powered by steam heated to more than 400 degrees.
To remind building owners and co-op boards that steam can do more than provide heat, Consolidated Edison, which sells the steam it makes to generate electricity, is offering rebates until the end of the year of up to 50 percent to those that either upgrade a steam system or install a new one.

Austere and autocratic, Mr.
Macioce kept a tight rein on operations from afar, handing down orders to the field through a layer of seven group executives.


HUSBAND'S AWAY? IT MUST BE SNOWING
LEAD: IT never fails: when it snows in unpredictably large proportions, my husband is always out of town and I'm left to do the dirty work.
There is no consolation when I pick up the phone at 6 A.M. on a Tuesday and hear my teaching colleague say, ''School's closed today.
Pass the word.'' She can well afford to be happy about it, because her husband will be there to shovel the driveway and revive the frozen automobile.

Soiled Sails In the South Seas
LEAD: THEY'RE KNOWN, TECHNICAL-ly, as ''tension membrane structures.'' But officials of World Expo 88, which opens in Brisbane, Australia, on April 30, call them ''sun sails,'' which seems appropriate; the theme of Expo 88 is, after all, ''Leisure in the Age of Technology.'' Made of a polyester fabric, the eight translucent canopies, each about 390 feet in diameter and together sheltering a ground area of close to 360,000 square feet, form the most striking architectural feature of the exposition site.

What's Doing In Puerto Vallarta
LEAD: It is still possible to hear a rooster crow at dawn or midnight in Puerto Vallarta, but one must listen carefully.
The city is on the go almost nonstop, especially from now until Easter.
Streets are jammed with cars, trucks and shoppers in the daytime.
Restaurants and bars are open late; 10 P.M. is a respectable time for supper.

Art
LEAD: The print, more than the painting, has been the chosen medium for political and social comment by artists.
Traditionally, it's had a wider audience, and it's closer to the printed word.
In recent years, though, we've been trained to view prints as more related to painting, alternate means for the artful expression of forms and colors.

LEAD: The youth and early manhood of Jean-Honore Fragonard (1732-1806) are a joy to contemplate.
He was quick, gifted, eager and adaptable.
In a stocky, well-fleshed way he was very good looking.
Everything went well for him, though he missed out on the classic art education that he could have got from the Academie in Paris.

Anchovies From Spain
LEAD: ALL along the Costa Brava, the stretch of coast that runs from Barcelona to the French border, Catalan bread topped with anchovies is a typical way to begin a meal at home and in restaurants.
Pa amb tomaquet, slices of bread lightly toasted, rubbed with fresh tomato, then doused with one of the region's virgin olive oils, is the base.

LEAD: A suit against the magazine Soldier of Fortune, brought by the family of the victim of a hired killer, will be heard in Federal District Court here next week.

LEAD: Andre Dawson, who virtually had to beg the Chicago Cubs for a job a year ago, encountered another setback with them yesterday.

U.S. TEXTILE INDUSTRY'S TURNAROUND
LEAD: Five years ago the textile industry looked pretty bad.
It was battered by imports and hampered by outmoded plants.
Since then, however, it has poured money into modernization and today has become one of the most efficient industries in the United States - operating at near capacity and turning out steady profits.

Art: Orsay's 'Van Gogh in Paris'
LEAD: For the first major exhibition at the Musee d'Orsay, ''Van Gogh in Paris'' is a natural.
With van Gogh, popular success is assured.
The subject is the crucial period between March 1886 and February 1888, when van Gogh lived in Paris and introduced his palette and brush to space and light.
Defining the importance of 19th-century Paris for a great Dutch artist underlines the importance of this year-old museum of 19th-century French art.

The Editorial Notebook; A Tale of Two Georges
LEAD: George III and Henry VI were the two maddest kings of England.
They had another connection, through the school for needy scholars that Henry VI founded in the shadow of Windsor Castle.
George III (pictured here) often sought refuge there from the intrigues of London and his attacks of porphyria, a disorder that affected his mental balance.

British Inflation Eases
LEAD: Britain's annual inflation rate registered its sharpest decline in 15 months in January, the Department of Employment said Friday.
It said that the Retail Price Index remained unchanged for the month and that the price increase for the year came to 3.3 percent.
The annual inflation figure in December was 3.7 percent.

LEAD: The University of Rhode Island's Thursday night fraternity parties have succumbed to the complaints of professors who teach Friday morning classes.

LEAD:  NEW YORK  Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation: No collection or street sweeping.
Government offices: Federal, state and city offices are closed.
Post offices: Closed, except for special delivery and Express Mail.
Banks: Option to close.
Financial markets: Closed.
Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedule, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedule.

James King, 74, Dead; Expert on Arms Control
LEAD: James E. King, a specialist in arms control and disarmament who served for many years in Government and academic posts, died of lung cancer on Feb. 1 at his home in Garrett Park, Md.
He was 74 years old.
Mr.
King, a native of Sumter, S.C., was a graduate of Harvard and a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford.
He taught government at Harvard before serving in the Army in World War II.

Reporter's Notebook; Private Talks on a Broken Knuckle at the Chambers Trial
LEAD: Robert E. Chambers Jr.'s right hand was so badly injured that he couldn't even make a fist.
There were bite marks and he apparently had a broken knuckle.
About three hours after he was arrested and charged with the murder of Jennifer Levin, and about 19 hours after her body was discovered, he was taken by the police to a hospital emergency room for treatment.

He was 86 years old.

Esposito, smiling at his own immodesty, simply pointed to his head.

The Treaty, Europeans and the Jitters
LEAD: What does Europe think of the treaty to eliminate Euromissiles?
The answer, as the Senate weighs ratification, is clear: Virtually all West European leaders support the treaty.
Some Americans say that behind the official blessings lie deep divisions and doubts.
But they confuse genuine support for this treaty and equally genuine concern about the state of the alliance.

A.

LEAD: The New York Post and its unions yesterday held tense talks on ways for the newspaper to save $24 million over the next three years, but agreed only to meet around the clock starting tomorrow in a last effort to avert a shutdown of the paper on Friday.


U.S. and Florida Fight Texas and California Over Citrus Shipments
LEAD: State and Federal officials are fighting efforts by Texas and California to keep out Florida citrus fruit after the lifting of a Federal ban imposed to keep a plant disease from spreading.


Bartlett H. Hayes Jr., an Educator And Art Historian, Is Dead at 83
LEAD: Bartlett H. Hayes Jr., an educator and art historian who was director for many years of the Addison Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., died of congestive heart failure on Sunday in Peterboro, N.H.
He was 83 years old and had lived in Peterboro since 1985.

LEAD: Carlos Fuentes, the Mexican novelist and critic, is to receive the Medal of Honor for Literature from the National Arts Club, at 15 Gramercy Park South, at its 20th annual literary award dinner on Feb. 24.

LEAD: 20th Century-Fox has paid Bruce Willis $5 million to star in a movie.
For Hollywood, the result is equivalent to an earthquake.
The map of movie-star salaries must now be redrawn.


Chess: A Dazzling Dzindzichashvili Wins the Continental Open
LEAD: The 19th annual Continental Open Tournament, held at the Hilton Hotel in Rye, N.Y., was won by Roman Dzindzichashvili.
The New York grandmaster, who originally hailed from the Soviet Union, scored 5-1 to capture the $2,000 first prize in the six-round Swiss-system event.


Concert: Ukrainian Choral Music
LEAD: IT is not every day that one celebrates an important millennium.
It was in A.D. 988 that the Ukrainians formally accepted the church into their lives, and this 1,000 years of Christianity was marked by a festive, grandly scaled evening of music at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday.
A big mixed chorus from Georgia - the Choral Guild of Atlanta - sang; members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra played, and there were five singers from the international opera scene.

LEAD: A turbine blade from an Eastern Air Lines A-300 Airbus shattered on takeoff today and started a brush fire just outside the airport, but the twin-engine plane returned safely and no one was injured, officials said.

LEAD: DRUGS that induce miscarriages may eventually replace traditional surgical abortions in the first three months of pregnancy, according to a World Health Organization official.

Margaret Parker Isaac, Art Gallery Manager
LEAD: Margaret Parker Isaac, the manager of the Fourcade Gallery in Manhattan for 14 years until last October, died in an automobile accident on Dec. 19, just outside of Winchester, Va.
She was 35 years old.
Her 14 month-old daughter, Marina, survived the crash unharmed.

LEAD: President Mauno Koivisto was re-elected to a second six-year term today, winning a second-round victory in the electoral college.


G.M. Eases Dealer Policy
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation is easing its long-held opposition to publicly traded automobile dealers, a key executive said today.
The development could spur stock offerings by some of the large multifranchise dealers that are beginning to dominate the retail car market.


76ers Will Retire No. 6
LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers said yesterday they would retire Julius Erving's number before an April 19 game against the Milwaukee Bucks.
Wearing the number 6, Erving scored 18,364 points with the 76ers over 11 seasons before he retired at the end of last season. ''If there was ever an athlete, or a man, deserving of this honor, it's certainly Julius Erving,'' said the 76ers' owner, Harold Katz.


Pirelli Is Silent On Firestone
LEAD: Several Italian newspapers said over the weekend that Pirelli S.p.A. was negotiating to acquire the tire division of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for $1 billion.
But Pirelli, the world's fifth-largest tire maker with sales of $3.65 billion last year, declined today to confirm or deny the reports.

MUELLER GLIDES TO GOLD IN LUGE
LEAD: Jens Mueller of East Germany rode his luge down the 4,104-foot course at Canada Olympic Park in 46.367 seconds yesterday in the fourth and final heat for a two-day total of 3 minutes 5.548 seconds, nearly four-tenths of a second faster than Georg Hackl of West Germany at 3:05.916.


Translation of Ancient Tao Text Brings $130,000
LEAD: After a spirited auction involving eight publishers, Harper &amp; Row has agreed to pay $130,000 for a new translation of a Chinese book of philosophy and religion written more than 2,000 years ago.
The amount is one of the highest ever paid to a translator, and it is certainly the most for a work in the public domain that has already been translated into English dozens of times.

LEAD: IT has been a long time since musicians competed against other musicians in the Olympics.
And a good thing, too.
The Greeks, who were wise in many ways, probably went wrong in putting musical performance in the same category as discus throwing.
It is a waste of time to try to rank artists, grading them as if they were prime, choice or utility cuts of athletic meat.

Its remedy is wrong.
Senate and House conferees, who today start negotiating the final trade bill, would do well to let this part die.

LEAD: James Diggs and Anthony Colon come from troubled and impoverished families, from neighborhoods where drugs offer the constant temptation of escape and quick money, and both have poor academic skills.

A Helpful Oncogene
LEAD: A GREAT deal of research has focused on oncogenes and the changes in their DNA that makes them either dangerous or useful, but now a scientist has discovered a potentially important property of the much studied oncogene called ras.
When activated in cells growing in laboratory cultures, ras makes those cells resistant to radiation.


Fryar Is Arrested
LEAD: Irving Fryar, the New England Patriots' wide receiver, was arrested Sunday on weapons charges in Pemberton, N.J., after a state trooper found a loaded shotgun and handgun and a hunting knife in Fryar's car, the police said.
Fryar, 25 years old, had been stopped for speeding.
He was charged with four counts of illegal weapons possession and released on $100 bail.

LEAD: The frigid winter waters off Simons Point, a flicker of land in Flanders Bay, are not particularly friendly to marine life.

LEAD: On a typical winter day, gulls outnumber the hardy visitors who brave icy Atlantic winds to walk here at Jones Beach.


Syracuse Player Quits
LEAD: Keith Hughes, a 6-foot-7-inch sophomore forward from Carteret, N.J., has quit the Syracuse basketball team and left school, according to Syracuse officials.
Hughes sat out five of Syracuse's last six games after averaging 16 minutes a game during the Orangemen's first 17 contests.
He was averaging 5.4 points and 2.7 rebounds per game.

With So Much Known, Exploration Evolves
LEAD: WHEN dreams drifted off to the Indies and Antipodes, when the source of the Nile beckoned from beyond every cataract, no one entertained any doubt about the meaning of exploration.
To explore was to follow human curiosity to the ends of the earth.
To explore - the word, in one version of its etymology, comes from the Latin to cry out - was to search out and exclaim discovery.

LEAD: The $2.7 billion nuclear aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln was christened and launched here Saturday.
The 1,092-foot ship is the Navy's fifth Nimitz class nuclear-powered carrier.
All have been built at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, where a sixth Nimitz carrier, the George Washington, is scheduled for completion in 1991.

By Design; Fashion Fallacies
LEAD: Some undeniably chic fashions are also expected to be functional.
But let's face it: they often aren't.
Take jump suits.
Forever being touted as the most contemporary, streamlined attire, they are, in fact, often a hindrance.
Just try dealing with one in a jumbo jet's minuscule bathroom.
Also, since a jump suit is cut in one piece, unless it is fitted perfectly, it tends to ride up.

ADVANCES: REPLACING AN ANCIENT PHONE NET
LEAD: EACH time employees place a call on the Federal Government's telephone system, they use technology put together a quarter-century ago and that has now become so outmoded and expensive to operate that it would be cheaper to place the calls on the public telephone system.
Federal officials say that getting a sophisticated new telephone network into place as soon as possible is essential to cut costs and deal with the growing volume of information associated with the typical bureaucrat's job.


Military 4 1/2, Civilians 2
LEAD: James C. Miller 3d, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, told a group of Republican members of the House of Representatives yesterday that the budget President Reagan is to submit on Thursday will call for wage increases of 4.5 percent for those in the military but less than half of that, 2 percent, in wage increases for civilians employed by the


Withholding Snag for Some
LEAD: Many Americans may have had too little tax withheld from their paychecks last year, so they will owe money when they file their tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service said today.


One Marketplace, Indivisible
LEAD: The financial markets in New York and Chicago today stand at a crossroads.
They can fight turf battles or they can take the bold steps needed to stabilize the markets.
One thing is certain, though: Without proper safeguards, there remains the long-term potential for a stock market break of the severity and speed of last

Al Cohn, 62, a Jazz Saxophonist, Arranger and Partner of Zoot Sims
LEAD: Al Cohn, a tenor saxophonist and arranger who worked with the Artie Shaw, Buddy Rich and Woody Herman orchestras, died of liver cancer Monday in Poconos Hospital in East Stroudsburg, Pa.
He was 62 years old and lived in Canadensis, Pa.

LEAD: Almost a year after the Governor's housing commissioner defended his agency's record in administering New York City's rent laws against a blistering attack by legislators, the Cuomo administration now says that the basic activities of the Office of Rent Administration are ''not functioning.''

Cruel, and Needless, Choice of Refugees
LEAD: Thailand's patience has snapped.
After years of receiving refugees from Communist neighbors, it is now experiencing an unexpectedly large new flow from Vietnam.
Officials and deputized fishermen are pushing the boats full of newcomers back to sea.
More than 100 refugees have died - and now the U.S.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Feb. 9 about the Scandinavian Airlines System misstated the basis for the airline's ranking among European carriers.
It ranked eighth in revenue passenger miles - the number of paying passengers multiplied by the distance they are flown.


Wider Use of Experimental Drug For AIDS Ailment Is Approved
LEAD: Federal health officials today announced approval for wider use of an experimental drug to treat AIDS patients who suffer from a life-threatening form of pneumonia.


A King's Fall: Tax Changes Reverse Rise Of Developer
LEAD: The fortunes of one of New York City's most flamboyant real-estate executives, Gerald Guterman, have taken a precipitous fall.


BUSH OVERCOMES DOLE'S BID AND DUKAKIS IS EASY WINNER IN NEW HAMPSHIRE PRIMARIES
LEAD: Vice President Bush soundly defeated Senator Bob Dole in the New Hampshire Republican primary today, keeping his Presidential candidacy alive after one of the most difficult weeks in his political life.


For California Chardonnays, A Graceful 12-YeaR Evolution
LEAD: CALIFORNIA chardonnay is the Cinderella of American wines.
Largely klutzy, over-oaked and superalcoholic 12 years ago, it is today often seductively complex and smoother.

LEAD: In the pairs figure skating competition at the XV Olympic Winter Games, the Soviet Union, led by Yekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov, won the gold and silver medals.

Firestone to Sell 75% of Tire Unit In $1 Billion Deal With Japanese
LEAD: In what analysts describe as the largest investment by a Japanese company in an American manufacturing concern, the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had preliminarily agreed to sell 75 percent of its tire operations to the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan for $1 billion.


P.L.O. 'Exodus' Ferry Faces a Sea of Trouble
LEAD: The Sol Phryne lay at rest today, a ship of a certain age and an opaque past.
A sign on the gaping mouth of the ferry's car deck announced, belatedly, ''No visitors.''

American Given Life in I.R.A. Case in London
LEAD: An American, the first member of the Irish Republican Army to be extradited from the United States, was convicted today of killing a London policeman in 1975 and sentenced to life in prison.


Canada Sputters to Victory
LEAD: The tighter the game, and the less predictable their grip on its outcome, the more familiar it seems to feel to Canada's Olympic hockey team.


Charlotte Rosen Musician, 95
LEAD: Charlotte Rosen, a musician and teacher, died of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 95 years old.
Born in Berlin, she was trained as a violinist.
After immigrating to New York in 1939, she switched to the viola, and performed at New York Public Library branches and the New-York Historical Society.


Downing St. Car-Fire Death Called Suicide
LEAD: British news organizations reported today that a man killed when his car exploded in flames about 120 feet from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's official residence had left a suicide note protesting unemployment.


Leader Faults Bid by Cuomo On Residency
LEAD: The Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, said today that he was against requiring newly hired New York City police officers and firefighters to live in the city.


Biden Out of Intensive Care; Condition Called Satisfactory
LEAD: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been moved out of intensive care, and his condition continues to improve after surgery to correct an aneurysm in an artery supplying blood to his brain, a spokesman for Walter Reed Army Medical Center said today.


Home Sales Steady in '87
LEAD: Sales of existing homes held steady in 1987 at close to four million units despite volatile mortgage rates and the October stock market collapse, a national real estate trade group reported today.

Sports People; Tibbs Traded to Orioles
LEAD: The Baltimore Orioles have acquired Jay Tibbs, a right-handed pitcher, and Alfredo Cardwood, a minor league pitcher, from the Montreal Expos for three minor league pitchers - John Hoover, Doug Cinnella and Rick Carriger.
Tibbs, 26 years old, was 4-5, with a 4.99 earned run average in 19 games and 12 starts with Montreal last year.


GAF Shuns Takeover Law
LEAD: The GAF Corporation said yesterday that it had decided to exempt itself from the recently enacted Delaware law that limits hostile takeovers.

Results Plus
LEAD:  Tennis  Kriek Downs Purcell: Johan Kriek overcame a slow start to beat Mel Purcell, 6-7, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday in the second round of the $415,000 United States Indoor championships in Memphis.
Kriek, seeded 15th, from Naples, Fla., had trouble with Purcell's variety of soft shots in the first set, but found his serve midway through the second set and dominated the rest of the match.(AP)  Becker Wins Despite Erratic Play: Despite some sloppy and erratic play and a late lapse, Boris Becker defeated Guy Forget of France, 6-4, 1-6, 6-4, in the opening round of the


Navy Promotes Its Ex-Chief
LEAD: John F. Lehman Jr., who was Secretary of the Navy in the first six years of the Reagan Administration, has been chosen for promotion to captain in the Naval Reserve, the service said today.
Mr.
Lehman, a naval flight officer who left the Government last April to pursue a career in investment banking, was selected for a captaincy along with more than 450 other commanders.


Dollar Posts Losses in U.S.; Gold Has Modest Decline
LEAD: The dollar fell against most major currencies in United States trading yesterday after turning in a mixed performance overseas.


Having a Vested Interest in the New Budget
LEAD: James C. Miller 3d, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, examining a copy of the proposed budget as it came off the press.
Mr.
Miller said the agreement last year between the White House and Congress has given members of the Legislature a larger stake in the outcome of the budget plan, which is due tomorrow.

Soviet Students Now Asking 'Why?'
LEAD: The 15- and 16-year-olds filed into Lev Sobolev's sparely furnished classroom in Moscow's school No. 67, some with the sprightly step of the well-prepared, some with bored looks, some full of gossipy whispers.
From under their arms peeked ''War and Peace.''


Oil Discovery in England
LEAD: Oil has been found beneath a wheat field in eastern England.
Enterprise Oil Investments said its test well at West Firsby in Lincolnshire flowed at 864 barrels of oil a day.
Analysts said it might be Britain's third-largest onshore deposit.
Most British oil comes from the North Sea.


Dance: Monte Company Opens at the Joyce
LEAD: OOZE and anvil are alternately suggested as the motor pulse behind Elisa Monte's choreography and her splendid dancers flow like molasses or strike with pistonlike force.


The Discreet Charms of Paris Bistros and Brasseries
LEAD: These are trying times for American gourmands in Paris, what with the dollar as deflated as a punctured souffle and local prices steadily climbing.
A three-course meal with wine in an average Parisian restaurant easily tops $40 a person; it's considerably more if you are picky about wine.
A bottle of decent Beaujolais, for example, can run $20 or more, and the price of a better Bordeaux is downright scary, often 25 percent or more over New

Tandem Computers To Buy Ungermann
LEAD: Tandem Computers Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Ungermann-Bass Inc., a leading maker of local area networks, for approximately $260 million.


Film: 'Frida,' Tribute To Mexican Artist
LEAD: FRIDA KAHLO'S death in 1954 at the age of 47 caused no great stir in the United States.
In her native Mexico, however, she had been a celebrity, at least within radical political and artistic circles.
About a year before, the first major exhibit of her paintings had been shown at Mexico City's Gallery of Contemporary Art.


Ash Wednesday: Faithful Decide on Going Public
LEAD: Millions of Americans who normally give little public sign of religious allegiance will walk around today with one smudged on the forehead.

Financial Woes Threaten Survival Of the Historical Society in Jersey
LEAD: The New Jersey Historical Society has told state officials that the society is in a financial crisis and that it must decide within a few weeks whether to begin laying off its staff and curtailing its operations.

LEAD: A new and powerful biological technology that enables livestock breeders to clone large numbers of identical animals from a single embryo is nearing commercial application in the United States and Canada.

LEAD: A Palestinian call for a ''day of anger'' today produced almost total observance of a commercial strike in the occupied territories but only scattered clashes between protesters and the Israeli Army.

Life in the 30's
LEAD: IF hospitals truly wanted to perform a valuable service for new parents, they would put an Enforcer on staff.
The Enforcer would enter your room just after the baby arrived for the 2 o'clock feeding, and would stand at your bedside surrounded by smoke.
He would look a little like the Grim Reaper, only shorter, and he would say in a hollow voice:

LEAD: Eastern Airlines has significantly improved maintenance deficiencies that led to a record $9.5 million fine two years ago, but more changes are still needed, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

Pathologist Says Levin Wasn't Drunk
LEAD: Jennifer Levin was not drunk when she died, a pathologist testified yesterday, but the alcohol level in her bloodstream was equivalent to at least three drinks consumed an hour earlier.

William U. Gardner, Professor, 80
LEAD: William U. Gardner, professor emeritus of anatomy at the Yale University School of Medicine, died of Parkinson's disease Sunday at the Yale New Haven Hospital.

A NEW ART FORM: DESIGNING STORE SHELVES BY COMPUTER
LEAD: It's no secret in the supermarket business that how items are placed on shelves and how often the inventory turns over can be crucial factors when it comes time to tote up the profit-loss statement.
As supermarkets have gathered more and more data about which items sell best and which make the most money, the computer has moved center stage, dictating not only what appears on the shelves, but also how merchandise is positioned.


The Bald Truth
LEAD: There is a man here who knows a terrible secret about a lot of important people, and he is making a great deal of money off it.
He is a physician who has restored forelocks and cowlicks to the heads of a Senator, two members of the House of Representatives, a general and a former member of the Reagan Cabinet and many others.

U.S. WON'T REOPEN PLUTONIUM PLANT
LEAD: The United States Department of Energy said yesterday that it would not reopen the nation's largest plant for making plutonium for nuclear weapons, which has been shut for safety improvements for 13 months.


TV Review; Tales of Discontent, on 13
LEAD: AMERICAN PLAYHOUSE offers a 90-minute double feature, two tales of rural life and its discontents, tonight on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock.
First comes ''Revolt of Mother,'' based on a short story by Mary E. Wilkins Freeman, who wrote around the turn of the century.
The mother is played by Amy Madigan and her revolt consists of turning the new barn, which her husband had meant to use for some cows, into a new home for the family, which has been squeezed into the old house for years.

NEXT AMBASSADOR
LEAD: The United States is planning to change ambassadors to Israel next summer.
According to State Department officials, William A. Brown, currently ambassador to Thailand, will replace Thomas R. Pickering, who has served in Tel Aviv since 1985.


Greenspan Implies Fed Won't Cut Rates Soon
LEAD: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that important features of the economy seemed stable, if not particularly strong.
Economists said his remarks implied that the Fed wanted interest rates and the dollar to stay where they are.

EDUCATION: LESSONS
LEAD: Not long ago, the President offered a lesson. ''Money,'' Mr.
Reagan said, ''can never take the place of basics like . . . homework.'' Pedagogical poverty aside, a number of teachers here thought he did not go far enough.
Homework is much more than old-fashioned drill, one of the basics; it is education's essence.


Bear Stearns Profit Drops
LEAD: Reflecting the difficult operating environment that has enveloped the securities industry since the stock market plunge on Oct. 19, the Bear Stearns Companies yesterday reported third-quarter net income of $36.8 million, or 40 cents a share, for the three months ended Jan. 29, a drop of 38.3 percent from the $59.6 million, or 70 cents a share, earned in the corresponding period a year ago.


Plan for Reagan Library Faces Local Resistance
LEAD: Planners of the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, forced to abandon a site at Stanford University after widespread protests, have proposed to build the library near this Southern California city, but they are running into resistance from local municipal officials.


Orange Juice Contracts Fall As Fear of Freeze Abates
LEAD: Frozen concentrated orange juice futures prices fell sharply yesterday as warmer weather moved into Florida's orange-grove country and eased fears of a freeze.


NASA to Test 2 Escape Systems for Shuttle
LEAD: Two systems designed to help astronauts escape a disabled space shuttle will undergo extensive tests in coming weeks to determine if one will be used when flights resume this summer, space officials said today.

Citicorp Rates Up
LEAD: Interest rates rose about one-fifth of a percentage point at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper.
The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.625 percent, up from 6.431 percent last week.
Another $50 million of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 6.667 percent, up from 6.4306 percent.

Sports People; Comings and Goings
LEAD: Sebastian Coe of Britain, a two-time Olympic gold medalist in the 1,500 meters, has a heavy cold and fever and will not be able to run in a 3,000-meter race Friday night in the Los Angeles Times/GTE Indoor Games. ''It's disappointing, but I wouldn't be giving myself a fair chance to redeem myself,'' Coe said.


Paramount Pictures Hires D'Arcy Masius
LEAD: Gulf and Western's Paramount Pictures has assigned its media and marketing business, worth more than $70 million, to D'Arcy Masius Benton &amp; Bowles, Los Angeles.
The creative side is being handled by smaller agencies, as is typical in the movie business.
Other Los Angeles shops in the race, which began at the end of the year, were the incumbent, AC&amp;R/ DHB &amp; Bess, a Saatchi &amp; Saatchi unit; BBDO West, a division of BBDO Worldwide, and Ogilvy &amp; Mather Worldwide's unit.

LEAD: The irony is inescapable.
Using a wide-open offense that averages 109 points a game, Loyola Marymount of California, with a 20-3 record, ranked 20th this week in making its first appearance ever in The Associated Press college basketball poll.
The head coach is Paul Westhead, the same coach who was dismissed by the Los Angeles Lakers 11 games into the 1981-82 season after Earvin (Magic) Johnson complained publicly that Westhead's offense was slow and stodgy.

Ginsburg, then the department's antitrust chief, dealt with cable television industry matters while holding cable stock, but found either his participation or chance of gain was too small to violate Government conflict-of-interest laws, it was reported today.

LEAD: NEITHER rain, nor slush, nor fumes from cars, nor numbing cold can keep hardy New Yorkers off their bicycles.
