A messenger battles midtown traffic like a Phantom of the Street, his face covered with a hockey mask to protect him from churned-up mud and sleet.

LEAD: Nortek Inc. has purchased a 7 percent stake in the Mohasco Corporation and said it might seek control of the carpet and furniture manufacturer, which is based in Fairfax, Va.

Sports People; Arbitration for Gooden
LEAD: Barring a last-minute settlement, the Mets and Dwight Gooden will meet in salary arbitration today.
Al Harazin, the Mets' senior vice president, said he had not heard from Gooden's agent, Jim Neader, yesterday and had no reason to think they would not debate their differences in a hearing.
Gooden, who earned $1.5 million last year, submitted a $1.65 million figure, the Mets $1.4 million.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Collection by 10-Year-Olds Benefits the Neediest Cases
LEAD: A group of 10-year-olds from the Gimel Class of Temple Israel in Ridgewood, N.J., shoveled snow, took out garbage bags and did other chores to raise money for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
In two weeks' time, they collected $100 in tzedaka (charitable funds), which they designated for helping homeless people.


An Impasse For Austrian
LEAD: It was by common consent the bitterest week to date of the two-year-old Waldheim affair.
But after all the recriminations, accusations, speeches and threats, the sense here was that an impasse had been reached.

Greece Won't Extradite Italian
LEAD: The Greek Gov ernment today overruled a Supreme Court decision to extradite to Italy a member of the Red Brigades who was sought by the Italian authorities for terrorist attacks.


Is This Icy Strip Worth $32 Billion?
LEAD: The frozen Arctic coastal plain of northeast Alaska may hide the largest untapped oilfield in America.
Should Congress let the oil companies search for it?


ABOUT EDUCATION
LEAD: State-mandated school reforms are on a collision course with demands to give teachers and school administrators greater powers to decide how and what to teach.
A classic war is shaping up between political and professional power.
The battle is between those who believe schools can be improved through legislation and those who insist that the search for better schools must be led by teachers who know what students need.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a brief report on Monday about Senator Joseph R. Biden's surgery misstated his medical problem.
An aneurysm in an artery supplying blood to his brain leaked but did not burst.
The Associated Press, which distributed the report, later sent a corrected version, which The Times omitted through an oversight.

Life After Shanker: Leader Mends Fences
LEAD: In the two years since she became president of the United Federation of Teachers, Sandra Feldman has carved a broad role for herself, aiming not only to better the lot of teachers but also to be a major force in turning the New York City school system around.


WNEW-AM May Be Sold
LEAD: The Metropolitan Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it was talking to several parties who have expressed interest in buying WNEW-AM, its New York station that for more than 50 years has been known as the home of ''Make Believe Ballroom.''

2 Sea Films at Museum
LEAD: Two films by the independent film maker Peter Gimbel - ''Andrea Doria: The Final Chapter'' and ''Blue Water, White Death'' - will be shown tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.
The screening is part of a series devoted to films about social and political issues. ''Andrea Doria'' will be shown at 3 P.M.

Andrew Young Makes Apology for Remark
LEAD: Mayor Andrew Young apologized today to local ministers for remarks last week about Pat Robertson and the Rev.
Jesse Jackson that were interpreted as being critical of preachers.


Chrysler Plans Fund In Layoffs
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation, which has been accused of misleading workers at its plant in Kenosha, Wis., annnounced today that it would establish a trust fund of about $20 million to assist workers after the plant is largely closed later this year.


Tug and Barge Workers Go on Strike in New York
LEAD: A union of 2,500 tugboat and barge crew members went on strike yesterday morning after negotiations collapsed on a three-year labor contract with nine towing companies.


Capital Rise Expected To Gain in World Bank
LEAD: The 151 member governments of the World Bank are expected to agree this week to a $75 billion increase in capital, but Congressional leaders warned that it would be unusually difficult to persuade Congress to approve United States participation in this election year.

Instead of Jail: 'Welcome, Reptile!'
LEAD: At first glance it sounds outrageous, like too much crime and too little punishment.
Two startling sentencing decisions, in Florida and New York, have resulted in white-collar criminals getting off without any jail time.
No jail at all is too little.
Still, by fashioning creative sentences, the judges in these cases have tailored the punishment to the crime and the criminal.


STANDARDIZED TEST SCORES: VOODOO STATISTICS?
LEAD: Garrison Keillor, the folk humorist, has provoked many a smile by his description of the mythical town of Lake Wobegon as a place where the women are strong, the men good looking and ''all the children are above average.''

INSIDE
LEAD:  Shooting at Defense Plant  An ex-employee of a top-secret plant in Sunnyvale, Calif., shot 12 people before surrendering.
As many as seven died, authorities said.
Page A11.
Cultural Rapprochement  Arts exchanges between the United States and the Soviet Union are surging, delighting some in the field but worrying others.


Max L. Heine, 77, Founder and Head Of Securities Firms
LEAD: Max L. Heine, a founder and chairman of leading mutual funds and president of the Heine Securities Corporation, died Friday after being struck by an automobile in Tucson, Ariz., where he was vacationing.
He was 77 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

American Cooks Win Prizes In England
LEAD: A team of student chefs from Johnson and Wales College, a cooking school in Providence, R.I., won 23 prizes in the British Open Cookery Championship in London.
They were the first American team to enter the contest.


Soviet Skaters Prevail in Pairs
LEAD: The Soviet Union maintained its dominance of the pairs event in figure skating tonight, winning the gold and silver medals at the XV Olympic Winter Games.
The third Russian pair finished in fourth place.


Stage: One-Act Comedies In Punch Line Festival
LEAD: IN David Ives's ''Sure Thing,'' a young man sees an attractive young woman sitting by herself in a cafe.
Planning his maneuvers, he wonders if he should be cool, forward or flattering.
She is reading ''The Sound and the Fury,'' and, furrowing his brow, he tries to remember what he knows about Faulkner.


Aid Is Asked on Recreation in Forests
LEAD: The Agriculture Department today announced a major new program for encouraging private business to develop recreational facilities in national forests.


A MERCHANT BANKER STARTS OWN FIRM
LEAD: It has been a long and winding road from the 1960's to the late 1980's for Ken Miller, a route that has taken him from social activism to the hottest money-making realm of Wall Street, merchant banking.


Metromedia-Orion
LEAD: John W. Kluge, chairman of the Metromedia Company, has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation to 28.3 percent from 26.7 percent.
Orion, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed today at $17.75 a share, up 50 cents.
Mr.
Kluge, who has been steadily purchasing shares of the motion picture and television production company since October, has not altered his original statement that the shares have been purchased for investment purposes.


Steel Output Falls 0.4%
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.867 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of four-tenths of a percent from the previous week's 1.875 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 86.9 percent of capacity for the week, compared with 87.3 percent in the previous week.


'Attack' Remains Strategy For U.S.
LEAD: Just as soon as they had absorbed the disappointment of their 7-5 loss to Czechoslovakia Monday night, a glum group of United States Olympic hockey players began plotting their strategy against the Soviet Union for what has become a must-win game on Wednesday.


Douglas Provides Spark for Syracuse
LEAD: There comes a time in every basketball game when an alarm goes off inside a coach's head.
It warns the coach who is ahead to brace for a final assault and implores the coach who is behind to launch a last-gasp attack.


Sports People; McPherson Honored
LEAD: Saying that his only preference for playing professional football was ''to play in this country,'' Don McPherson, the all-America from Syracuse, became the first black player to receive the Davey O'Brien National Quarterback Award when he was honored Monday night in Fort Worth.
But, he pointed out, although he appreciated the honor, the award would not erase the stereotype that black quarterbacks operate best out of an option offense similar to that at Oklahoma and out of the country, notably Canada.

Executive Role for Clavell in TV Series
LEAD: On ''Noble House,'' the eight-hour mini-series that begins Sunday on NBC, James Clavell is not credited merely as the author of the original novel.
He also acted as executive producer of the mini-series, and he was closely involved at every stage of production. ''Noble House,'' a tale of intrigue in the business community of contemporary Hong Kong, stars Pierce Brosnan, Deborah Raffin, John Rhys-Davies, Khigh Dhiegh and Denholm


About New York; Trying to Give Cupid an Assist On His Shots
LEAD: People in the love game are feeling pretty good here in the middle of the week after Valentine's Day, just as caterers in other trades are happy to have got the biggest day of their year behind them.
In Abby Hirsch's case the market was particularly strong in gift certificates.
Ms.
Hirsch runs a dating service.

LEAD: The Islanders were effective in every phase of their play tonight and posted a resounding triumph against the best team in the National Hockey League.


Notebook; Vanishing Act Is Explained
LEAD: The mystery over why a Rumanian speed skating coach and three female skaters disappeared Saturday, more than a week before they were scheduled to compete, was solved today.


SCHOOL CONTROL FOR THE MAYOR IS ABANDONED
LEAD: Cuomo administration officials said today that they had abandoned for now their efforts to give the New York City Mayor more direct control over the city's Board of Education.


Banks File $83 Million Suit Charging Finley, Kumble
LEAD: Four major United States banks filed suit in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday seeking more than $83 million from the law firm of Finley, Kumble, which dissolved Jan. 4.

FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Florida Power and Light Company offered $125 million of 9 5/8 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2018 at a price of 99.75 to yield 9.649 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.


Accord Seen in Protest At U. of Massachusetts
LEAD: A tentative understanding that could end the five-day takeover of a University of Massachusetts black studies center by nearly 200 students was reached today, school officials said.


Economic Scene; Putting the Brakes On Easy Trading
LEAD: IS Wall Street drowning in a tide of trading?
Complaints about the Street's casino mentality are treated as public relations headaches by the exchanges and the big brokerage houses.
Nor are they taken seriously by most free market economists, who see rapid turnover as the welcome consequence of increased competition and computerization.

Walesa Plans Australia Trip; First Time Abroad Since '81
LEAD: The Polish Solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, has accepted an invitation to an international trade union congress in Australia next month - his first trip abroad since his union was banned under martial law in December 1981.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Feb. 10 about a court ruling in a New York City zoning case incompletely described the error in a map at the center of the dispute.
The developer, Parkview Associates, relied upon a map published by the city in putting up a 31-story building.

Smokers Protest Ban on Commuter Trains
LEAD: A police officer from the Metro-North Commuter Railroad entering a Poughkeepsie-bound car yesterday evening at Grand Central Terminal to inform passengers that a smoking ban was in effect.
Doug Jones, right, was one of seven people to receive summonses from the Metro-North police because he refused to comply with the smoking ban.


New Zealand Ponders a 'Nuclear Survival Kit'
LEAD: Isolated in the distant South Pacific and stubbornly free of nuclear weapons and nuclear power, New Zealand has begun examining ways to survive a nuclear war.


Engine Failure Halts Flight
LEAD: An engine on a USAir jetliner bound for Newark failed Monday morning, forcing the plane to return to Pittsburgh.
The Boeing 737, carrying 80 people on Flight 264, was about 45 miles east of Pittsburgh when its right engine compressor stalled and oil pressure dropped.
No one was injured in the incident, which the authorities were investigating today.


Angola Terms on Cuban Troops Seen as Major Sticking Point
LEAD: Angola is willing to send home all the Cuban troops stationed there, according to a senior Angolan official, but only under conditions that few diplomats and other experts expect South Africa to accept.


Huge Warhol Catalogue
LEAD: The auction catalogue of the Andy Warhol collection, which goes on sale today at Sotheby's, is the costliest at $95, weightiest at 8 1/4 pounds and one of the largest ever published.


BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: FAMILY ATTRACTIONS. By Judith Freeman. 227 pages. Viking. $16.95.


Rule on Abortion Counseling Is Blocked
LEAD: A Federal district judge in Colorado has temporarily blocked enforcement of a new rule that prevents many of the nation's family planning clinics from helping women to obtain abortions.


Dr. John Meng, 81, Ex-President At Hunter and Marymount, Dies
LEAD: Dr.
John J. Meng, the president of Hunter College from 1960 to 1966 and later executive vice president of Fordham University and president of Marymount College,, died of heart failure on Monday at his home in Jackson, Miss.
He was 81 years old.
Dr.
Meng, a historian and an authority on French-American relations in the period of the American and French Revolutions, retired in 1973 as president of Marymount but remained active in educational affairs.

Marcos Property Sold at Auction
LEAD: A pair of shoes being sold yesterday at Christie's East at an auction of items that belonged to the former Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda.
Many of the people had come out of curiosity; others came to buy something belonging to the Marcoses.
The items were recovered from a luxury apartment and auctioned on behalf of the Philippine Government.


Ortega Mutes His Tone
LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra still wants talks with the U.S., although his Sandinista regime is committed now to direct cease-fire negotiations with the contras.


I.R.A.'s, Not as Useful Now, Still a Good Idea for Many
LEAD: With new restrictions on Individual Retirement Account deductions, millions of Americans have to decide whether to continue what has been the annual tradition of contributing to an I.R.A. - but now without the lure of a $2,000 deduction.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. The cedar shingles on our 60-year-old home were originally stained, then painted several times.
The paint is peeling, and I would like to go back to stain.
Can the shingles be sandblasted professionally and then stained?
A.
The paint can be removed by sandblasting, but this could damage the shingles if not done carefully.

LEAD: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that it had won a $383 million arbitration judgment against the Emirates General Petroleum Corporation, an agency of the United Arab Emirates, in a dispute over the nonpayment for natural gas.

Mardi Gras Accidents Kill 2
LEAD: Two people were killed in separate Mardi Gras accidents Tuesday.
One of the victims was an 11-year-old boy, Michael W. Dupree, who, watching a parade in suburban Gretna, reached for a trinket under the wheels of a truck that was pulling a float, and was crushed.
About two hours later an unidentified man in his early 20's was killed when he ran up to a truck float in city traffic, leaped between the cab and the float, lost his grip and slipped beneath the tires.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Recession Forecast
LEAD: Rudolph G. Penner, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, is predicting a recession next year.
But until then he foresees nothing worse than a ''slowdown, and not a very severe one.''


Red Barber Honored
LEAD: Red Barber, the baseball Hall of Fame announcer, was saluted on his 80th birthday at a ceremony yesterday in Tallahassee, Fla.
Barber's career included 33 years with the Brooklyn Dodgers, the Yankees and the Cincinnati Reds.
The Florida Cabinet declared yesterday ''Red Barber Day'' in Florida, and a birthday party was held in the state capitol building.


Metro Matters; Applying Logic And Equity To Welfare
LEAD: New York State is spending $7.4 billion on aid to local schools this year and the State Education Commissioner says that if only he had three or four million dollars more he might be able to figure out where the money is going.

Truce in Border Fight By Thais and Laotians
LEAD: Thailand and Laos agreed today to a truce and disengagement in a disputed, sparsely populated border area where hundreds of their soldiers have been killed since November.


GARDEN DESIGNS FOR ALL AGES
LEAD: ''IF you're not careful, a sandbox can be disgusting - a huge kitty-litter bin,'' said Dudley Mason.
Ms.
Mason and her partner, Signe Nielsen, are landscape designers who specialize in city gardens.
But coping with a sandbox is only one of the myriad concerns in planning a garden for a family with children.

LEAD: Jay Leyda, a film historian and professor of cinema studies at New York University, died of heart failure Monday at the New York University Medical Center.
He was 78 years old.

Switzerland Extradites Fugitive Italian Financier
LEAD: A financier accused of masterminding a web of criminal and political conspiracies involving many of the most powerful men in Italy was extradited from Switzerland today in a predawn police operation, officials said.

Drinking Themselves to Death
LEAD: Rutgers University has now banned fraternity and sorority parties indefinitely, too late to save James Callahan but maybe soon enough to keep other young people from drinking themselves to death.
That's what Mr.
Callahan, an 18-year-old freshman, apparently did at an initiation party.


What Do You Do After a Drubbing at the Polls? Claim Victory!
LEAD: In the face of defeat, candidates in a Presidential primary can generally be counted on to do the obvious: claim victory.


Emotional Defense in Israel Nazi Trial
LEAD: The time of trial is dwindling as the son sits in the front row of the theater audience watching his father on stage, the older man all pink pate and owlish stare as he absorbs the accusation that he is the Nazi killer nicknamed Ivan the Terrible, the gas chamber operator of the Treblinka death camp.


Jogger in Park Testifies He Saw Man and a Body
LEAD: A doctor who was jogging in Central Park in the predawn darkness of Aug. 26, 1986, testified yesterday that he saw a man shaking an apparently lifeless body in woods behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art but did not stop to help.

Advertising; Ad Clutter: Even in Restrooms Now
LEAD: Studies show that the typical consumer is bombarded by 5,000 advertising messages a day, and the number of ads is expected to increase steadily.
That trend has many executives in the industry worried about the growing advertising clutter.

LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation rejected the current $1.08 billion buyout offer from the Bank of New York Company and unleashed another sharp verbal attack against its unwanted suitor.
Irving's board rejected as ''significantly inadequate'' Bank of New York's offer to pay $15 in cash and 1.575 shares of its own stock for each of


With New Hampshire Now History, Campaign Enters a Different Phase
LEAD: After New Hampshire primaries that anointed no new leaders, the two parties' squads of Presidential candidates headed south and west today as the campaign emphasis shifted from small-state glamour events to the pursuit of larger blocks of national convention delegates.


Road Team Announced
LEAD: The five-man team that will represent the United States in a 50-kilometer (31-mile) relay road race against eight other national teams on April 9 in Manhattan was announced yesterday at the weekly luncheon of track and field writers at Madison Square Garden.
The race, called the Asics Cup America's Ekiden, will be held in New York City, the first time an Ekiden race will be held outside of Japan.


A Settlement In Silver Case
LEAD: A company accused of cornering the silver market with the Hunt brothers of Texas in 1980 has agreed to pay a Peruvian company $3.65 million in an out-of-court settlement, a lawyer for Minpeco S.A. said today.


Budget Fantasies, Deficit Realities
LEAD: The budget that President Reagan submits to Congress today is effectively his last.
But he need not fret about his waning power.
He has already left his mark: a monumental legacy of deficits and debt.
Mr.
Reagan can claim to have rebuilt the nation's defenses, slowed the spread of government and cut taxes.


Suspended Policeman Denies Role In Beating of a Marijuana Dealer
LEAD: A suspended New York City police lieutenant denied in court yesterday that he had abetted the beating of a marijuana dealer by other officers, and asserted that the beating never took place.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: BANISTERS, or balustrades as they are also called, consist of a handrail supported by posts and spindles (called balusters).
Like staircases, banisters usually reflect the most sophisticated carpentry in a home.
As a result, their construction may be mysterious to some homeowners because care is taken to hide all signs of fasteners.


Calton Investor Plans Takeover
LEAD: Michael S. Weinstein, the chairman of Coated Sales Inc., has purchased a 5 percent stake in Calton Inc. class A common stock and said he plans to acquire control of the company through a tender offer.


Fire Forces Evacuation of U.S. Embassy in Moscow
LEAD: A Soviet fire truck leaving the embassy compound after firefighters extinguished a brief but intense blaze that swept through several floors of the main building.
Staff members left the building.
Officials said that damage was not serious and that Soviet fire crews had not entered any sensitive areas.


Ulster Police Order New Inquiry
LEAD: The Northern Ireland police announced a disciplinary inquiry today against officers involved in the killing of six unarmed men in the province in three incidents in late 1982.


Crack Use Pervades Life in a Shelter
LEAD: At the Fort Washington Armory in upper Manhattan, where 850 men sleep in one huge room, drug use, particularly crack, pervades every aspect of life and gives the shelter a mood of perpetual danger.

U.S. Studying Injuries Linked to Child Car Seat
LEAD: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating injuries linked to a children's automobile seat made by Fisher-Price to decide whether they merit a Federal recall action.


Manila Says At Least 33 Die In Ambush and Voter Clash
LEAD: The Government said today that at least 33 people were killed Tuesday as political groups clashed during regional elections in Sulu Province and rebels ambushed a police patrol in Luzon.


Joffrey Plans New Ballet For Its 1988 Season
LEAD: The Joffrey Ballet will present a new ballet, ''Concerto Grosso'' by James Kudelka, as the highlight of its 1988 season.
Set to music by Jean Papineau-Couture, a Canadian composer, ''Concerto Grosso'' was commissioned for the 1988 Winter Olympic Festival in Calgary, Alberta.

'Prison Program' Lets Families Do the Talking
LEAD: THE young boy talks too loudly into the telephone, his mouth too close. ''Hello Daddy,'' he says. ''It is nice outside here.
My birthday is soon.
I will be 6.
When will you come home?
I love you.'' He is not sure his father is listening, but he can be fairly certain that thousands of other people are.

LEAD: Greg Bell made a 5-foot shot with one second remaining to give Tennessee a 72-70 upset over Kentucky tonight in a Southeastern Conference game.

Peerless Pair
LEAD: Every once in a while an athlete comes along who so outclasses the competition that he, or she, seems to be performing in a different event.
That person has no real peer but himself; his only real contest is with his last performance.
Torvill and Dean, who won an Olympic gold medal for ice dancing in 1984, are that kind of athlete.


Talks Collapse in a Racial Attack Case
LEAD: After two days of talks, lawyers for a black Dutchess County teen-ager who says she was abducted and raped by six white men indicated yesterday that they would not for now permit their client to cooperate with a state investigation.
Although both sides said that they were at an impasse, they indicated that they were open to further discussion.


ESTIMATE ON DAWN OF HUMANS REVISED
LEAD: Fossils from an Israeli cave show that anatomically modern humans were living about 92,000 years ago, more than twice as long ago as scientists had been able to establish reliably before, researchers say.

LEAD: The American Ballet Theater star Patrick Bissell died of an overdose of cocaine, codeine, methadone and other drugs, according to an autopsy report released today.

LEAD: On the 618th day of his campaign, Bruce Babbitt stopped campaigning.
Instead, he drank a chocolate milkshake, read telegrams urging him to stay in the Presidential race and took his sons to the Lincoln Memorial so they could read the Gettysburg Address etched in bronze there.

The gallery specializes in idealistic work done by artists who choose not to show in commercial galleries.

A REMODELED ROOM COMFORTS AIDS PATIENTS
LEAD: THE 44 residents of Bailey House, an AIDS hospice in the former River Hotel on Christopher Street, already had rooms of their own.
What they wanted was rooms together: lounges in which to socialize, read and prepare food.
A room on each of the four floors was designated as a lounge, but the spaces needed work.


Critic's Notebook; Transcending Distractions in the Opera Audience
LEAD: ONE of the signs of King Ludwig of Bavaria's supposed madness was his penchant for having Wagner's operas staged for himself alone, as he sat serenely and presumably undistracted in his Royal Box at what is now the Bavarian State Opera in Munich.
Such waste! cried his critics, several of whom were politically motivated bureaucrats overseeing the Bavarian budget.

TV Review; Fireworks, Not Issues, In the News
LEAD: IT peaked early, a minute or so before 7 P.M. on Tuesday.
Vice President Bush, Peter Jennings reported, had ''pulled it out just by that.'' He gestured to indicate the size of the victory.
How big was that?
The ABC anchor wouldn't say; technically, the New Hampshire polls were still open.
When CBS and NBC came on at 7, however, the polls were closed.

LEAD: Unable to agree on the size of a pay cut, the Mets and Dwight Gooden argued their salary differences before an arbitrator yesterday.
Roger McDowell, though, decided to forgo his hearing, scheduled for tomorrow, and agreed to the Mets' offer of $615,000 for this year.

Man Held in Wife's Beating
LEAD: A Bethpage man was arrested and charged wifh severely beating his newlywed wife on Valentine's Day, the Nassau County Police said late today.
A police spokesman, Officer Charles Koller, said no details on the arrest of the man, Thomas Porcella, 30 years old, were immediately available.
The woman, Anne Marie Porcella, 24, is listed in critical condition with a fractured skull at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow.


High on the Hog in the Cattle Country
LEAD: Wearing a stetson, a western-cut jacket, pointed boots and a silver belt buckle, Rob Brown was in garb that seemed the uniform of the week at Orange County's big convention center here.


Conspiracy Trial of 14 White Supremacists Begins
LEAD: Opening arguments began in Federal District Court here today in the trial of 14 members of the white supremacist movement, including 10 leaders who are charged with seditious conspiracy by plotting to overthrow the Government by force.


Bucharest Journal; It's Mother Nature, Not Ceausescu, Who Relents
LEAD: An exceptionally mild winter, days on end of spring sunshine instead of the usual leaden skies of February, have brought an air of well-being to Bucharest.
It is an illusion.

Health; Treatment For Cancer Is Criticized
LEAD: Many cancer patients are not receiving state-of-the-art treatments that could prolong their lives, according to a new Federal report.


Whimsical Crafts on View in Baltimore
LEAD: A few years ago Judith Strong, a Florida ceramist, had a small but bothersome problem.
Her husband, Sal Guastella, liked to drink strong Cuban coffee but could not find the right size cup for it.
The solution seemed simple enough.
Since she is a clay artist, she created a four-inch-tall narrowed vessel that has become one of her best sellers.

Stabbing on a Jetliner
LEAD: A passenger was slashed in the throat by another traveler on a flight from Panama to Miami on Tuesday, leaving the victim in critical condition and the man accused as his assailant under arrest.
Eduardo A. Noel, a 35-year-old aviation inspector from Panama, was slashed with a pocketknife.
Robert Dean Clark of Austin, Tex., and Corona Del Mar, Calif., was charged with attempted murder.

Lawsuit Challenges Census on Illegal Aliens
LEAD: Forty members of Congress, arguing that including illegal aliens in the 1990 census would deprive some states of seats in the House, plan to file a lawsuit to force the Census Bureau to exclude the aliens from calculations for the next Congressional reapportionment.


Charges and Cuts Seen At Lomas &amp; Nettleton
LEAD: The Lomas &amp; Nettleton Financial Corporation, one of the nation's largest mortgage bankers, said today that it expected to take write-offs totaling $93 million after taxes in the current quarter because of rising foreclosures and bankruptcies.


C.F.T.C. Nominee Gains
LEAD: The Senate Agriculture Committee today approved the nomination of Wendy Gramm to be chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
The full Senate may vote on her nomination this week, Senate staff members said.


Cocaine-Related Death
LEAD: A star football player at Forestville High School in Maryland died of cocaine intoxication, according to Dr.
John Smialek, the state's Chief Medical Examiner.
In a report in The Prince George's Journal yesterday, Smialek was quoted as saying that initial toxicological tests showed there was a considerable amount of cocaine in the blood and stomach of Rico Marshall, who died last Saturday.


Soviet Schools Sharply Faulted By Top Official
LEAD: A senior Soviet leader said today that the education system is afflicted with underfinancing, rigid central control and physical conditions so primitive that 40 percent of schools have no indoor toilets.


Wood Fires Restricted By Resorts in Colorado
LEAD: Worried that dirty mountain air might tarnish their image and turn away skiers, Colorado resort towns are clamping down on pollution from wood-burning stoves and fireplaces.


Construction Decline Seen
LEAD: Construction contracts will drop 4 percent this year because of steep declines in office and other commercial building and lesser drops in housing and public works projects, according to a forecast released yesterday.


NEW YORK COURT STRIKES DOWN LAW TO CURB LOITERING
LEAD: In a case affecting hundreds of homeless people in New York City, the state's highest court ruled today that a law banning loitering in major transportation centers like the Port Authority Bus Terminal and Pennsylvania Station was unconstitutional.


P.L.O. SCUTTLES SHIP PLANS
LEAD: The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it had shelved plans for a ''ship of return'' to take 130 deported Palestinians to Israel, two days after the vessel was bombed in a harbor in Cyprus.

LEAD: A lion dancer strutting through a barrage of firecrackers as residents of Chinatown celebrated the Chinese New Year and the arrival of the year 4686.


Fire Kills AIDS Patient at a Manhattan Hospital
LEAD: A smoky, fast-moving fire erupted near an oxygen respirator at Beekman-Downtown Hospital in lower Manhattan yesterday, killing a 26-year-old AIDS patient as he lay in his bed.


Rumanian Incident: 4 Conflicting Tales
LEAD: Four conflicting reports have arisen over the reason that all three Rumanian female speed skaters and their coach returned home last weekend, before their Winter Olympics competition began.
The reports revolved around defection, drugs, an automobile accident and a family matter.

LEAD: As 55 percent of the nursing staff called in sick at Lincoln Medical Center, crowds formed outside.
The nurses were protesting what they called deplorable working conditions.

E.P.A. Reports Dip in Lead Emissions
LEAD: Emissions of lead into the atmosphere declined 59 percent in 1986, the second straight record drop, the Environmental Protection Agency said today in its annual report on air pollution.

LEAD: The Soviet Union defeated the U.S., 7-5, last night, further dimming the American hockey team's chances of winning a medal in the XV Olympic Winter Games.


Afghan Guerrillas Appear to Ease Position on a Future Government
LEAD: Guerrilla leaders in Afghanistan were reported today to be ready to modify a longstanding position and accept minor participation by members of the current Communist regime in Kabul in a future interim government.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Regulatory Czar
LEAD: S. Jay Plager, a senior official at the Office of Management and Budget, is in line for a new, more important position as the Reagan Administration's regulatory czar, the man who reviews virtually all the regulations issued by the Government.


Waldheim Linked to Nazi Roundup
LEAD: The Justice Department based one of its principal charges against President Kurt Waldheim of Austria on captured German documents that point to his involvement in the deportation of 488 Yugoslav civilians to slave labor camps in 1942, possibly making him an accessory to war crimes.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Bridgestone's agreement to buy 75 percent of Firestone's tire-making operations described the status of a Tennessee truck-tire plant incorrectly.
Bridgestone bought the plant from Firestone in 1983; it is not part of the current deal.

Mr.
Caffrey, 49, is also an executive vice president and executive director of operations at Ogilvy &amp; Mather, New York.
Jules Fine, vice chairman of Ogilvy &amp; Mather Worldwide, held the responsibilities that Mr.


Joseph Brodsky Begins Queens Reading Series
LEAD: Joseph Brodsky, winner of last year's Nobel Prize in Literature, is to read from his works on March 7 at 7 P.M. at the Queens College Student Union, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing.
Mr.
Brodsky, who left the Soviet Union more than 15 years ago, gave his first poetry reading in the United States at the college.


Shultz Expected to See Sakharov in Moscow
LEAD: To dramatize the Reagan Administration's campaign for improvement in the Soviet human-rights record, Secretary of State George P. Shultz plans to meet with Andrei D. Sakharov and other rights campaigners when he visits Moscow early next week, a senior Administration official said today.


Rikers Inmates Set Up Barricades
LEAD: Rebelious prisoners erected barricades early this morning in a dormitory area of the Rikers Island prison, authorities said.


North Conway Journal; The 'Malling' of a White Mountain Resort Town
LEAD: It is a clear, crisp morning in this White Mountain town, a perfect day to hit the slopes.


The Stage: 'Woman in Mind'
LEAD: THE true test of an artist, whatever the art form, is often to be found in the half-tones, not the primary colors.
Stockard Channing, an actress whose indelible recent performances in ''The House of Blue Leaves'' and ''Joe Egg'' leave her with little need to prove anything, subjects herself to this rough test and triumphs in ''Woman in Mind,'' the modest but watchable Alan Ayckbourn play at the Manhattan Theater

LEAD: To the Editor:


Opposition to Steagall Act
LEAD: More than three-quarters of the chief financial officers of the nation's largest non-financial corporations favor the repeal of a Federal banking law that separates commercial banking from securities underwriting, according to a survey conducted by the Senate Banking Committee and made available this week.


Students End Takeover At U. of Massachusetts
LEAD: Minority students at the Amherst campus of the University of Massachusetts today ended their occupation of a school building after administrators met many of their demands on addressing campus racial problems.


Yields Are Down Again
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all down for the second consecutive week, but in the week ended yesterday the steepness in the decline eased.


Bridge: Trying for Terrible Contract, Player Was Teased by Fates
LEAD: When providence smiles kindly on a declarer and permits a virtually hopeless contract to be made, the declarer may feel inclined to offer thanks for a miracle.


As Man Dies, a Friend Says E.M.S. Crew Refused to Help
LEAD: A 68-year-old man suffered a fatal heart attack in a Bronx church last night and a friend of the man said that he had urged a city ambulance crew buying sandwiches at a delicatessen to come to the man's aid, but that the paramedics refused.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday and a brief sports report about the New Jersey Devils' attempts to sign Soviet hockey players misidentified one player.
He is Vyacheslav Fetisov, not Fetislov.


Rescued Boy Quits Hospital
LEAD: A 9-year-old boy who was trapped 40 minutes under the ice of a frozen pond walked out of the Medical University of South Carolina Hospital today, smiling shyly at reporters.
The boy, Kendall Smith, and two other children were playing on the pond Jan. 12 when the ice gave way.
His companions were rescued quickly but it was almost 40 minutes before Kendall was rescued.


Advertising; Grey Earnings Rise
LEAD: Grey Advertising has reported an 18 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings.
It said on Tuesday that net income had climbed to $2.74 million, or $2.06 a share, from $2.32 million, or $1.66 a share, a year earlier.
Revenues rose 26 percent, to $98.1 million, from $77.8 million.
For the year the agency reported that profit was up 13 percent, to $10.3 million, or $7.43 a share, from $9.1 million, or $6.60 a share.


Hunter Gains Final; Staten Island Wins
LEAD: Hunter College rallied from a 7-point halftime deficit in the semifinals of the CUNY tournament at Nat Holman Gymnasium last night to score a 78-64 victory over Lehman.


Paper for All Purposes
LEAD: ''PAPER is a common denominator of all my interests,'' said Wendy Stewart, owner of 80 Papers. ''I like photography, calligraphy and bookbinding.
Paper is so important for all those things.
Also, I really love Oriental things, and the Japanese make wonderful paper.''


Societe Generale's Record Stock Price
LEAD: The stock of Societe Generale de Belgique closed at a record high of 5,000 Belgian francs, or $143, a share, up 140 francs on the Brussels stock exchange today.
The closing price was 1,000 francs above the price offered by the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti in his public bid for 15 percent of the company.


HERS
LEAD: ''POVERTY stinks,'' Bette exlaims when we meet at a faux-Nantucket seafood house in Santa Monica.
Is she comparing herself with illegal aliens or the Rockefellers, I wonder.
She is wearing a $300 orange and purple quilted satin jacket over a $400 crushed velvet skirt.


Portugal Woos Two Aggrieved Ex-Colonies
LEAD: Portugal and two troubled former colonies, Angola and Mozambique, are forming closer ties after more than a decade of tense relations.

LEAD: ARGUING with our children is as much a part of being a parent as nurturing them.


Arizona Senate Grants Mecham Week Delay in Impeachment Trial
LEAD: The Arizona Senate today granted Gov.
Evan Mecham a one-week delay of his impeachment trial, which had been set to begin Monday.


SPORTS OF THE TIMES: THE BEAR ON THE BOBSLED
LEAD: IN his red-white-and-blue Olympic warm-up suit, Willie Gault was holding forth on his sudden presence on the United States bobsled team.
But he's always a presence.
Although best known as a wide receiver for the Chicago Bears, he organized and was the lead singer of their ''Super Bowl Shuffle'' rap video.

LEAD: A brief but intense fire swept through several rooms of the main building of the United States Embassy here today, disrupting operations five days before a visit by Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

Health: Medical Costs; A Few Expensive Procedures Are Focus of Effort to Trim Bill
LEAD: The coronary bypass operation, developed in the 1960's, was still uncommon 15 years ago.
But as techniques improved, more Americans began to demand it and insurance plans began to pay for it.
Thousands of lives have been saved by the procedure, in which blood is shunted around clogged portions of an artery to the heart.


Talking Deals; More Japanese Investing in U.S.
LEAD: THE pace of Japanese investment in the United States continues unabated.
The type of companies making acquisitions is changing, and so is the type of targets.
This week Japanese companies have announced plans to make their largest investments in the United States so far - in a manufacturer and in a financial institution.


Music: Jazz Passengers, A Modernist Septet
LEAD: SEVEN seems to be a lucky number for avant-gutbucket jazz.
Henry Threadgill's seven-member Sextett, the Microscopic Septet and now the seven-piece Jazz Passengers make jazz that's smart and witty and raucous.
For all its unpredictable forms and modernist dissonances, the music comes across as boisterous fun.

LEAD: Francisco Manrique, a former Argentine naval officer, journalist and presidential candidate who served as Secretary of Tourism under President Raul Alfonsin, died of lymph cancer Monday at the Diagnostic Institute in Buenos Aires.
He was 69 years old and lived in Buenos Aires.

Life Term for Bronx Rapist
LEAD: A Bronx judge imposed a life term yesterday on a 30-year-old man who raped a woman and later beat her because she went to the police.
The man, Luis McCray, must serve at least 20 years in prison before seeking parole, Justice Donald Covington of State Supreme Court ruled.
Mr.
McCray raped and sodomized a 22-year-old civilian employee of the Police Department in a deserted Bronx schoolyard on March 6, 1986, the prosecutors said.


299-Billion Military Budget Drops Weapons and People
LEAD: The Pentagon today proposed cutting military forces on active duty by 36,000 people while canceling 18 weapon programs as it sent to Congress a $299.5 billion budget for in 1989.


Capital Losses
LEAD: To the Editor:


TWO NIGHTS OF SINGING THE BLUES
LEAD: IN an ironic fit of democracy, the local music of some of the most dispossessed citizens of the United States - black, rural Southerners - has changed the nature of international life.
The relatively small, 200-mile-long area known as the Mississippi Delta produces music full of pride, rebellion and emotion, a deeply felt version of the blues.

Rothschild's New Trouble
LEAD: L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc., the brokerage house that went into a precipitous decline in the wake of the stock market crash, announced yesterday that it faces further problems because its net worth has declined sharply.

Carter Hawley, Penney Gain
LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company yesterday reported an increase in its fourth-quarter profit despite a slight drop in sales, while another important retailer, Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., also said it had stronger fiscal second-quarter earnings.


PERES SAYS ISRAEL SHOULD YIELD GAZA
LEAD: Underlining the governing coalition's disarray, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres suggested today that Israel would do well to yield control of the Gaza Strip, not because of unrest there but because of the ''demographic clock'' of the Palestinians' population growth.


A Budget Without Bluster
LEAD: There is a welcome breath of reality in President Reagan's new budget.
His past budgets have been studded with blustering assaults on the fundamental social functions of government.
Not the new midnight-blue tome for fiscal 1989.
There will be battles with Congressional Democrats over individual priorities.

Restaurants
LEAD: THERE are only a handful of restaurants in the Lincoln Center area where I could be persuaded to pass an evening unless I was at the business end of a revolver.
At first I had reservations about the newcomer Cameos, a splashy, pastel-hued, piano bar with an overly energetic public-relations staff.


I.R.S. Harder to Convince On Doing Business at Home
LEAD: A personal computer, a luxury car, a home-office and even hobby expenses can still be written off under the new tax law by many employees and self-employed business people.
But many taxpayers will also find that they can no longer count on the Government to provide as much of a helping hand in subsidizing the cost of an I.B.M.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: THE flourishing neighborhood between Union Square and the Flatiron district has spawned yet another stylish restaurant, Ristorante da Umberto.
Owned by Umberto Assante and his wife, Kathleen, the three-month-old establishment specializes in the hearty cuisine of Florence.
The high-ceilinged dining rooms are bright and tidy, with sponge-dappled amber walls and well-spaced tables.


West German Chancellor Begins Talks in Washington
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, center, meeting yesterday with Jesse Helms, left, and Claiborne Pell of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Mr.
Kohl also met with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who asured the Chancellor of American support for his efforts to obtain a comprehensive NATO decision on the development of a new overall arms strategy.


Kennedy Sworn As 104th Justice On High Court
LEAD: Anthony McLeod Kennedy took his two oaths as the 104th Justice of the Supreme Court today, in separate ceremonies at the Court and the White House.


ART BLAKEY
LEAD: Art Blakey on drums and his Jazz Messengers will perform tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785).
Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.


Is Central America Ready for Self-Government?; Trained in the U.S.
LEAD: To the Editor:


Art: A Tamer Vito Acconci in Show at the Modern
LEAD: ONCE confrontational, he now cajoles.
Still, Vito Acconci continues to implicate an audience in his discomfiting scenarios.
Having created a reputation during the 1970's as a Conceptual artist who staged bizarre, often sexually charged events, Mr.
Acconci turns his attention these days to superficially peaceable pastimes -constructing environmental sculptures that function something like playgrounds or parks.


Empty Seats Upset Residents
LEAD: Local residents were told months ago that many Olympic events, including hockey, speed skating, figure skating and curling, were sold out.
They have become angry because there have been large blocks of empty seats at these events.


ETHICS COMMITTEE URGES THE HOUSE TO REMOVE BIAGGI
LEAD: The ethics committee of the House of Representatives recommended today that Mario Biaggi be expelled from Congress.

Du Pont Quits Republican Race; Babbitt Makes Pullout Official
LEAD: Former Gov.
Pete du Pont of Delaware, who had vowed last Tuesday night to take his battered Republican Presidential campaign south for the crucial primaries on March 8, capitulated to fiscal and political reality today and withdrew from the race.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Aiding the Rebels
LEAD: While the White House has taken great pains to dissociate itself from private efforts to raise money for the Nicaraguan rebels, a political organization called Citizens for Reagan, is trying to take up the slack.


Crew Gives Statement in Ambulance Inquiry
LEAD: The New York City Emergency Medical Service said yesterday that it had received statements from an ambulance crew that was said to have refused to leave a Bronx delicatessen to help a man dying of a heart attack in a church a block away.


'MYSTERY!' AT OXFORD
LEAD: ''MYSTERY!'' turns plummy tomorrow night.
Chief Inspector Morse looks for a killer among Oxford's dons.
The dons inhabit spacious, sunny offices amid turrets, spires and greens.
Morse drinks ale, listens to Wagner, and solves difficult crossword puzzles in his bachelor apartment.
There is not a handgun to be seen.


ABC Fans the Fire of Of Emotional Game
LEAD: FOR a United States-Soviet Union hockey game to succeed for the 80 million fans watching on television, the game has to be set up with dramatic tension.


Conservationists Offer Park System 'Blueprint'
LEAD: A leading conservation group called today for reform and a major expansion of the national park system.
The proposal drew quick support on Capitol Hill.


Lisbon Seeks Revision Of U.S. Defense Accord
LEAD: Portugal plans to ask for a ''thorough overhaul'' of a 37-year-old mutual defense treaty with the United States that allows the use of military sites in the Azores Islands, the Portuguese Foreign Minister says.


The U.N. Today
LEAD: General Assembly

LEAD: *
AST Research Inc., Irvine, Calif., a maker of computer hardware and software products, appointed Bruce Edwards chief financial officer and a senior vice president and Bruce Cassel senior vice president of United States sales.

Art: Skewed World Of Steve Gianakos
LEAD: STEVE GIANAKOS in his new paintings at the Barbara Toll Gallery comes on at first like a cartoonist.
A master of everyday embarrassments and nighttime fears, he touches terrain often worked over by others.
Of old, we know his baffled businessmen.
The house that goes out of control is also a familiar ploy, though one with unlimited potential.

CUNY Final Is Tonight
LEAD: There will be two objectives for College of Staten Island in the CUNY Conference basketball final tonight in Nat Holman Gymnasium.
One is in the hands of the players, but for the other, the players can only keep their fingers crossed.


Livestock Down the Limit; Precious Metals Also Fall
LEAD: Livestock futures plummeted the limit allowed for daily trading yesterday in a wave of profit taking apparently prompted by weak demand for beef and pork products.


Stage: Len Jenkin's 'American Notes,' at the Public
LEAD: IN his plays, Len Jenkin has often taken us on dark midnight rides to mythic environments.
With ''American Notes,'' his new play at the Public Theater, he leads us through a stretch of the American landscape.
Though the route is almost as strange as ever, there are signposts, identifiable at least to those who have seen ''Buried Child,'' ''Blue Velvet'' and other baleful studies of small-town provincial life.


Latin Aid Bank Selects Leader
LEAD: Uruguay's Foreign Minister, Enrique V. Iglesias, who once headed one of the largest private banking groups in his country, was elected president of the Inter-American Development Bank today.

Stage: 'Yard Sale' and 'Betty Lemon'
LEAD: BOTH of Arnold Wesker's one-act, one-character dramas, which the Jewish Repertory Theater is presenting together under the title of the evening's curtain-raiser, ''Yard Sale,'' profile mature women painfully coping with life beyond marriage.
Both plays star Marilyn Chris, an actress of considerable resourcefulness who over the course of the evening successfully leaps from the role of a Brooklyn school teacher to that of a bilious invalid widow of a British M


Insider Penalties' Effect
LEAD: Severe insider-trading penalties are damaging new cases by discouraging potential defendants from cooperating, a top official of the Securities and Exchange Commission has been quoted as saying.
Gary Lynch, the S.E.C. enforcement director, was quoted as saying in an interview that the prospect of imprisonment, civil fines and financial ruin is convincing some people that ''it's better to hunker down than cooperate.


Sports People; Bird Expected to Play
LEAD: Larry Bird, who suffered a broken nose Wednesday night in the Celtics' 138-125 loss to the Denver Nuggets, is expected to play tonight when Boston continues its trip in Portland, Ore., against the Trail Blazers.


Farm Credit Shows Profit
LEAD: The Farm Credit System said yesterday that it had earned a profit of $179 million in the final quarter of 1987, but the nation's biggest farm lender posted a loss for the full year in spite of a big reduction in its reserve for loan losses.


Photos of Levin Are Released By Prosecutors
LEAD: The last three photographs of Jennifer Levin in the hours before her death, taken in an Upper East Side bar as she posed, tanned and smiling, with her friends, were shown to reporters and photographers for the first time yesterday by prosecutors.

Quick Shifts in Public Mood Can Fool Day-to-Day Polling
LEAD: Two major polling operations failed to predict Vice President Bush's surge of last-minute support in the New Hampshire primary election on Tuesday, and polling specialists said it demonstrated the difficulty of using day-by-day surveys for news coverage of a Presidential primary.


Dining Out Guide: 3-Star French, Part 1
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
The date of original publication is listed after the phone number.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
AURORA, 60 East 49th Street (692-9292) - (Jan. 31, 1986) Well-spaced tables and comfortable chairs and banquettes contribute to the luxurious atmosphere of this midtown restaurant.


Soviet Says It Lost 3 Satellites as Rocket Failed
LEAD: The Soviet Union's Proton rocket experienced its third failure in 13 months today when the rocket's fourth stage failed to send three satellites into a planned orbit high above the Earth.


Jansen Tumbles; Gold to Guliaev
LEAD: Four nights after having fallen on the first turn of the Olympic 500-meter only hours after his sister's death, Dan Jansen of West Allis, Wis., fell again tonight on the backstretch straightaway during the 1,000-meter speedskating event.


SOVIET JEWISH ART, 1912-1928
LEAD: The Russian Revolution fostered a brief though remarkable burst of artistic creativity that was particularly pronounced amoung many of the country's Jewish artists.
Yet unlike others in the new Soviet avant-garde, many of the Jewish artists incorporated traditional and folk-art styles into their work.


More Time Allowed on Canada Pact
LEAD: The Reagan Administration and Democratic Congressional leaders agreed today to allow the White House more time to present the Canadian free-trade accord to Congress for final approval.
The agreement assures that a vote will be taken this year.

LEAD: It has been four years since Conde Nast Publications created a new trade campaign, and with its new one, beginning this month, it is moving away from its traditional black-and-white style.

Oliver Lake and Quartet

Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

Bristol Journal; The Border War That's Fought With Billboards
LEAD: A border war is brewing along Interstate 94, the major thoroughfare between Chicago and Milwaukee.
It involves Wisconsin and Illinois and is being waged in three-foot-high letters on a pair of billboards at the state line just south of here.


Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 418 money market mutual funds decreased $1.19 billion, to $276.85 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 113 institutional funds decreased $1.32 billion, to $81.01 billion.
The 208 general purpose funds had an increase in assets of $370.9 million, to $81.78 billion.


Soviet Ousts Yeltsin From Ruling Body
LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin, a onetime ally of Mikhail S. Gorbachev whose sharp criticism of the pace of reform last October led to his ouster as Communist Party chief in Moscow, lost his Politburo post today while two new Gorbachev allies joined the ruling body.


Chinese New Year's
LEAD: A Chinese New Year celebration, with music and dance, is to be held Sunday at 2 P.M. at Pace University, Schimmel Center, Spruce Street, between Park Row and Gold Street.
Those appearing include former members of dance companies in Beijing, Shanghai and Tianjin.
The event is sponsored by the Young People's Chinese Cultural Center.


A NEW SITE OPENS FOR OLD MOVIES
LEAD: OLD-MOVIE buffs in New York have had little to cheer about in the last few years, with revival theaters closing or being transformed into first-run theaters at the faster-than-life pace of a Mack Sennett comedy.
But good news finally has arrived, in the form of a new revival house called the Biograph Theater that opens today at 225 West 57th

MORGAN STANLEY LOSES CHIEF OF LONDON OFFICE
LEAD: After 23 prosperous years at Morgan Stanley &amp; Company, including the last 11 as managing director in charge of the firm's highly successful London office, Archibald Cox Jr. has decided to resign.


People
LEAD: *
David Charney, a senior vice president at Robert A. Becker, the medical advertising subsidiary of the WCRS Group, has been named creative director.


Candidates Regroup for Test in South
LEAD: After months of intense politicking in two states, the campaign for President spread across half the continent today, with most candidates focusing on the South.


Chock Full o'Nuts Prices
LEAD: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation said yesterday that it had raised coffee prices by 20 cents a pound because of the higher cost of the high-quality beans used in its blends, and industry sources expect similar moves from other United States roasters shortly.
The suggested retail price for a pound of Chock Full o'Nuts coffee was increased to $3 a pound.


Results Plus
LEAD:  Golf  Couples Takes Lead: Fred Couples capped a nine-under-par 63 with a birdie-birdie-birdie finish yesterday to take the opening-round lead at the $650,000 Andy Williams Open in La Jolla, Calif.
Couples, who lost the Phoenix Open in a playoff, birdied 10 of the 18 holes at the North course at the Torrey Pines Golf Club.


A Dance-Music Project
LEAD: Meet the Composer has initiated a $1.3 million national project to pay for collaborations between American composers and choreographers.
The three-year project was begun by a $300,000 first-year grant from the Ford Foundation, with an additional $600,000 committed over the next two years, and a contribution of $450,000 from the Pew Charitable Trusts.


U.S. Needs Help to Advance
LEAD: It will take close to a miracle, and some unsolicited cooperation from the Soviet Union, for the United States hockey team to advance to the medal round.

Writer, Twice Restrained, Has New Salinger Book
LEAD: Barred by the courts from publishing an unauthorized biography of J. D. Salinger by Ian Hamilton, Random House will soon publish what it describes as ''a substantially new book'' by Mr.
Hamilton about the reclusive Mr.
Salinger.


Knicks Win 9th in Row at Home, 108-104
LEAD: The Knicks beat the Sacramento Kings by 108-104 last night to run their winning streak at Madison Square Garden to nine games, their longest at home since the 1975-76 season.


Sports People; Wagner Star Sidelined
LEAD: Dean Borges of Wagner, the nation's fifth-leading scorer with a 25.4 average, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee Wednesday and will be out for the rest of the season, said Coach Neil Kennett.


Standard Acts to Foil Decker Bid
LEAD: In a move to thwart an unwanted takeover offer from the Black &amp; Decker Corporation, American Standard Inc. said yesterday that its directors had approved a recapitalization plan that was ''financially superior'' to Black &amp; Decker's cash offer of $65 a share, or $2.1 billion.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about personnel changes at the New York Film Festival incorrectly described Richard Corliss, who has resigned from its program committee.
Mr.
Corliss remains co-editor of Film Comment, the magazine of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, which sponsors the festival.


Hewlett Net Rises 54.3%
LEAD: Buoyed by strong sales growth in all its product lines, the Hewlett-Packard Company today reported improved revenues and earnings for its first quarter, which ended Jan. 31.
Hewlett-Packard also said order levels were the highest for any quarter in the company's history.

More Wheat to Soviet
LEAD: An additional 500,000 metric tons of subsidized United States wheat has been sold to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.
At recent prices averaging $2.82 a bushel, the wheat would have a value of $52 million.
Nearly 5.7 million tons of subsidized wheat has been sold to the Soviet Union under the department's Export Enhancement Program for delivery in the fiscal year that began Oct.

Jean-Paul Bourelly's Avant-Garde Jazz
LEAD: Jean-Paul Bourelly, a young guitarist from Chicago, moved to New York eight years ago.

LEAD: The independent prosecutor investigating the Iran-contra affair said today that he had retained Laurence H. Tribe, a leading constitutional scholar, to defend the 1978 law authorizing courts to appoint such special prosecutors.

LEAD: THE worst kind of exploitation film masquerades as a spoof, luring innocent but otherwise intelligent people to the theater.

UNION THREATENS STRIKE AT PAN AM
LEAD: The head of the teamsters' union's airline division warned yesterday that the union would strike Pan American World Airways Sunday unless the airline withdrew what the teamsters called ''unreasonable'' contract demands or agreed to binding arbitration.


Sports People; Gretzky Ties Mark
LEAD: Down by 2-0 after the first two periods, the Toronto Maple Leafs battled back to take a 4-3 lead in the third period Wednesday night before Mark Messier of Edmonton scored with 26 seconds left in regulation, giving the Oilers a 4-4 tie.
But the goal gave more than that to Wayne Gretzky.
It was his second assist of the game, and it enabled him to tie Gordie Howe at l,049 on the career assists list.

Jersey Balks at Renewal Of Trump Casino Permit
LEAD: The Casino Control Commission refused today to relicense Donald J. Trump's Resorts International casino, unless he cleared up ''numerous contradictions'' in his testimony before the panel.


Strike Ends At British Ford Plants
LEAD: Workers at the Ford Motor Company's factories in Britain voted overwhelmingly today to end an 11-day strike that had threatened production across Europe and cost the company millions of dollars, Ford said.


Dollar Up Modestly in U.S.; Gold Prices Mostly Lower
LEAD: The dollar closed moderately higher in New York and mixed in London yesterday after falling in Tokyo earlier in the day.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  FRIDAY  IN THE DRAGON'S YEAR


Jasper Johns's 'Diver' To Be Sold at Auction
LEAD: Jasper Johns's ''Diver,'' one of the the artist's first large-scale paintings, is to be auctioned at Christie's on May 3.
The 1962 work, on five panels, is 7 1/2 feet high and 14 feet wide.


Brazil Agrees to Renew Meetings With I.M.F.
LEAD: Ending a three-year boycott of talks with the International Monetary Fund, Brazil expects to start negotiations on a new borrowing arrangement next month and to conclude an agreement by the end of June, Finance Minister Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega said here today.


On Stage
LEAD:  Holzer Is Back, With Projects


Arbitrator Cuts Gooden's Pay $100,000
LEAD: The Mets registered their first victory of the year yesterday, emerging as a philosophical and financial winner over Dwight Gooden in their salary-arbitration encounter.
The outcome made Gooden only the eighth player of the 265 whose salaries have been determined by arbitrators to have his salary cut.

CENTRAL BANK GETS ADVISE
LEAD: Using the 1989 Budget Message as a platform, the Reagan Administration continued to warn the Federal Reserve Board today against clamping down on economic growth and pushing up interest rates.


ZZZZ Case Guilty Plea
LEAD: An associate of Barry Minkow, the young entrepreneur whose ZZZZ Best Company collapsed amid scandal last year, pleaded guilty to three fraud charges today.
Thomas Gordon Padgett, who posed as the source of ZZZZ Best's phony carpet restoration contracts, was the second of 11 co-defendants to plead guilty to what prosecutors described as a scheme that defrauded investors and banks of $24 million.


Finland Shocks Punchless Canada, 3-1
LEAD: They knew their chronically weak offense would probably return to haunt them.
Tonight, not even a calculated attack on the legality of the opposing goalie's helmet proved useful.


Ex-CBS Official In Joint Venture
LEAD: The former president of the CBS entertainment division, B. Donald Grant, and a subsidiary of the Tribune Company said they had agreed to form a venture to produce television programs.


The Law; In Celebration of 'Dignified Frivolity'
LEAD: Whereas the law profession is often perceived as ruled by arcane stuffiness and sartorial solemnity, and whereas it is considered stylishly unsafe for any one party to appear too different, be it known that one day each year the Manhattan firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam &amp; Roberts will henceforth spoof itself by celebrating the lowly bow tie.

LEAD: Japan will not stop a hunt in the Antarctic in which 300 whales are to be killed for what it calls research purposes, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

Silverstein's Designs
LEAD: An exhibition devoted to Louis Silverstein's contributions to the redesign of The New York Times is on view at the Houghton Gallery and Lubalin Study Center of Cooper Union at 7 East Seventh Street.
During the 1970's and early 80's, when Mr.
Silverstein was an assistant managing editor and corporate art director at The Times, the paper gave itself a major facelift, introducing nine new sections, redesigning several old ones and shifting to a six-column format.

LEAD: AT the moment, two exhibitions of African art that have just opened in uptown museums are igniting an unexpected dialogue and exchange of ideas. ''Art/ Artifact: African Art in Anthropology Collections,'' now at the Center for African Art, takes as its subject not so much African art per se, but the various ways Westerners have displayed it since the late 19th century.

LEAD: Most economic analysis is dated within a few months or years.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the possible liquidation of an insurer of home mortgages misidentified the company.
It is the TMIC Insurance Company, formerly called the Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company.

Art Directors Museum
LEAD: Karl H. Steinbrenner, president of the Art Directors Club, announced the formation of the Art Directors Club Museum of Advertising and Communications Design.
The club, which publishes an advertising and graphic design annual, also has a large television commercial archive.
Those interested in donating historical material dealing with advertising, design and television to the nonprofit museum should write to the club, 250 Park Avenue South, New York 10003, or call 212-674-0500.

He was 92 years old.

Korea Tariff Cut Praised
LEAD: United States Government officials today applauded an announcement by South Korea that it would lower import tariffs on cars and more than 400 other products next month.
The Ministry of Finance said the move was intended to curb inflation and reduce the country's trade surplus.


Nabisco Bakery
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. plans to build a $600 million bakery, covering 1.1 million square feet on 120 acres near Raleigh, N.C.
The bakery will make Nabisco-brand cookies and crackers.
Construction is to start this spring and is scheduled to be completed in 1990, the company said.


OFFICIALS CRITICIZE FEDERAL RESERVE
LEAD: The Reagan Administration today blamed the Federal Reserve, along with October's stock market rout, for the slowdown in the election-year economy.
The President's economic advisers also said that the Federal Reserve had helped cause the rout but that its current policies were satisfactory.

Andrysiak Loses
LEAD: Terry Andrysiak, the Notre Dame senior who started four games at quarterback last season until he suffered a broken collarbone, will not be permitted to play a fifth season although he played only four minutes in his freshman season, the university announced. ''In Terry's case, there is not sufficient medical evidence of physical injury in his freshman season to merit the extra season being approved,'' said Richard Rosenthal, the athletic director.

Fed's Report Shift Stuns Traders
LEAD: Trading in fixed-income securities ground to a near-halt yesterday after the Federal Reserve announced late Thursday that it would report weekly, rather than monthly, changes in the nation's broader money supply, or M-2 and M-3.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1988
LEAD:  The Economy


Stage: 'Shirley Basin,' on a Lonely Mining Town
LEAD: Shirley Basin, as described by Molly Ivins in a 1978 article in The New York Times, was an incredibly isolated uranium-mining town in a desolate area of Wyoming.
The town was like ''a moonscape capped with snow, a huge clot of trailers, one after another, and nothing else.'' There were no trees, houses or parks and the barren social life revolved around the bar at the Bad Medicine Inn.


NETS FALL AS BARKLEY SCORES 43
LEAD: Charles Barkley scored 43 points, hitting 16 of 22 shots from the field, to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 115-100 victory over the Nets tonight.

''How many people are in the house with you?

CORRECTION
LEAD: An article yesterday about the potential impact of President Reagan's budget on major Government programs misstated the change proposed for the Environmental Protection Agency.
The $1.63 billion budget would be an increase of $48 million over this year, not a decrease.


Bowles Wins in Hurdles
LEAD: Dawn Bowles was smiling when the race was over last night.
Monifa Taylor was laughing.
The nation's two best high school performers in the 55-meter hurdles had just completed another duel, this time at the Colgate Women's Games at Madison Square Garden.
But the two athletes would not overplay the importance of one meet or the significance of who won.


Boy, 16, Charged in Ax Murders Of 4 in His Family in Minnesota
LEAD: The authorities today arrested David Brom, 16 years old, in the ax murders of his parents, a brother and a sister.
Prosecutors said they would seek to try him as an adult on murder charges.

CORRECTION
LEAD: A chart on Thursday listing foreigners held captive in Lebanon carried an erroneous identification from The Associated Press for a British hostage, John McCarthy.
He is a producer not a cameraman, for Worldwide Television News.


Candidates Less Than Eager For Advice From Economists
LEAD: For all the Presidential candidates' promises on matters of trade, taxes, jobs, welfare and Social Security, something quite novel is happening this election year.
They are making much less use of economists and their advice than candidates did in the past.


Kluge Files to Buy More Orion Shares
LEAD: John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Company, is seeking Federal antitrust clearance to raise his stake in the Orion Pictures Company to as much as 50 percent.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr.
Kluge said that the purchases of shares in the New York-based motion picture and television company would be for investment purposes.

LEAD: For Theodore W. Kheel, perhaps the most influential industrial peacemaker in New York City in the last half-century, advising the newspaper unions in their negotiations with The New York Post is a matter of providing guidance and ''clarification'' - in what are acknowledged by both sides to have been very important dollops.


Caraguatay Journal; People Leave and the Dollars Arrive
LEAD: Many inhabitants of this small farming town have never visited Asuncion, the Paraguayan capital, and a few speak only the traditional Guarani language, but everyone, it seems, has a daughter or a cousin or some other close relative living in New York.

LEAD: The semiconductor industry's new research consortium, Sematech, is facing a sharp cutback in Federal financing in the 1989 fiscal year under the President's proposed budget, which was released this week.


Webster Retires
LEAD: Mike Webster, the Pittsburgh Steelers' center for 14 years, said yesterday he was retiring.
Webster, 35 years old, was the last active Steeler to have played in all four of the team's Super Bowl victories.

TV: 'Noble House,' Four-Part Mini-Series
LEAD: ''Noble House'' clunks through eight hours on nearly leaden feet.
The fire in the floating restaurant is spectacular; the horse race isn't bad; the landslide is at least dramatic.
Otherwise, there's not much to see.
People get in and out of cars or on and off of junks and yachts or wander through board rooms, houses and lobbies.

Bush Edges Dole in a Straw Poll in Nevada
LEAD: Vice President Bush has won a Presidential straw poll among Nevada Republicans, but his total was nearly equaled by the undecided votes, many of which were said to have been cast by supporters of Pat Robertson in an attempt to control later balloting.

A FAMILY'S LOVE OF FLAGS HELPS TO AVERT TRAGEDY
LEAD: &gt;I USED to live on the third floor of an apartment building facing a row of town houses.
When one of those houses changed hands, the new owners erected an oversized flagpole in the small yard beside their front steps.
Every morning around seven, either the husband or the wife would emerge with a flag, attach it to the halyard and hoist it up, and every evening, not precisely at sunset but around that time, it was lowered and carefully folded away for the night.


Too Close To Reality
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


IF TAX RISES ARE COMIN, WHICH ONE WILL THEY BE?
LEAD: ALTHOUGH the budget President Reagan submitted last week formally projects that the Federal deficit will fall in each of the next five years, reaching a relatively negligible $23 billion in 1993, politicians and economists generally agree that the chances of this happening are practically zero.


South Africa's Liberals: Divided and Dropping Out
LEAD: South African liberals are more divided than ever about their future.


Pre-CPC Days
LEAD: To the Editor:


A Palestinian View
LEAD: OBVIOUSLY, A LONGSTANDING conflict like that between the Israelis and the Palestinians can be resolved any number of ways - particularly when one side has the power to impose a settlement on the other.
The question here, however, is not about a so-called ''agreement'' that one side forces the other to accept, but a true, lasting settlement that elicits a reasonable degree of consent from both.


GROUP OFFERS ADVICE ON OLDER BUILDINGS
LEAD: NEW LONDON LANDMARKS, a nonprofit preservation group, has begun a program to provide owners of the city's many older homes and other buildings with advice on rehabilitation and restoration.


Ambulance Workers To Face Discipline In a Death in Bronx
LEAD: Two Emergency Medical Service ambulance workers face disciplinary action because they waited for sandwiches in a Bronx delicatessen before responding to a report that a man was suffering a heart attack in a church one block away, officials said yesterday.


Virus' Threat
LEAD: To the Editor:


A GREAT HOSPITAL IN CRISIS
LEAD: From the moment I arrived in the emergency room of New York Hospital complaining of chest pains, I was treated by doctors, nurses and technicians with promptness, consideration and good humor.
I don't know how you measure a good outcome like mine against the terrible misfortune of Libby Zion.
But I do know that a fair analysis would not have focused on specific cases of negligence at one hospital without mentioning specific cases at any other hospitals.


PHOTOGRAPHERS TAKE AIM AT THE IMAGES FROM EARLIER WORKS
LEAD: MARCEL DUCHAMP bestowed a moustache on a reproduction of the Mona Lisa in 1919.
However, art about art didn't take root as an official policy until the 1950's when Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns began their careers parodying Abstract Expressionism and it was another two decades before photography followed suit.

A GREAT HOSPITAL IN CRISIS
LEAD: Individual physicians, or even New York Hospital, should not be blamed for the deaths of Andy Warhol and Libby Zion.
The system failed these patients, and the system must be changed.
When interns, fresh out of medical school, are forced to work for 36 hours without sleep and are left alone at night in charge of 30 or 40 seriously ill patients, deaths that should be avoidable will occur.


ABORTION DEBATE REVIVED IN CANADA
LEAD: After an uneasy political truce that lasted nearly 20 years, Canada has been thrust anew into a bitter dispute over its abortion laws.

LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced new austerity measures today to accompany the jarring currency devaluation he decreed a week ago.

New Loans Easing the Process
LEAD: Because married couples increasingly need the incomes of both spouses to qualify for a mortgage, a problem can arise when an employer relocates one of the partners.
The spouse of the transferred employee may take several months to find a suitable job in the new location and thus have the second income needed for the loan.

Opera: 'Curlew River,' Britten's Mystery Play
LEAD: DURING a trip to Tokyo in 1956, Britten twice attended a Noh play, and saw in its static, austere forms a solemn, graceful poetry. ''Sumidagawa,'' the story of a madwoman who had lost her child, struck the composer for the slowness of its action, the combination of speaking, singing and chanting, and the quiet, mystical intensity that sustained the piece, presented both times with no conductor guiding the ensemble of players and musicians.


Q AND A
LEAD: Alaska Ferries  Question: I am told there are ferries from Seattle to Alaska that stop at ports in the way cruise ships do.
Are there sleeping accommodations?
Where do you write for information? - H. C., Hauppauge, L.I.
Answer: A ferry service called Alaska Marine Highway operates year-round between Seattle and Skagway, Alaska.

LEAD: ''YEARS ago, security was at the bottom of the totem pole,'' said Michael Goodrich, general manager of Spectra Audio Research Inc., which makes electronic security devices.
Now, he went on, executives are quietly investing in bodyguards, bulletproof vests, automatic vehicle locators to trace a missing car and other high-tech gear.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

Colorful, maybe.

Until now.
