Jazz: Jelly Roll Kings In Mississippi Blues Bill
LEAD: RAW-BONED, loose-limbed Mississippi blues - music so traditional it can sound avant-garde -twanged and strutted at the Triplex on Friday night, in a triple bill presented by the World Music Institute.
Two of the oldest Mississippi styles and one of their wayward, electrified offspring filled the theater with sounds usually heard at barbecues, back porches and juke joints, defying the formality of a concert hall with down-home directness.

Correction
LEAD: An article in The Times Magazine on Jan. 10 about Nicaragua's leader, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, misstated the date of a secret meeting at which the Sandinistas sought to take control of the provisional legislature by adding members.
It was May 2, 1980.


LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
LEAD: Soft Breezes, Hard Water THEY prefer ''hard water'' to ''soft water,'' but not from the tap.
Hard water means ice to a certain segment of Long Island's sailing population, and sailing on ice tops sailing on water any day, iceboaters contend.


FICTION
LEAD:  THE DARK PATH TO THE RIVER.
By Joanne Leedom-Ackerman. (Saybrook/Norton, $19.95.) Joanne Leedom-Ackerman's first novel is a densely plotted, dialogue-filled story that reads like commercial fiction yet examines unconventional territory.
Frequently shifting points of view, the book focuses on the fates of two American friends and former newspaper colleagues who are united in their interest in a small, unnamed African country on the brink of revolution.

Controversy - and Platitudes - Writ Large
LEAD: ''Committed to Print'' at the Museum of Modern Art is an exhibition of ''social and political'' material - prints, posters, books and magazines that relate to concerns of today and yesterday in the United States.
In almost all of them, the word ranks equal with the image.
The general tone is defined by the museum as ''leftist or liberal,'' and for much of the way the word pulls the image along, the way horses pulled a covered wagon.

Correction
LEAD: An article in the Sports section on Feb. 7 previewing Winter Olympic competition misidentified the current world hockey champion, and another article misidentified the 1984 winner of the Olympic bronze medal in hockey.
Sweden is the world champion and won the bronze in the 1984 Games at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

IN SAN FRANCISCO, TV BATTLES ON THE FRONT LINES AGAINST AIDS
LEAD: Early in 1983, Jim Bunn, a new reporter for KPIX-TV here, finished writing his first AIDS report and knew the story was like none before.
It had sex, death, medical intrigue, a host of complex social issues - not the least of which were civil rights and gay life styles - and, by definition, it was going to challenge every taboo known to television.


India Bus Crash Kills 35
LEAD: At least 35 people were killed and many injured when a bus plunged into a ravine in northern India today, the Press Trust of India said.
About 60 people were aboard the bus when the accident occurred 40 miles from Simla, the capital of Himachal Pradesh state.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  IN SEARCH OF THE DARK AGES.
By Michael Wood. (Facts on File, $22.95.) Michael Wood, author of ''In Search of the Trojan War,'' has now turned to slightly more modern times: the genesis of the English nation.
He begins in A.D. 60, when Boadicea led her Celtic tribesmen in a doomed revolt against Roman rule, and ends a millennium later with William the Conqueror.

LEAD: Q. I plan to remove the glass doors that now enclose our tub-shower.
However, the metal runner on the bottom of these doors is apparently cemented onto the top of the tub rim with some kind of grout.
I'm afraid that chipping and scraping might damage the finish on the tub.
Is there any way you know of to remove this grout more easily?

DRIED FRUITS CAN BRIGHTEN DESSERTS
LEAD: IF you are looking for new ideas for winter desserts, consider dried fruits.
They are at their best during the winter and are a fine alternative to expensive tropical or out-of-season fresh fruit.
You can now get prunes, dried apple rings, apricots, pears, peaches and figs, mostly from California, good enough to eat straight from the package.

LEAD: A traveling swindler comes to town.
What he sells to the rural folk isn't worth much, but the power of suggestion runs rampant.
From apparent fraud emerges surprising results - love, happiness and success.
As an operagoer's ''who am I?'' quiz, this one isn't very difficult: Donizetti's ''Elixir of Love.


Sell Solutions, Not Just Products
LEAD: SOME say multinational corporations threaten the economic and political independence of developing countries and represent one of the greatest obstacles to development.
Others find progress in the third world inconceivable without companies operating on an international scale.
Multinationals, they say, transfer technologies, as well as exemplary standards for production safety, the environment and social responsibility.

LEAD: It was exciting to read about how Donald Perry has learned to traverse the jungle canopy to explore the secrets of the rain forest (''Secrets of the Rain Forest,'' by Erik Eckholm, Jan. 17).

THE GUIDE
LEAD:  MOLIERE AT YALE REP  Lewis J. Stadlen, a Tony Award nominee for his performance as Pangloss in the Broadway production of ''Candide'' in 1974, plays the title role in Moliere's ''Miser,'' which will run to March 12 at the Yale Repertory Theater.


Duke Rallies to Top Kansas in Overtime
LEAD: Quin Snyder scored 21 points, including 7 in overtime, as Duke came back twice to beat Kansas, 74-70, today.


Anti-Poverty Program Seeks to Build Self-Esteem
LEAD: On a raw winter morning near Skid Row, a dozen mothers on welfare listened to a story about a poor woman like them who once thought she had not a chance in the world.


NEW YORK'S BRIDGES ARE CRUMBLING TOWERS OF NEGLECT
LEAD: THE next time someone tries to sell you a bridge in New York City, be sure to ask for a warranty.
Officials say about half the city's bridges are rated in poor or fair condition, 31 have had to be at least partly closed off and 100 need to be replaced.


Composing Prize Awarded
LEAD: Jay Anthony Gach, born in New York in 1953, has won first prize in the first Frederick P. Rose Competition of the Brooklyn Philharmonic for new orchestral works by American composers.
Mr.
Gach won a cash award of $10,000 and a performance of his score, ''Chant,'' during the orchestra's 1988-89 season.


A WEEK THAT STARS THE AVANT-GARDE
LEAD: THE big musical event of the week is the six-day series of lectures, discussions and concerts that Wesleyan University is devoting to the avant-garde composer John Cage, who has turned 75 years old.


The Hull Story
LEAD: THE MYSTERY AT THE HEART of the yachting world's raging controversy is scheduled for unveiling March 27, when Michael Fay, a New Zealand investment banker, is to launch the boat with which he'll compete for the America's Cup in September.
The $3 million yacht is being built (above) near Auckland by Marten Marine Ltd.


Opera: At Juilliard, 'Beatrice and Benedict'
LEAD: BERLIOZ'S opera ''Beatrice and Benedict'' contains some of his most magical music, but with its rigorous demands for accomplished acting and singing and its musical complexity, it is rarely performed.
Thus one welcomed Friday evening's production by the Juilliard American Opera Center, especially in the confines of the city's best opera facility, the Juilliard Theater.


Cheap Dollars
LEAD: To the Editor:


From Fathers to Sons on the Waterfront
LEAD: ON RAW DAYS LIKE THIS, with the wind whipping off a hide-brown Hudson and his containers slick with snow, Joseph Benedetto Jr. is numb to everything but the four levers at his finger tips and the greasy square of asphalt 50 feet beneath him.
One distraction and whatever is in that 40-foot aluminum shipping crate he's lifting - shoes or whisky or computers - could slip out of his grasp and go crashing down on the men below.


'BLOOD BROTHERS,' NEW FROM BRITAIN
LEAD: ''BLOOD BROTHERS'' at the Downtown Cabaret Theater has the earmarks of a double event.
Here is the American premiere of a 1983 award-winning, long-running -and downbeat - British musical that can alienate and attract audiences, and what a bold step this is for a theater noted for unthreatening, familiar fare!


NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1988
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-23


2 Arabs Killed in Clashes on West Bank
LEAD: Israeli security forces shot and killed two Palestinians, one of them a 12-year-old boy, in another day of protests today.
The shootings raised the death toll to at least 61 Palestinians in the 10 weeks of what Arabs are calling ''the uprising.''


U.S. 'COLONY' IS FEELING A BREEZE OF CHANGE
LEAD: OF all America's possessions, none has appeared more content with the relationship, at least in recent years, than the Virgin Islands.
But there are signs of change.


PROSPECTS
LEAD:  High Tech's Next Twist


Budget Called Bad for New York Area
LEAD: Legislators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say that President Reagan's $1.09 trillion budget calls for too many sacrifices from the region's cities, but that the most improvement they expect is revisions for several key programs.


THE ADVENT OF DO-IT-YOURSELF PRINTS
LEAD: THE longest lines at my friendly neighborhood film-processing lab aren't at the counter.
They're over in the corner where the self-service printing machine sits.
No matter that it may take 30 minutes to get to the front of the line, the appeal of while-you-wait prints is apparently too great to resist.


One Woman's Quest For a Hong Kong Suit
LEAD: IF you think having a suit made in Hong Kong, where the tourist association's booklet on shopping and restaurants lists 142 tailoring establishments, is easy, think again.
At least, if you have visions of a beautifully made, perfectly fitting suit with the construction, fit and hand-sewn touches that come only with custom work.

George H. Hartman Jr. of Northbrook, Ill.

LEAD: TO Morgan Kaolian, it is ''the best-kept secret in Fairfield County.'' Mr.
Kaolian is referring to Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford, of which he is the manager.
Although it is within a half-hour's drive of anywhere in the county, the airport remains a little-known resource.


FICTION
LEAD:  PURSUED BY THE CROOKED MAN.
By Susan Trott. (Harper &amp; Row, $16.95.) You've heard of novels based on the Bible, Greek myths or even Arthurian legend; this may be one of the first inspired by Mother Goose.
But why not?
The heroine, Miliana Bartha, who is possessed of ''three children, one husband, two lovers, and a woman friend,'' has an inspiration while scrubbing the floor one day.


Anti-Government Protest in South Korea
LEAD: Demonstrators clashing with riot police after a rally yesterday in Seoul, South Korea.
About 500 anti-Government demonstrators protested the proposed changes in rules for electing members of the National Assembly.
Elections are scheduled for April.


Jazz: Irma Thomas
LEAD: IRMA THOMAS'S 47th birthday was celebrated during her early set Thursday at the Lone Star Cafe -much to the audience's, and apparently the singer's, surprise - when her fan club president brought a cake onstage.
Although Ms.
Thomas has been making records since 1958 and had a string of New Orleans rhythm-and-blues hits in the early 1960's, time has been on her side.


New Rochelle Condos: Boat Slips On the Creek
LEAD: Guy Blundon is not one to waste a waterfront.
Of the 16 apartments that compose the Davenport Slip condominium he is developing with his partner, Lenard Thylan, 12 will have stepped terraces and sliding glass walls facing New Rochelle Creek.
The four other apartments will have dockside views.
The creek, a stubby estuary off Long Island Sound in the New Rochelle, N.Y., is lined with marinas, making for lively viewing.


NEW YORKERS, Etc.
LEAD: There are certain inevitables in life and there is absolutely no point fighting them because it won't help.
The only good thing that can be said about them is that they're nondiscriminatory: they happen to everyone -maybe not every single one to every single person, but most of them to most people.

Not for Kids Only
LEAD: To the Editor:


A GREAT HOSPITAL IN CRISIS
LEAD: The authors purport to examine problems at New York Hospital by focusing on a few celebrated cases, but their own statistics do not support their allegations.
If the hospital admits roughly 40,000 patients a year, and 109 complaints have been registered in the last three years (with only 29 percent of those apparently justified), greater than 99 percent of the cases are handled without significant incident.


FLASHING THE FASHIONABLE METALLIC SMILE
LEAD: SOMETIMES it seems as if everyone is wearing them.
Braces are in, especially if you are 11 years old and attending junior high school.
There it is de rigueur to flash a metallic smile.
You can make your peace with not eating bagels and with spending time in the orthodontist's office, where, periodically, the doctor tightens your wires and decorates your mouth with rubber bands.

LEAD: THERE is an Austrian saying that seemed to sum up the mood here as the bitter dispute over Kurt Waldheim increasingly battered and divided his small nation: ''Better a horrible end than horror without end.''


In Guatemala, Growing Pessimism on Human Rights Issues
LEAD: In Guatemala, where thousands of people have died in political violence during the 1980's, human rights advocates have never been popular.
So the creation last year of an independent agency empowered to denounce any and all abuses aroused considerable curiosity and even some hope.

Toxic Chemical Spill
LEAD: About 100,000 gallons of flammable toluene has spilled from a ruptured Sun Company pipeline into the Sandusky River near here, forcing the evacuation of about 5,000 people.
Mayor Fred Singer said today that those evacuated Wednesday and Thursday would be allowed to return home.

HOW PARAGUAY'S GENERAL STILL KEEPS THE WORLD AT BAY
LEAD: THE official version was that, in a moving display of loyalty and enthusiasm, Paraguayans turned out en masse last Sunday to approve Gen.
Alfredo Stroessner's eighth successive presidential term.
No less predictably, opposition leaders, the Roman Catholic Church and foreign diplomats said the elections were too fraudulent to be taken seriously.

Rene Char, French Poet, 80, Dies
LEAD: Rene Char, called ''the greatest French poet of the 20th century'' by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, died here Friday, according to the publishing company Gallimard.
He was 80 years old and lived in Paris.
Gallimard said Mr.
Char died at the Val-de-Grace military hospital.
No cause of death was given.


Does Meyerbeer Deserve His Years of Obscurity?
LEAD: Whatever hap-pened to Meyerbeer?


Electronic Watchdogs for Computers
LEAD: IN December, a computer enthusiast wreaked havoc at Lehigh University by programming a self-destruct code in personal computers on campus.
The prank, which affected an estimated 200 people, was a sobering reminder that computer-dependent executives are vulnerable both to careless leaks and intentional sabotage.


RULING THE JET SET
LEAD: William Safire refers to the phrase ''jet set'' as having ''first appeared in print in 1951 to describe the fashion-conscious group that used jet aircraft to take them to the world's watering spots in passionate pursuit of pleasure'' (On Language: ''Ruling the Jet Set,'' Jan. 24).


Two Soviets Take an Eye-Opening Historic Step
LEAD: George Balanchine was a complex man of firm convictions and deep contradictions.
Like many Russian emigres, he had a love-hate relationship with his native land and he could not abide the Communist regime.
Yet, he enthusiastically accepted its invitation to visit the Soviet Union twice and show off the fruit of his 60-year artistic endeavor abroad - the masterworks he had choreographed and the fabulous company, the New York City Ballet, that he had created and molded.


U.S. Industry's Unfinished Struggle
LEAD: THROUGHOUT the country, corporate chiefs are sounding paeans to American industry's rebound from the competitive doldrums.
In speeches, published papers and annual reports, they note how they have cut the fat out of management layers and divested businesses that did not fit in with overall corporate strategy.


STEAKHOUSE GOES BEYOND CLICHES
LEAD: BRYANT &amp; COOPER in Roslyn is a steakhouse with a difference.
Its dual personality will delight those who normally shun beef palaces.
But fear not, the red meat gang will definitely not be shut out.

Correction
LEAD: An article Feb. 7 from Baghdad, Iraq, about an exiled Iranian opposition movement, the People's Mujahedeen, incorrectly gave the reason that Massoud Rajavi, the movement's leader, was jailed in 1971.
Mr.
Rajavi was in jail for revolutionary activity against the Shah, not for purportedly trying to abduct the American Ambassador in


An Iran-Iraq Peace Is Up to the U.N.
LEAD: ''If the Iran-Iraq war does not come to an end officially in 1988, it will at least be practically over.'' This judgment, so contrary to the prevailing image of the war as a conflict without end, was expressed several weeks ago not by an armchair observer from afar but by Crown Prince Abdallah of Saudi Arabia, who had just completed a round of consultations about the war in the major Arab capitals followed by a summit meeting of Arab Gulf states.


Pact to Save The Post Is Reached; Buyer Looks to Regain Advertisers
LEAD: Rupert Murdoch and 10 unions agreed early yesterday on $22 million in concessions to save The New York Post, and hours later plans were under way to rejuvenate the paper and win back readers and advertisers who have defected in recent months.


SoHo Marble
LEAD: To the Editor:


DRAWING THE LINE ON STUDENT RIGHTS: COMMUNITY VALUES ARE ESSENTIAL
LEAD: AS a former member of a Board of Education on Long Island, I believe that the recent Supreme Court decision upholding control of student publications should be supported.
I do not believe the decision to permit school boards and administrators to ban material deemed unsuited for publication is either a devastating blow to freedom of speech or ''the wrong civic lesson'' for teen-age students.


Crewman Dies, 16 Hurt in Fire Aboard a Train
LEAD: A smoky fire in a crew car aboard the Amtrak system's California Zephyr killed a crew member and injured 16 people early today, officials said.
Passengers said they had received no warning of any danger and had been given no help in getting off the train.

'Looking Backward'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
LEAD: When it comes down to Olympic tradition, the biathlon is the best Winter Olympic sport.
Cross-country skiers swiftly stride through the woods, pushing the limits of physical endurance, then immediately gain absolute control of mind, body and emotion to prove their marksmanship, with the clock ticking in the background.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. I plan to remove the glass doors that now enclose our tub-shower.
However, the metal runner on the bottom of these doors is apparently cemented onto the top of the tub rim with some kind of grout.
I'm afraid that chipping and scraping might damage the finish on the tub.
Is there any way you know of to remove this grout more easily?


A LATIN REVIVAL TAKES THE STAGE AT JOHN JAY HIGH SCHOOL
LEAD: DOROTHY (DOBBIE) R. NICHOLLS loves the insults her classes hurl at her on exam days. ''Nos morituri te salutamus,'' they shout. (We who are about to die, salute you) and ''Dux femina facti.'' (The woman is the leader of the deed.) Mrs.
Nicholls is a teacher of Latin - the so-called dead language that this 43-year-old classics enthusiast has made the ''in'' language at Katonah's John Jay High School.

NONFICTION
LEAD: Few Americans have suffered in such a curious manner from distorted public image as have those of Italian background.
The prejudices have been less harsh than those affecting other groups, but no less demeaning.
THE ITALIAN AMERICANS (Macmillan, $49.50), an account by Allon Schoener, a cultural historian, of Italian life in the United States in word and picture, is a more positive testimony to the nature and achievements of these remarkably vibrant people.

Jazz: Saxophone, Doug White

LEAD: On a side street in one of Philadelphia's poorest and meanest neighborhoods, there sits a vacant stone building that is about to be transformed into a residence for 25 homeless people.
It might serve as a minor monument to the way in which a meddling Federal Government, in the view of governors and mayors, often frustrates local efforts to address many of the nation's urgent domestic ills.

PAPAL AIDES CITE ORIGINS OF LETTER
LEAD: Pope John Paul II's encyclical letter condemning the superpower rivalry is a highly personal document that reflects his Polish heritage and is characteristically both blunt and meditative, according to senior Vatican officials.


Fixing Up: The Home Show
LEAD: Under the high glass ceiling of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, a complete house is being assembled, landscaped and decorated in preparation for the Greater New York Apartment &amp; Home Show.
It opens next Saturday for a run until March 6 and it promises many informative seminars and displays on ownership, management, renovation and decoration of a home, be it a rental apartment, a pied-a-terre condominium, a family-size co-op or a suburban ranch.

Photography
LEAD: ''The Return of the Hero'' is a group show that asks, then answers, the question: Does Lt.
Col.
Oliver North represent merely the tip of the iceberg when it comes to our current yearnings?
Apparently.
The 13 artists included - not all of them photographers, it should be said - seem to be in agreement that warrior-like appearance and behavior are definitely ''in'' in the late 80's.

LEAD: The police have detained at least seven opposition leaders, apparently in an effort to prevent the outlawed trade union Solidarity from convening a meeting this weekend, opposition spokesmen said today.

'BORN YESTERDAY' IS REBORN IN CHICAGO
LEAD: Chicago!
What a perilous, politically-blooded arena in which to revive ''Born Yesterday,'' Garson Kanin's 1945 play about governmental corruption in wartime Washington.
Fixes and graft have long been a form of street theater in Chicago; most citizens' knowledge of municipal deals darker than the century-old bricks of the Steppenwolf Theater building lies as deep in memory as their childhood prayers.

He was 94 years old.

WHAT THEY'RE WEARING
LEAD: THE FASCINATION WITH FASHIONS PAT-terned after animal coats comes and goes.
This winter, however, it arrived full force.
Faux pelts have been spotted everywhere.
From skirts to handbags to slipcovers, everything appeared to be more desirable if it had leopards' spots or tigers' stripes.
These beasts' natural markings are carried out in complicated sequin embroideries; printed on silk, satin, denim or cotton, or stenciled on calfskin.

LEAD: As a neighbor and friend of Patti LuPone, I remember that Patti was always bursting out with a song, even when she was a little girl (''She's the Top,'' by David Sacks, Jan. 24).
I would be outside, doing my weekend building.
She would be coming down the hill to play with my children.
She would see me and would sing, in her own style: ''Good morning, Mr.

Dance
LEAD: Dancing is an exhausting profession, and one that leaves little time or resources for providing for an unforeseen problem.
Sunday night the New York City Ballet closes its winter season at the New York State Theater with the Dancers' Emergency Fund Benefit.
Instituted three years ago, the benefit raises money that is used to help resolve sudden crises in the lives of the dancers who bring the City Ballet repertory to life season after season.

LEAD: Gabriel Garcia Marquez is about to publish ''Love in the Time of Cholera,'' a work he calls a novel of manners: the story of two people whose love, thwarted in their youth, finally flourishes when they are close to 80.

Mark of Champion
LEAD: It apparently takes more than a broken nose to stop Larry Bird.

Lights! Camera! Easel!
LEAD: What do Edward G. Robinson, Alec Guinness, Daryl Hannah and Dick Van Dyke have in common?
Apart from being artists in the entertainment sense, they have also played artists in the artistic sense.
And as Hollywood and the New York art world move closer together in the 1980's - with their star systems, the big prices and instant fame that awaits hot new discoveries - Hollywood has started to take the art world seriously (or humorously, as the case may be).

Pagnol, From the Source
LEAD: More than a decade after the death of Marcel Pagnol, the international triumph of ''Jean de Florette'' and ''Manon des Sources'' introduced millions of people to Pagnol's Provence - as distinctive and enduring a terrain of the imagination as William Faulkner's Yoknapatawpha County.
Contemporary audiences could be pardoned for believing that these picturesquely colored views of Yves Montand making mischief in the arid hills of the Midi - so scrupulously orchestrated by the director Claude Berri - were indeed the real thing.

Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
LEAD: I'm not tremendously educated in the art of figure skating, but I enjoy what I see.
The beauty and physical efficiency of the competitors, the graceful and sophisticated movements, the poise, the confidence, the acrobatic ability that is exhibited is what provides for the most glamorous, yet most difficult of the winter sports events.


Black Whose Death Penalty Was Overturned Is Convicted
LEAD: A black teen-ager sentenced to death at the age of 15 was convicted today of murder in a retrial brought after the state Supreme Court overturned his original conviction by an all-white jury.
The prosecutor said he would not seek the death penalty again.


Japan Seeks Stake In American Tires
LEAD: Bridgestone Tire agreed to pay $1 billion for 75 percent of Firestone in what is believed to be the largest Japanese investment yet in an American manufacturer.
Firestone is the nation's third-largest tire maker, with $2.6 billion of tire sales annually.
But after the deal, its largest business will be 1,500 retail stores that sell tires and other automotive goods and services.


Seton Hall Overcomes B.C.
LEAD: Seton Hall did not try to disguise its intentions against Boston College today.
The Pirates wanted to work the ball inside to Mark Bryant, stop Dana Barros and earn a Big East Conference victory.

Mexican Owner Sells Control of U.P.I.
LEAD: Mario Vazquez Rana, the Mexican publisher who has owned United Press International since 1986, announced Friday that he had sold the right to operate the news service to an investment group associated with Financial News Network, a cable television service.


FOR WINTER READING
LEAD: WEATHER permitting, this is a good season to prune dormant trees especially young apples and pears to strengthen them, but wait until after flowering to prune stone fruits such as peaches, nectarines and cherries.
Grapevines are pruned any time this month and next.
Arrange for tree pruning by arborists if shade or specimen trees have grown too thick and tall or have been weakened by ice or snow storms.


Question Of the Week; What's the Best Winter Olympic Sport?
LEAD: Only ice hockey requires the molding of 18 to 20 individuals into a competitive team.
Moreover, there is a uniqueness in the contrasting styles of play among the Europeans, Canadians and Americans.
And the unpredictable nature of the Olympic ice-hockey tournament adds to the sport's premier status in the Winter Games.

LEAD: As Cyprus prepares for a presidential runoff election on Sunday, the result is far from clear, but the problem that will confront the winner is evident: how to revive efforts to reconcile and reunite the island's Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot communities.

They Are Not Non-Persons
LEAD: Some legislators and citizens, and the states of Kansas and Pennsylvania, have brought a suit demanding that illegal aliens not be counted when Congress redistricts after the 1990 Census.
They claim that undocumented aliens in states like New York and California will skew the results and perhaps cost their states a House seat.


AMERICAN COMPANY AND SOVIET AGREE ON SPACE VENTURE
LEAD: For the first time an American company has contracted to have the Soviet Union carry Western commercial payloads into orbit.
The agreement is likely to spur similar moves by other companies, Federal officials said.

DRIED FRUITS CAN BRIGHTEN DESSERTS
LEAD: IF you are looking for new ideas for winter desserts, consider dried fruits.
They are at their best during the winter and are a fine alternative to expensive tropical or out-of-season fresh fruit.
You can now get prunes, dried apple rings, apricots, pears, peaches and figs, mostly from California, good enough to eat straight from the package.

WHY THE COURSE OF AIDS IS DEFYING AFRICA'S PRECEDENT
LEAD: HAVING finally persuaded much of the public that the United States is on the verge of a heterosexual AIDS pandemic, health officials are suddenly reversing their prognosis.
For months, a growing volume of statistics has been showing that HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, is not moving rapidly through the population after all.

Missing Out
LEAD: When Dan Jansen fell, it was not from grace.
Last week, hours before he was to compete in the first of two Olympic speed-skating events in which he had high hopes of winning medals, Jansen got word that his sister, Jane Jansen Beres, had died of leukemia.
He was noticeably distraught as he started the 500-meter finals, and tumbled to the ice in the first turn.

I learned from him the supreme importance of geometry -the relationship of abstract shapes within a frame,'' says Marc Riboud.

LEAD: THE fight to remain open in a residential Woodmere community has become more than a zoning issue for the Life Center for Holocaust Studies.
It is a matter of principle and recognition that the study of the Holocaust cannot be separated from the Jewish religion, according to Rabbi Benjamin Kamenetzky.

BEYOND THE CHANCELLOR'S HONEYMOON
LEAD: DR.
Richard R. Green, who will become New York City's Schools Chancellor on March 1, is preparing for what is likely to be a brief honeymoon in an environment that has been notoriously unfriendly to outsiders.
But he made it clear in an interview last week that without underestimating the difficulty of attempting to reform a system widely considered enormously resistant to change, he feels ready to take on any forces that might think of him as an easily manipulated newcomer.

Arbitration Season Ends

NEW GROUP OF THE UNEMPLOYED EMERGES
LEAD: FOR 33 years the Senior Personnel Employment Council of Westchester has offered a no-fee employment service for workers older than 55.
The first organization of its type in the nation, it has been replicated many times.
The key ''plus'' that the council offers to workers is the absence of any discrimination because of age: employers list jobs with the full knowledge that we on the council deal only with workers 55 and older.

Music
LEAD: The Lower East Side is still home to some of the most creative rock-and-roll groups in the country.
The area that fostered Blondie, Velvet Underground and Television supports groups that push rock forms to their limits.
The music often winds its way in and around political lyrics; just as often, pop-styled songs with user-friendly melodies grab listeners' attention, only to hit them with odd-angled rhythms, subversive lyrics and crooked harmonies.

Preparing for Nepal's Rugged Reality
LEAD: I STOOD before the courtyard of the great Buddhist monastery at Tengboche in Nepal; the festival of Mani-Rimdu was about to begin.
First there were long blasts on the conch shells - an unearthly sound.
Then a procession of monks dressed in robes of deep red, over tunics of yellow, apricot and orange, began to wind around the courtyard.

DRIED FRUITS CAN BRIGHTEN DESSERTS
LEAD: IF you are looking for new ideas for winter desserts, consider dried fruits.
They are at their best during the winter and are a fine alternative to expensive tropical or out-of-season fresh fruit.
You can now get prunes, dried apple rings, apricots, pears, peaches and figs, mostly from California, good enough to eat straight from the package.

What's This? A Lot of Hot Air
LEAD: The Super Maine, a huge hot air balloon, rose 50 feet over frozen Sebago Lake several times today, carrying as many as 60 people at a time, though it was firmly tied to the ground.
The designers, builders and supporters of the 210-foot-high, 168-foot-wide balloon simply wanted to make a balloon larger than the Virgin Atlantic Flier, which crossed the Atlantic last summer.

THE DRAWBACKS OF PLAYING FAVORITES
LEAD: BEING known for a favorite defense is a two-way street.
If you are really good with it, you will intimidate many an opponent and score victories against listless play.
Yet no matter how good you are with it, it does point the opponent toward what he has to prepare when he comes up against you.
And there are opponents who cannot be intimidated.

LEAD:  NEARBY RAFTING  North American Whitewater Expeditions Inc., based in Hamden, Conn., offers what it believes is ''some of the best whitewater rafting in the East'' beginning in March and continuing through early May.
An eight-mile stretch of the upper Housatonic River, starting at Bull's Bridge Gorge in western Connecticut, provides a course through rapids that drop 90 feet in the first mile, then rushes through steep chasms, over large waves and difficult ledge drops.

DRIED FRUITS CAN BRIGHTEN DESSERTS
LEAD: IF you are looking for new ideas for winter desserts, consider dried fruits.
They are at their best during the winter and are a fine alternative to expensive tropical or out-of-season fresh fruit.
You can now get prunes, dried apple rings, apricots, pears, peaches and figs, mostly from California, good enough to eat straight from the package.

Market Place; Big Gold Loan's Effect on Prices
LEAD: ONE of the oldest anti-gold arguments used by monetarists, those who would sever any link between bullion and paper money, is that gold is a ''sterile investment.'' Why?
Because gold does not yield interest or dividends; its value is largely dependent on investor concerns about other assets.

Strange Money
LEAD: The S.D.R. may rise again.
The Special Drawing Right is a form of money, but not the kind that people use to buy a loaf of bread.
Consumers have never seen one.
It is money managed not by the United States Treasury but by the 151-government International Monetary Fund.
Only governments use it, to pay their bills.

LEAD: Every night, each homeless person who arrives at a shelter a few blocks south of downtown is asked to give his name and Social Security number.

Brass Quintet in Premiere
LEAD: The American Brass Quintet is to give the world premiere performance of ''Colchester Fantasy'' by Eric Ewazen and the New York premiere of Milton Babbitt's ''Fanfare,'' Thursday evening at 8 in the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street.
The program includes Two Sonatas by Bertali, a 17-century Suite of Dances by Simpson and Brade, Contrapuncti III and VII from Bach's ''Art of the Fugue,'' ''Serenade for Brass'' by Starer and Venetian Songs by Bartolini, Guami and Gabrieli.

Maple Leaf Coin No. 1
LEAD: Canada's Maple Leaf has regained its position as the world's most-purchased gold coin, overcoming the upstart United States Eagle in 1987.
Official figures will be released next month, but a spokesman for the Royal Canadian Mint said Friday that 1987 sales ranged between 1.3 million and 1.5 million ounces.


The Sweetest Time of the Year
LEAD: Bill Rudy heading into the sugar bush with empty pails to collect the sap of maple trees at Lenoir Preserve in Yonkers.
Holes are drilled into the trees, and the clear liquid tapped is boiled down to a rich, golden syrup.
It takes 35 to 50 gallons of sap to make a gallon of syrup. (NYT/Suzanne DeChillo)

The four-member band from Boston, which performed Thursday at Drums, rejects concise melodies, conventional chord sequences, naturalistic singing, narrative lyrics and just about anything else that might suggest symmetry or surface clarity.

Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The number of oil and gas rigs engaged in exploration in the United States rose by 10 last week, to a total of 978, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today.
A year ago the count was 839.
The rig count is the most widely watched industry index of drilling activity.


Piano: Mitsuko Uchida
LEAD: MITSUKO UCHIDA'S elegant Mozart recordings scarcely prepare us for the headlong passion she brought to Chopin at the Frick Collection on Sunday Afternoon.
The ubiquitous B flat minor Piano Sonata is not exactly a welcome item on the program of so interesting a musician, but one was struck by.
Miss Uchida's broad rubato in the first movement and a fury in the second that stretched both the music and her excellent technique to their limits.

Castro Rebuts Robertson
LEAD: Fidel Castro, in an interview published today in USA Today, denied Pat Robertson's charge that the Soviet Union had nuclear missiles in Cuba.
President Castro said there ''is not even a semblance of a Soviet missile in Cuba - not one.
I repeat, not one.'' Mr.
Robertson, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, said recently that 25 intermediate-range Soviet SS-4 and SS-5 missiles, armed with nuclear warheads, were in Cuba.

LEAD: Despite a crushing second-round loss to the Yugoslav grandmaster Predrag Nikolic, Anatoly Karpov fought back to capture first prize in the 50th Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands.
The former world champion displaced the Swedish grandmaster Ulf Andersson from the lead in Round 12 and the two drew in the final round.

LEAD: HARVARD AIDS researchers have acknowledged a laboratory error, clearing up confusion about AIDS-related viruses that infect humans and monkeys in Africa.
As some other scientists previously suggested, cells studied in the Harvard laboratory became contaminated with a monkey virus that was mistakenly identified as a human virus.

BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1988
LEAD: THE ECONOMY  The I.R.S. is giving incorrect information to people who call for help with their returns at least 25 percent of the time, the agency concedes.
The G.A.O. says the bad information is offered in response to 39 percent of the questions.
The telephone assistance program is more important than ever because most provisions of the monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 take effect this year.

Business and Health; Honeywell's Push To Track Doctors
LEAD: FOR some doctors, the name Honeywell may soon seem about as appealing as malpractice suits and hypochondriacs.
The Minneapolis company is one of a small number of American employers that have decided to become pushy in dealing with the medical community that cares for their employees.
If these companies are successful, a lot of employers might decide they have been passive too long and use them as models.

LEAD: On Sunday night, they were knocked from medal contention in an unflattering loss to West Germany.
Today they took a break from hockey and toured the Olympic pagaent.

By Design; Color Coordination
LEAD: A tricolor scheme is a great way to coordinate a wardrobe.
Every element is in one, or a combination, of the three colors, in both solids and patterns.
A fast-moving woman can mix the elements to create any number of looks, and her accessories always key in.
She can also pack in a jiffy.


I.B.M.'s New Strategy Worries the Industry
LEAD: Less than a year after introducing their newest personal computer line, the PS/2, officials at the International Business Machines Corporation are now planning an overhaul of the line that will distance the company from advancing clone makers.
The move is creating concern among industry executives who fear a sharp round of price-cutting and a flurry of new products could cause enough confusion to stall the industry's healthy recovery.

LEAD: Until six years ago, Andy Goldmark, a successful 36-year-old New York songwriter and producer, composed on an acoustic grand piano.

Bulgaria Resort Fire Kills 6
LEAD: Six people, including two Dutch tourists, were killed today when fire swept through a hotel in the ski resort of Borovets, the official Bulgarian press agency said.

LEAD: Citing precedents in the Soviet Union, a group of Czechoslovak journalists is negotiating with the Government in an effort to register an independent newspaper.


High Court To Rule on Phone Tax
LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed today to judge the validity of a 5 percent tax Illinois imposes on all telephone calls charged to in-state numbers.
The Court said it would study arguments that the tax interfered impermissibly with interstate commerce.


Sports People; Montana Has Surgery
LEAD: Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49ers' quarterback, underwent surgery in Redwood City, Calif., for an inflamation of the right elbow.
Dr.
Michael Dillingham, the team physician who performed the operation, described it as minor and said, ''The elbow looks real healthy.'' Montana is expected to be able to begin throwing again soon after a splint comes off, which will be in 8 to 10 days.

Scientists Gain Full Picture of Cancer Protein
LEAD: SCIENTISTS have determined the complete three-dimensional structure of the product of an important human oncogene, an aberrant gene believed to play a role in causing cancer.
The new picture of the oncogene product, a protein, should add to the understanding of how oncogenes work and might someday lead to the design of drugs that could change malignant cells back to normal.

Created after many months of work by Robert Perkins, with the agency for four years and now the subsidiary's president and chief executive, the division has finally come into being thanks to the acquisition of a veteran creative man.

LEAD: RISING profits for pollution control stocks have made them consistent winners on Wall Street.
Standard &amp; Poor's index for this group showed price gains of 67 percent in 1985, 52 percent in 1986 and 28 percent in 1987, compared with gains of 26 percent, 14 percent and 2 percent in the S.&amp;P. 500-stock index.

Supernova Remnants
LEAD: Pulsars, stars that emit rapid and highly regular pulses of energy, have puzzled astronomers ever since the first was discovered in 1967.
Initially dubbed ''Little Green Men,'' pulsars were suspected for a time of harboring intelligent beings that might be trying to communicate across interstellar space using precisely timed, pulsed signals.

John Allegro, 65; Aided Deciphering of Dead Sea Scrolls
LEAD: Dr.
John Allegro, who was renowned for his work in deciphering the Dead Sea Scrolls but ridiculed for his theories that Western religions were based on the worship of mushrooms, died Wednesday.
He was 65 years old.

LEAD: Ever-fragile relations between Britain and Ireland have slipped into a new cycle of erosion in the face of Britain's refusal, on the ground of national security, to prosecute police officers found to have perverted justice in Northern Ireland.

LEAD: After major campaign tests in Iowa and New Hampshire, a majority of the public is now paying attention to the Presidential race and throwing more support to three of the early winners, Michael S. Dukakis, Richard A. Gephardt and Bob Dole, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

Music Noted in Brief; Munir Bashir of Iraq Plays Oud Recital
LEAD: Perhaps not since Paderewski has a musician parlayed his art into political power in the way Munir Bashir has managed to do.
The Polish pianist became Prime Minister of his country after World War I. Several generations later, Mr.
Bashir - who is a virtuoso on the oud - enjoys enormous authority over the cultural affairs of Iraq.

LEAD: The military announced today that a South African plane had been shot down in southeastern Angola and that three more of its soldiers had been killed in combat.

But in the end, Larry Bird brought the Knicks back into the world of reality as the Celtics scored a 95-93 victory at the Hartford Civic Center.

He plays by the rules.

Emotion Is Key to Swaggart Church
LEAD: The Assemblies of God church, once again enmeshed in a scandal involving a prominent television evangelist, offers a highly personal, emotional approach to religion that has made it the fastest-growing major Christian denomination in the United States.


Report Faults Biaggi for 'Criminal Conduct'
LEAD: In a report released today, the House Ethics Committee said Mario Biaggi was guilty of ''criminal conduct of a most serious nature going to the heart of his representation responsibilities.''


U.S. Plans Big Cut in Funds to U.N. Food Agency
LEAD: The Reagan Administration plans a 50 percent cut in its contribution to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization as part of an economy drive aimed at international organizations that are deemed not to serve American interests, according to United States diplomats and United Nations officials.


Land-Rover Strike Begins
LEAD: About 6,000 employees began a strike today at Land-Rover.
It was the first walkout against the state-owned auto maker in six years and the second strike in the British auto-making industry this month.
Production resumed at the Ford Motor Company today after a two-week stoppage.


Angie Debo, Oklahoma Historian, 98
LEAD: Angie Debo, who came to Oklahoma in a covered wagon and wrote 13 books and hundreds of articles about Indian and Oklahoma history, died Sunday at a hospital in Enid.
She was 98 years old and lived in Marshall, a small town in central Oklahoma.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about overcrowding in New York City psychiatric wards described New York State's plans incorrectly.
While the state intends to eliminate 7,000 psychiatric beds in upstate communities over the next 10 years, it has no plans to close hospitals.

LEAD: A memorial service will be held for Gwyda DonHowe, an actress, on Friday at 4 P.M. at the Edison Theater, 240 West 47th Street.

LEAD: After failing to obtain acceptance by Federated Department Stores Inc. of its takeover offer of $66 a share, the Campeau Corporation extended the bid, which was to have expired at midnight Sunday, until Friday.
As before, the proposal was conditioned on obtaining a definitive merger agreement from Federated for all shares.

Music Noted in Brief; Olaker and Hester Offer Four Centuries of Music
LEAD: For a program entitled ''Cords and Strings'' at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon, Charlae Olaker and Daryl Hester presented music for soprano, lute and guitar that spanned four centuries.
Ms.
Olaker sang works by Campion, Handel, Britten, Villa-Lobos and others.
She was terrific.
Mr.
Hester accompanied and performed selections for solo lute and guitar.


The Minimum-Wage Illusion
LEAD: It's small wonder that politicians like the idea of raising the minimum wage: improving the lot of the lowest-paid workers seems virtuous, at no apparent cost to the public.
But the rationale is half-true at best, and the free price tag is false.

LEAD: The critics back home should be placated now.
In a sport in which rivalries are fueled by nationalism, the Austrian skiers had fallen in disfavor as the neighboring Swiss had become all the rage of the Alpine set in the past two World Cup seasons.
While the Swiss collected medals, the Austrians lived on memories of Franz Klammer's almost death-defying downhill run for the gold in the 1976 Winter Olympics in Innsbruck,

LEAD: The Mets, who announced five months ago that Dave Johnson would not return as manager in 1989, opened spring training today with a bit of a blockbuster: Johnson may return next year, after all.

ACA Joe Inc., San Francisco, said it had received default notices on $9 million of bank loans and $9.5 million of term notes, including accrued interest.

Maddox Jr. and C. Vernon Mason.

LEAD: In its third venture into investment banking in the last 15 months, the Franklin Savings Corporation, of Ottawa, Kan., agreed yesterday to buy L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc., the financially troubled 89-year-old investment house.

LEAD: Southdown Inc., an energy and cement concern, said it would offer $31 a share, or a total of about $177 million, for Moore McCormack Resources Inc.
Southdown, based in Houston, also filed suit in United States District Court against Moore McCormack's chairman, Paul R. Tregurtha, contending that he and the board had violated their fiduciary duties by illegally trying to prevent shareholder consideration of the tender offer.

Sun Equities' Stake
LEAD: The Sun Equities Corporation said it had increased its holdings in Computer Memories Inc. to 25 percent by buying 1.7 million shares previously owned by the Intel Corporation for $3 million.
The Far Hills, N.J., investment concern headed by Paul and Natalie Koether plans to solicit proxies to elect its own nominees to the board of Computer Memories, based in Chatsworth, Calif.

LEAD: The television evangelist Jimmy Swaggart, who has been the subject of reports of sexual misconduct, was ordered tonight by the hierarchy of the Assemblies of God Church in Louisiana to immediately begin a two-year rehabilitation period that will limit his preaching and place him in counseling, an official said.

LEAD: A dispute is emerging over the price that the Sony Corporation will pay for CBS Records, someone close to the negotiations said yesterday.

Douglaston Windmill Burns
LEAD: A century-old windmill that was being restored by residents of Douglaston, Queens, burned to the ground last night in the Alley Pond Environmental Center.
The tower of the windmill was moved to the center in November 1986, from its original site on Arleigh Road, in Douglaston.
Pat Juviler, the chairman of the Committee to Save the Windmill, said that despite the fire, the community would ''continue with its plans to restore the windmill.


Aid Group Says Rebels Released 6 in Ethiopia
LEAD: Six European relief workers who were abducted by rebels in Ethiopia have been released, a medical aid official said today.

NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1988
LEAD:  International A3-15


School Will Not Waive Rules For Talks on Racial Tension
LEAD: The chancellor of the University of Massachusetts today rejected calls to excuse students from classes for two days so they could discuss racial tensions at the school.


Mob Figure Gets 15 Years; He is Also Fined $820,000
LEAD: The convicted underboss of the Gambino crime family - who last December chose to go to jail rather than renounce any criminal affiliation - was sentenced yesterday to 15 years in Federal prison and fined $820,000.


Gustavia Journal; On Hushed St. Barts, a Loud Echo From Wall St.
LEAD: A lot of Americans with deep pockets think of this tiny French island as paradise.
It is uncommonly neat and tidy.
The hotels are small and quietly elegant.
The food is exquisite and everywhere the eye turns there is natural beauty.


Home Sweet Home As Knicks Prevail
LEAD: The Knicks committed 26 turnovers last night.
Earlier in the season that would have spelled almost certain defeat.
But these are different Knicks.
They still do not have any player they can count on to give them a big game, but they have learned to cover up for their errors with outstanding defense and they have learned to win consistently on their home court.

Next month he is moving from a Chelsea studio to a $650,000, two-bedroom condominium on the Upper East Side, surroundings that better befit a man who founded a company that grosses $12 million a year.

THE PIPELINE DRAMA: 5 ACTORS
LEAD:  Edwin Meese 3d: A longtime associate of Ronald Reagan who became counselor to President Reagan in 1981, and Attorney General in February 1985.
Backers of the pipeline project sought his aid in obtaining United States Government support for their plans.
Bruce Rappaport: A Swiss businessman based in Geneva, who has close ties to officials in Israel, including Shimon Peres.

LEAD: Three leading carriers -American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Air Lines -plan to increase their lowest discount fares by $10 per round trip, effective March 2.
The seasonal adjustment comes at a time when traffic usually strengthens after a period of weakness at the beginning of the year.

The Iran Panel Never Received Pipeline Memo

BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; Creating an Envelope: A System to Prevent Air Collisions
LEAD: AS a United Airlines DC-8 descends for a landing here, a series of white diamonds move across a video screen on the cockpit control panel.
They are part of the long-awaited, much-debated collision avoidance system that tracks nearby planes and advises pilots on evasive action when collisions are imminent.

LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: I APPLIED to college barely a year after the '68 student uprisings.
It was a difficult time for my parents.
I was opposed to the war in Vietnam in a uninformed way, and my parents were not opposed to it, with a kind of reflexive patriotism that most adults still had then.


Houston
LEAD: FEW of Houston's best-known restaurants are in quaint brownstones or at sidewalk level with a view of passing pedestrians.
Instead, they are in the hundreds of small shopping malls that are synonymous with this city.
Tony's is in a strip shopping center, as is its brother restaurant, Anthony's; both are owned by Tony Vallone.

Women: Out of the House But Not Out of the Kitchen
LEAD: It has been at least 25 years since women began campaigning to have their husbands share the household chores, but according to a recent New York Times nationwide survey, they have not made much headway.

Caspar Weinberger, G.B.E.
LEAD: Former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger became an honorary knight today.
Queen Elizabeth II bestowed the medals on Mr.
Weinberger in a simple ceremony at Buckingham Palace, but that does not mean he can call himself Sir Caspar.
The title Caspar Weinberger, G.B.E. will have to do.
He received the gold cross of the Order of the British Empire and the silver star of a Knight Grand Cross.

Seoul Urged to Make Amends for 1980 Massacre

Woolridge Admits to Cocaine Problem
LEAD: One day after Orlando Woolridge told the National Basketball Association that he had a cocaine dependency problem, the league announced yesterday that the Nets' high-scoring forward had been placed in the hands of drug counselors, in accordance with the 1984 agreement between the league and the players union.


New Stock Is Issued By Irving
LEAD: In another move that could thwart the Bank of New York's $1.08 billion hostile takeover bid, the Irving Bank Corporation announced yesterday that it had issued $100.1 million of preferred stock to 15 investors.

British Economy Grows
LEAD: The British gross domestic product rose by 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1987 over the third quarter, according to data released today by the Central Statistical Office.
This compares with a 2.1 percent gain in the third quarter of 1987 over the second.
The annual growth rate was 5.23 percent.


More Than Arms Control
LEAD: Something modest, but potentially momentous, occurred during Secretary of State Shultz's visit to Moscow this week.
The United States and the Soviet Union seemed in position, perhaps for the first time, to make as much progress on regional disputes and human rights issues as on arms control.

Arab Satellite Delay
LEAD: The Arab Space Communication and Satellite Organization is postponing the launching of a new satellite until 1995 but plans to extend the life of two already in orbit.
The group, which has had two satellites in orbit since 1985 with an original seven-year life span, said after a Monday board meeting that it would extend their lives by three years.


Sports People; Rowing to Antarctica
LEAD: Ned Gillette, a 43-year-old explorer-adventurer, launched a 28-foot boat early Monday for the start of a 600-mile rowing expedition from the tip of South America to Antarctica.
Gillette and three teammates set off from Cape Brecknock, a land mass in the Chilean archipelago above Cape Horn.
The trip across the treacherous Drake Passage is expected to take 15 to 20 days.

Questions and Answers In the Brawley Inquiry
LEAD: Three months ago today, 15-year-old Tawana Brawley vanished after stepping off a bus near her home in Wappingers Falls, N.Y.
Four days later, the black high school junior was found nearby, brutalized, incoherent and covered with excrement and scrawled racial epithets.
Repeated efforts to gain her testimony have been stymied by disputes over who should investigate the case.


Oil Rig Collapses in Gulf
LEAD: An oil-drilling rig collapsed in 30-knot winds and waves up to 10 feet high in the Gulf of Mexico on Monday.
The 34 workers on the rig, which is owned by Keyes Offshore Inc., were evacuated in lifeboats and then transferred to a workboat for the 82-mile trip north to Galveston, where they arrived this morning.

Music: Thomas Hampson
LEAD: THOMAS HAMPSON, the American baritone who has been making such a good impression in lyric roles at the Metropolitan Opera recently, came to Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon with an interestingly chosen program of Haydn (English canzonets), Meyerbeer, Debussy and a series of songs based on ''Des Knaben Wunderhorn,'' one of the folk anthologies that redirected German poetry in the 18th century.


TEXACO WILL PAY $1.2 BILLION TO U.S. FOR OVERCHARGES
LEAD: Texaco Inc. agreed yesterday to pay the Energy Department $1.25 billion to settle a complaint that it had overcharged customers for crude oil and refined oil products between 1973 and 1981, when Federal price controls were in effect.


PAROLE BY BRITISH STIRS IRISH FUROR
LEAD: Britain announced today that the only British soldier to be sentenced to life imprisonment for fatally shooting an Irish civilian had been paroled and restored to service after only 26 months of prison confinement.

LEAD: Gene Rambo, a former world champion cowboy, died Sunday of an apparently accidental self-inflicted shooting.
He was 67.
Mr.
Rambo apparently was trying to climb a fence when the trigger of his rifle caught and the weapon fired, said Tom Crompton, a Monterey County deputy coroner.

Sports People; Paxson Traded
LEAD: The Portland Trail Blazers traded their team's career-scoring leader, Jim Paxson, a guard, to the Boston Celtics yesterday for reserve guard Jerry Sichting and unspecified future considerations.
Paxson, who became the 30th active player in the National Basketball Association to pass the 10,000-point mark Sunday night, averaged 16 points a game in his eight-plus seasons with Portland.

The sites are on loops 1, 2, 7 and 9.

Meese and the Pipeline: The Story So Far
LEAD:  1980: War breaks out between Iran and Iraq, and Iran shuts off Iraq's access to the Persian Gulf, through which Iraq had previously shipped most of its oil exports.  1982: Syria, sympathetic to Iran, shuts down an oil pipeline carrying Iraqi oil to the Mediterranean.
Iraq, desperate for funds to finance its conflict with Iran, begins shipping its oil across Turkey and Jordan and negotiating with Turkey, Jordan and Saudi Arabia for rights to build permanent pipelines.


Group Burns Records On Euthanasia Survey
LEAD: Amid a controversy over an anonymous essay in The Journal of the American Medical Association describing the killing of a cancer patient by a resident physician, the Hemlock Society said today that it had destroyed responses to a recent survey of doctors about euthanasia.


Owens Illinois
LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission asked a Federal appeals court today to prevent Owens-Illinois Inc., the nation's second-largest glass container manufacturer, from acquiring Brockway Inc. for $750 million while it appeals a lower court's refusal to halt the deal.
The F.T.C. contends that the merger, which would create the nation's largest glass container manufacturer, would reduce competition and raise the price of bottles, jars and other containers the companies make for foods and drinks.


WINE TALK
LEAD: THERE is something to be said for spending $32 in a Paris hotel for a breakfast of grapefruit juice, two eggs and coffee: it steels one for what is to come.


Takeover Talks For Public Service
LEAD: A Massachusetts electric holding company has begun talks aimed at taking over the ailing Public Service Company of New Hampshire, except for its 36 percent share of the stalled Seabrook nuclear plant, a Public Service spokesman said.

Kalikow Revives Plan to Build On Historic East Side Block
LEAD: Peter S. Kalikow, the developer, has revived his efforts to build a new apartment tower on the site of a historic East River apartment block, this time with plans to erect the tallest building on the Upper East Side.
But the plan is drawing the same angry opposition from residents and neighborhood leaders that defeated his previous efforts to build at the site.


N.J. Transit Seeks to Raise Fares by 9%
LEAD: N.J.
Transit today proposed fare increases averaging 9 percent for 325,000 bus and rail riders.

President Is Named At Continental Can
LEAD: Robert A. Fox contends that microwave foods will provide the greatest growth for the packaging industry and that research and development in this field will become his priority.


Portable Macintosh Details Published
LEAD: A trade journal published this week contains thorough details of Apple Computer Inc.'s portable Macintosh personal computer - a serious breach of internal security.
Macintosh Today said its article was based on a 160-page confidential document.
Apple has declined comment.
The article said the machine, code-named Laguna, will weigh 12 pounds and will feature an active matrix screen, which will work better with graphics than the displays in current laptops.


Egyptian Art Treasures Need Protection
LEAD: To the Editor:


Rates Move Lower On Citicorp Paper
LEAD: Interest rates fell at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper.
The bank holding company said it had sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.567 percent, down from 6.625 percent last week.

Which Hats Are in the Ring?
LEAD: Until this month the image most likely to be evoked by ''he threw his hat into the ring'' was a felt fedora or a straw skimmer.
No more.
Judging by the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary, the hat most apt to be found on a Presidential aspirant's head is the one that proclaims he's just folks.

Education; Colleges Grapple With Dark Side of Fraternities
LEAD: The death here of a Rutgers University freshman who drank too much at a fraternity initiation party has increased the edginess of campuses across the nation already grappling with the darker dilemmas of fraternity life.


Larry Shay, 90, Dies; Composer and Coach
LEAD: Larry Shay, a composer and musical coach who worked with such stars as Al Jolson and Jimmy Durante and whose best-known song was ''When You're Smiling,'' died of lung cancer on Monday at Hoag Memorial Hospital.
He was 90 years old.


Peru Rebels Black Out Cities
LEAD: Suspected Marxist guerrillas blew up two power stations Monday night, blacking out nine coastal cities in Peru, the police said today.

It's a Trap!
LEAD: In case anyone is wondering how well the Central Intelligence Agency is policing itself these days, there was a hint in the parking lot facing agency headquarters on Tuesday: there stood a uniformed security guard deploying a radar gun, happily registering violators of the 25-mile-an-hour speed limit - nearly all of them agency employees.

LEAD: After becoming a telephone service representative four years ago, Tanya Davis took several courses in journalism and magazine publishing to pursue her dream of a career in the field.


A Bug to Help Out On Gravy Stains
LEAD: The latest news from the detergent industry's never-ending war on stains is that biotechnology has produced an enzyme that will split fatty acids.
This means that those troublesome gravy spots that won't come out in the laundry (not to mention the lipstick stains on a collar that a teen-age heartthrob sang about a generation ago) may finally yield.

Oliver Swan, 83, Literary Agent With Eye for Worthy Unknowns
LEAD: Oliver G. Swan, a literary agent whose career spanned almost 40 years, died of pneumonia yesterday at Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital.
He was 83 years old.
Among the authors he represented were Conrad Richter, Richard Wright, Morris West, Alex Hailey and the estate of Henry James.


State Department Asks Reagan to Penalize Panama Over Drug Trafficking
LEAD: Rejecting the conclusions of its bureau in charge of drugs, the State Department has recommended that President Reagan penalize Panama for failing to take adequate steps to control drug trafficking, State Department aides said today.


An E.M.S. Lieutenant Is Held on Drug Charge
LEAD: An Emergency Medical Service lieutenant was charged yesterday with bribing a police officer after he was arrested on drug and weapons charges, the police said.


Inmate Escapes From Manhattan Court
LEAD: A man charged with trying to kill police officers escaped from a holding pen at the State Supreme Court building in Manhattan on Monday and was still at large yesterday, officials of the New York City Department of Correction said last night.

Chambers's Fingers Were Bitten, Doctor Testifies
LEAD: Almost 24 hours after Jennifer Levin died, the hands of Robert E. Chambers Jr. were ''inflamed, swollen, red and tender'' from human bites that had broken the skin on three fingers, a doctor who treated him testified yesterday.

F.B.I. Admits Informer Misled Inquiry
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged today that it had been repeatedly misled by an undercover informer whose information led to a two-year surveillance campaign against Americans opposed to the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: DEVELOPING a taste for one food or another may depend on the context in which that food is eaten.
I know several baseball buffs who consider a hot dog with sauerkraut absolutely vital at a game.
And yet these same people look on a platter of sauerkraut, using the pickled vegetable as the focal point of a main course, with something that borders on contempt.


Hijacking Confession 'Illegal'
LEAD: A Federal judge ruled today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation illegally obtained a Lebanese Shiite Moslem's confession to leading a 1985 plane hijacking during ''relentless interrogation'' that violated his rights.


Hopes for Peace Fade Despite Contra Cutoff
LEAD: Six months after the signing of a regional peace accord, prospects for an end to the Nicaraguan conflict appear to be dimming.


Connecticut Bonds Attract Investors
LEAD: The thin supply of tax-exempt issues in the marketplace was evident in the yields of a $125 million issue of Connecticut special tax obligation bonds priced yesterday to offer a maximum yield of 7.347 percent for an issue due in 2008.


'88 Winter Olympics; Soviet Gets Gold In Ice Dancing
LEAD: The Soviet Union made its Olympic superiority in the couples events in figure skating complete tonight when Natalya Bestemianova and Sergei Bukin, the world champions of the last three years, won the gold medal in dance.


Greenspan Sees Lag in Economy
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, who dominates economic policy-making at present, today predicted a slower but fairly sound economy for this year and indicated that he saw little reason now to help it through such means as cutting interest rates more.


'88 Winter Olympics; Corporate Rivalry Far From Calgary Over Games Logo
LEAD: What is the difference between an official Olympic sponsor that advertises on an Olympic telecast and a sponsor of an official Olympic telecast?
Between $5 million and $15 million, by one reckoning.
Some special sauce and a sesame seed bun by another.


Historic Windmill Destroyed in Queens Fire
LEAD: George O. Pratt, the director of the Alley Pond Environmental Center in Douglaston, Queens, standing near the charred ruins of a century-old windmill that was destroyed in a fire Monday night.
Investigators suspect arson in the fire.
The windmill was built on Arleigh Road in Queens and was moved in 1986 to the environmental center in an effort to prevent its demolition.

Biden Needs 2d Operation
LEAD: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., who underwent surgery on Feb. 12 to repair an aneurysm in an artery supplying blood to his brain, left Walter Reed Army Medical Center today, but officials said he will require another operation to correct a second aneurysm.
Larry Rasky, a spokesman for the Biden family, said the 45-year-old Delaware Democrat would not return to his Washington office until he had recovered from the second operation, which has not yet been scheduled.


Rise in Firefighters' Medical Leaves Seen as Protest
LEAD: A marked increase in the number of New York City firefighters requesting medical leave for on-duty injuries, apparently to protest the closing of a Brooklyn firehouse, has cost several hundred thousand dollars and has prompted the city to consider invoking a state law that bars job actions by public employees.


Sports of The Times; '88 Winter Olympics; Bonnie Blair's Golden Opportunity
LEAD: SHE'S already the Mary Lou Retton and more of these XV Olympic Winter Games.
And now Bonnie Blair, the lady leprechaun who seems to have stepped off the drawing board of a Disney artist, has the golden opportunity to win what no American female speed skater ever has: two Olympic gold medals.
But she's too smart to talk about another gold, only about the possibility of a silver or a bronze, or both.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1988
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A2-15  News analysis: In Nicaragua, political recriminations have become more bitter than at any time since the regional peace accord was signed.
The tensions make prospects for an end to the conflict there appear to be dimming.

A.T.&amp;T.'s Unix Is a Hit at Last, And Other Companies Are Wary
LEAD: AFTER nearly 20 years of unfulfilled promise under the wing of its creator, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Unix computer operating system is becoming a hit, emerging with the potential to establish an industry standard.


High Court Hears Challenge to New York Curb on Men's Clubs
LEAD: A skeptical Supreme Court today heard a constitutional challenge to a New York City law intended to force some of the country's most prestigious men's clubs to admit women as members.


Pearson-Les Echos
LEAD: Finance Minister Edouard Balladur has opposed the planned sale of the French financial newspaper Les Echos to Pearson P.L.C. of Britain, saying he will not allow the transfer of ownership to proceed automatically.
Mr.
Balladur said the deal, worth about $158 million, that was signed Jan. 11 between Pearson and Les Echo's owner, Jacqueline Beytout, ''is subject to the explicit authorization of the French authorities.


Blazers Keep Nets Mired in Bad Luck
LEAD: The Portland Trail Blazers, one of the better teams in the National Basketball Association this season, played their part in the Nets' disastrous season tonight.
They breezed to a 114-102 victory, then left the Byrne Meadowlands Arena before any of the Nets' bad luck could rub off on them.


Rock: Budka Suflera
LEAD: BUDKA SUFLERA, a six-member Polish rock group, made its New York debut on Saturday at the Beacon Theater.
Not surprisingly, since much of the world has embraced Anglo-American music as cultural overlord, the group sounded denationalized; even though its members sang in Polish, the group trafficked in a sort of gray rock internationalism.


Women at Home

Stage: Bergman Version Of Ibsen's 'Doll's House'
LEAD: ''NORA,'' Ingmar Bergman's stripped-down adaptation of ''A Doll's House,'' is akin to an opera composed entirely of arias.
Having eliminated the Helmer children and servants, he offers two hours of confrontations.

ARMY TO DESTROY OLD CHEMICAL ARMS
LEAD: The Army will dispose of its aging stockpile of chemical weapons by burning them in closed incinerators to be built at the eight sites where the chemicals are now stored, a top official said today.


Big East Notebook; Directors Approve A Ban for Brawling
LEAD: In response to a string of bench-clearing brawls in the Big East Conference this season, Commissioner Dave Gavitt and the league's athletic directors approved legislation yesterday that calls for an automatic one-game suspension of any player leaving the bench to participate in a fight or any player ejected for fighting.

Winfield Is Wasting No Time Getting Into Camp Routine
LEAD: In past springs, he has been among the later arrivals in camp, never here on the day the regulars were asked to report, never apparently bothered by the criticism that usually followed.
This year, however, Dave Winfield - newly married and perhaps beginning his final season as a Yankee - was on time.


Economic Scene; A Little Daylight On the Deficits
LEAD: VIRTUE is nice, but sometimes luck will suffice: Four months and much hand-wringing after the October crash, the United States economy seems no worse for wear.
In fact, there is growing reason to think that the stock plunge may actually protect the nation from a dollar crisis that would cut deeply into income and employment.

LEAD: A job of uncommon power is opening up in Washington: that of executive director of the 12-member National Economic Commission, the eminent bipartisan panel that in March of next year will offer Congress and the White House a way out of the budget deficits.

Education; Lessons
LEAD: It has always seemed an addled adage: ''Those who can, do.
Those who cannot, teach.'' Some of the doers, it now seems, have long yearned to educate.
Lawyers, nurses, millwrights, accountants and executives - people of experience - in growing numbers are leaving their professions, earning teaching certificates and heading for the classroom.

LEAD: The New York Botanical Garden is planning an ambitious expansion that will include a new plant science center and the renovation of its landmark museum building in the Bronx to house exhibitions.

Sports People; Johnson Honored
LEAD: When he broke the world record for the 100-meter dash at the world track and field championships in Rome last summer, Ben Johnson of Canada did so in 9.83 seconds, shaving a full 10th of a second off the previous mark.
It was the kind of stunning performance worthy of another sprinter, Jesse Owens, more than 50 years ago.


Joyner, Tartabull May Not Report
LEAD: Wally Joyner of the California Angels and Danny Tartabull of the Kansas City Royals said yesterday that they were considering not reporting to spring training this week because of contract disputes.


Governors Seek Housing and Child Care Changes
LEAD: Seeking to reshape a Federal system they consider out of kilter, the nation's governors today announced a major effort to increase state responsibilities substantially in housing and child care.


Reagan Chooses a Skilled Infighter to Lead Navy
LEAD: President Reagan today chose a veteran Capitol Hill infighter, William L. Ball 3d, to step into a simmering dispute over Pentagon budget cuts as his new Secretary of the Navy.


Western States Get a Taste of Prosperity as a Weak Dollar Spurs Exports
LEAD: After three years of troubled times, much of the West is experiencing an economic rebound, spurred by a weaker dollar, which has stimulated exports, as well as increased demand for the wood, minerals, livestock and other commodities produced in the mountains and plains of the region.


A Computer Traffic Cop
LEAD: Anyone who has ever given a computer a command and received a response, intelligible or not, has used a computer operating system.
People who seek to explain computers to the unintiated often search for operating system metaphors.
A traffic cop is a common one.
Another is a super-efficient office manager.


Dolls in Paris Fashions Of '46 Will Tour Again
LEAD: In 1945, to show the world that French fashion had survived World War II, Paris designers planned a world tour of their creations.
But with material, models and money in short supply just after the war, the designers turned to miniature mannequins to show their clothes.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: New-issue activity was relatively light in the tax-exempt market yesterday, except for the Maryland Health and Higher Educational Facilities Authority, which tentatively offered $210.9 million of refunding revenue bonds for Johns Hopkins University.
The bonds have a maximum yield of 7.54 percent for an issue due in 2020 through underwriters led by Alex.


Mr. Webb's Petulant Resignation
LEAD: It's a fine thing to resign on principle.
But James Webb seems to have resigned as Secretary of the Navy on something closer to pique.
He failed to get on with his boss, Secretary of Defense Frank Carlucci, and left with a gratuitous personal blast.
Mr.
Webb's departure raises no great debate about the future of the


BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1988
LEAD:  Companies


Kraft Settlement
LEAD: Kraft Inc. said it would will pay Ambrit Inc. $8.5 million to settle a trademark dispute.
The case involved Kraft's Polar B'ar ice cream bars, which Ambrit contended were packaged in a manner that infringed on its own Klondike bar's trademark.
The United States Supreme Court last year let stand a lower court ruling prohibiting Polar B'ar from using a wrapper resembling Klondike's.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart of Olympic medal winners in Sports Pages yesterday gave an incorrect nationality for Sigrid Wolf, the winner of the women's Super G race.
She is from Austria, not France.


Reagan News Session Will Be on Air Today
LEAD: President Reagan's news conference at 8 o'clock tonight will be broadcast on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks and on CNN, the Cable News Network.
In addition, some local affiliates of PBS and SIN, the Spanish International Network, will carry the conference, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast.


Robertson Hints a Bush Link To Disclosures on Swaggart
LEAD: Pat Robertson asserted today that it was no accident that news of the Rev.
Jimmy Swaggart's difficulties broke two weeks before the South Carolina Republican Presidential primary, in which Mr.
Robertson, a former television evangelist, hopes to score a major success.


Real Estate; Outlet Mall Planned for Manhattan
LEAD: ALTHOUGH Manhattan has long had discount shopping districts, like Orchard Street on the Lower East Side or the stretch of 14th Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway, bargain hunters in New York City have had to leave town to find deep discounts offered in the region's growing number of factory outlet shopping centers.


West Virginia Budget Held Unconstitutional
LEAD: The state Supreme Court declared West Virginia's $1.49 billion budget unconstitutional today because it contains a deficit, and the state auditor's office said all state spending would cease immediately.
