NEC Challenges Intel Copyrights
LEAD: The NEC Corporation and its California subsidiary asked a Federal judge to rule that the Intel Corporation had forfeited the copyrights it claims for the powerful and widely used 8086 and 8088 microprocessors.
The action by NEC of Tokyo and NEC Electronics Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., is the latest salvo in a two-and-a-half-year battle with Intel over the microprocessors.


Education; Deflecting Protests With Open Heart and Mind
LEAD: For just about any other college chancellor, it would have been a nightmare: 100 minority students occupying a campus building to protest racial violence and harassment, vowing not to leave until the school met their demands.


Sale by Federated Of Unit Held Near
LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc. stock inched up 12.5 cents yesterday to close at $60.875, a tick away from the $61-a-share tender offer by the Campeau Corporation.
Reports persisted that Federated was close to a sale of its Ralphs Grocery Company supermarket chain in California.


U.S. Seen as Confident of Afghan Pullout by Soviet
LEAD: Intelligence reports from Afghanistan showing Soviet troops retreating to defensive bases and dependents leaving the country have increased American confidence that the Soviet Union is preparing to withdraw its forces, a senior official traveling with Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today.


Japanese Weigh Backing a Harlem Project
LEAD: A contingent of Japanese real-estate executives, visiting New York City yesterday, said it was considering an investment in Harlem on the Hudson, a huge development that would transform 40 acres of Harlem riverfront into a center of new housing, business and cultural events.


Berlin, N.H.
LEAD: SINCE washing clothes is a drag, while eating is fun, a diner-laundry doesn't seem outrageous.
Well, not too outrageous.
Welcome to Berlin, home of the Eastern Depot Restaurant and Laundromat.
Here you will find that elusive hybrid, a place where you can cram your clothes into a washing machine, then escape next door for first-rate diner fare.


Agent Affidavits Needed
LEAD: For the first time since 1971, players in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament next month will have to submit notarized affidavits stating that they have not signed with an agent and will not do so during the tournament.


A Dispute With Religious Overtones
LEAD: The southern rim of Soviet Transcaucasia, the focal point of recent nationalist demonstrations, is an arid mountainous region crisscrossed by ancient scars of geology and the more recent scars of Islamic-Christian friction.


The Dinner Party Quietly Bows To More Casual Alternatives
LEAD: ANDREA GROVER, who lives in West Orange, N.J., is adding a dining room to her home and redoing her kitchen so that she can have dinner parties more comfortably.
That makes her something of an anomaly among her friends, who rarely entertain guests at dinner.


While the Dollar Falls, Paris Bistros and Brasseries Surge
LEAD: AMERICAN travelers, victimized by two ruthless pickpockets in the past year -the falling dollar and the plunging stock market - seem to have lost their appetite for stellar French restaurants.
Instead, they are seeking out more affordable fare in brasseries and bistros.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about Foodmaker Inc.'s purchase of Chi-Chi's Inc. misstated the price to be paid for each share.
Foodmaker will pay $10.15 a share, or a total of $230 million, for the chain of Mexican restaurants.


Hostile Bidder for IU Tops a Friendly Offer
LEAD: The protracted battle for control of the IU International Corporation intensified today as the company announced a friendly leveraged buyout proposal and later became the subject of a higher hostile takeover offer.


Death Toll at 275 in Flooding in Rio
LEAD: Rescuers pulling a woman from the wreckage of a building that collapsed yesterday as a result of a week of tropical rainstorms that have left at least 275 people dead in Rio de Janeiro state.
Relief funds began arriving yesterday for rescue efforts and repairs.
Although damage was widespread, destruction was greatest in the poor shanty towns scattered around Rio.

LEAD: ''Corner Boys,'' a play by James Himelsbach about four young men coming of age in the 1960's, is to be presented by the Walden Theater Company weekends through March 5 at the 1010 Theater, Park Avenue Christian Church, Park Avenue and 85th Street.


Drop in U.S. Steel Jobs
LEAD: Employment in the nation's steel industry fell in 1987 to its lowest level in at least 54 years, but wages increased slightly, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
An average of 163,300 people, including 120,900 production workers, were employed in the steel industry in 1987, the lowest number since records were first kept in 1933, the institute said.


Bahrain Offers Rare Welcome to U.S. in Gulf
LEAD: The rains that drenched Bahrain last weekend were a good omen for the people of this dry desert land, but they nearly ruined the American Fourth of July celebration.

The greatest increase is for the top-of-the-line model, the 12-cylinder 750iL, the price of which will rise 3 percent, to $69,000 from $67,000.

To Help the Botanical Garden Grow
LEAD: The New York Botanical Garden, deeply concerned with the welfare of growing things, now faces the need for growth of its own.
Its new expansion plan deserves the support of all who would celebrate and protect plant life around the globe.


Sentences in Panda Killings
LEAD: Eleven men have been given prison sentences ranging from three years to life for killing two giant pandas, the official New China News Agency said today.
The report said a court in Sichuan Province, one of the last natural habitats of the endangered species, found the men guilty in two incidents of killing pandas and selling pelts.


Anti-Defamation League Honors Vuitton for What It Didn't Do
LEAD: No one knows how the rumors began, but they have plagued and pained the Louis Vuitton company since the early 1970's.
In New York and Paris, word spread that the purveyor of luxury goods had run employment ads in French newspapers that said, ''Israelites S'Abstenir.'' (''Jews Need Not Apply.'') In 1974, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith investigated and found the rumors groundless.

A City Hopes to Strike Oil
LEAD: The City of Baytown, banking that City Hall may be sitting on a pool of oil, is looking in its own backyard for more income.
The City Council voted Tuesday to approve a plan for Trace Oil and Gas to drill a well 5,000 to 6,000 feet deep near the entrance to the 30-acre wooded City Hall complex.
The city would receive a 20 percent royalty on any petroleum uncovered under the agreement.

LEAD: The San Diego Yacht Club agreed yesterday to a proposal for a multination America's Cup challenge this year, but the concession may have come too late for anybody to build a boat in time for a sailoff with New Zealand before the September cup regatta.

Untimely Exercise

Soviet Buys More Wheat
LEAD: An additional 700,000 metric tons of subsidized United States wheat has been sold to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.
Overall wheat exports, spurred by subsidized sales to China and the Soviet Union, are expected to rise more than 50 percent from last year, reducing the American stockpile to its lowest level in six years.

Year at Dartmouth $18,199
LEAD: Tuition, room and board at Dartmouth College will cost $18,199 next year, up 6.4 percent from this year, the trustees have announced.
Tuition will rise from $12,474 to $13,335, a 6.9 percent increase.
Room and board will go up 5 percent.
Robert Field, the college treasurer, said continued pressure for higher salaries and increases in financial aid were largely responsible for the increases.

LEAD: The Phoenix Suns traded James Edwards, a 32-year-old center, to the Detroit Pistons yesterday for Ron Moore, a rookie center, and a second-round choice in the 1991 college draft.
Moore, 25 years old and 6 feet 10 inches tall, was the second-round pick of the Knicks in the 1987 draft.
He was traded to the Pistons in October for Sidney Green and played in only nine games for Detroit this season, averaging 1.1 points.

U.S. OFFICIAL MEETS AFGHAN ALLIANCE
LEAD: A State Department official met with representatives of all seven Afghan guerrilla factions today in Pakistan to discuss a Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan, the department announced.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Secret Weapon
LEAD: Worried that the elimination of several classes of nuclear missiles and the sharp reduction of other strategic weapons may dangerously weaken the United States or the Soviet Union?
Rest easy.
According to Alan Greenspan, by way of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, there is another megaweapon that nobody has thought of scrapping.


Trade Deficit $159.2 Billion
LEAD: The United States foreign trade deficit was a seasonally adjusted $40.17 billion in October through December, bringing the total deficit to a record $159.2 billion in 1987, the Commerce Department said today.


Tennessee Tops Florida, 65-63
LEAD: Greg Bell of Tennessee hit a jumper from 16 feet with three seconds left tonight as the Volunteers rallied from a 15-point deficit to beat Florida, 65-63, and give Coach Don DeVoe his 300th victory.
DeVoe's career record is 300-193.


Bribing Foreigners: What the Law Says
LEAD: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977, the law that is at the center of a special prosecutor's investigation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, is so complicated that even prosecutors have trouble determining when it is broken.


COURT, 8-0, EXTENDS RIGHT TO CRITICIZE THOSE IN PUBLIC EYE
LEAD: The Supreme Court, in an 8-to-0 ruling today, broadly reaffirmed and extended its rules protecting criticism of public figures as free speech, even if the criticism is ''outrageous'' and offensive.

LEAD: RIBBONS and bows, swags and rosettes are still popular in interiors, though using them has always taken skill and a professional eye.
In response to a growing do-it-yourself market, several companies are producing these decorations as precut pieces of wallpaper, some to coordinate with wallpaper and fabric lines.

LEAD: Rabbi Seymour Siegel, an architect of contemporary Conservative Jewish theology whose writings helped open the door for the ordination of female rabbis and other innovations, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness.
He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Other Bids Sought By Stop and Shop
LEAD: Eager to escape Dart Group Inc. and the Haft family, which controls it, the Stop and Shop Companies said it was negotiating with several other parties with a view to being acquired.
But the Boston-based retailer, which operates 113 Stop and Shop supermarkets and 169 Bradlees discount department stores, did not identify the companies it was talking with and said there was no assurance that a deal would be reached.

Steinbrenner Heads Panel on U.S. Effort
LEAD: The United States Olympic Committee named a special Olympic Overview Commission today to determine how well it had done and what direction it should take.
The commission chairman is George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees and a member of the U.S.O.C.
Executive Board representing the private sector.


TV Ad Expenses Questioned On Dukakis and Gephardt
LEAD: The Federal Election Commission's general counsel today urged the commission to deem ''unreasonable'' a practice used in Iowa by the Presidential campaigns of Michael S. Dukakis and Richard A. Gephardt.
Those candidates counted half the cost of television advertising as a fund-raising expense.


Davis Near Decision
LEAD: Since Tom Flores resigned as head coach of the Los Angeles Raiders on Jan. 20, Al Davis, the team's owner, has been interviewing candidates in the hope of filling the vacancy before the National Football League meetings begin on March 14.
Yesterday, The Associated Press said Davis was leaning toward one of five candidates but would not say which one: Mike Shanahan, the offensive coordinator of the Denver Broncos; Dennis Green, an assistant coach with the San Francisco 49ers; or one of three Raider assistant coaches, Charlie Sumner, Tom Walsh and Sam Gruneisen.

Delta Flight 235, a Boeing 757 with 127 people on board, landed safely and taxied on its own to a terminal, said a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration.

One answer is 5 feet 11 inches.

PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: THERE'S a public-service announcement on national television in which a teary-eyed girl flinches as she hears her parents call her stupid and clumsy.
A few seconds later a young boy smiles proudly as his parents tell him what a good job he's done.
The message is clear.
Children learn who they are by how we label them.


Big Loan to Kodak
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company has secured a three-year loan of $5 billion from a group of international banks to help finance its acquisition of Sterling Drug Inc.
The bridge loan - in the form of a revolving credit -comes from a syndicate of 23 international banks, with the Bankers Trust Company of New York acting as agent for the interim financing.


TV Review; McKellen as a Retarded Man in 'Walter'
LEAD: ON American television, addicted to uplift, society's outsiders will inevitably find the friendship and love they crave.
On ''L.A.
Law,'' for instance, a mentally retarded man named Benny fortuitously wanders into an office full of compassion and understanding.
We all know, of course, that that is hardly always the case.


Physical for Klecko
LEAD: Joe Klecko, the four-time Pro Bowl defensive lineman the Jets waived earlier this month, will meet with the Denver Broncos' doctors next Tuesday to find if he is medically fit for a tryout.
When the Jets dropped Klecko, a 34-year-old pass rusher who played 11 seasons in New York, Dr.
James Nicholas, the team physician, recommended that Klecko retire because of an unstable left knee that had undergone two major operations.

LEAD: Many House Democrats are so disgusted with Reagan Administration policy toward Nicaragua that they'd simply stop all aid to the contras.

It would relieve pressure on the Sandinistas to compromise and would shift political responsibility for what happens in Central America to the moderates and away from President


U.S. and Lisbon to Negotiate On Air Base Treaty Problems
LEAD: Portugal and the United States agreed today to reopen talks on an agreement that allows the United States to use a military base in the Azores in exchange for military and economic aid.


Turning Point in Korea
LEAD: Roh Tae Woo being installed as President in Seoul.
He replaced Chun Doo Hwan in the first peaceful transfer of power in South Korea's history.

BEAR HUNTING CASE YIELDS 17 ARRESTS
LEAD: Federal agents arrested 17 people today, 12 of them in Virginia, and were looking for seven more in the conclusion of a four-year investigation into illegal bear hunting.

250 Chicago Pupils Demoted; Parents Protest
LEAD: Angry parents in a tough neighborhood on Chicago's South Side kept nearly half the pupils home from a public school today after the principal demoted 250 students at midyear because of their poor reading skills.


Bomb Blast Kills 2 Soldiers On Northern Ireland Patrol
LEAD: Two soldiers of the Ulster Defense Regiment were killed and a civilian and two soldiers were wounded in a bomb attack in Belfast tonight, a police spokesman said.


Bob O'Farrell, Catcher, 91
LEAD: Bob O'Farrell, a catcher with four National League teams from 1915 to 1935, died last Saturday at St.
Therese Medical Center.
He was 91 years old.


Kramer Acquitted
LEAD: It took only a little more than an hour yesterday for a jury in Minneapolis to acquit Tommy Kramer, the Minnesota Vikings' quarterback, of a drunken-driving charge.
Kramer was arrested last July 24 after leaving a restaurant in Bloomington, a Minneapolis suburb.
Three police officers testified that Kramer's car was weaving on the road and that, after he was stopped, he had trouble with a balance test and reciting the alphabet.

Oldest Embryo of a Dinosaur Is Found in a Fossil in Utah
LEAD: An X-ray examination of a 150 million-year-old fossil egg discovered in Utah has revealed the outlines of what probably is the oldest dinosaur embryo ever found, paleontologists at Brigham Young University reported yesterday.


REAGAN SUPPORTS ANY CONTRA HELP
LEAD: President Reagan said tonight that any aid package Congress was willing to pass to keep the Nicaraguan rebels in existence was worthwhile even if it did not include money for military aid.


U.S. Is Protesting Detention Of 28 Servicemen in Panama
LEAD: The State Department said today that it would protest to Panama over the two-hour detention of 28 American servicemen on Monday.


Arms for Hostages? No
LEAD: In an answer to a question about the nature of Vice President Bush's reservations about the arms shipments to Iran, President Reagan insisted at his news conference tonight that he had never traded arms for hostages.


Brain Wound Eliminates Man's Mental Illness
LEAD: A mentally ill young man who shot himself in the head in a suicide attempt suffered a brain injury that apparently eliminated his phobia of germs and his obsession with washing his hands, doctors say.


PENTAGON DELAYS ON MISSILE BASING
LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci retreated today from the Pentagon's plan to begin deploying MX nuclear missiles on railroad cars in 1991 to make it easier for them to escape detection by an enemy.
He said more research and discussions with Congress must come before the program proceeds.

LEAD: A subsidiary of First Interstate Bancorp said it had put up for sale $165 million worth of property, or about 24 percent of its portfolio of nonperforming real estate assets.

LEAD: Steve Konroyd, the valuable defenseman for the Islanders, has a fractured orbital rim above one eye as well as a fractured frontal sinus.
He was hit in the face with a puck Sunday in Hartford and is expected to miss three weeks.
The loss of Konroyd is just one more setback for the Islanders, who have been troubled by injuries in recent weeks.

Ethel Saniel Brook, 84, Essayist and Professor
LEAD: Ethel Saniel Brook, an essayist and former professor of French literature at New York University and Hofstra University, died of congestive heart failure Saturday at St.
Luke's Hospital.
She was 84 years old.
During her career, Mrs.
Brook served as liaison in France for the Loyalist international brigades during the Spanish Civil War.

LEAD: There were 5 minutes 26 seconds left in the third period last night when Kelly Kisio's stick crashed across Randy Cunneyworth's back.
Fortunately, Cunneyworth, a forward for the Pittsburgh Penguins, skated away unhurt.
The incident, though, still posed an enormous threat to the Rangers.
It was their backs it threatened to break.

LEAD: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu indicated today that churches would try to take up the mantle of anti-apartheid resistance after the Government crackdown Wednesday on 17 anti-apartheid organizations.


At Least 9 Are Killed In Army Copter Crash
LEAD: An Army helicopter carrying 18 soldiers crashed and burned in a pasture today, killing nine people,the authorities said.
Nine others were seriously burned.
The helicopter, a twin-rotor Ch-47D Chinook based at Fort Sill, Okla., crashed about 3 P.M. near this community northwest of Fort Worth, Wise County sheriff's officers said.

LEAD: An unusual way of laying out houses on a large tract is being devised for a Westchester development of 306 high-priced homes in Harrison, N.Y.
The idea is to provide privacy amid an unspoiled natural setting.


Spending Rises in Japan
LEAD: Japan's inflation-adjusted consumer spending rose 1.9 percent in December from a year ago, the Government reported today.
The Government also said that major retailers reported a rise in sales of 7.1 percent from the period a year earlier.

The move followed the recent dismissal, for medical reasons, of 34-year-old Joe Klecko.

Pop/Jazz; City College Offers Sound Of Tangier
LEAD: THE Gnaoua musicians of northern Africa carry an exalted musical tradition.
In the public squares of Marrakesh and Tangier, they perform for ecstatic, all-night ceremonies.
They accompany dancers and acrobats; they summon spirits; sometimes they work what Westerners would regard as miracles - walking on hot coals, or making wounds disappear.

Piano: Weissenberg at Carnegie Hall
LEAD: ALEXIS WEISSENBERG is a continuing enigma.
Few pianists play with his staggering facility, but even fewer give such maddeningly uneven performances on a regular basis.
Tuesday evening's recital by the Bulgarian-born musician at Carnegie Hall turned out to be one more in a series of such erratic events, redeemed here and there by the flashes of keyboard brilliance that have always been the Weissenberg trademark.


Kodak's Optimism
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company, under fire for purportedly overpaying in its $5.1 billion acquisition of Sterling Drug Inc., said it expected to earn profits ''well in excess'' of the amount predicted by Wall Street analysts.
Analysts had lowered their 1988 earnings projections by about 35 cents a share since Jan.


Philips '87 Net Declined 15%
LEAD: The Dutch electronics giant Philips N.V. said today that the weak dollar had cut the 1987 profit by 15 percent, and that it would eliminate up to 20,000 jobs worldwide in the next two years to cut costs as it consolidates operations in Europe and perhaps expands operations in Mexico.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 418 money market mutual funds increased $2.56 billion, to $279.99 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $2.01 billion, to $83.02 billion.
Assets of the 208 general purpose funds were down $522.8 million, to $81.44 billion.

LEAD: The concept of Smell-o-Vision never really took hold in America's movie theaters, but it's very nearly a reality in John Waters's ''Hairspray.'' ''But what were freebies over 20 years ago are now fetching upward of $20,000 at auction.

Abbey Simon: Evolution of 'a Pianist's Pianist'
LEAD: Some years ago, a music critic called Abbey Simon ''a pianist's pianist.'' Mr.
Simon has never been one of the big, publicized headliners, but his has been a solid, consistent career, and when he gives a recital - as he will on Sunday at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall - the audience will be full of professionals trying to figure out how those infallible fingers do this or that, how he gets the kind of color he does, and what he does with the rhythms to make them so flexible.

India Tests Its Own Surface-to-Surface Missile
LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi announced today that India had successfully tested a surface-to-surface missile.
He said it would be used ''purely for defense purposes.''


Fed Clears Bid by Bank of New York
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board voted unanimouslytoday to permit the Bank of New York to proceed with its $1.08 billion takeover bid for the Irving Bank Corporation, provided it raises large amounts of new capital.

Irwin Chanin, Builder of Theaters And Art Deco Towers, Dies at 96
LEAD: Irwin S. Chanin, an architect and builder whose skyline signature was formed of jazzy Art Deco towers and whose legacy to Broadway was a half dozen elegant theaters, died of natural causes Wednesday at his Manhattan home, his family said.
He was 96 years old.


Officer Testifies Again In Killing of Her Partner
LEAD: In quiet tones that belied the high-stakes drama, a New York City police detective dueled with defense lawyers in a Queens court yesterday over a shootout that left the detective wounded and her partner dead.

Waldheim Won't Speak at Anniversary Rite
LEAD: Amid a continuing uproar over his war record, President Kurt Waldheim said today that he would not speak as scheduled at the main ceremony on the 50th anniversary of Nazi Germany's annexation of Austria.

PURIM CELEBRATION
LEAD: The Jewish holiday of Purim, which begins on Wednesday, is to be celebrated this Sunday with a parade and fair at the Loeb Student Center of New York University West Fourth Street and La Guardia Place.
At 12:15 P.M., youngsters in holdiay costumes are to walk from the arch in Washington Square to the student center, where food, crafts and entertainment will await.

North's Testimony on Casey Is Made Public
LEAD: Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North testified that he discussed specific plans with William J. Casey for covert operations that would have been financed with profits from the Iran arms sales, according to testimony made public today by the Senate Iran-contra committee.


In South Carolina, Republicans Find Import Issue
LEAD: The battle over foreign imports, a powerful and dividing question in the Democratic race for President, has become a major issue for the Republican candidates as well.

Dole's Chairman Angrily Dismisses 2 Senior Campaign Aides
LEAD: A power struggle in Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign ended abruptly today when Bill Brock, the campaign chairman, angrily dismissed two senior aides who have been traveling with the Kansan.


Film: 'Apprentice to Murder'
LEAD: THE film that announces for no good reason that it is ''inspired by a true story'' often lacks any authenticity of its own.
Certainly that's the trouble with ''Apprentice to Murder,'' which opens today at Loews Astor Plaza and other theaters and tells of strange goings-on in rural Pennyslvania, circa 1927.

Disputed Court Nominee Promises No Surprises
LEAD: Bernard H. Siegan, a California law professor whose nomination to a Federal appeals court has touched off intense liberal opposition, insisted at his Senate confirmation hearing today that he would follow Supreme Court precedent ''without question or reservation of any sort.''

Film: Wilford Brimley Stars in 'End of the Line'
LEAD: THERE is a moment when ''End of the Line'' looks like a small miracle.
However, that moment is extremely brief, and it occurs during the film's opening credits; no such impression ever comes again.
Here in the cast of this unprepossessing small-town story are such singular actors as Mary Steenburgen, Holly Hunter, Kevin Bacon and Levon Helm, whose presence alone ought to be enough to hold the interest.


A Financial Head Start For Campaigns Is Cited
LEAD: Members of the New York City Board of Estimate will have a ''substantial fund-raising head start'' for the 1989 campaign as a result of between-elections contributions, according to an analysis of campaign finance records.


Autopsy Finds Drinking Led To Death of Rutgers Student
LEAD: An autopsy confirms that alcohol consumed by a Rutgers University freshman at a fraternity party led to his death, the Middlesex County Prosecutor, Alan A. Rockoff, said today.


Broken Hill Plan
LEAD: Shareholders of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company have approved a restructuring.
Broken Hill, a steel, oil and mining company, will pay about $1.5 billion for 300 million shares controlled by Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier.
It will also pay about $412 million to Elders IXL Ltd., a company run by the entrepreneur John D.


NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1988
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL


Signs of Spring Erupt in Galleries And Museums
LEAD: THIS is the season when the art world gets a jump on spring.
At the Jewish Museum, Marc Chagall goes heels over head in his ''Homage to Gogol.'' At the New York Public Library, the red-vented bulbul sits high in a custard apple tree as part of the ''Bird Illustrated'' exhibition.
At the Cordier &amp; Ekstrom Gallery, on East 75th Street, Varujan Boghosian tells us the tale of a beautiful young woman with a mantilla of queen-sized butterflies.


Election Unit Eases TV Ad Limit, Rejecting Advice of Own Counsel
LEAD: The Federal Election Commission, rejecting its lawyers' recommendation, today condoned a practice used by two current Presidential campaigns to skirt state spending limits.


Economic Scene; Election Year's Monetary Drama
LEAD: THE conflict between the Federal Reserve and the Reagan Administration over what monetary policy should be and whose monetary policy is it, anyway, can easily be turned into a morality play.


A Recently Healed Boston Is Facing a New Racial Issue
LEAD: With the pain of a decadelong school desegregation battle still fresh, the people of Boston are reluctantly confronting another sensitive and divisive social issue.


A String Quartet Savors the New
LEAD: THERE are those who worry about the future of classical music.
But insofar as the string quartet, the core ensemble of such music, is concerned, their worries seem misplaced.
On both sides of the Atlantic, composers are writing new quartets with beaverish glee and audiences are flocking to hear them.


Halliburton Agrees To Buy Gearhart
LEAD: The Halliburton Company, the large oil-field service concern, has agreed to acquire a smaller rival, Gearhart Industries, for about $276 million.
Gearhart, based in Fort Worth, has lost money for several years and has not paid a shareholder dividend since 1985.
The company stopped servicing its debt in 1986, when oil prices reached a low of $10 a barrel.

AT THE BAR
LEAD: A decade ago, George C. Kern Jr. described his frenetic life as Sullivan &amp; Cromwell's premier corporate takeover lawyer. ''Fulfilling?
Challenging?
Exciting?
You better believe it!'' he gushed. ''Happy?
You betcha!
And the answers would have been the same on any day in the past 28 years.''


Corrections
LEAD: The Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Wednesday misidentified a rumored candidate for executive director of the National Economic Commission.
He is Stephen E. Bell, head of the Washington office of Salomon Brothers.

Panel Urges Retesting of All New York Physicians
LEAD: All 50,000 physicians in New York State would have to be re-examined to retain their licenses under a plan unanimously agreed on by a state medical panel formed by Governor Cuomo.


The Shrinking Supercomputer . . .
LEAD: Using a supercomputer has always been a little like flying on the Concorde: it may be fast, but traffic can still cause delays on the way to the airport.
The lines of engineers and scientists waiting to get time on the company machine could shrink, however, with the arrival on the market of a new generation of small but extremely fast computers.


Liberace Items at Christie's
LEAD: Objects from Liberace's collection - personalized jewelry, cigarette cases, candelabra, pianos, music stands, sculpture, crystal and porcelains - are to be exhibited tomorrow and Sunday at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street.


Mideast Long Shot Worth Taking
LEAD: Everyone knows that Secretary of State Shultz's foray into the Middle East doesn't stand much chance of success.
But here is a clear case where it pays to fail, and even fail again.
If the United States doesn't make every effort to get an Arab-Israeli peace process under way, the only beneficiaries will be the extremists.


G.I. Who Fled to Soviet Escapes Prison Term
LEAD: An Army private who fled his post in West Germany for the Soviet Union last year was convicted today of having been absent without leave but was cleared of the more serious charge of desertion.


National Rise Reported in Teacher Pay
LEAD: The country's average teacher salary rose 5.3 percent in 1987 while the percentage of students graduating from high school stayed roughly the same, the Department of Education reported today in its annual state-by-state review of public education.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Aaron Spelling Productions Inc. named Douglas S. Cramer vice chairman and E. Duke Vincent president of its executive committee.


Robert Lapham, 58, Demographics Expert
LEAD: Dr.
Robert J. Lapham, an authority on international demographics, died of brain cancer Saturday at his home in Arlington, Va.
He was 58 years old.


Kentucky Star Sidelined
LEAD: Rex Chapman, Kentucky's standout guard, is expected to be out for two weeks while he recovers from a back injury, the team physician said.
Chapman fractured a small bone next to the vertebrae that is attached to muscle in the lower back, in a 95-69 victory over Louisiana State Wednesday night. ''His return will depend on his comfort and rest over the next few weeks,'' said Dr.


Soviet Indicates Easing of Stand On 'Star Wars'
LEAD: A senior Soviet official indicated today that the Soviet Union might drop a key objection to the American development of a space-based missile defense system by permitting the testing of components in space.

Film: 'The Last Minute'
LEAD: IN the last minutes of ''The Last Minute,'' we seem about to be treated to the big soccer match for which we have been prepared by the first hour and a half of the Italian movie that opens today at the Carnegie Screening Room.
And, sure enough, the game starts - only the camera is facing the wrong way.


Viacom Loss For Quarter
LEAD: Viacom Inc. reported a $35.4 million net loss for the fourth quarter, in contrast to a $695,000 profit in the third quarter.
Revenues rose to $265.8 million, from $246.3 million the previous year.


Crude Prices at Year's Low After U.S. Inventory Report
LEAD: Prices of crude oil futures dropped to their lowest levels of the year yesterday after a Government report placed American crude oil inventories at surprisingly high levels.


FLEEMAN AT SPEAKEASY
LEAD: Gregory Fleeman and the Fleewomen are to perform Mr.
Fleeman's songs tonight and tomorrow at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670).
Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; admission is $6 with a two-dring minimum.


Pregame Brawl Studied
LEAD: Bryan O'Neill, executive vice president of the National Hockey League, met with representatives of the Montreal Canadiens and the Quebec Nordiques in Montreal yesterday, seeking explanations for a brawl before their game Tuesday night.
O'Neill said he would announce today whether suspensions would be assessed.

BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1988
LEAD:  The Economy


Diner's Journal
LEAD: PERIPATETIC nibblers should note the name of a new Spanish tapas bar and restaurant on the Upper West Side: Alcala.


Market Place; Niche Companies In Technology
LEAD: WHILE certain large technology companies reported lackluster operating earnings in their most recent quarter, some smaller companies are expected to experience strong gains in both earnings and stock prices in 1988, benefiting from their niche markets.


Billions Are in Play Today in Mexico's Bond Sale
LEAD: Bankers were playing a guessing game yesterday, trying to gauge how many banks around the world will bid for the novel Mexican bonds being offered today at a special auction and the prices at which they might be offered.


Suns Trade Nance To the Cavaliers
LEAD: The Phoenix Suns, unhappy with the prospect of heading for a fourth consecutive losing season, traded Larry Nance, their All-Star forward and Mike Sanders, another forward, to the Cleveland Cavaliers yesterday.
The five-player transaction also involved the exchange of draft choices.


Film: 'Thy Kingdom Come'
LEAD: A CONGREGATION sings a hymn - its members' heads thrown back, eyes closed, voices raised in ecstasy -and it seems they have surrendered their hearts to Jesus and their minds to their preachers. ''Thy Kingdom Come, Thy Will Be Done,'' Antony Thomas's documentary about born-again Christians and the political right, is powerful enough to lead to that conclusion, and hectoring enough to make us aware of Mr.


Our Towns; Neighborliness, The Homeless And Westchester
LEAD: There are 4,000 homeless people in Westchester right now, and it is projected that by the time President Reagan leaves office there will be 6,000.
Perhaps no suburban area has felt the turmoil of the President's dismantling of Federal low-income housing programs worse than Westchester.
Robert M. Hayes, counsel of the National Coalition for the Homeless, calls


Bridge: New York City Tournament Is Focusing on Newcomers
LEAD: An assortment of events will be provided at the first tournament of the year to be played in New York City, but the focus will be on newcomers - players with little or no experience in serious play.


Memo Urges Justice Department 'To Polarize Debate' on Key Issues
LEAD: An internal Justice Department memorandum urges officials to ''polarize the debate'' on key legal issues such as drugs, AIDS, obscenity and the death penalty and to seek confrontation instead of consensus in the remaining months of the Reagan Administration.

Louis Iacucci, 52, Expert on Italian Wine
LEAD: Louis Iacucci, a wine merchant and an authority on Italian wines, died of a heart attack yesterday after an automobile accident on Tuesday near Siena, Italy, according to his family.
He was 52 years old and lived in Queens.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about Vice President Bush's demand for an apology from Pat Robertson misstated some results of Tuesday's Presidential contests.
The vote percentages given for Albert Gore (8 percent), Paul Simon (6), Jesse Jackson (5) and Gary Hart (5) were for the South Dakota Democratic primary, not the Minnesota caucuses.

Weekend Show of Antique Fishing Gear
LEAD: THOSE who deal in antique collectibles know that old fishing gear, whether rods, reels, lures or even yellowing tackle catalogues, has become highly prized in recent years.
To this, one may now add antique fish decoys, used, usually through a hole cut in the ice, to lure large fish within range of a spear.

U.S. Officials Move to Clarify Reagan's Remarks

Infringement Case Ruling Disclosed
LEAD: Genetics Institute Inc., a biotechnology company in Cambridge, Mass., said that a United States district judge had ruled that Amgen Inc. had infringed on its patent covering recombinant erythropoietin, or EPO, a hormone used to treat anemia in kidney dialysis patients.

Uptown, Novices and Modern Masters
LEAD: WHEN voices are raised, cooler heads generally prevail.
So it is that with all the high-flown rhetoric one can see nowadays in works on display at galleries along 57th Street and uptown, several of the more soft-spoken artists make the most persuasive statements: at the Cordier &amp; Ekstrom Gallery (417 East 75th Street, through March 19), for instance, are the small, Surrealistic collages of Varujan Boghosian.

LEAD: The last seven days of Gulfstream Park's meeting were already going to compose the best racing week of the winter, with seven stakes races worth $1.4 million being offered starting Saturday.
A planeload of California horses that arrived last Sunday will make it even better, the kind of week that less modest tracks routinely call a ''festival of racing.


Isabel Hoopes Grinnell, Art Curator, Dies at 89
LEAD: Isabel Hoopes Grinnell, a former assistant curator in the department of Greek and Roman art at the Metropolitan Museum, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md.
She was 89 years old and until recently lived in New York City and Waquoit, Mass.

An Array of Artists, Styles and Trends in Downtown Galleries
LEAD: FOR better and for worse, SoHo is still the place to go for an overview of the current art scene.
Inevitably, there are always exhibitions, representing artists of different generations and styles, that are worth seeing in themselves.
Just as inevitably there are also shows that provide temporarily valuable data, keeping one current with some of the latest trends and fads.


Study Suggests Poor Readers Are Hurt by Teachers' Tactics
LEAD: A new report suggests that poor readers are left at a disadvantage by school teachers who help them figure out hard words but neglect to make them discuss the meaning of the passages the words are in.

The Shrinking Supercomputer . . . Will Add to Turmoil in Industry
LEAD: Severe price cutting and the market clutter created by many new products have slowed growth in the mini-supercomputer industry, which many analysts had thought could achieve $1 billion in sales in 1990.
Although demand continues to rise and sales hit $300 million last year, these experts think the industry will not reach the $1 billion benchmark until 1992.

Conner Set to Sail
LEAD: In a change of heart, Dennis Conner, the America's Cup defender, said he would compete in the world 12-Meter championships in northern Sweden June 22 through July 7.

Gault's Sled Fails In a Bid to Compete
LEAD: For eight years, Willie Gault has been trying to compete in the Olympics.
His quest may have ended today.
In 1980, when he made the United States Olympic track team as a sprinter, the United States boycotted the Moscow Olympics.
In 1984, he was playing wide receiver for the Chicago Bears of the National Football League.

Restaurants; Downtown bistro, uptown Italian.
LEAD: WHEN the French bistro Quatorze opened three-and-a-half years ago along West 14th Street, a Latin-flavored commercial strip of bodegas, cut-rate clothing emporiums and bilingual driving schools, it seemed as incongruous as Yves Montand in a salsa band.
Yet the restaurant was an immediate hit, both for its ingenuous, reasonably priced food and its casual, convivial setting.


Italian Doubles Offer for Belgique
LEAD: Carlo de Benedetti doubled his public offer tonight for Societe Generale de Belgique's shares, from 4,000 Belgian francs a share, or about $113, to 8,000 francs in an attack on the French-Belgian coalition that claims to have 52 percent of the vast holding company's capital.


The Stage: Heiner Muller's 'Quartet'
LEAD: Heiner Muller's ''Quartet'' is a dense, mordant rumination on Choderlos de Laclos's novel, ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses.'' This means that Robert Wilson's production of ''Quartet'' is twice removed from the original novel.
The production at the American Repertory Theater is filtered through two diverse sensibilities, the one German and philosophical, the other American and visual.

Salute to Black Dancers At Columbia University
LEAD: Charles Cook, Ernest Brown and the Norma Miller Jazz Dancers are to perform in ''Black History Salute to the Legendary Black Dancers'' on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Columbia University's Wollman Auditorium, 115th Street and Broadway.
Other performers include Juanita Boisseau, a former Cotton Club dancer; Jack Hammer, who will perform a tap-dance homage to Bill Robinson and Baby Lawrence; Melvin Moore, the singer, and Bill Dillard, the trumpet player, and his orchestra.

Outrageous Speech? Yes, and Free.
LEAD: When a Supreme Court headed by William Rehnquist declares the deepest commitment to free speech, and does so unanimously, it furthers a thrilling principle of liberty.
Larry Flynt's rancid Hustler magazine may have ridiculed the Rev.
Jerry Falwell in the coarsest and most outrageous way.
But freedom of speech, the Court declares, extends to utterances that are outlandish, even detestable.

Sounds Around Town
LEAD: Many Strings Attached The 1988 String Band Festival, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880).
Fingers will fly at this all-star gathering of bluegrass and old-timey bands.
Breakfast Special, Lazy Aces, the Wretched Refuse String Band and Tony Trischka and Skyline are all trying to bring bluegrass music into the 1980's without losing its essence: close-harmony singing and amazing, virtuosic picking on instruments from the backwoods.


Surgeon Testifies Chambers's Hand Showed Evidence of Punching
LEAD: The chief hand surgeon at the Bellevue Hospital Center testified yesterday that X-ray photographs of the broken bone in Robert E. Chambers Jr.'s right hand showed a ''classic picture of a wild swing of a forceful nature striking a hard object.''

Mr. Bork Regrets
LEAD: True to his promise when he left the Federal bench, Robert Bork is refighting his unsuccessful battle for the Supreme Court.
In TV appearances, he complains that the Senate's refusal to confirm his nomination has discouraged lawyers from publishing controversial legal articles.
Like Attorney General Meese, who called the Senate's action ''anti-intellectual,'' Mr.


Telephone May Be Helpful in Some Trials
LEAD: The lawyers were surprised at the idea, and the telephone bill has yet to arrive.
But the plaintiff, the defendant and the judge all seem pleased by a recent experiment to hold a trial by phone.


Olajide-Barkley Bout
LEAD: Both Michael Olajide and Iran Barkley lost in their bids for middleweight titles last October, Olajide to Frank Tate for the International Boxing Federation title and Barkley to Sumbu Kalambay for the World Boxing Association title.
But neither sounded like a loser at a news conference yesterday for the Olajide-Barkley bout at the Felt Forum March 6.


Advertising; Chock Full o'Nuts Spot by TBWA
LEAD: New Yorkers may get plenty of Chock Full o'Nuts coffee, but of late they haven't been getting much Chock Full o'Nuts advertising.
And those of you who remember the advertising are probably glad.


Soviet Missiles Withdrawn From East Germany
LEAD: Soviet soldiers preparing an SS-12 nuclear missile for transport yesterday in Bischofswerda.
Thirty-two canvas wrapped containers, said by Communist officials to hold parts of the dismantled missiles, were loaded aboard a train for shipment to the Soviet Union.
In Czechoslovakia, the state-run press said 19 SS-12 missile launchers left Hranice for the Soviet Union.


Corrections
LEAD: A table of New York City school reading scores on Tuesday gave an incorrect ranking for Junior High School 59 in southeastern Queens.
It was 39th.
In addition, the scores for 19 Staten Island elementary schools were omitted.
They are printed today on page B4.

Brawleys Called Willing to Be Jailed
LEAD: Tawana Brawley and her family would go to jail rather than testify to a grand jury empaneled by State Attorney General Robert Abrams, a minister who has been advising the Dutchess County teen-ager said today.


Martin Starts To Grow Impatient
LEAD: Another day passed, and there was still no Rickey Henderson in the Yankees' training camp, and no Gary Ward, either.
With next Tuesday as the deadline for reporting, the absence of Henderson and Ward from the second day of workouts remained a low priority for Manager Billy Martin.
But his patience seemed to be thinning.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: TENNIS  Lendl Is Upset: Sixteenth-seeded John Fitzgerald upset Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, 7-6, 6-4, last night in the third round of the $600,000 United States Pro Indoor Tennis Championships in Philadelphia.
Lendl had trouble making his first serve and became irritated by distractions from a game on an adjacent court, slamming a ball into the Spectrum's overhead scoreboard.


New AIDS Test Is Being Offered To Confirm Infection With Virus
LEAD: A medical testing company says it has developed a new backup test for AIDS antibodies in the blood that virtually eliminates results that falsely indicate the antibodies' presence and reduces the number of inconclusive results.

LEAD: The filibuster that had halted activity in the Senate ended this evening, setting the stage for Republicans to win their effort to stop a bill limiting spending on Congressional campaigns.

LEAD: Alan M. Fiers, the Central Intelligence Agency official who was in charge of aiding the Nicaraguan rebels and who was reprimanded in the wake of the Iran-contra affair, has resigned from the agency.


College Basketball; Syracuse Trounces Providence, 91-73
LEAD: Steve Thompson scored 18 points tonight as Syracuse used 15-point runs in each half to rout Providence, 91-73, giving the Orangemen their 18th consecutive Big East Conference victory over the Friars.


Woman, 82, Stabbed to Death In a Staten Island Apartment
LEAD: An 82-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her Staten Island apartment on Wednesday, the police said.
Her body was discovered by neighbors who found her apartment door ajar, Sgt.
Raymond O'Donnell, a police spokesman, said.


Home Resale Pace Slows
LEAD: Sales of existing homes fell for the third consecutive month, declining 3.6 percent in January, the National Association of Realtors said today.

LEAD: He arrived in the early morning, smiling as he always does and simply saying that personal business had prevented him from being here sooner.
But as he dressed and talked, Rickey Henderson seemed to grow more disturbed over the events of last summer that caused him to miss 67 games with a hamstring injury.

Study for Regents Finds Higher Scores and Cut in Dropout Rate
LEAD: The State Education Department said today that scores on standardized state tests were rising, annual dropout rates were declining and class sizes were shrinking.


Stop Meddling With the Fed
LEAD: President Reagan seems not to know that his Administration still has problems with the Federal Reserve Board.
Carping from the Treasury and the Council of Economic Advisers continues, even though all board members are now Reagan appointees with a Reagan chairman, Alan Greenspan.
The President needs to brush up - on current events and on proper policy roles.

LEAD: The Irish tenor Frank Patterson will be featured in a St.
Patrick's Day celebration of music and dance, March 16 at 8 P.M. at Radio City Music Hall, Avenue of the Americas at 50th Street.
Mr.
Patterson, who has been a singer since childhood, has performed for the Pope, for President Reagan, and at churches and concert halls in the United States and Europe.

Pat Robertson: A Candidate of Contradictions
LEAD: By now Pat Robertson has made clear that he cannot be written off as an electronic Elmer Gantry, a colorful distraction from the rest of the Republican Presidential field.


Visa Charges Increase
LEAD: United States Visa card holders charged nearly $100 billion last year, a $13 billion increase over 1986. the company said Thursday.
Third- and fourth-quarter volumes set records and exceeded expectations by more than 50 percent, Charles T. Russell, president of Visa U.S.A.
Inc., said.
The number of card holders increased from 98.2 million in 1986 to 106.5 million in 1987, including more than five million Premier Visa card holders, the company said.


Santucci Urges A Judge to Quit An Abuse Case
LEAD: The Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, has demanded that a state judge remove himself from a child molestation case because the judge has advocated allowing the defendant to lecture on pedophilia in place of serving a prison sentence.

Societe Generale
LEAD: The Brussels bourse halted trading at the start of business today in shares of Belgium's biggest company, Societe Generale de Belgique, the object of a five-week takeover battle between Italy's Carlo de Benedetti and an array of rivals.
Bourse officials suspended stock of Societe Generale, a huge conglomerate, when it jumped 15 percent, to a new high of 8,060 francs, or about $228.32, a share.


Recital: Victor Derevianko
LEAD: Victor Derevianko's program of Brahms and Liszt at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night was narrow in its choice of repertory but probably said the most any music could about his tastes and skills.
Mr.
Derevianko, who is a pianist, teacher and chamber player in Israel, has the bigness of sound and gesture we associate with the Russian school, but his playing is refreshingly free of the leaden aggression that so often accompanies it.

Farley Considers a Bid For Montgomery Ward
LEAD: Farley Inc., the controlling shareholder of Fruit of the Loom Inc., said today that it was exploring the possibility of buying the Montgomery Ward &amp; Company subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation.


French Inflation Down
LEAD: French consumer price inflation fell sharply, to an annual rate of 2.4 percent last month from 3.1 percent in December, the National Statistics Institute said today.
It attributed the fall mostly to exceptionally high price rises recorded in January 1987, which had an inflation rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent.


Consumer Price Index Rose by 0.3% in January
LEAD: The Consumer Price Index climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in January as higher charges for a broad range of goods and services were substantially offset by the second straight month of lower energy costs, the Labor Department reported today.


Donald C. Adams, Banker, 83
LEAD: Donald C. Adams, a retired vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died Wednesday at the Holy Spirit Hospital in Camp Hill, Pa.
He was 83 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

Bid for Atlas Stake
LEAD: A New York investment firm, the Tweedy Browne Company, said that it had rejected an offer from the Edgar Bronfman family to buy its 20 percent stake in the Atlas Corporation for $34 a share.
But the firm also said it was actively seeking to sell its stake in the gold-exploration concern, which is based in Princeton, N.J.

GORBACHEV URGES ARMENIANS TO END NATIONALIST FUROR
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, faced with one of his most difficult challenges since taking office, called on Armenians today to end nationalist protests that have disrupted two Soviet southern republics.


Baker Presses Seoul to Spur Imports
LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d told South Korea's new Government today that the United States expected it to move quickly to accept more imports and to strengthen the value of its currency, the won.


Judge Bars U.S. Damages in Shuttle Suit
LEAD: The widow of an astronaut who was killed when the space shuttle Challenger exploded cannot sue the Government for damages because her husband was on military duty at the time, a Federal district judge has ruled.

Spending And Income Rise 0.3%
LEAD: American personal income and consumer spending both rose at moderate rates of three-tenths of 1 percent in January, less than half the increases posted in December, the Commerce Department reported today.


Death on Slopes Is Ruled Accident
LEAD: Officials said today that no one appeared to be to blame for the death of the Austrian Olympic team's physician in a skiing collision Thursday.


A 'Puppet' Turns Patriot in Panama
LEAD: President Eric Delvalle acted in Panama's best interests Thursday when he tried to dismiss Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of the military.
But Noriega loyalists won't go along, and Panama moves closer to a showdown.
Washington's best stance for now is to continue backing the democrats while staying out of the field of fire.


Rumania Rejects U.S. Trade Benefits Over Human Rights Dispute
LEAD: Apparently rebuffing American demands for improvement in human rights policies, Rumania has told the United States it no longer wants the trade benefits that Washington links to such policies, the State Department announced today.


The Calgary Spirit
LEAD: Measured in gold, silver and bronze, the United States hasn't gotten the kick out of Calgary's Olympics that it did from the one-sided extravaganza at Los Angeles four years ago, or from the spectacular American victory in hockey at Lake Placid in 1980.
But who cares?
Calgary has been what the Olympics ought to be - a test of the best, and a great show.

About New York; Suing the Hand That Insists On Feeding Them
LEAD: Even the soreheads who live in St.
Margaret's House, a low-income, congregate-care, pretty fair deal across the street from the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan, thank their lucky stars for the blond brick building.
The best part of it is that no one's rent is more than 30 percent of his income.


CORRECTION
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the alignment of political convention delegates in New York misidentified a Democratic candidate for delegate for the campaign of the Rev.
Jesse Jackson.
He was Allen Roskoff.


Good Fortune: The Leap Year Saves Tax Rise
LEAD: In Dogpatch, the comic strip environs of Li'l Abner, leap year signals Sadie Hawkins Day, a special celebration.
In New York City, human error could have cost the city a bundle in real-estate taxes, but leap year saved the day.


Choosing Up Sides: What a Poll Found
LEAD: Robertson backers are more likely to call themselves independent, Bush Republicans are younger, and more Dole supporters are women.


Cocoa Plunges on Reports Of High Estimate on Surplus
LEAD: Prices of cocoa futures dropped sharply yesterday amid fears that a London trading house was preparing to release an estimate showing a jump in surplus production.

LEAD: Despite Debi Thomas's slim lead in the Olympic figure-skating competition, her coach said today that he doubted she would prevent Katarina Witt of East Germany from winning her second Olympic gold medal when competition ends Saturday night with the freestyle program.

LEAD: Peter N. Brant, a former stockbroker who was a major prosecution witness in the R. Foster Winans case, was sentenced yesterday to eight months in prison for trading stocks using inside information about forthcoming articles in The Wall Street Journal.

PRICE INDEX JUMPS IN NEW YORK AREA
LEAD: Consumer prices for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose twice as fast as those in the rest of the country in January, spurred largely by increases in housing and grocery costs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

Soccer Plan for Pay Cuts
LEAD: The Major Indoor Soccer League said yesterday that it would go out of business in June unless the league's players' union agreed to reduce each team's salary cap from $1.275 million to $898,000.
The league gave the Players Association until April 15 to respond.

LEAD: After campaigning more or less at arm's length for months, three of the main Democratic Presidential candidates began slugging it out in earnest this week with direct attacks on one another's records.

LEAD: After rebuffing a presidential move to oust him, Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega appeared today to have solidified his power as Panama's principal leader.


Rangers Move Up As Devils Drop
LEAD: The Rangers climbed into a potential playoff spot for the first time since Nov. 1 and the Devils fell into the cellar of the Patrick Division for the first time this season as a result of New York's 2-1 triumph tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.


Musical for Children
LEAD: ''Simple Things,'' an original musical for children, will begin Monday at the Manhattan Children's Museum, 314 West 54th Street.
The production, which has a medieval theme, will be presented by the Children's Musical Entertainment.
The show was jointly created by Sherry Edelman, Lynn Schnurnberger, Emily Squires and Seymour Wishman.

LEAD: Democrats used to complain that their Presidential candidates were too much alike.
That is still a matter of debate, but it is clear that their supporters are different.

LEAD: Maybe there was too much peanut butter on her sandwich.
Or not enough jelly.

LEAD: Federal regulators warned major aspirin makers Friday that advertisements asserting that aspirin prevents heart attacks might be harmful to public health and a violation of Federal law.

Mimi Moody, Puzzle Creator, 62
LEAD: Mimi Moody, a composer of crossword puzzles for newspapers, including The New York Times and The International Herald Tribune, died of emphysema Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital.
She was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Campaign Spending Bill Is Lifted After Vote Fails to End Filibuster
LEAD: Democrats withdrew a bill to limit spending on Congressional elections today after failing for the eighth time to break a Republican-led filibuster against the measure.

N.H.L. Suspends Two
LEAD: Twice in three days over the last week, John Kordic of the Montreal Canadiens and Gord Donnelly of the Quebec Nordiques squared off, once before the opening face-off last Saturday and the other time just after it last Tuesday.
Yesterday, both were suspended for five games each by Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League vice president.


Justice Kennedy Shuns Special Prosecutor Case
LEAD: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who joined the Supreme Court last week, has disqualified himself in one of the most momentous cases the Court has faced in years, the challenge by the Reagan Administration and others to the constitutionality of the special prosecutor law.


Film: William Richert's 'Reardon'
LEAD: ''A Night in the Life of Jimmy Reardon'' is hardly the first film about the sexual exploits of a very busy adolescent boy, and it won't be the last.
But since it's the work of William Richert, director of the unforgettably nutty little masterpiece ''Winter Kills,'' it's anything but standard issue.

LEAD: Acknowledging that the move was contrary to his franchise's commitment to build with young players, Wayne Embry, general manager of the Cleveland Cavaliers, said he traded to obtain Larry Nance because Nance was the best small forward the team could expect to find for several years. ''We thought that it was an opportunity to get an All-Star small forward,'' Embry said.

Bridge:; When a Foursome of Norths Get Together to Play a Game
LEAD: A tourist postcard recently arrived from Charles Coon of Gloucester, Mass., who represented the United States in world championship competition 26 years ago.
It came from the tiny town of Porvenir on the Chilean island of Tierra Del Fuego, his last civilized port of call en route to the South Pole.


Ford to Overhaul 2 Plants in Ohio
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would invest $320 million in two Ohio plants that are to manufacture a new-generation Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar.


Living With Violence: Disbelief and Fear Shake South Jamaica
LEAD: When the man known only as Arjune and his family moved into a vacant three-story house on Inwood Street and 107th Avenue in South Jamaica, Queens, last September, the double lot was overgrown with weeds and littered with whisky bottles and vials for crack.
He cut back the brush, cleaned the lot and had the house painted and remodeled.


JAMES ROSATI, 76, SCULPTOR NOTED FOR MONUMENTAL WORKS, IS DEAD
LEAD: James Rosati, a sculptor whose monumental yet precisely crafted geometric works stand in the gardens and plazas of many art museums and corporate headquarters, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan.
He was 76 years old.

Maurizio Pollini to Play Beethoven Sonatas
LEAD: The pianist Maurizio Pollini will play Beethoven's middle sonatas in three recitals at Carnegie Hall, March 9, 14 and 21, at 8 P.M.
The first program will comprise Sonatas Nos. 12-15; the second, Nos. 16, 17, 18 and 21, and the third, Nos. 22-26.


Most Latin Nations, Ending Reticence, Back Deposed Panamanian
LEAD: Most Latin American Governments today condemned the move to dismiss Panama's civilian President in a confrontation with the military ruler.

Drug Smugglers Used Cuban Base For U.S. Shipment, Jury Charges
LEAD: Two Federal indictments unsealed today charge 17 people with smuggling Colombian cocaine into Florida through a Cuban military base.

Federal Action Seen as Option In Brawley Case
LEAD: Saying he did not want Tawana Brawley to become ''a pawn in a political shell game,'' a lawyer for the black Dutchess County teen-ager said yesterday that he would turn to Federal officials if Governor Cuomo did not replace the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, as the special prosecutor in the case.


Couple Is Slain in Brooklyn
LEAD: An elderly couple were fatally stabbed yesterday in their Brooklyn apartment, the police said.
The couple's son was arrested in the slayings.
The victims, Michael Gaurilou, 81 years old, and his wife, Theresa, 78, were stabbed about 4:30 P.M. in an apartment at 765 Ninth Street in the Kensington section.


Dispute in South China Sea
LEAD: Vietnam says China has landed troops on two reefs in the South China Sea claimed by both countries, according to a Communist Party newspaper.
The paper, Nhan Dan, said Chinese had landed on the reefs in the Spratly Islands between Vietnam and Malaysia.
The area is said to have oil deposits.

Specialist Sanction
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that a fifth firm of specialists - market makers on the floor of the exchange - would lose the right to deal exclusively in a stock because of poor performance during the market collapse last October.

LEAD: I am helplessly in love with English women.
Well, not with the women themselves but with their names.
The names, in solitary splendor, unconnected to any face or body, float by me every morning in the Forthcoming Marriages announcements in The Times of London.


Music: The Berg Quartet
LEAD: It made perfect sense that the Alban Berg Quartet, whose playing often resembles a civilized discussion among amiable gentlemen, should decide to begin its all-Beethoven program at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening with the String Quartet No. 2 in G (Op. 18, No. 2), sometimes known as the ''conversation quartet.


Shamir Resists Shultz on Parts Of Peace Plan
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz was reported to have met resistance today from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to at least two key elements of American proposals aimed at starting Arab-Israeli peace talks.


Metromedia Is Buying Chain of Steakhouses
LEAD: In a foray into a business far removed from its history, the former media giant, the Metromedia Company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the company that owns the Ponderosa restaurants.

FINANCIAL CRISIS IN SAN FRANCISCO
LEAD: Mayor Art Agnos said today that San Francisco faced a $172.4 million deficit in the next fiscal year and city workers would have to be furloughed, city services reduced and transit fares increased.

It's All in Genesis
LEAD: To the Editor:


Officer Guarding Drug Witness Is Slain
LEAD: A rookie New York City police officer was shot to death early yesterday as he guarded the home of a Queens man who had complained to the police about crack dealers bedeviling his South Jamaica neighborhood.


U.S. to Order P.L.O. Mission Closed
LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has decided to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission to the United Nations but is prepared for the P.L.O. to take legal action that may delay the closing for several months, Reagan Administration officials said today.

Photo of Dalit Paz Warshaw (NYT/Dith Pran); Music Prodigy, 13, Reflects on Her Work
LEAD: Dalit Paz Warshaw was about a year old, in bed with a high fever, when her aunt put on a record of Israeli songs.
The infant heard it once, ''perking right up,'' her mother said. ''Then she sang half the record back - on pitch of course, and remembering all the Hebrew words.'' That's when Ruti Warshaw began to suspect her baby daughter might be a genius.

Lone Officers Aren't Unusual, Authorities Say
LEAD: New York City Police Department officials said yesterday that it is not unusual for a sole police officer to be assigned to guard a witness's home, as Officer Edward Byrne was when he was killed early yesterday.


Pirates Sign Berenyi
LEAD: Bruce Berenyi, who last pitched in the major leagues with the Mets in 1986, has signed a minor league contract with the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Berenyi, a right-hander with a 45-55 record in seven major league seasons, is 33 years old.
He went to spring training with Montreal last year, but underwent shoulder surgery in March and did not play.


First-Run Syndicators Find Tight TV Market
LEAD: In recent years, the business of making programs for local television stations has been one of the fastest-growing segments of the entertainment industry, if also the least glamorous.


BUSINESSMAN BOUGHT WHITE ROCK IN 50'S
LEAD: Alfred Y. Morgan Jr., chairman of the White Rock Products Corporation, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 81 years old.

LEAD: Local school boards normally resist orders from above, but many say they need strong state leadership to overcome community obstacles to teaching children about AIDS.

Dance: Peridance Offers Work Based on Folk Mass
LEAD: Peridance is a company connected with a popular Manhattan dance school of the same name.


Guidepost; Saving Your Shoes
LEAD: Pavement, rain and snow can damage shoes quickly.
With preventive care each season, it's possible to avoid buying new shoes every year.
The cost of repairs should be a guide to whether the shoe is worth fixing.
Do-it-yourself maintenance can delay professional repairs.
Frequent polishing of shoes is the best way to preserve them, industry experts say.


A Killing Mutes 'Joyous' Event Of Police Dept.
LEAD: The slaying of a rookie police officer who was guarding the home of a witness in a drug case in Queens yesterday cast a pall over a promotion ceremony for 91 people at Police Headquarters, where the Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, had planned a congratulatory speech.


U.S. to Require Wider Security for Largest Airports
LEAD: The Government is drafting regulations that will require the nation's largest airports to install new security systems to screen the movements of airport and airline workers.


Music: English Chamber Orchestra
LEAD: The English Chamber Orchestra is one of the quality brand names for record buyers in this country, so it was no surprise to see a healthy crowd on hand for the orchestra's first Manhattan concert of the season Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall (it will also appear at Carnegie Hall tonight).


Sale of Prescription Drugs by Mail Booming but Some Warn of Risks
LEAD: In an effort to hold down their health-care bills, people with chronic diseases are increasingly buying prescription drugs from mail-order houses that offer bulk discounts.

Memphis Slim, Singer Of Blues, Is Dead at 72
LEAD: Memphis Slim, an American blues singer who lived in Paris for more than two decades, died Wednesday in Necker Hospital here, his family announced today.
He was 72 years old.

It is $90 at Bloomingdale's.

Cassini Drives a Winner
LEAD: He's 74 years old, the oldest man to be given his first driving license in harness racing, and he was coming off an inauspicious debut the day before.
Besides, his career had been built on fashion lengths, not racing lengths.
No matter.
Oleg Cassini drove a 10-1 shot to victory at Freehold Raceway Thursday, the second day of his career as a professional harness racing driver.

LEAD: William C. Schuerman, dean of the University of Dayton, talking to students in the president's office.

LEAD: The head of the Tactical Air Command says he has told companies producing fighter planes and other war materiel that he will no longer accept their products unless they are made more reliable.

Art Show on the Seasons
LEAD: Winter in the city - as well as summer, spring and fall - can be seen in a free photography exhibition that opens March 8 at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park, at Fifth Avenue and 64th Street.
About 30 photographs by Jonathan Weld that capture the seasons' changes are featured in the show, which will be up through April 1.


The Day of Light
LEAD: When Democrats talked about holding a brokered convention they thought of Mayor Daley and a smoke-filled room, forgetting that Mayor Daley was dead and that nobody smoked anymore.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


The 'Secret' Warranty
LEAD: How long does an automobile warranty last?
Sometimes a lot longer than the document states.


Treasury Bond Prices Up Sharply
LEAD: The Treasury securities market rebounded sharply yesterday, largely in reaction to further declines in the price of energy and gold.
But the bond market largely ignored another key inflation indicator, the Consumer Price Index, which rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in January.


Farm Export Gains Seen
LEAD: The Agriculture Department has predicted that the value of United States agricultural exports will rise to a four-year high in the fiscal year 1988.


Army to Reduce Officer Corps
LEAD: The Army, in a budget move, has announced plans for cutting the number of officers including appointment of a board to select more than 350 lieutenant colonels and colonels for early retirement.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Nordiques Beat Red Wings: Michel Goulet's 35th goal of the season, 5 minutes 57 seconds into the second period, broke a 2-2 tie last night and Quebec held on for a 3-2 victory in Detroit.
Mario Brunetta, the Nordiques' goalie, stopped the final 27 shots he faced as Quebec won for only the second time in its last six games.


Wrestling Benefit
LEAD: The 1984 Olympic gold medalist in heavyweight freestyle wrestling, Bruce Baumgartner, was named yesterday to lead a 10-man team against 10 wrestlers from the Soviet Union in a meet March 29 at Madison Square Garden.
The meet is a benefit for the Kiwanis' Say No to Drugs Foundation, the United States Olympic wrestling team and the Metropolitan Wrestling Association.


Common Market Makes Deal With Moroccans on Fishing
LEAD: Morocco and the European Community reached an agreement on Thursday that will allow thousands of Spanish and Portuguese fishermen to resume fishing in Moroccan waters.

Judge Drops Murder Charges In the Hurricane Carter Case
LEAD: A Superior Court judge today formally dismissed 22-year-old triple murder charges against Rubin (Hurricane) Carter a week after prosecutors said they would not seek a third trial of the former boxer.


A Downhill Sport, a Rising Business
LEAD: Snowboarding, a relatively new winter sport that combines elements of surfing, skateboarding and sailboarding, has grown so popular that it is creating a new industry built around the boards and bringing new consumer money to ski shops and resorts.


William Harold Cox, Outspoken U.S. Judge
LEAD: William Harold Cox, a Federal district judge who enraged civil rights advocates with his remarks about blacks but presided over a 1967 trial that convicted eight members of the Ku Klux Klan of killing three civil rights workers, died Thursday at his home here.
He was 87 years old.
Judge Cox, the son of a Sunflower County sheriff, had a successful practice in corporate and civil law before being named to the Federal bench in 1961.

New Financial Tool Revives Old Block
LEAD: Five years ago, the block on Underhill Avenue in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn looked like many streets in New York City's most devastated neighborhoods.

They were flanked by three abandoned shells.

IU in Reversal On Buyout
LEAD: IU International Inc. said this evening that its board had withdrawn its approval of a $21.50-a-share leveraged buyout led by the Dean Witter Capital Corporation.
The bid, made on Monday, was immediately topped by an unfriendly offer of $22-a-share by Neoax Inc.


3 From S.I. Indicted In Stolen-Car Case
LEAD: Three men from Staten Island were indicted yesterday on charges that they had failed to report $1.4 million in income from a stolen-car ring.
They are also under indictment in North Carolina, where, United States Attorney Andrew J. Maloney said, they sold cars stolen from New York.


Concerns Agree to Quit Kosher Meat Business
LEAD: Three companies accused of fraudulently selling as kosher thousands of pounds of non-kosher poultry have agreed in a legal settlement to leave the business, officials said today.

LEAD: The Government will announce by next Friday its response to foreign banks' secret bids for bonds offered by Mexico in an innovative plan to reduce its $105 billion in foreign debt, the Treasury Department said.

Cubs and Commitment
LEAD: Mayor Eugene Sawyer of Chicago said yesterday he will not sign the ordinance allowing the Cubs to play at night unless they agree to stay until 2002. ''I am convinced they will sign'' such an agreement, Sawyer said. ''I heard from them last evening.'' The City Council approved Sawyer's plan to allow 8 night games this year and 18 each subsequent year until 2002, but the Mayor said, ''We won't sign unless we get a commitment from the Cubs that they will stay.

Year-Round on the Ocean: Condos for Long Branch
LEAD: Every apartment of the High Horizon condominium in Long Branch, N.J., will face the ocean, but its developer expects few to be used as summer homes.
Jeffrey Aidekman, vice president of Mountain Development Corporation, said a survey indicated 70 percent of potential buyers for the 58 two- and three-bedroom units, priced from $195,000 to $400,000, would live in the beachfront community year round.

ON TRAIL AND MEADOW
LEAD: BACK-COUNTRY skiing is cross-country skiing in areas that are not groomed and tracked by machines.
You can do back-country skiing in three kinds of areas: public parks and state forests, where bridle paths and carriage roads become perfect ski trails in winter, touring centers that have back-country trails linked to their main trail systems, and true wilderness regions, which may involve skiing up and down mountains on hiking trails.

'Discovery' and Rediscoveries In Two Shows in the County
LEAD: FRANK S. HERRMANN, at the White Plains Public Library, is an artist brought back from the dead.
The 11 painters and sculptors forgathered at the Hudson River Gallery in Ossining are rediscoveries, too, although very much alive.
Herrmann, who lived from 1866 to 1942, never had to worry about money, while the Ossining artists can have worried about little else in their early years, because all worked for the Works Progress Administration's Federal Art Project.

LEAD: A cliff, weakened by days of rain, collapsed today onto a shanty settlement, killing at least 21 people and injuring 6 others, the authorities said.

Stonewall Jackson and landed in the Atlantic.

Early Music Is Icumen In on New Disks
LEAD: Early music is flourishing on recordings.
The term early music serves as a convenient label for the vast number of works composed before the universal adoption of our modern scales, around the time of Bach.
Pre-Bach music is based on scales that differ significantly from our present major and minor, and therefore often sounds strange to modern listeners.

Hardy Flower Seed to Plant Now
LEAD: LAST call to start seed indoors of petunias, snapdragons, impatiens, coleus, salvias, begonias, lisianthus, ageratums and geraniums, which need a long season to grow and set flower buds.
Use sterile mixes and keep seed pans moist and warm to hasten germination; once seeds have sprouted, put them under fluorescent lamps to accelerate growth.
