MULTIPLEX CINEMA FEATURES TRAFFIC
LEAD: Your recent article about the new All-Westchester Saw Mill Multiplex Cinema in Hawthorne  [ About Westchester, Jan. 31 ]  completely missed what is, in our view, the most significant feature of the new center: traffic access in and out of the mammoth parking lot is entirely inadequate.
Our recent visit to the complex on a Saturday night provoked vivid and heated comparisons to a descent into hell, as we waited, and waited, for the traffic to inch down into the packed and poorly laid-out parking area.


National Hall: Westport Revival
LEAD: National Hall in Westport, Conn., is on the Saugatuck River, but no one need look outside to realize that. ''The basement is tidal,'' said Peter F. Tauck, general manager of the company restoring the structure, which is in a historic district. ''When the tide comes up, the cellar fills up.'' A leaky foundation is only one of troubles plaguing the one-time home of The Westport News, the Westport Bank and Trust and the Westport High School.


Knight Rerouted
LEAD: After driving nine hours down the length of Florida to report to the Baltimore Orioles' training camp in Miami, Ray Knight found out that he had driven about four hours too far.
The Orioles are still in Miami, to be sure, but while the former Mets star was on the road from South Carolina with his wife, Nancy Lopez, and their two daughters, the 35-year-old third baseman was being traded to the Detroit Tigers, whose camp is in Lakeland, Fla., 200 miles to the north of Miami.


THE WORLD: Arab and Israeli - The Roots of the Conflict; The Battleground from the Jordan to the Sea
LEAD: IN the West Bank, Gaza and Jerusalem, the conflict between Israeli and Palestinian is being shaped by a fratricidal agony: competing, centuries-old claims to the same precious strip of land between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, and the right to exist there as a nation.


Moving Up Fast in the Software Sweepstakes
LEAD: WHEN the marketing folks at the Oracle Systems Corporation describe their impact on the competition, they like to talk about ''the autobahn effect.''

CLOSE-UP LOOK AT POLAR BEARS IN MANITOBA
LEAD: YOU don't have to look far to see polar bears when you camp out with them on the shores of Hudson Bay near Churchill in Manitoba province.
Even at the cocktail hour, when you're having a snotch (Scotch poured over a cup of snow) and a smoked oyster, you're likely to hear and feel half a ton of bear slam against the school bus that serves the camp's meals and smack its black snout against a frosted windowpane inches from your face.


For Stylish Women, Jackets Required
LEAD: THIS season marks the return of the dinner suit, an ensemble that evokes the long-legged, cigarette-in-a-holder look of New York in the 40's.
Not many cigarette holders are in evidence these days (nor many cigarettes, for that matter), but the suit still wafts up its share of heady, nighttime-in-the-big-city sophistication.

FAR AWAY FROM THE LONG LIFT LINE

NONFICTION
LEAD:  MABEL MERCER: A Life.
By James Haskins. (Atheneum, $19.95.) Mabel Mercer was the antithesis of a show-business personality.
She was shy, self-conscious and had little confidence in her singing talent.
She never reached a wide audience, but was a strong influence on singers who did - singers such as Frank Sinatra and Peggy Lee, who appreciated her superb craftsmanship.

The contract is expected to be approved Sunday by Darwin Dornbush, who has been representing Reed.

THE REAL KEY WEST
LEAD: THE ''CONCH REPUBLIC'' is the only place in the United States where you can stroll past shrimp-pink houses shaded by chocolate-colored orchid trees and eat ''jelly'' coconuts with a spoon.
The Conch Republic is better known as Key West, where native islanders call themselves Conchs, after the giant sea snails that once sustained pirates and other renegades, and now feed tourists with conch chowders, fritters, salads, steaks, burgers and pizzas.

The Heartland Still Belongs to Trains Ives (pg. 39)
LEAD: The most haunting sound ever made by an instrument of human devising is the far-off whistle of a steam locomotive.
The impact is doubled if the locomotive is visible in the middle distance, pulling a fast train from one city to another, blowing for every curve and crossing.
It's tripled if all this happens at night, so that you wake at 2 A.M.

Mary Dunhill; Business Executive, 81
LEAD: Mary Dunhill, the last surviving child of Alfred Dunhill, founder of the tobacco and pipe-making company, died Wednesday, death notices said today.
She was 81 years old.
The only daughter among Dunhill's four children, Ms.
Dunhill joined the board of Dunhill Holdings in 1944, explaining ''they were rather short of men,'' and in 1961 became chairman, succeeding her eldest brother, Alfred.

Ornamental avenues were battered, rare species damaged or destroyed.

Theater
LEAD: The vitality of youth in black South Africa is celebrated in ''Sarafina!'', a musical with a message that reverberates long after one has left the theater. ''Sarafina'' is a song of freedom, persisting in spite of years of repression.
Watching the show, one is saddened by the slowness of change in South Africa, at the same time one is uplifted by the idealism on stage.

Radio's Global Earful
LEAD: When public con-fidence in the government is shaken, it seems that people are eager to hear what is said about us in other countries.
That's why the sale of shortwave radios perks up during political crises.
For example, during last year's Congressional investigation of arms sales to Iran, there was a run on such radios, and - according to trade reports - they have been selling briskly since.

THE GARDEN PATH TO EUROPE
LEAD: FOR gardeners and garden lovers, Europe is the place.
Its gardens not only display some of the finest collections of rare plantings but also reveal the development of landscape design.
Some encompass flowing fountains and conservatories; others are nestled in woodlands and parks; many feature rock gardens, herbaceous borders and topiary as well as carpets of dazzling blooms.

For Those Passionate About Pasta
LEAD: RISTORANTE IL POZZO in Hauppauge was conceived with love.
At its heart is the owner, Pat Zummo.
He is everywhere: greeting diners, table hopping in the dining room and on weekends popping out from the kitchen in his chef's whites.
On a slow night, diners might find his gregariousness a mite intrusive, but he has a genuine enthusiasm for food and his restaurant that's contagious.

VENI, VIDI, LEGI
LEAD: THE Italians over the years have adorned their historic buildings with countless inscriptions: So-and-So lived here, So-and-So built (or rebuilt) this building, here lies So-and-So, and the like.
Before the 19th century virtually all such inscriptions were written in Latin.
This used to mean that they could be read by all literate people, from anywhere.

LEAD: Britain's Prince Andrew and his wife, Sarah, began a 10-day visit to Southern California today, and they were greeted by a freeway traffic jam that delayed their arrival at a City Hall ceremony by 25 minutes.
The car carrying the Duke and Duchess of York had to make a detour around the congestion on the trip from the royal yacht Britannia, moored at Long Beach, 25 miles south of Los Angeles.

Enfolding India in A Length Of Cloth
LEAD: THE sari is merely a length of cloth about six yards long, but it enfolds all the exoticism of India.
Without the need for tailoring, buttons or zippers, the sari provides its wearer with the modesty of a veil, a shield from the sun and protection from the cold.
Like the sarong and the serape, the sari combines simplicity with ingenuity to become an elegant solution in the technical sense of the word.

Play On!
LEAD: IN THE RATHER DANK basement of Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center, the history of the New York Philharmonic, America's oldest symphony orchestra, is sitting in cardboard boxes.
According to Barbara Haws, the archivist whose task it is to organize it all, the correspondence, photographs, financial records, programs, scores and other memorabilia would fill 1,600 file cabinet drawers.

Music: Philharmonic's Wind Players
LEAD: THE oboe d'amore is a small musical reminder of how poor communications 300 years ago promoted an almost limitless variety of invention.
Closeness to one another has bred standardization; thus double-reed instruments are now narrowed to roughly the same bassoon, English horn and oboe one meets in every part of the world.

LEAD: In his article ''Leveraged Buyouts: On the Level?'' (Jan. 17), Benjamin J. Stein presumes, but never offers any proof, that management's offer for Narragansett Capital was below fair market value.

PAINTERS WHO USED CAMERAS AS MEANS AND END
LEAD: THAT ARTISTS WHO ARE KNOWN primarily as painters also take photographs is not news.
Photography, after all, is no longer considered a natural enemy of the brush, as it was in the dark ages 100 years ago.
As a result, what matters today is not whether an artist uses photographs, but the part that camera images play in his or her work.

Whether anybody else thinks it's promising is a question.
But we will be working together to make that so.''  - Secretary of State George P. Shultz after seeing  President Hosni Mubarak.


Carbon Monoxide Kills Five
LEAD: Four children and their baby sitter were killed by carbon monoxide fumes from a gas heater, officials in this northern Florida community said.
Pronounced dead Saturday at the home of Ola Weerts were two of her three children, 10-year-old James and 6-year-old Sherri.
Julie Meador, 10, granddaughter of a friend of Mrs.


School Board Is Ready For a Custodian Strike
LEAD: The New York City Board of Education is prepared ''to take a strike if necessary'' by school custodians to win contract concessions from their union, the board's president, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said in a television interview broadcast yesterday.


Advertising; Ruder Finn &amp; Rotman's President Resigns
LEAD: Morris B. Rotman, who will be 70 years old June 6, has resigned his post as president of Ruder Finn &amp; Rotman, the public relations firm, and will take on the newly created title of senior consultant.
David Finn, 66, continues as chairman.


House Vote on Contras To Defer Real Decision
LEAD: The vote that House members are scheduled to take Thursday on rival Democratic and Republican plans to aid the contras will once again postpone rather than establish a real decision on United States policy toward Nicaragua, members of Congress said this weekend.


Iranian Missiles Hit Iraqi Capital; Renewal of 'War of Cities' Feared
LEAD: Iran fired three surface-to-surface missiles at the Iraqi capital early today, the Iranian press agency said.  [ Reports from Baghdad said that two Iranian missiles slammed into the Iraqi capital, killing or wounding a large number of residents and destroying houses, shops and cars in two residential areas.


Abortion Group Opposes Cuomo's Medicaid Plan
LEAD: A proposal by Governor Cuomo to expand Medicaid coverage for prenatal care, but not for abortion, has abortion rights groups gearing up for their first major fight in the state in almost a decade.


Armenian Protests Reportedly Subside
LEAD: The streets of Yerevan were quiet today for the first time in more than a week as organizers of huge nationalist demonstrations that had paralyzed the Armenian capital met to discuss a planned monthlong suspension of the protests, Armenian nationalists said.


Concert: The Takacs
LEAD: SHORT, precisely imaged pieces by two 20th-century masters brought the best playing from the Takacs String Quartet Friday evening in Weill Recital Hall.
Webern's Six Bagatelles (Op. 9) and Stravinsky's Three Pieces for String Quartet were composed at nearly the same time, at and just before the beginning of World War I.


The Hostage Scourge: How Europe Is Faring
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl recently referred to hostage-taking as ''the pest of modern times,'' and it is one few West European countries have escaped.


Koch and LeFrak Agree on Plan For 1,200 Middle-Income Units
LEAD: The Koch administration and Samuel J. LeFrak have reached an agreement for the developer to build 1,200 apartments for limited profit on the Lower East Side.
The plan would involve a creative financing arrangement and would be among the largest middle-income projects built in New York City in a decade.


Winners Satisfied With Losing
LEAD: This has been a winning season for basketball at Hunter College, but at first glance it doesn't appear to be for its winning basketball coaches.
The women's varsity team and the men's junior varsity won their divisions at the annual City University of New York tournament.


Early Music Finale
LEAD: An all-Beethoven program is to be presented on March 7 at 8 P.M. as the last of the ''On Original Instruments'' series at the Merkin Concert Hall, Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street.
The performers are to be Malcolm Bilson, fortepiano; Daniel Pincus, tenor; Stephen Hammer, oboe; Lawrence McDonald, clarinet; William Purvis, horn and Dennis Godburn, bassoon.


Singapore's Economy Up
LEAD: Singapore, one of Asia's richest nations, made an impressive economic recovery in 1987, but growth will slow this year with consumers having less money to spend, the Government's annual economic survey said.


Unexpected Strong Traffic Allows Airlines to Lift Fares
LEAD: Americans are seeking lower-priced package tours to offset the higher prices in Europe.
Many travelers have shrugged off the stock market crash and are not crimping on their vacation and business travel.
And Europeans by the thousands are flocking to the United States to take advantage of the greater buying power of their currencies.


Topics of The Times; No-Fault Fat
LEAD: Two studies published in The New England Journal of Medicine last week won't help the obese drop any pounds but the research should lift another enormous weight: guilt.


Tool Orders Jumped 23.7% In January
LEAD: Bolstered by increased exports and Federal policies requiring some Government agencies to buy more domestic products, orders in January for American-made machine tools rose 23.7 percent from December's level, the industry's trade association said.


Reed Will Become Nets Coach Today
LEAD: Willis Reed, who as a player led the Knicks to the only two National Baskeball Association championships the franchise ever won, will be officially named today as the head coach of the New Jersey Nets, a struggling franchise that needs wholesale rebuilding.


Arts Troupes Caught In East-West Squeeze
LEAD: To the Editor:


For Refugees: Open Arms, or Stiff-Arm?
LEAD: In Moscow, the Secretary of State won a Soviet promise to let more emigres out.
In Washington meanwhile, the Reagan Administration proposed a budget that would cut by a quarter the funds for resettling refugees in the United States.
This beckoning with one hand and shooing with the other constitutes a two-faced policy, unacceptable even given dire budget difficulties.


Jansen Has Victory, of Sorts
LEAD: Dan Jansen, the speed skater from West Allis, Wis., was named today as the winner of the Olympic Spirit Award for these Winter Olympics.


Knicks Defeated by Nuggets
LEAD: Michael Adams scored 15 of his 18 points in the first quarter, helping Denver get off to a fast start today as the Nuggets went on to defeat New York by 109-100 and snap the Knicks' three-game winning streak.


Privatization Faces Test in Britain
LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's plan to end Government ownership of Britain's electrical power system is emerging as a major test of public satisfaction with her policy of privatization.

As Salvadoran Vote Nears, Political Killings Increase
LEAD: The worst wave of political killings in the last two years has swept El Salvador in recent weeks as campaigning picks up for legislative and municipal elections next month.


Creating a Bernstein Tribute
LEAD: When Julia Migenes steps onto the stage of Alice Tully Hall this evening to sing Leonard Bernstein's ''I Hate Music,'' the song, which opens an evening celebrating the composer's 70th birthday year, will set the freewheeling musical mood of a concert devoted entirely to Mr.
Bernstein's songs.

LEAD: Governor Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts scored another victory in his backyard today, easily winning Maine's Democratic caucuses, while the Rev.
Jesse Jackson's solid second-place finish again demonstrated his ability to build support in a state with an overwhelmingly white population.

Panamanian's Wife Recounts Crisis
LEAD: With the deposed President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, still in hiding today, his wife has said he intends to remain in Panama as long as possible to assert that he is still the constitutional President.


Brockway Bid Cleared
LEAD: Owens-Illinois Inc. has won another victory in its attempt to purchase Brockway Inc., another glass maker.
The company said that the Court of Appeals in Washington on Friday unanimously denied the Federal Trade Commission's motion to block the merger.

VW Increases Prices
LEAD: Volkswagen of America Inc. said Friday that it would increase the average price of its vehicles by 2.2 percent, or $248, effective Monday.
Prices of the least expensive models, the two-door Golf hatchback and the Fox line, are to remain the same.


Attention Is Focused on Florida Derby
LEAD: The last two Kentucky Derby winners, Alysheba and Ferdinand, emerged from obscurity and California late in the spring.
This year, though, it appears that the East may rise again.


Very High Levels of Alcohol Are Found in Drunken Drivers
LEAD: Half of the jail inmates convicted of drunken driving had consumed the equivalent of at least 12 bottles of beer or eight mixed drinks before their arrest, the Federal Government said today.

LEAD:  QUESTION: Has a major leaguer ever failed to bat at least .300 in a season in which he had 200 or more hits?


TV Review; Superman At 50, A Special
LEAD: BETWEEN 8 and 9 this evening, you can choose between two specials.
At 8, CBS is mounting a pop-culture party in ''Superman's 50th Anniversary: A Celebration of the Man of Steel.'' At 8:30, NBC has a preview (another is scheduled Thursday), of a new sitcom called ''Day by Day,'' which will have an official premiere in its regular time period next Sunday night at 8:30.


Advertising; Rodale Press Prepares A Magazine for Lipton
LEAD: Rodale Press plans to publish Kidsmarts, a magazine for children, that will be used by Thomas J. Lipton Inc. as a premium offer.
Consumers of its Lipton Cup-A-Soup, Lipton Side Dishes, Wyler drinks and Sunkist Fun Fruits can get copies through on-pack coupons.


World Trade Increased 4% in 1987
LEAD: International trade, led by a sharp rise in shipments of manufactured goods, grew by 4 percent last year and is likely to match that rate again in 1988, economists of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said in a report scheduled for release Monday.

It was her third tournament championship in three weeks.
She won the first six games and the final six games.

Business and the Law; More Obstacles For the Raiders
LEAD: FOR corporate raiders, these are not happy times.
State and Federal regulators have made it harder for hostile bidders to conceal their intentions.
They have given the prey of raiders more time to defend themselves.
And they have made several forms of takeovers more costly.

Topics of The Times; Toy Gun Terror
LEAD: Brandishing a pistol, a crazed man disrupted a Burbank, Calif., news broadcast last August and demanded that his statement be read by the commentator.
The weapon turned out to be a fake.
But the real terror it caused underscores the need for Federal legislation barring the manufacture of realistic-looking toy guns.

LEAD: A Queens woman died of either suffocation or a heart attack when her companion folded her into a convertible bed in a fit of anger, the authorities said yesterday.

LEAD: Item: With help from Morgan Guaranty, Mexico promotes a plan to exchange some of its foreign bank debt for securities backed by U.S. bonds.


A Restaurant Empire, Parisian Style
LEAD: Jean-Paul Bucher, a former chef at world-famous Maxim's, just might have the most successful recipe in Paris: Take a half-dozen preferably large and ornate brasseries, spice up the traditional fare of cabbage and sausage with some nouvelle cuisine fish dishes, blend in some Beaujolais and beer and throw in a little business sense.


A Drive for Basketball
LEAD: Wayne and Carol Lis of Killingly, Conn., suspected they had a burgeoning hoop prospect in the family, when their 8-year-old daughter, Tracy, started spending hours shooting baskets in the driveway of their home.
She seldom missed.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Going Easy on Panama  President Reagan will not order the maximum sanctions against Panama when he rules that Panama has failed to take adequate steps to control drug trafficking, officials said.
Page A3.
Fighting AIDS With Needles  A program in Liverpool, England, that gives out clean needles to addicts is being watched as one approach to curbing the spread of AIDS.


Dance Award Winners
LEAD: The winners of the 1988 Dance Magazine Awards are Kyra Nichols, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet; P. W. Manchester, a critic and dance historian, and Moscelyne Larkin and Roman Jasinski, the artistic directors of the Tulsa Ballet Theater.
A special award will also be given this year to the presenters of ''Dancing for Life,'' a benefit last fall that raised $1.4 million for AIDS programs.

LEAD: An event that seemed headed for cancellation because of lack of interest turned into a success Friday night at the Roosevelt Hotel, at Madison Avenue and 46th Street.


Israelis Sink a Dinghy, Thwarting P.L.O. Raid
LEAD: An attempt by Palestinian guerrillas to infiltrate Israel from Lebanon by sea was foiled today when an Israeli naval vessel intercepted their rubber dinghy and sank it.

LEAD: If imitation is the most sincere form of flattery, Chris Demetriades, a builder known for his stately $2 million-plus homes, should be glowing.

Cyprus Leader Pledges Talks in Taking Office
LEAD: President George Vassiliou ushered in his administration today by promising to seek direct talks with Turkey to unify this island, divided between Greek and Turkish Cypriots for 14 years.

Elephants Kill Kenyan
LEAD: Elephants trampled a 60-year-old Kenyan man to death in southeastern Kenya Friday, and a hippopotamus emerged from a sewage pond and attacked a bicyclist on the outskirts of Nairobi, a newspaper said today.
The Daily Nation said the 35-year-old man bitten by the hippopatmus on Thursday was hospitalized in serious condition.

LEAD: The violence-ridden drug trade that is said to be the backdrop for the execution-style killing of a rookie police officer in Queens on Friday includes 10 or more groups plying their drugs and vying for turf in southeast Queens, law-enforcement authorities say.

SHULTZ SAID TO GET MUBARAK SUPPORT IN TALKS IN CAIRO
LEAD: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt today became the first Middle East leader to support the peace proposals being offered by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, American officials said.


Topics of The Times; Injudicious, to a Degree
LEAD: According to The Wall Street Journal, Solomon Casseb Jr., the Texas judge in the Pennzoil-Texaco trial, never graduated from law school.
That's no great offense.
He apparently did pass the Texas bar exam, and otherwise met the minimum requirements for service in the state's courts.
But there is reason to ask why he lists a degree from the University of Texas Law School on state bar association and military service records.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Closing Up Shop
LEAD: The Congressional Iran-contra commmitees are scheduled to go out of business Tuesday.
But they will be leaving behind something for journalists and aficionados of the affair to chew on.
The committees are scheduled to make public upward of 40,000 pages of deposition testimony and documents that will be published by the Government Printing


Corrections
LEAD: An article from Baton Rouge, La., on Thursday about the Rev.
Jimmy Swaggart misidentified the television station that interviewed a woman who said she had several sexual encounters with him.
It was WVUE-TV in New Orleans.


L.I. Group Presses Fight Over Shoreham
LEAD: Citizens to Replace Lilco, a powerful organization credited with starting the public power movement on Long Island, is opening an advertising and letter-writing campaign this week against a negotiated settlement to end the long stalemate over the Shoreham nuclear power plant.


Hyundai's Success Is Challenged in Canada
LEAD: When the Hyundai Motor Corporation began exporting cars to Canada in 1984, there were few signs that its competitors were concerned.
The Canadian industry was recovering from its worst recession since the 1930's and its executives had little time to worry about a South Korean manufacturer with less than 20 years in the business and no experience in selling cars in the competitive North American market.


China's Coastal Plans
LEAD: The Chinese leader Zhao Ziyang said his country is planning to concentrate on developing the economies of its coastal areas, strengthening their links with international markets, according to a Japanese newspaper.
He said economic reform and open-door policies have led to considerable progress and that the economy of the areas would gradually be transformed to look outward.

The 15-Second Career
LEAD: IT took Debi Thomas 15 years to get there and 15 seconds to lose it.
The moment she felt her body and her skates slip out of synchronization her active mind went a third direction - south.


Smoke in Cockpit Prompts Unscheduled Landing by Jet
LEAD: A Midway Airlines 737 flying from Tampa to Chicago made an unscheduled landing here today after its pilot reported an electrical problem that produced smoke in the cockpit, the authorities said.

Metro Matters; Residency Laws: Costly Realities Complicate Issue
LEAD: More New York City police officers commute from Suffolk County than come from Staten Island.
As many live in Nassau as in Brooklyn.
Almost as many come from Rockland as from Manhattan.


Continental Grain Getting New Leader After 44 Years
LEAD: In what is the end of a virtual corporate dynasty, Donald L. Staheli, president of the Continental Grain Company since 1984, has been named chief executive, a post held at the international agribusiness company since 1944 by Michel Fribourg.


Corrections
LEAD: The Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Friday misstated the number of rapes that occurred in buildings operated by the General Services Administration in the fiscal year ending last October.
Two rapes took place in the 7,000 buildings for which the Federal agency is responsible.

LEAD: Leo Liebowitz has been besieged with questions about his company's moves, announced last week, to purchase a stake of more than $15 million in Texaco Inc.
But Mr.
Liebowitz, who is president and chief executive officer of the Getty Petroleum Corporation, insists that he is interested is the stock ''for investment purposes only.


Censures in Hutton Case Reported
LEAD: George L. Ball, the chairman of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., has agreed to be censured by the New York Stock Exchange for a supervisory failure during an illegal check overdrafting scheme when he was president of E F. Hutton &amp; Company, according to Wall Street professionals with knowledge of the settlement.


TV Review; 'Perfect People,' With Perry King
LEAD: KENNETH and Barbara -think of them as Ken and Barbie dolls - are married, middle-aged and morose.
Their daughter is heading for college.
They have let themselves disintegrate into acute frumpiness.
Visiting the local disco on an uncharacteristic lark, they find that they have become invisible while the merry singles and cheerfully divorced seem to be having all the fun.


The 'Two Societies' Today
LEAD: It has been 20 years since the Kerner commission's report on urban riots predicted that America was heading toward ''two societies, one black, one white - separate but unequal.''

The defense is not saying how long it may take.

LEAD: IN one of several funny passages that threaten to quicken ''A Walk in the Woods'' into nearly a trot, a Soviet disarmament negotiator tells his American counterpart that the real blame for their nations' nuclear deadlock belongs to Switzerland.
With its bucolic mountains and centuries of peace, Switzerland is so soothing that it drains the urgency from diplomatic talks about Armageddon.

Iran Hangs 2 for Bombing
LEAD: Two Iranian men were hanged today in a Teheran square where they had planted a bomb on orders from Iraq, Iran's national news agency reported.
The agency, monitored here, gave few details, but several people were killed and dozens wounded when a car bomb exploded in Tajrish Square in December 1985.

LEAD: Gather round and listen to the tale of Saul S. Weitzman.
It is the oldest one in the book - the docket book, that is, of the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York.
For that matter, it ranks among the 100 oldest civil cases still active in the Federal judicial system.

Departure Pays Off
LEAD: Anthony Mason remembers playing at Brandeis High School on the Upper West Side with Mark Jackson, Walter Berry and Eddie Pinckney in pick-up games made for new dribbles, new dunks, and razzle-dazzle basketball moves that coaches detest.

LEAD: WITH the wisdom of hindsight, we now regard Domenico Cimarosa as a footnote among 18th-century composers, scarcely to be mentioned in the same breath as his contemporary, Mozart.
Yet, in their day, Cimarosa's operas found greater favor with the Viennese public, and while they lack the consistent depth and ingenuity of Mozart's scores, the most durable of Cimarosa's works, ''Il Matrimonio Segreto,'' proves to be not only a charming example of the period's style, but also a precursor of

Trade Move by Rumania
LEAD: Rumania, one of three Communist countries to which the United States has granted favorable tariffs on exports, has said it will not seek renewal of those special trading rights when they expire in July, the State Department said Friday.

LYNN VILLENCY MARRIES STEPHEN COHEN
LEAD: Lynn Marie Villency, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Charles Villency of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Abraham Cohen, the son of Mrs.
Stanley Novack of Stamford, Conn., and the late Robert M. Cohen.
Rabbi Harold Spivack performed the ceremony at Westbury Manor in Westbury, L.I.


Appeals Court Finds Mother Guilty of Abuse in Son's Death
LEAD: A Manhattan appeals court has overturned a Family Court ruling and found a Bronx mother guilty of abuse in the death of her 19-month-old son, who was found scalded and drowned in a bathtub.
The appeals court also ruled that her 5-year-old son should be removed from her custody.


Stowaways Set Fire in Ship
LEAD: Four Dominican stowaways who were locked in the cargo hold of a container ship set a fire early today to get the crew's attention, but the blaze burned out of control, the Coast Guard said.
A spokesman said no one was injured in the fire.


Champion Sets Layoffs
LEAD: The Champion Spark Plug Company announced that it would lay off more than a quarter of its work force here.
The layoffs, which will begin March 22, will be phased in over four months, said William Walker, Champion's director of industrial relations.
A total of 243 workers - 119 people from the aviation products group and 124 from automotive operations -will lose their jobs in Toledo, where Champion employs 834 production workers.


Raiders Name Shanahan
LEAD: The Los Angeles Raiders will name Mike Shanahan, an assistant with the Denver Broncos, as their new head coach Monday.


Advocacy Group Seeks Park For Westway's Replacement
LEAD: Saying that government is not paying enough attention to the Hudson River waterfront, the Parks Council yesterday proposed its own accompaniment to the Westway replacement - a 65-acre park along the West Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: To mark a rare game against Kentucky and a trip to the Adolph Rupp Arena, the Syracuse Orangemen traded in the orange uniforms they have worn on the road for the last 13 seasons for sharp new blue ones.


20 Years After the Kerner Report: Three Societies, All Separate
LEAD: Like a line on a graph, Euclid Avenue traces 20 years of race relations in this old industrial town, an east-west passage from American dream to American nightmare.


Venture Capitalist Back, But She Is Nearer to Top
LEAD: In her long career as a venture capitalist, Patricia M. Cloherty has often managed to squeeze something extra from a deal.
When her company, Alan Patricof Associates, tried to buy the Childcraft Education Corporation, a maker of educational toys, in 1972, one shareholder balked. ''He thought the price was too low,'' she recalled.

Market Place; Interpreting Standard's Plan
LEAD: WHAT'S a shareholder to do when assessing the rival offers for American Standard Inc., the big producer of plumbing fixtures and air-conditioning units.
The Black &amp; Decker Corporation has offered $68 in cash, while American Standard is proposing a recapitalization plan whose value is less certain but has been estimated by some analysts to be worth as much as $71 a share.


Brazil Debt Agreement Is Reached
LEAD: Brazil and its principal commercial creditors announced tonight that they had reached preliminary agreement on a financial package that should help end this country's yearlong moratorium on its debt payments to foreign banks.


Land Rover Pay Pact
LEAD: About 2,000 white-collar workers at Land Rover U.K.
Ltd. have accepted a two-year pay increase that was previously rejected by 6,000 striking production workers, the vehicle company said on Friday.
The state-owned company said the pay package represented a 14 percent raise, but the strikers contend that it amounts to 8 percent.

New Helmets Add Speed
LEAD: Jim Gentes, a bicycle racer and industrial designer from Santa Cruz, Calif., has designed a helmet that he claims will make a cyclist go 20 percent faster than he would without the helmet.
Yet speed isn't as big a factor with the new helmet as weight.
The Giro Prolight weighs 7 1/2 ounces, 50 percent less than conventional bike helmets.


Advertising; Faberge Builds Up McGregor
LEAD: WHEN Mark R. Goldston, the president of Faberge USA, asked the Smith/Greenland agency to create something new to introduce the McGregor line of men's cologne and after shave, he certainly could not have expected an ad with the headline: ''Introducing Scotch before breakfast.''


Stage: Moliere's 'Miser,' at Yale Rep
LEAD: For a septuagenarian with a cane, Harpagon, the funniest skinflint in literature (''so mean he won't even give you a good day, he'll lend it to you'') is covering a lot of stage in ''The Miser'' at the Yale Repertory Theater.
He comes on with a bound and goes off with a dive.
In a burst of despair, he jumps and jumps and jumps, higher and higher till he threatens to fly from the premises; in an excess of agitation, he climbs a pole that occupies the center of his living room for no particular purpose other than to provide something for people to climb when emotions require it.


Environmental Records Rated
LEAD: Senator Paul Simon received the highest rating among the Presidential candidates graded by an environmental coalition but no candidate in either party rated better than fair.

65 Bolshoi Dancers Coming to Boston
LEAD: Maya Plisetskaya is to lead 65 dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow in the dance component of the Festival of Russian Music and Dance in Boston, in March and April.
The festival has been organized by Sarah Caldwell, the artistic director of the Opera Company of Boston; Miss Plisetskaya, a prima ballerina with the Bolshoi, and her husband, Rodion Shchedrin, a Soviet composer.

Outdoors: No Medals, but One Rewarding Trout
LEAD: THE quad in the Olympic Village is nestled between the athletes' dorms and the dining area.
It is protected from the wind, but at least part of it receives full sunlight all day, and the athletes, like college-age kids everywhere, like to hang out and catch rays during the warm and breezy afternoons that have bedeviled the skiers, sliders, ski jumpers and bobsledders for the last two weeks.
